Pensions shall be granted only by the concurring vote of four members of said board voting in favor thereof. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 2; L.L. No. 1945-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 2; L.L. No. 1973-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1973-3, § 1) 
Sec. 3. - Involuntary disability retirement. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall have the power and authority by the concurring vote of at least four of its members to retire any member of the fire department who may be found on examination by the physician of the department, duly certified under oath, disqualified physically or mentally for the performance of his duties in the department by reason of disease, illness or disability, mental or physical. Such retirement shall continue during the disability of such member. 
(b)  It is provided, however, that if such member objects to being so retired, he may demand an examination as to such disability by three competent physicians of good repute and standing, one to be the physician of the department, one to be selected by the member of the department whose retirement is in question, and the third to be selected by the two physicians, as aforesaid, and the three so selected shall examine said member of the department and the findings of a majority of such examiners shall be final as to the ability or disability at the time of the member to perform his full duty, and if found able he shall be returned to duty at the same salary and rank then paid and held by him. Any member retired in the department under this section or the following section shall, however, remain under the orders of the city manager, who may order him at any time to do such duty of which he is capable as may be decided to be for the best interests of said department, and while so serving he shall be paid the same salary as that received by other members of the department of the same rank. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 3; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - Voluntary disability retirement. 
    Every member of said department who may have become incapacitated from performing full duty as a fireman as the result of physical or mental disability, without fault or misconduct on his part, may, on his own application, and on the concurring vote of at least four members of the board of trustees, be retired from service providing the applicant has been examined by the physician of the department and his sworn certificate filed showing that the applicant is incapacitated from performing his duties as a member of the department. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 4; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 4) 
Sec. 5. - Twenty-five year retirement. 
    Every member of the department who shall have served therein for twenty-five years or more, shall, upon his own application, without examination or certification, be retired from membership therein. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 4; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 5) 
Sec. 6. - Amount of pensions. 
(a)  A pension shall be granted and paid to each member retired under the provisions of sections three and four of an amount which equals four percent of the full retirement pension hereafter granted to members retiring after twenty-five years of service, multiplied by the number of years in the department, and any period over six months shall be considered an additional year. 
(b)  Members retired under the provisions of section five, shall receive pensions based on the following scale: 
Per year Per month Firemen $1,800.00 $150.00 Fire lieutenants, automotive mechanic and fire alarm electrician 1,890.00 157.50 Fire captains, head motive mechanic and fire alarm superintendent 1,965.00 163.75 Deputy fire chief 2,130.00 177.50 Fire chief 2,550.00 212.50  
(c)  Any member of the department who is permanently and totally disabled on account of injuries received while in actual performance of his duties, or on his way directly to or from a fire, without fault or misconduct on his part, shall be entitled to a full retirement pension as though he had retired after twenty-five years of service as above provided. Such a member shall be retired when examined by a physician of the department and his sworn certificate filed, showing that the applicant is totally and permanently disabled from performing his duties as a member of the department, and provided further that the trustees may, if they so desire, require a certificate from an independent physician certifying that the applicant is totally and permanently disabled from performing his full duties in the department as a result of injuries sustained in the course of his duties as above provided. 
(d)  In no case of retirement shall the member's annual pension exceed the rates set out above for retirement after twenty-five years of service in the department. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary, and in lieu of any lesser amount otherwise prescribed, any person who is an officer or member of the uniformed force of the fire department of the City of Elmira and is a member of the fire department pension or retirement system, and who has completed service as a member of such city-maintained fire department pension or retirement system for the minimum number of years specified therein, shall, upon retirement for service, receive a pension on account of such minimum service which shall be equal to one-half of his annual compensation earnable upon the date of his retirement. 
(f)  In case a member of the Elmira fire department is permanently disabled pursuant to section six C. of local law number one of nineteen hundred forty-four, any person who is an officer or member of the uniformed force of the fire department and is retired on a pension on account of said injury as provided therein, shall receive a pension or a retirement allowance on account of such injury which shall be equal to one-half of his annual compensation earnable upon the date of his retirement. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, and in lieu of any lesser amount thereby prescribed, in the event a fireman has served as such for a minimum period and thereafter continues in such service, upon his subsequent retirement for service or disability, there shall be added to the amount of the annual pension or retirement allowance to which he was entitled upon such retirement, an additional amount computed at the rate of one-sixtieth of his final compensation for each year of such additional service. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, §§ 5-7; L.L. No. 1940-1, §§ 5-7; L.L. No. 1944-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1945-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 6; L.L. No. 1952-6, § 1; L.L. No. 1959-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1965-2) 
Sec. 7. - Amount of pensions for widows and children. 
(a)  Local law number one of nineteen hundred forty, as amended by local law number five of nineteen hundred fifty to increase the amount of pensions paid, shall apply only to pensions hereafter granted and shall not affect pensions which have heretofore been granted. 
(b)  The board of trustees shall pay to the widow of any member of the department who shall have died as the result of the performance of duty in the department, eighty percent of the sum which the member would have been entitled to receive in case he had retired on a disability retirement at the time of the occurrence of the injury which resulted in his death. 
(c)  For the benefit of the child or children of such member under the age of eighteen years if there be no widow, or if the widow dies, the same sum as would be paid or was paid to the widow, to be divided equally between the children. 
(d)  In case there be both widow and children, the board of trustees is given the power and authority if in its judgment it deems it for the best interest of the child or children, to prorate the monthly pension between the widow and the child or children in such proportion as it deems wise, notwithstanding any provision of this law to the contrary. 
(e)  This section shall apply only to the widow of such member who was his wife at the time of the injury which caused his death and, to his children by her or by a prior wife. 
(f)  To the dependent parent or parents of such member who dies leaving no widow, or children under the age of eighteen years, there shall be paid a pension of one hundred dollars per month, but no more than the maximum sum of one hundred dollars shall be paid in case both parents survive. 
(g)  Pensions granted to a widow shall terminate when the widow shall remarry, and pension granted for the benefit of a child or children shall terminate when such child or children shall respectively marry or arrive at the age of eighteen years. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 8; L.L. No. 1926-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 8; L.L. No. 1945-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 7; L.L. No. 1952-6, § 1) 
Sec. 8. - Death pensions. 
(a)  Local law number one of nineteen hundred forty, as amended to increase the amount of death pensions paid, shall apply only to death pensions hereafter granted and shall not affect pensions which have heretofore been granted. 
(b)  In the case of any member of the fire department who has served ten or more consecutive years, and whose death occurs during his service in said department, or whose death occurs after he has been retired on a pension under the provisions of this law, the board of trustees of said firemen's pension fund shall make allowance or pension from said fund as follows: 
1.  To the widow of such member who has not been retired on a pension, eighty percent of the sum which the member would have been entitled to receive in case he had been retired on a pension beginning with the date of his death. 
2.  To the widow of such member who has been retired on a pension, eighty percent of the same sum that said member was receiving at the time of his death. 
3.  For the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years of such member who has not been retired on a pension, at the time of his death, if there be no widow, the same sum which the widow would be entitled to receive under the provisions of subdivision (a) of this section. In the case of the death of the widow who is receiving a pension under the provisions of subdivision (a) of this section, the said pension shall be continued and applied for the benefit of the children under the age of eighteen years. 
4.  For the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years of such member who has been retired on a pension, if there be no widow, eighty percent of the same sum as was paid to said member at the time of his death. In the case of the death of the widow who is receiving a pension under the provisions of subdivision (b) of this section, the said pension shall be continued and applied for the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years. 
5.  If there be both widow and children the whole amount shall be paid to the widow and for the benefit of the child or children, under the age of eighteen years. 
6.  In case there be both widow and children, the board of trustees is given the power and authority, if in its judgment it deems it for the best interest of the child or children to prorate the monthly pension to be paid under the provisions of this section between the widow and children in such proportion as the said board shall deem wise, notwithstanding any provision of this law to the contrary. 
7.  In case of the death of a member of the department leaving no widow or children, under the age of eighteen years, there shall be paid to the dependent parent or parents of such member the same sum as would be paid to the widow of the member if she were living at the time of his death under this section. 
8.  Pensions granted to a widow shall terminate when the widow shall remarry. The pension granted to children shall terminate whenever they shall respectively marry or arrive at the age of eighteen years. 
9.  This section shall apply only to the widow of such member who was his wife at the time of his retirement under this law, and to his children by her or by a prior wife, and in no case shall it apply to a widow who was married to said member subsequent to the date when he was authorized to retire on his own motion. 
10.  The provisions concerning the amount of pensions for widows and children and others provided in sections seven and eight thereof, shall not apply to any member of the department who did not elect to contribute to the fund the additional sum required as provided in local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty as evidenced by notice in writing to the city chamberlain on or before September first, nineteen hundred fifty, but the widow, children and dependent children of such member shall receive the amount of pension prescribed in the pension law in effect immediately prior to the passage of local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 9; L.L. No. 1926-3, § 2; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 9; L.L. No. 1945-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 8; L.L. No. 1952-6, § 1) 
Sec. 9. - Return of contributions. 
    No member of the department shall be entitled to the return of any contributions made to the firemen's pension fund, other than as herein provided. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 10; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 10; L.L. No. 1945-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 9) 
Sec. 10. - Election of trustees. 
(a)  Within thirty days after this law takes effect the members of the fire department who have been members for ten years, shall select by ballot one of their number as a member of the board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund. The name of the new member so selected shall be handed to the mayor of the City of Elmira for presentation to the council for confirmation. If said member is confirmed by a majority vote of the council, said member, after taking the oath of office, shall be a member of said board of trustees. The term of office of said member first chosen under this law shall be until the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and until his successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(b)  Within sixty days prior to the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and each two years thereafter, the members of said fire department shall select their representative for said board of trustees by ballot and hand the name of the person so chosen to the mayor for presentation to the council for confirmation. No person who has not been a member of the fire department for at least ten years shall be eligible to membership on the board of trustees. 
(c)  At the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and every two years thereafter, the mayor shall present the name handed to him to said council for confirmation. 
(d)  In case at any time the members of the fire department are unable by a majority vote to agree upon a member of said department as its representative on said board of trustees, or fail to present at their required time a name approved by a majority of said members, then in that case the mayor of the City of Elmira shall present to the city council for confirmation the name of a member of the fire department as a member of said board of trustees. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 11; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 11; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 10) 
Sec. 11. - Methods of payment. 
    Said board of trustees shall pay the pensions as allowed and fixed by this law, from said pension fund, to the pensioner in a check payable to the order of said pensioner to be mailed to him, on or before the fifth day of each and every month, or in case the said board of trustees shall deem it expedient said check shall be delivered to said pensioner on or before said date, by one of the members of said board personally and not otherwise, and said board of trustees may, in its discretion, pay the pension of said minor child or children to the mother or to their general or testamentary guardian, or to the person or persons who shall have the care of said minor child or children and the decision of said board of trustees as to manner of payment for the best interest of said minor child or children shall be final and conclusive, and payment according to its determination of the pensions herein provided for shall be a full discharge for the moneys so paid. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 12; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 12; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 11) 
Sec. 12. - War service. 
    Members of the department who serve in the Army or Navy of the United States in a war in which the United States is involved, and who shall have been granted leaves of absence for the period while in such service, shall not be penalized thereby or deprived of any rights specified in this law. The period of time while a member is in such service shall be considered in construing this law as time served in the department, and the payments herein required to be paid into the pension fund by such members shall not be required to be paid during such war service period. 
(L.L. No. 1940-1, § 13; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 12) 
Sec. 13. - Fund closed to new members. 
(a)  This law shall apply to all persons who are now active members of the Elmira fire department and to all persons under the age of thirty-five years who shall become members of the fire department prior to the date this local law takes effect, and all such persons shall be eligible to the benefits secured by the creation of this fund. 
(b)  All pensions now charged on said fund, or any part thereof, by or under prior or existing law, are hereby continued and confirmed, but no person who becomes a member of the fire department after the date when this local law takes effect, and no relative or dependent of such person, shall become entitled to or be paid any pension or benefit from the firemen's pension fund. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 13; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 14; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 13) 
Sec. 14. - Investment of the fund. 
    All moneys ordered to be paid out of said pension fund to any person or persons shall be paid by the treasurer only on warrants signed by the chairman of the board and countersigned by the secretary thereof, and no warrant shall be drawn except by the order of said board duly entered on the record of the proceedings of said board. Said board of trustees is hereby authorized to deposit said fund in any of the banks of the City of Elmira upon receiving adequate security therefor or to invest the same in securities in which the funds of municipalities under the laws of the state may be invested, or to deposit said funds in the current city budget and to authorize payment of the same out of the city payroll according to current payroll practices. All interest, income or dividends which shall be paid on account of any loan or deposit, shall belong to and constitute a part of said fund. Nothing herein contained shall, however, be construed as authorizing the treasurer to loan or deposit said fund or any part thereof unless so authorized by the board. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 14; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 15; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 14; L.L. No. 1973-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1973-3, § 2) 
Sec. 15. - Reports of board of trustees. 
    The board of trustees shall make a report of the condition of said pension fund to the council in the month of January in each and every year, in which report there shall be clearly set forth a complete itemized statement of all receipts and disbursements giving the name of each and every person, corporation or association from whom any money has been received on account of said fund, together with the total amount thereof, and every person who has received any benefits from said fund and the amount thereof. And it shall be the duty of the treasurer of said board of trustees, within sixty days after the first day of February in each and every year, to furnish to the corporation counsel of the City of Elmira, a complete list of all insurance companies, or their agents, who shall not then have paid to said treasurer the whole of the two per centum tax on foreign insurance as prescribed by law. Thereupon, the said corporation counsel shall forthwith institute, whatever legal proceedings may be necessary to compel such delinquent companies, or their agents, to make proper payment to said treasurer of such overdue tax. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 15; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 16; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 15) 
Sec. 16. - Final disposition of fund. 
    If by reason of death or for other reasons a time shall come when there shall be no members of the department, and no beneficiaries entitled to receive payments from the pension fund, the balance of money and property then remaining in said fund shall become the property of the City of Elmira. 
(L.L. No. 1940-1, § 17; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 16) 
Sec. 17. - [Repealed.] 
Editor's note- Section 17 was repealed by L.L. No. 1960-6, § 1. 
Sec. 18. - Repeals. 
    All special laws in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this law, are hereby superseded, and all local laws and all ordinances of the City of Elmira in conflict or inconsistent with this law are hereby repealed except as hereinabove provided. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 17; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 18; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 18) 
Sec. 19. - Effective date. 
    This local law shall take effect immediately upon passage. 
(L.L. No. 1925-2, § 18; L.L. No. 1940-1, § 19; L.L. No. 1950-5, § 19) 
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL LAW NO. 1 OF 1926-COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
    A local law in relation to powers of the common council to increase the compensation of officers and employees and any office or position of the city. 
    Became a law March 27, 1926, with the approval of the mayor. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. 
    Be it enacted by the common council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [Power of council to increase compensation.] 
    The common council, of the City of Elmira, shall have the power by resolution to increase at any time the compensation of officers and employees and of any office or position of such city, including the office of the city judge, of the City of Elmira, and the clerk and stenographer of the city court, and order the payment of the same out of the treasury of the city. 
(L.L. No. 1926-1, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Repealer.] 
    Every provision inconsistent herewith of the existing charter, of the City of Elmira, and of chapter six hundred and four of the laws of nineteen hundred and twenty-three and of every other provision of law is hereby superseded. 
(L.L. No. 1926-1, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect immediately. 
(L.L. No. 1926-1, § 3) 
ARTICLE III. - LOCAL LAW NO. 2 OF 1926-POLICE PENSION FUND 

Sec. 1. - Pension fund. 
    The policemen's pension fund heretofore established in the City of Elmira, is hereby continued and shall consist of: 
(a)  All capital, interest, income, dividends, cash deposits, securities and credits in the possession of the treasurer of the policemen's pension fund, or belonging to the policemen's pension fund at the time of the passage of this law. 
(b)  All moneys that may be hereafter received by the police department, by the City of Elmira, or by any officer of the police department, or of the city, under the provisions of the insurance law, and one-half of all fines received by the city recorder, except as otherwise provided by statute. 
(c)  All fines, penalties and forfeitures that from time to time may be hereafter collected from any officer or member of the police department of said city by way of discipline collectible from pay or salary. 
(d)  All rewards, fees, gifts or emoluments that may be paid or given for extraordinary services rendered by any officer or member of said police department, except when allowed to be retained by said officer or member by the city manager, or given to endow a medal or other permanent competitive reward. 
(e)  All sums of money or property that may be contributed or distributed by the state, or received from any other source, or raised by entertainments given for that purpose. 
(f)  All moneys realized, derived or received from the sale of condemned, unfit and unserviceable property that has been used by the police department and lawfully disposed of where the same does not exceed the sum of one hundred twenty-five dollars for any one article. 
(g)  All sums deducted from the payrolls for the police department from the respective salaries of persons in the police department entitled to share in the policemen's pension fund in the amounts set out hereafter. 
(h)  All sums which the council of the City of Elmira shall each year include in the annual budget to equal the amounts deducted from the salaries of the members of the police department on account of the policemen's pension fund during the previous calendar year, and in addition to this amount, providing the members entitled to participate in said fund are contributing to said fund, as hereinafter provided, the mayor and the council shall annually provide a sum adequate to bring said fund up to an amount sufficient to pay all drafts thereon or withdrawals therefrom on account of pensions. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - Board of trustees. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the policemen's pension fund shall consist of five members, one of whom shall be city manager, one the mayor, one the city clerk, one the chief of the police department, and one a member of the police department elected as hereinafter provided. All members and officers of the board of trustees of the pension fund shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  The said board of trustees shall have control, management and distribution of said fund, and it shall have charge of and administer said fund, and from time to time invest and reinvest the same or any part thereof, in such securities as is permitted by law for the investment of municipal funds. 
(c)  The city manager shall be chairman and the city chamberlain, treasurer of said board of trustees. The city clerk shall be secretary of said board of trustees. 
(d)  The board of trustees is authorized from time to time to adopt and amend rules and regulations, not in conflict with this or any other law, for the disposition, investment, preservation and administration of said fund. 
(e)  The treasurer of said fund is authorized upon the order or warrant of said board of trustees to make payment from said fund of pensions, granted in pursuance of this law, and also pension now charged on said fund, or any part thereof, by or under prior existing laws; and said board of trustees shall be the legal successor of the board of trustees of the present policemen's pension fund in office at the time this law takes effect. 
(f)  The said board of trustees shall determine all applications for pensions according to the provisions of this law, and shall cause to be kept a full and complete record of all its proceedings and meetings. Pensions shall be granted only by the concurring vote of four members of said board voting in favor thereof. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1945-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - Involuntary disability retirement. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the policemen's pension fund shall have the power and authority by the concurring vote of at least four of its members to retire any member of the police department who may be found on examination by the physician of the department, duly certified under oath, disqualified physically or mentally for the performance of his duties in the department by reason of disease, illness or disability, mental or physical. Such retirement shall continue during the disability of such member. 
(b)  It is provided, however, that if such member objects to being so retired, he may demand an examination as to such disability by three competent physicians of good repute and standing, one to be selected by the member of the department whose retirement is in question, and the third to be selected by the two physicians, as aforesaid, and the three so selected shall examine said member of the department and the findings of a majority of such examiners shall be final as to the ability or disability at the time of the member to perform his full duty, and if found able he shall be returned to duty at the same salary and rank then paid and held by him. Any member retired in the department under this section or the following section shall, however, remain under the orders of the city manager, who may order him at any time to do such duty of which he is capable as may be decided to be for the best interests of said department, and while so serving he shall be paid the same salary as that received by other members of the department of the same rank. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - Voluntary disability retirement. 
    Every member of said department who may have become incapacitated from performing full duty as a policeman as the result of physical or mental disability, without fault or misconduct on his part, may, on his own application, and on the concurring vote of at least four members of the board of trustees, be retired from service providing the applicant has been examined by the physician of the department and his sworn certificate filed showing that the applicant is incapacitated from performing his duties as a member of the department. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 5; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 4) 
Sec. 5. - Twenty-five year retirement. 
    Every member of the department who shall have served therein for twenty-five years or more, shall, upon his own application, without examination or certification, be retired from membership therein. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 5; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 5) 
Sec. 6. - Amount of pensions. 
(a)  A pension shall be granted and paid to each member retired under the provisions of sections three and four of an amount which equals four percent of the full retirement pension hereafter granted to members retiring after twenty-five years of service, multiplied by the number of years in the department, and any period over six months shall be considered an additional year. 
(b)  Members retired under the provisions of section five, shall receive pensions based on the following scale: 
Per year Per month Patrolmen $1,800.00 $150.00 Police sergeants 1,890.00 157.50 Police lieutenants, identification officer 1,965.00 163.75 Police captains 2,130.00 177.50 Police chief 2,550.00 212.50 Deputy chief 2,295.50 191.25  
(c)  Any member of the department who is permanently and totally disabled on account of injuries received while in the actual performance of his duties, or on his way directly to or from a such duty, without fault or misconduct on his part, shall be entitled to a full retirement pension as though he had retired after twenty-five years of service as above provided. Such a member shall be retired when examined by a physician of the department and his sworn certificate filed, showing that the applicant is totally and permanently disabled from performing his duties as a member of the department, and provided further that the trustees may, if they so desire, require a certificate from an independent physician certifying that the applicant is totally and permanently disabled from performing his full duties in the department as a result of injuries sustained in the course of his duties as above provided. 
(d)  In no case of retirement shall the member's annual pension exceed the rates set out above for retirement after twenty-five years of service in the department. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary, and in lieu of any lesser amount otherwise prescribed, any person who is an officer or member of the uniformed force of the police department of the City of Elmira and is a member of the police department pension or retirement system, and who has completed service as a member of such city-maintained police department pension or retirement system for the minimum number of years specified therein, shall, upon retirement for service, receive a pension on account of such minimum service which shall be equal to one-half of his annual compensation earnable upon the date of his retirement. 
(f)  In case a member of the Elmira police department is permanently disabled pursuant to section six C. of local law number one of nineteen hundred forty-four, any person who is an officer or member of the uniformed force of the police department and is retired on a pension on account of said injury as provided therein, shall receive a pension or a retirement allowance on account of such injury which shall be equal to one-half of his annual compensation earnable upon the date of his retirement. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, and in lieu of any lesser amount thereby prescribed, in the event a policeman has served as such for a minimum period and thereafter continues in such service, upon his subsequent retirement for service or disability, there shall be added to the amount of the annual pension or retirement allowance to which he was entitled upon such retirement, an additional amount computed at the rate of one-sixtieth of his final compensation for each year of such additional service. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, §§ 5-7; L.L. No. 1931-3; L.L. No. 1940-2, §§ 6, 7; L.L. No. 1944-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1945-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 6; L.L. No. 1952-4, § 1; L.L. No. 1965-3) 
Sec. 7. - Amount of pensions for widows and children. 
(a)  Local law number one of nineteen hundred forty, as amended by local law number five of nineteen fifty-two to increase the amount of pensions paid, shall apply only to pensions hereafter granted and shall not affect pensions which have heretofore been granted. 
(b)  The board of trustees shall pay to the widow of any member of the department who shall have died as the result of the performance of duty in the department, eighty percent of the sum which the member would have been entitled to receive in case he had retired on a disability retirement at the time of the occurrence of the injury which resulted in his death. 
(c)  For the benefit of the child or children of such member under the age of eighteen years if there be no widow, or if the widow dies, the same sum as would be paid or was paid to the widow, to be divided equally between the children. 
(d)  In case there be both widow and children, the board of trustees is given the power and authority if in its judgment it deems it for the best interest of the child or children, to prorate the monthly pension between the widow and the child or children in such proportion as it deems wise, notwithstanding any provision of this law to the contrary. 
(e)  This section shall apply only to the widow of such member who was his wife at the time of the injury which caused his death and, to his children by her or by a prior wife. 
(f)  To the dependent parent or parents of such member who dies leaving no widow, or children under the age of eighteen years, there shall be paid a pension of one hundred dollars per month, but no more than the maximum sum of one hundred dollars shall be paid in case both parents survive. 
(g)  Pensions granted to a widow shall terminate when the widow shall remarry, and pension granted for the benefit of a child or children shall terminate when such child or children shall respectively marry or arrive at the age of eighteen years. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 8; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 8; L.L. No. 1945-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 7; L.L. No. 1952-5, § 1) 
Sec. 8. - Death pensions. 
(a)  Local law number one of nineteen hundred forty, as amended to increase the amount of death pensions paid, shall apply only to death pensions hereafter granted and shall not affect pensions which have heretofore been granted. 
(b)  In the case of any member of the police department who has served ten or more consecutive years, and whose death occurs during his service in said department, or whose death occurs after he has been retired on a pension under the provisions of this law, the board of trustees of said policemen's pension fund shall make allowance or pension from said fund as follows: 
1.  To the widow of such member who has not been retired on a pension, eighty percent of the sum which the member would have been entitled to receive in case he had been retired on a pension beginning with the date of his death. 
2.  To the widow of such member who has been retired on a pension, eighty percent of the same sum that said member was receiving at the time of his death. 
3.  For the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years of such member who has not been retired on a pension, at the time of his death, if there be no widow, the same sum which the widow would be entitled to receive under the provisions of subdivision (a) of this section. In the case of the death of the widow who is receiving a pension under the provisions of subdivision (a) of this section, the said pension shall be continued and applied for the benefit of the children under the age of eighteen years. 
4.  For the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years of such member who has been retired on a pension, if there be no widow, eighty percent of the same sum as was paid to said member at the time of his death. In the case of the death of the widow who is receiving a pension under the provisions of subdivision (b) of this section, the said pension shall be continued and applied for the benefit of the child or children under the age of eighteen years. 
5.  If there be both widow and children the whole amount shall be paid to the widow and for the benefit of the child or children, under the age of eighteen years. 
6.  In case there be both widow and children, the board of trustees is given the power and authority, if in its judgment it deems it for the best interest of the child or children to prorate the monthly pension to be paid under the provisions of this section between the widow and children in such proportion as the said board shall deem wise, notwithstanding any provision of this law to the contrary. 
7.  In case of the death of a member of the department leaving no widow or children, under the age of eighteen years, there shall be paid to the dependent parent or parents of such member the same sum as would be paid to the widow of the member if she were living at the time of his death under this section. 
8.  Pensions granted to a widow shall terminate when the widow shall remarry. The pension granted to children shall terminate whenever they shall respectively marry or arrive at the age of eighteen years. 
9.  This section shall apply only to the widow of such member who was his wife at the time of his retirement under this law, and to his children by her or by a prior wife, and in no case shall it apply to a widow who was married to said member subsequent to the date when he was authorized to retire on his own motion. 
10.  The provisions concerning the amount of pensions for widows and children and others provided in sections seven and eight hereof, shall not apply to any member of the department who did not elect to contribute to the fund the additional sum required as provided in local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty as evidenced by notice in writing to the city chamberlain on or before September first, nineteen hundred fifty, but the widow, children and dependent children of such member shall receive the amount of pension prescribed in the pension law in effect immediately prior to the passage of local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 9; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 9; L.L. No. 1945-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 8) 
Sec. 9. - Return of contributions. 
    No member of the department shall be entitled to the return of any contributions made to the policemen's pension fund, other than as herein provided. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 10; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 10; L.L. No. 1945-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 9) 
Sec. 10. - Election of trustees. 
(a)  Within thirty days after this law takes effect the members of the police department who have been members for ten years, shall select by ballot one of their number as a member of the board of trustees of the policemen's pension fund. The name of the new member so selected shall be handed to the mayor of the City of Elmira for presentation to the council for confirmation. If said member is confirmed by a majority vote of the council, said member, after taking the oath of office, shall be a member of said board of trustees. The term of office of said member first chosen under this law shall be until the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and until his successor is appointed and qualifies. 
(b)  Within sixty days prior to the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and each two years thereafter, the members of said police department shall select their representative for said board of trustees by ballot and hand the name of the person so chosen to the mayor for presentation to the council for confirmation. No person who has not been a member of the police department for at least ten years shall be eligible to membership on the board of trustees. 
(c)  At the first meeting of the council in the month of January nineteen hundred forty-one, and every two years thereafter, the mayor shall present the name handed to him to said council for confirmation. 
(d)  In case at any time the members of the police department are unable by a majority vote to agree upon a member of said department as its representative on said board of trustees, or fail to present at their required time a name approved by a majority of said members, then in that case the mayor of the City of Elmira shall present to the city council for confirmation the name of a member of the police department as a member of said board of trustees. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 11; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 11; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 10) 
Sec. 11. - Methods of payment. 
    Said board of trustees shall pay the pensions as allowed and fixed by this law, from said pension fund, to the pensioner in a check payable to the order of said pensioner to be mailed to him, on or before the fifth day of each and every month, or in case the said board of trustees shall deem it expedient said check shall be delivered to said pensioner on or before said date, by one of the members of said board personally and not otherwise, and said board of trustees may, in its discretion, pay the pension of said minor child or children to the mother or to their general or testamentary guardian, or to the person or persons who shall have the care of said minor child or children and the decision of said board of trustees as to manner of payment for the best interest of said minor child or children shall be final and conclusive, and payment according to its determination of the pensions herein provided for shall be a full discharge for the moneys so paid. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 12; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 12; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 11) 
Sec. 12. - War service. 
    Members of the department who serve in the Army or Navy of the United States in a war in which the United States is involved, and who shall have been granted leaves of absence for the period while in such service, shall not be penalized thereby or deprived of any rights specified in this law. The period of time while a member is in such service shall be considered in construing this law as time served in the department, and the payments herein required to be paid into the pension fund by such members shall not be required to be paid during such war service period. 
(L.L. No. 1940-2, § 13; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 12) 
Sec. 13. - Fund closed to new members. 
(a)  This law shall apply to all persons who are now active members of the Elmira police department and to all persons under the age of thirty-five years who shall become members of the police department prior to the date this local law takes effect, and all such persons shall be eligible to the benefits secured by the creation of this fund. 
(b)  All pensions now charged on said fund, or any part thereof, by or under prior or existing law, are hereby continued and confirmed, but no person who becomes a member of the police department after the date when this local law takes effect, and no relative or dependent of such person, shall become entitled to or be paid any pension or benefit from the policemen's pension fund. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 13; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 14; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 13) 
Sec. 14. - Investment of the fund. 
    All moneys ordered to be paid out of said pension fund to any person or persons shall be paid by the treasurer only upon warrants signed by the chairman of the board and countersigned by the secretary thereof, and no warrant shall be drawn except by the order of said board duly entered on the record of the proceedings of said board. Said board of trustees is hereby authorized to deposit said fund in any of the banks of the City of Elmira upon receiving adequate security therefor or to invest the same in securities in which the funds of municipalities under the laws of the state may be invested. All interest, income or dividends which shall be paid on account of any loan or deposit, shall belong to and constitute a part of said fund. Nothing herein contained shall, however, be construed as authorizing the treasurer to loan or deposit said fund or any part thereof unless so authorized by the board. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 14; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 15; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 14) 
Sec. 15. - Reports of board of trustees. 
    The board of trustees shall make a report of the condition of said pension fund to the council in the month of January in each and every year, in which report there shall be clearly set forth a complete itemized statement of all receipts and disbursements giving the name of each and every person, corporation or association from whom any money has been received on account of said fund, together with the total amount thereof, and every person who has received any benefits from said fund and the amount thereof. And it shall be the duty of the treasurer of said board of trustees, within sixty days after the first day of February in each and every year, to furnish to the corporation counsel of the City of Elmira, a complete list of all insurance companies, or their agents, who shall not then have paid to said treasurer the whole of the two per centum tax on foreign insurance as prescribed by law. Thereupon, the said corporation counsel shall forthwith institute, whatever legal proceedings may be necessary to compel such delinquent companies, or their agents, to make proper payment to said treasurer of such overdue tax. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 15; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 16; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 15) 
Sec. 16. - Final disposition of fund. 
    If by reason of death or for other reasons a time shall come when there shall be no members of the department, and no beneficiaries entitled to receive payments from the pension fund, the balance of money and property then remaining in said fund shall become the property of the City of Elmira. 
(L.L. No. 1940-2, § 17; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 16) 
Sec. 17. - [Repealed.] 
Editor's note- Section 17 was repealed by L.L. No. 1960-5, § 1. 
Sec. 18. - Repeals. 
    All special laws in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this law, are hereby superseded, and all local laws and all ordinances of the City of Elmira in conflict or inconsistent with this law are hereby repealed except as hereinabove provided. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 16; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 18; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 18) 
Sec. 19. - Effective date. 
    This local law shall take effect immediately upon passage. 
(L.L. No. 1926-2, § 17; L.L. No. 1940-2, § 19; L.L. No. 1950-6, § 19) 
ARTICLE IV. - LOCAL LAW NO. 1 OF 1938-TAX ON INCOME OF UTILITIES 
    A local law imposing tax of one percent on gross incomes or gross operating incomes of corporations and persons furnishing utility services in the City of Elmira, for the purpose of granting relief from the hardships and suffering caused by unemployment, as authorized by section twenty-b of the general city law of the state of New York and in relation to the definition of gross income and gross operating income and the time of filing returns of the tax imposed by said local law. 
    Became a law July 1, 1938, with the approval of the mayor, no petition protesting. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira; retroactive to July 1, 1938. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira, as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [Imposed; amount.] 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by section twenty-b of the general city law of the state of New York a tax equal to one per centum of its gross income is hereby imposed upon every utility doing business in the City of Elmira which is subject to the supervision of the state department of public service of the state of New York, which has a gross income for the twelve months ending May thirty-first in excess of five hundred dollars, except that the tax rate on omnibus corporations subject to the supervision of the state department of public service under article three-a of the public service law shall be one-tenth of one per centum; and excepting altogether from the tax imposed by this local law motor carriers or brokers subject to supervision under article three-b of the public service law; and a tax equal to one per centum of its gross operating income is hereby imposed for the same period upon every other utility doing business in the City of Elmira, which has a gross income for the twelve months ending May thirty-first in excess of five hundred dollars, which taxes shall have application only within the territorial limits of the City of Elmira, and shall be in addition to any and all other taxes and fees imposed by any other provision of law for the same period. Such taxes shall not be imposed on any transaction originating or consummated outside of the territorial limits of the City of Elmira notwithstanding that some act be necessarily performed with respect to such transaction within such limits. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 1; L.L. No. 1956-1, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Definitions.] 
    As used in this section, (a) the word "utility" includes every person subject to the supervision of either division of the state department of public service, except persons engaged in the business of operating or leasing sleeping and parlor railroad cars or of operating railroads other than street surface, rapid transit, subway and elevated railroads, and also includes every person (whether or not such person is subject to such supervision) who sells gas, electricity, steam, water, refrigeration, telephony or telegraphy, delivered through mains, pipes or wires, or furnishes gas, electric, steam, water, refrigeration, telephone or telegraph service by means of mains, pipes, or wires, regardless of whether such activities are the main business of such person or are only incidental thereto, or of whether use is made of public streets; (b) the word "person" means persons, corporations, companies, associations, joint-stock associations, co-partnerships, estates, assignee of rents, any person acting in a fiduciary capacity, or any other entity, and persons, their assignees, lessees, trustees, or receivers, appointed by any court whatsoever, or by any other means, except the state, municipalities, political and civil subdivisions of the state or municipality, and public districts; (c) the words "gross income" mean and include receipts received in or by reason of any sale, conditional or otherwise, (except sales hereinafter referred to with respect to which it is provided that profits from the sale shall be included in gross income) made or service rendered for ultimate consumption or use by the purchaser in the City of Elmira, including cash, credits and property of any kind or nature (whether or not such sale is made or such service is rendered for profit), without any deduction therefrom on account of the cost of the property sold, the cost of the materials used, labor or services or other costs, interest or discount paid, or any other expense whatsoever; also profits from the sale of real property growing out of the ownership or use of or interest in such property; also profit from the sale of personal property (other than property of a kind which would properly be included in the inventory of the taxpayer if on hand at the close of the period for which a return is made); also receipts from interest, dividends, and royalties, derived from sources within the City of Elmira other than such as are received from a corporation a majority of whose voting stock is owned by the taxpaying utility, without any deduction therefrom for any expenses whatsoever incurred in connection with the receipt thereof, and also profits from any transaction (except sales for resale and rentals) within the City of Elmira whatsoever; and (d) the words "gross operating income" mean and include receipts received in or by reason of any sale, conditional or otherwise, made for ultimate consumption or use by the purchaser of gas, electricity, steam, water, refrigeration, telephony, or telegraphy, or in or by reason of the furnishing for such consumption or use of gas, electric, steam, water, refrigeration, telephone or telegraph service in the City of Elmira, including cash, credits, and property of any kind or nature; without any deduction therefrom on account of the cost of the property sold, the cost of materials used, labor or services or other costs, interest or discount paid, or any other expenses whatsoever. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 2; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 2; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 2; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 2; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Returns; filing; contents.] 
    Every utility subject to tax hereunder shall file on or before September twenty-fifth, December twenty-fifth, March twenty-fifth, and June twenty-fifth, a return for the three calendar months preceding each such return date including any period for which the tax imposed hereby or by any amendment hereof is effective, each of which returns shall state the gross income or gross operating income for the period covered by each such return. Returns shall be filed with the city chamberlain on a form to be furnished by him for such purpose and shall contain such other data, information or matter as the city chamberlain of the City of Elmira may require to be included therein. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, any utility whose average gross income or average gross operating income, as the case may be, for the aforesaid three months' period is less than fifteen hundred dollars, may file its return for such periods on June twenty-fifth, of each year. The city chamberlain of the City of Elmira, in order to ensure payment of the tax imposed, may require at any time a further or supplemental return, which shall contain any data that may be specified by the city chamberlain of the City of Elmira. Every return shall have annexed thereto an affidavit of the head of the utility making the same, or of the owner or of the co-partner thereof, or of a principal officer of the corporation, if such business be conducted by a corporation, to the effect that the statements contained therein are true. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 4; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 4; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 4; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 3; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 3; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - [Payment.] 
    At the time of filing a return as required by this local law, each utility shall pay to the city chamberlain, the tax imposed by this local law for the period covered by such return. Such tax shall be due and payable at the time of filling the return or, if a return is not filed when due, on the last day on which the return is required to be filed. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 5; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 5; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 5; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 4; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 4; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 4) 
Sec. 5. - [Records.] 
    Every utility subject to tax under this local law shall keep such records of its business in such form as the city chamberlain may require, and such records shall be preserved for a period of three years, except that the city chamberlain may consent to their destruction within that period or may require that they be kept longer. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 3; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 3; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 5; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 5; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 5) 
Sec. 6. - [Disposition of taxes and penalties received by city chamberlain.] 
    All taxes and penalties received by the city chamberlain for taxes heretofore or hereafter imposed under this section shall be credited and deposited by him in the general funds of the city. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 6; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 6; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 6; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 6; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 6; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 6) 
Sec. 7. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect July first, nineteen hundred fifty. 
(L.L. No. 1938-1, § 7; L.L. No. 1939-2, § 7; L.L. No. 1940-3, § 7; L.L. No. 1941-1, § 7; L.L. No. 1942-1, § 7; L.L. No. 1950-1, § 7) 
ARTICLE V. - LOCAL LAW NO. 1 OF 1960-TAX ON TELEPHONY AND TELEGRAPHY 
    A local law to repeal local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty-nine except that portion which imposes a tax on telephony and telegraphy. 
    Became a law March 2, 1960, no petition protesting. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. Filed in the office of the secretary of state March 9, 1960. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [Repeal of L.L. No. 1959-2, except portion imposing tax on telephony and telegraphy and telephone or telegraph service.] 
    Local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty-nine, entitled "A local law of the City of Elmira imposing a consumer's utility tax," as authorized by chapter two hundred seventy-eight of the laws of nineteen hundred forty-seven, as amended, duly enacted by the council of the City of Elmira on the twenty-eighth day of December, nineteen hundred fifty-nine, is hereby repealed, except that portion which imposes a tax on telephony and telegraphy and telephone or telegraph service of whatsoever nature, which tax shall be continued to read and provide as follows: 
    § 2. Imposition of tax. (a) Commencing January first, nineteen hundred sixty, there shall be paid by the purchaser and collected by the vendor a tax at the rate of three percent (3%) of the charge for the consumption or use within this city of the following: Telephony and telegraphy and telephone or telegraph service of whatsoever nature, except service paid for by inserting coins in coin-operated telephones available to the public. 
(L.L. No. 1960-1, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Notice.] 
    The notice required by section four of chapter two hundred seventy-eight of the laws of nineteen hundred forty-seven, as amended, required to be given by the County of Chemung and the postponement of the effective date of the county tax levied in accordance with chapter two hundred seventy-eight of the laws of nineteen hundred forty-seven, as amended, is expressly waived. 
(L.L. No. 1960-1, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Provisions of L.L. No. 1959-2 not inconsistent herewith are ratified and confirmed and continued in full force and effect.] 
    Each and every provision of said local law number two of nineteen hundred fifty-nine not inconsistent herewith is hereby ratified and confirmed and continued in full force and effect. 
(L.L. No. 1960-1, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect on March first, nineteen hundred sixty. 
(L.L. No. 1960-1, § 4) 
ARTICLE VI. - LOCAL LAW NO. 5 OF 1964-INCREASED PENSION PAYMENTS FOR CERTAIN DEPENDENTS OF DECEASED OR DECEASED RETIRED POLICEMEN AND FIREMEN 
    A local law to authorize the City of Elmira to provide increased pension payments for certain dependents of deceased or deceased retired policemen and firemen. 
    Became a law June 1, 1964. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. Filed in the office of the secretary of state June 5, 1964. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [Established.] 
    Pursuant to the provisions of chapter seven hundred ninety-two of the laws of nineteen hundred sixty-four, as amended by chapter nine hundred seventy-two of the laws of nineteen hundred sixty-five, and chapter two hundred eighteen of the laws of nineteen hundred sixty-seven, and chapter one hundred fourteen of the laws of nineteen hundred seventy-seven, the council of the City of Elmira shall provide for monthly supplemental pensions to widows and dependent children of deceased policemen and firemen and widows and dependent children of deceased retired policemen and firemen, receiving pensions pursuant to the provisions of chapter five hundred twenty-five of the laws of nineteen hundred, entitled "An act to establish a police pension fund for the City of Elmira," as continued and amended, and the provisions of sections one hundred eighty-four and one hundred eighty-five of chapter four hundred seventy-seven of the laws of nineteen hundred six, as continued and amended, the aggregate amount of any such monthly supplemental pension and the monthly pension presently being received from either the police pension fund or the firemen's pension fund, as the case may be, to not exceed three hundred twenty-five dollars ($325.00). 
(L.L. No. 1964-5, § 1; L.L. No. 1974-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1977-3, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Council to prescribe methods for providing supplemental pensions, etc.] 
    The council of the City of Elmira shall prescribe by resolution methods for providing such supplemental pensions and computing the amounts thereof and may contain provisions necessary and appropriate for the proper administration thereof, including a provision requiring the filing of verified application for such payments. 
(L.L. No. 1964-5, § 2; L.L. No. 1974-3, § 2; L.L. No. 1977-3, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Payment.] 
    Monthly supplemental pensions shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of this local law from the police pension fund, established pursuant to chapter five hundred twenty-five of the laws of nineteen hundred, and the firemen's pension fund, established pursuant to chapter four hundred seventy-seven of the laws of nineteen hundred six, as both were continued and amended. 
(L.L. No. 1964-5, § 3; L.L. No. 1974-3, § 3; L.L. No. 1977-3, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect immediately. 
(L.L. No. 1964-5, § 4; L.L. No. 1974-3, § 4; L.L. No. 1977-3, § 4) 
ARTICLE VIII. - LOCAL LAW NO. 2 OF 1966-PARTIAL TAX EXEMPTION[3] 
    A local law to provide for a partial tax exemption of real property owned by certain persons with limited income who are sixty-five years of age or over. 
    Became a law October 10, 1966. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. Filed in the office of the secretary of state October 14, 1966. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- See Real Property Tax Law § 467 for present state law. 

Sec. 1. - [Purpose.] 
    The purpose of this local law is to grant a partial exemption from taxation of the assessed valuation of the real property which is owned by certain persons with limited income who are sixty-five years of age or over meeting the requirements set forth in section four hundred sixty-seven of the Real Property Tax Law, to the extent as provided in the following schedule: 
Annual Income Percentage Assessed Valuation Exempt From Taxation $16,500 or under 50 percent $16,501 or more, but less than $17,501 45 percent $17,501 or more, but less than $18,501 40 percent $18,501 or more, but less than $19,501 35 percent $19,501 or more, but less than $20,401 30 percent $20,401 or more, but less than $21,301 25 percent $21,301 or more, but less than $22,201 20 percent More than $22,201 0 percent  
(L.L. No. 1966-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1973-4, § 1; L.L. No. 1978-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1980-2, § 1; L.L. No. 1982-4, § 1; L.L. No. 1990-3, § 1; L.L. No. 1993-5, § 1; L.L. No. 1994-7, § 1; L.L. No. 1996-1, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Scope of exemption; conditions for exemption.] 
    Real property owned by one or more persons, each of whom is sixty-five years of age or over, or real property owned by a husband and wife or by siblings, one of whom is sixty-five years of age, or over, shall be exempt from city taxes as set forth in section 1 of this Local Law, subject to the following conditions. For purposes of this section, sibling shall mean a brother or a sister, whether related through half blood, whole blood or adoption. 
a.  Except as hereinafter provided, the owner of or all of the owners must file an application annually in the assessor's office on forms prescribed by the state board to be furnished by the assessor's office and shall furnish the information and be executed in such manner as prescribed in such forms and shall be filed in such assessor's office on or before the appropriate taxable status date, or such time as may be hereafter fixed by law. Provided, however, an application for such exemption may be filed with the assessor after the appropriate taxable status date, but not later than the last date on which a petition with respect to complaints of assessment may be filed where (i) failure to file a timely application resulted from (a) a death of the applicant's spouse, child, parent, brother or sister which actually prevents the applicant from filing on a timely basis, as certified by a licensed physician, or (ii) the owner or all of the owners, of property which received an exemption pursuant to this local law on the preceding assessment role, fail to file the application for such exemption on or before the taxable status date and upon such filing assessor shall approve or deny such application as if it had been filed on or before the taxable status date. 
b.  Any person otherwise qualifying under the local law shall not be denied the exemption under the local law if he or she becomes sixty-five years of age after the appropriate taxable status date and on or before December thirty-first of the same year. 
c.  The income of the owner or the combined income of the owners must not exceed the amounts as set forth in section 1 of this Local Law for the income tax year immediately preceding the date of making application, or if no tax return is filed, the calendar year. 
d.  Title to the property must be vested in the owner or one of the owners of the property for at least twenty-four (24) consecutive months prior to the date the application is filed. 
e.  The property must be used exclusively for residential purposes, be occupied in whole or in part by the owners, and constitute the legal residence of the owners. 
(L.L. No. 1966-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1973-4, § 2; L.L. No. 1978-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1980-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1982-4, § 2; L.L. No. 1990-3, § 2; L.L. No. 1993-5, § 2; L.L. No. 1994-7, § 2; L.L. No. 1996-1, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Automatic grant of exemption, when.] 
    Any person who has been granted an exemption pursuant to this local law or any previous local law on five consecutive completed assessment rolls, including any years when the exemption was granted to a property owned by a husband and/or wife while both resided in such property, shall not be required to file an application for exemption and such person shall be automatically granted an exemption on each subsequent assessment roll; provided, however, that when tax payment is made by such person, that person must include with such payment an affidavit which shall state that such person continues to be eligible for such exemption. The affidavit shall be on a form prescribed by the state board. If such affidavit is not included with the tax payment, the city chamberlain shall proceed pursuant to section five hundred fifty-one-a of the Real Property Tax Law. 
(L.L. No. 1990-3, § 3; L.L. No. 1993-5, § 3; L.L. No. 1994-7, § 3; L.L. No. 1996-1, § 3) 
Sec. 4. - [Applicability of Real Property Tax Law.] 
    This tax exemption shall be subject to the conditions set forth in section 467 of the Real Property Tax Law. 
(L.L. No. 1966-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1973-4, § 3; L.L. No. 1978-2, § 3; L.L. No. 1980-2, § 2; L.L. No. 1982-4, § 2; L.L. No. 1990-3, § 4; L.L. No. 1993-5, § 4; L.L. No. 1994-7, § 4; L.L. No. 1996-1, § 4) 
Sec. 5. - Effective date. 
    This local law shall take effect upon filing and publication in accordance with law. 
(L.L. No. 1993-5, § 5; L.L. No. 1994-7, § 5; L.L. No. 1996-1, § 5) 
Editor's note- L.L. No. 1973-4, §§ 1-3, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion herein as amending Art. VIII, §§ 1-3, was at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE IX. - LOCAL LAW NO. 2 OF 1967-TRAVEL EXPENSE PAYMENTS 
    A local law authorizing advance lump sum travel expense payments to finance trips by city officers and employees. 
    Became a law September 11, 1967. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. Filed in the office of the secretary of state September 19, 1967. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [City chamberlain authorized and empowered to make payments.] 
    The city chamberlain of the City of Elmira be and hereby is authorized and empowered to make advance lump sum travel expense payments to any city officer or city employee to finance trips by such officer or city employee outside the City of Elmira. No lump sum travel expense payment to any city officer or city employee for any one trip outside the City of Elmira shall exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500). As used herein the term "trips" shall mean and include travel on city business and attendance at any convention, conference or school authorized by section seventy-seven-b of the general municipal law, as amended. 
(L.L. No. 1967-2, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Prior written authorization required.] 
    No lump sum travel expense payment shall be made unless prior written authorization therefor shall be given by the manager of the City of Elmira and by the department head exercising supervision over the city officer or city employee to receive such payment. 
(L.L. No. 1967-2, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Written statement to be filed, etc.] 
    Within five (5) days after any city officer or city employee receiving such a lump sum payment shall have returned to the city following completion of his or her trip or within thirty (30) days after the payment of the advance to the city officer or city employee, whichever shall occur first, such city officer or city employee shall file with the city manager a written statement setting forth in detail any and all actual and necessary expenses of travel, meals, lodging and registration or tuition fees, if any, and such city officer or city employee shall immediately refund to the city the difference, if any, between the advance lump sum payment, and the actual and necessary travel expenses of such city officer or city employee. 
(L.L. No. 1967-2, § 4) 
Sec. 4. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect immediately. 
(L.L. No. 1967-2, § 4) 
ARTICLE X. - LOCAL LAW NO. 8 OF 1968-MASS TRANSPORTATION SERVICES 
    A local law to assure the provision of mass transportation services to the public at adequate levels and at reasonable cost by authorizing the City of Elmira to participate in the provision of such services pursuant to section 119-r of the general municipal law. 
    Became a law December 2, 1968. Passed by the local legislative body of the City of Elmira. Filed in the office of the secretary of state December 9, 1968. 
    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira as follows: 

Sec. 1. - [Purpose.] 
    The purpose of this local law is to authorize the City of Elmira to take action to assure the provision of mass transportation services to the public at adequate levels and at reasonable cost. 
(L.L. No. 1968-8, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - [Council may authorize and direct mayor to enter into contracts.] 
    Pursuant to the provisions of chapter seven hundred seventeen of the laws of nineteen hundred sixty-seven, being section 119-r of the general municipal law, the council of the City of Elmira may, by resolution, authorize and direct the mayor of the City of Elmira to enter into: 
a.  A contract or contracts for the acquisition by purchase of all or any part of the property, plant and equipment of an existing mass transportation facility actually used and useful for the convenience of the public; 
b.  A contract or contracts with any person, firm or corporation, including a public authority, for the equipment, maintenance or operation of a mass transportation facility owned, acquired, constructed, reconstructed or improved by it; or 
c.  A contract or contracts for a fair and reasonable consideration for mass transportation services to be rendered to the public by a privately owned or operated mass transportation facility. Such power shall include but not be limited to the power to appropriate funds for payment of such consideration, and to provide that all or part of such consideration shall be in the form of capital equipment to be furnished to and used and maintained by such privately owned or operated mass transportation facility. 
(L.L. No. 1968-8, § 2) 
Sec. 3. - [Effective date.] 
    This local law shall take effect immediately. 
(L.L. No. 1968-8, § 3)

    Be it enacted by the council of the City of Elmira, New York, as follows:

    The council of the City of Elmira shall prescribe by resolution methods for providing such supplemental pensions and computing the amounts thereof and may contain provisions necessary and appropriate for the proper administration thereof, including a provision requiring the filing of verified application for such payments. 
(L.L. No. 1974-4, § 2; L.L. No. 1977-2, § 2)
