PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the chapters and sections in this Code shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Elmira, New York," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1973, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council: 
    Generally. The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expression thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular conduct for which the provisions were enacted. Words shall be construed in their common and usual significance unless the contrary is clearly indicated. 
    City. Whenever the term "city" is used, it shall be construed as if the term "of Elmira, New York," followed it. 
    City manager. Wherever the term "city manager" is used, it means the city manager of the City of Elmira. 
    Code. Whenever the term "Code" or "Code of Ordinances" is used without further qualification, it means this Code as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall not be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be counted. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 20. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits, city limits. Whenever the term "corporate limits," "corporation limits" or "city limits" are used, it means the legal boundary of the City of Elmira. 
    Council, city council. Whenever the term "council" or "city council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the city council of the City of Elmira. 
    County. The term "the county" or "this county" means the County of Chemung in the State of New York. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, limited liability companies and corporations, as well as to males. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Mayor. Whenever the term "mayor" is used it means the mayor of the City of Elmira. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Name of officer. Whenever the title of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the term "of the City of Elmira" was added. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing, and the plural number shall include the singular. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 35. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 36. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as herein described. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 27. 
    Premises. Whenever the term "premises" is used, it means place. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 27. 
    Public place. The term "public place" means any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, and all beaches, canals or other waterways. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 40. 
    Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the term "seal" is used it means the city or corporate seal. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The signature or subscription of a person includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The term "the state" shall be construed to mean the State of New York. 
    State statutes. All references to the New York state law means and refers to the latest edition or supplement of such law. 
    Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
    Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such buildings or lands, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, General Construction Law § 48. 
    Week. The term "week" shall be construed to mean seven days. 
    Written, in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, General Construction Law § 10 et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 1-3) 
Charter reference- City boundaries, § 1; legislative ward boundaries, § 2; election districts, § 7. 
State Law reference- Meanings of terms, General Construction Law §§ 10-61. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1973, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-4. - References to chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
    All references to chapters, articles, divisions and sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The sections appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the Code of Ordinances, City of Elmira, New York, 1973, and of ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not new enactments. 
Sec. 1-8. - Prior offenses, penalties and rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-9. - Certain ordinances not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following, when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or occurring before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(3)  Any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by the city; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(6)  Any appropriation ordinance or budget ordinance; 
(7)  Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective only for a stated or limited time; 
(8)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat; 
(10)  Any ordinance dealing with acquisition of property by the city; 
(11)  Any ordinance repealing prior ordinances; 
(12)  Any ordinance establishing tax millage; 
(13)  Any ordinance establishing fees, rates and charges; 
(14)  Any ordinance regarding land use, zoning, or adopting an official zoning map of the city or zoning or rezoning specific property; 
(15)  Any ordinance: 
a.  Establishing personnel rules; 
b.  Establishing personnel benefits, including old-age and survivors insurance benefits; or 
c.  Relating to salaries of city officers or employees; 
(16)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory or any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city; 
(17)  Any administrative ordinance; and 
(18)  Any ordinance calling elections or prescribing the manner of conducting the election. 
(b)  All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code and are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-10. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: 
    "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Elmira, New York, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
    In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Elmira, New York, is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered _____, which said section shall read as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. In lieu of designating the number of the section to be added, the ordinance adding the section to the Code may provide that said section may be appropriately numbered for inclusion in said Code. 
(c)  All chapters, articles, sections, subsections, paragraphs or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically and expressly repealed by chapter, article, section, subsection or paragraph number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1973, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-11. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1973, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions with respect to repeal of a statute, General Construction Law § 90 et seq. 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, when necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the term "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to the terms "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to the term "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-13. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1973, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- General power of city to regulate, manage and control its local affairs, General City Law § 19. 
Sec. 1-14. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the offense shall constitute a violation as prescribed by Penal Law § 55.10, and shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $250.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 15 days, or both. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any such ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalty provided in subsection (a) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any such ordinance or resolution shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the city, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Power of city to maintain order, enforce the laws, etc., General City Law § 20(13); power to provide penalties, forfeitures and imprisonment to punish violations of ordinances, General City Law § 20(22). 
Sec. 1-15. - Prosecution where different penalties exist for same offense. 
    In all cases where the same offense may be made punishable, or shall be created by different clauses or sections of the ordinances of the city, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. 
(Code 1973, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-16. - Recording by city clerk; certificate of publication. 
    All ordinances passed by the council shall be recorded by the city clerk in a proper book or books, with indexes. The originals shall be filed in the city clerk's office; and due proof of the publication of all ordinances requiring publication, by the certificate of the publisher or printer, shall be procured by the clerk, and attached thereto, or written and attested upon the face of the record of such ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-17. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-18. - Fee schedule. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city council to establish fees and charges for various services and permits provided by the city and to assemble said fees in a single location to facilitate the administration of said fees and charges. 
(b)  The city council authorizes and approves the fee schedule attached hereto and made a part of this section ("fee schedule"). 
(c)  Wherever a fee or charge is set forth in any other section or sections of the Code of Ordinances or in a departmental policy, procedure or general order which differs from the fees and charges set forth on the "fee schedule", the fees and charges set forth on the "fee schedule" shall prevail and apply.

Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Corporate name; powers, § 3; department of finance generally, § 40 et seq.; department of judiciary; city court generally, § 101 et seq.; department of judiciary; recorder's court generally, § 136 et seq.; department of public works generally, § 153 et seq.; department of public relief generally, § 200 et seq.; department of law generally, § 219 et seq.; council generally, § 250 et seq.; department of personnel and purchasing generally, § 280 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate manner of conducting city business, General City Law § 20(19); authority to exercise all necessary powers, General City Law § 20(23). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-1-2-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-19. - Time and place of meetings. 
    All meetings of the city council shall be held at 5:30 p.m. at the city council chambers, second floor, 317 East Church Street, Elmira, New York unless, by resolution approved by the council, a different time or different location within the city is designated. At the discretion of the presiding officer, a delay of up to five minutes may be allowed for a member of the council not yet in attendance. 
(Ord. No. 97-354, § 1, 8-18-1997; Ord. No. 2003-406, § 1, 12-29-2003; Ord. No. 2016-98, § 1, 3-7-2016) 
Sec. 2-20. - Mayor authorized to enter hold-harmless agreements. 
    The mayor is authorized and empowered to execute undertakings of defense and indemnification as needed with the advice of the city staff responsible for risk management and in a form as approved by the corporation counsel. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3; Ord. No. 93-85, § 1, 2-22-1993) 
Secs. 2-21-2-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City officers, § 4; elective officers, terms of office, § 5; appointive officers, terms of office, § 6; organization of common council, § 10; oath of office, § 11; vacancies, §§ 12, 13; qualifications of office, § 14; official bonds, § 15; constables' bonds, § 16; common council generally, § 20 et seq.; mayor, power and duties, § 31; supervisors, § 34; duties of city clerk, § 39; duties of city chamberlain, § 40; salary of city chamberlain, § 41; bond of city chamberlain, § 44; books and report of city chamberlain, § 45; acting city judge, § 133. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to create civil service, regulate classification of offices and employments, General City Law § 20(18); authority to provide for and regulate funds for pensions and annuities for city officers and employees, General City Law § 20(20). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-44. - Reimbursement for using private cars for city business; liability insurance required. 
(a)  Officers and employees of the city who are authorized by the city manager and actually use their automobiles for city business, shall be paid for such use at the mileage reimbursement rate authorized by the federal Internal Revenue Service and in effect at the time the mileage was incurred. No mileage reimbursement shall be paid for travel between the home of said officer or employee to his place of employment. 
(b)  Claims for mileage must be made on verified vouchers by the 15th day of each month for the use of automobiles during the preceding month. Each claim shall set out the daily mileage actually incurred on city business, show purposes of travel and points between which cars are driven. 
(c)  Officers and employees receiving payment of mileage allowance for the use of their automobiles must furnish evidence that liability insurance in amounts satisfactory to the corporation counsel are carried to protect the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-17; Ord. No. 81-134, §§ 1-3, 3-23-1981; Ord. No. 2002-233, § 1, 6-17-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority regarding expenses, etc., General Municipal Law § 20(19), (33); reimbursement for certain expenses, General Municipal Law §§ 77-b, 77-c. 
Sec. 2-45. - Employee early retirement incentive. 
(a)  Due to the state's substantial reduction in municipal aid to the city, it is necessary for the city to seek substantial reductions in its expenditures. One way to effect these savings is to offer certain municipal employees, who have reached retirement eligibility, a retirement incentive. 
(b)  There is hereby established a retirement incentive program for all management/confidential and Civil Service Employees Association, Inc. (CSEA) employees who are 55 years of age or older and who are, or will be, eligible to retire from the New York State Employees Retirement System on or before October 15, 1991. 
(c)  The said incentive program shall result in the payment of $5,000.00 to each retiring employee who would, upon retirement, meet all qualifications to commence receipt of retirement benefits through the New York State Retirement System. 
(d)  To qualify and to receive this retirement incentive, the employee must notify the city's personnel director, in writing, of his decision to retire within 30 days of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived and must actually retire from his service with the city no later than October 15, 1991. 
(e)  Any necessary regulations of implementation of this incentive program shall be established by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-18; Ord. No. 91-425, § 1, 7-29-1991) 
Sec. 2-46. - Special deputy city clerks, appointment, function. 
    The city clerk of the city may appoint not more than two deputy clerks who shall be employees of the city's correctional facility, and residents of the city. The function of the clerks will be to work at the facility and take sworn affidavits from inmates for marriage licenses. The deputies' powers and duties shall be limited solely to taking affidavits for marriage licenses from inmates and there shall be no provision for payment of salary by the city to the special deputy city clerks. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Ord. of 11-8-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 92-559, § 1, 11-16-1992) 
Sec. 2-47. - Relocation expenses. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means a person holding the position of city manager, department head, assistant or deputy department head or any other person employed by the city when approved by the city manager and authorized by the city council, provided said employee is not covered under the provisions of any collective bargaining agreement. 
    Household goods means tangible personal property owned by the employee at the time of relocation, excluding automobiles, motorcycles, and any other type of motorized vehicle, trailers, boats, airplanes of all categories and classes, animals, building materials, cord wood and any tangible property which is for resale, disposal or for use in conducting a business or commercial enterprise. 
(b)  The city recognizes that individuals who are appointed or hired by the city and who, at the time of such employment, live outside the county, may incur additional financial expenses in relocating in order to accept such employment. Reimbursement of moving expenses will enhance the city's ability to recruit and hire qualified individuals. 
(c)  Upon satisfactory fulfillment of the procedural requirements set forth in this subsection and subsection (d) of this section, the city council does hereby authorize reimbursement to an employee for relocation expenses to the extent provided herein. 
(d)  In order to be eligible for and receive reimbursement for relocation expenses, the employee must establish residency in the city, if required by law. The city shall reimburse the employee for moving expenses of household goods in an amount as authorized by the city council, provided the employee submits to the personnel director three separate written estimates of the moving expenses. The city shall have the right to substitute a reasonable alternative amount in lieu of any estimates of actual costs incurred by the employee. An employee who has received reimbursement for moving expenses of household goods shall pay to the city the amount of the reimbursement payment if the employee voluntarily terminates his employment with the city prior to the completion of one year of service. 
(e)  To be eligible for reimbursement, the employee shall complete a request for relocation reimbursement to be issued by the personnel department, together with three estimates of moving expenses of the employee's household goods. Upon receipt of the request, the personnel director shall forward it to the city manager, who shall forward it to the city council for its authorization. Upon the city council's authorization, the city chamberlain shall issue a check to the employee. 
(f)  The reimbursement procedures are as follows: 
(1)  The authority to reimburse shall not create or impose any legal liability or obligation on the city to pay the employee an amount in excess of the amount authorized by the city council in the event that the employee's actual moving expenses exceed the amount authorized. 
(2)  No payment shall be made to the employee until the employee has completed his move and commenced employment with the city. 
(3)  Any authorized payment shall be made solely and directly to the employee and to no other person or entity. 
(4)  The city shall not enter into any contract with a moving company for moving services for a relocating employee nor shall the city guarantee payment of such expenses. 
(Ord. No. 98-134, § 1, 3-16-1998) 
Secs. 2-48-2-67. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYMENT BENEFITS FOR NONUNION CITY EMPLOYEES AND NONELECTED OFFICERS 

Sec. 2-68. - Purpose. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means any city officer, other than an elected officer, and employee, other than a police deputy chief, a temporary or seasonal employee, who does not receive his salary and employment benefits pursuant to the terms and conditions of a collective bargaining agreement to which the city is a party, a mandatory arbitration decision or a contract imposed pursuant to law. 
    Member means a city employee covered under the provisions of a collective bargaining unit representing the police or fire departments. 
(b)  Intent. Pursuant to the sections set forth in this division, it is the intent of the city council of the city to establish a comprehensive compensation and benefit plan for city officers, other than elected officers, and employees who do not receive their salaries and benefits pursuant to the terms and conditions of a collective bargaining agreement to which the city is a party, a mandatory arbitration decision, or a contract imposed pursuant to law. It is also the city's intent to maintain in this division the existing provisions regarding vacation and sick leave for members of the police and fire departments. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 2, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 2002-151, § 1, 4-10-2000) 
Sec. 2-69. - Salary, longevity, on-call, overtime pay and compensatory time. 
(a)  Salary. An employee shall be paid a salary as set forth in the salary pay plan approved by resolution adopted by the city council. The plan shall set forth designated grades for positions and within each grade there shall be seven steps. The determination of the applicable step for each employee shall be made annually by the city manager based upon the employee's performance appraisal. The city manager is authorized to develop criteria for performance evaluation and annually move each employee to the next higher or next lower step or to make no step adjustment. If the city manager determines: 
(1)  The employee has performed above expectation, the employee will advance to the next higher step within the grade; 
(2)  The employee has performed at expectation, the employee will not advance; or 
(3)  The employee has performed below expectation, the employee will revert to the next lower step within the grade. 
In the event an employee is promoted to a position with a higher grade, the employee shall be placed at a salary step within the new grade which step is at least five percent higher than the salary being received immediately before the promotion, or the base step of the new grade, whichever is higher. In the event an employee is demoted to a position with a lower grade, the employee shall be placed at the salary step within the new grade which is the nearest to a five percent decrease in the salary being received immediately before the demotion. 
(b)  Longevity pay. The salary pay plan shall provide for and contain the following longevity payments: 
(1)  An employee with ten or more but less than 15 years of continuous employment shall receive a payment of $800.00 annually; 
(2)  An employee with 15 or more but less than 20 years of continuous employment shall receive a payment of $1,200.00 annually; 
(3)  An employee with 20 or more years of continuous employment shall receive a payment of $1,600.00 annually; 
(4)  An employee with 25 or more years of continuous employment shall receive a payment of $2,000.00 annually. 
The annual longevity payment shall be paid in equal installments based upon the number of pay periods in the year. 
(c)  On-call pay. An employee required to be on-call shall be paid an additional $150.00 per week for each week the employee is actually on call. 
(d)  Overtime pay; compensatory time. 
(1)  An employee in a salary grade one through nine who works in excess of the standard workday shall be paid overtime at the rate of 11/2 the employee's standard rate in accordance with the provisions of the Fair Labors Standard Act, or such employee may elect to take compensatory time at the rate of 11/2 hours of compensatory time for each hour of overtime; provided, however, no such employee shall be entitled or permitted to accrue more than 15 days of compensatory time. 
(2)  Except as otherwise herein below provided, an employee in the salary grades 10 through 14 shall not be entitled to overtime pay. Such employee shall be entitled to compensatory time at the rate of one hour of compensatory time for each hour of overtime in excess of 50 hours per week; provided, however, no such employee shall be entitled or permitted to accrue more than 15 days of compensatory time. Employees holding the positions of superintendent/director of buildings and grounds and electrical supervisor shall be paid overtime at the rate of one and one-half the employee standard rate but only when the work performed is on a call-out basis occurring after the standard work day and only when the work performed is outside the territorial limits of the city and rendered pursuant to an intermunicipal agreement between the city and the county, town or village within Chemung County. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 3, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 2000-19, § 1, 1-3-2000; Ord. No. 2002-417, § 1, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2014-423, § 1, 12-29-2014 ; Ord. No. 2015-188, § 1, 6-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-70. - Health, dental, optical, life and disability insurances option. 
(a)  The city shall provide health, dental, optical, life or disability insurances as approved by the city council. Such coverages may include a cafeteria plan established pursuant to section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code as now in effect and as hereinafter amended. Unless prohibited by section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code or regulations thereunder, an employee may elect to have the cash value of his accrued vacation days up to a maximum of ten accrued days, added to the employee's cafeteria plan as additional moneys available for benefits under the plan. 
(b)  Except as hereinafter provided, if an employee chooses not to be covered under any of the insurance coverages made available by the city, the employee may elect and, upon such election, the city shall pay to the employee in December of the year, one third of the city's cost of the premiums applicable to the city insurance coverages under which the employee has elected not to be covered; provided, however, if an employee is or could be covered under any city insurance coverages of another city employee, the employee may not make the election and shall not receive the payment provided for herein. 
(c)  Contribution procedure by employees in various insurance plans is as follows: 
(1)  Effective the first pay period in December 2002, each employee covered under the health insurance coverage made available by the city shall contribute the following percentage toward the cost of such health insurance coverage: 
a.  Two percent of the employee's base salary if the employee has family coverage; or 
b.  One percent of the employee's base salary if the employee has individual coverage. 
(2)  Effective the first pay period in December 2002, each employee not covered under the health insurance coverage made available by the city but covered under either the city's dental coverage or vision coverage or both, shall contribute $5.00 per pay period for each coverage applicable to the employee. 
(3)  The city chamberlain is hereby authorized and directed to deduct from each employee's pay the contributions required pursuant to subsections (c)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 4, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 2002-417, §§ 2, 3, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 2-71. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Subject to the terms hereinafter provided and in addition to any annual vacation, holiday and personal leave and bereavement days, each employee shall receive sick leave for 12 working days each year computed on the basis of one day sick leave for each month of employment during the calendar year. 
(b)  Sick leave may be accumulated over a period of years of continuous employment to a maximum of 174 working days. 
(c)  The determination as to whether an employee has been continuously employed shall be made by the city manager. 
(d)  If an employee exhausts all of his accrued sick leave, accrued compensatory time, accrued vacation and personal days due to a continuous non-work-related sickness or injury which prevents the employee from returning to work for a total of more than 12 work days during the elapse of the time during which the leaves stated in subsections (a) through (c) of this section, compensatory time, vacation and personal days are exhausted, the employee, upon approval of the city manager, shall receive a sick leave payment at the rate of one half of the employee's base salary at the time of exhaustion of all leaves for up to 90 days following such exhaustion. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 5, 10-13-1998) 
Sec. 2-72. - Personal leave and bereavement leave. 
(a)  In addition to vacation, holidays and sick leave, each employee shall be entitled annually to two days of personal leave. Each employee may convert any unused personal leave at the end of each year to additional sick leave subject to the maximum amount of sick leave pursuant to section 2-71. 
(b)  In addition to vacation, holidays, sick leave and personal leave, each employee shall be entitled to a maximum of three days leave in the event of the death of the employee's spouse, natural or adopted or stepchild, mother, father, sister, brother, grandmother, grandfather, grandchild, father-in-law or mother-in-law. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 6, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 99-402, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-73. - Vacation. 
(a)  Subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter provided in this section, each employee in grades one through nine for each of his first five years of employment shall earn and receive vacation at the rate of 11/12 of a day for each month of continuous employment. Such employee shall be entitled to use five days' vacation after six months of continuous employment. Beginning the sixth year of an employee's continuous employment and at the beginning of each year thereafter, the employee shall receive one additional day of vacation; provided, however, in no event shall the employee be entitled to more than 21 days, regardless of the number of years of continuous employment. 
(b)  Subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter provided in this section, each employee in grades ten through 14 shall be entitled to and shall receive vacation as follows: 
(1)  For such employees with less than three years of continuous employment, 11 working days annually; 
(2)  For such employees with three years but less than ten years of continuous employment, 15 working days annually; 
(3)  For such employees with ten or more years of continuous employment, 15 working days plus one additional working day for each additional continuous year of employment; provided, however, in no event shall the employee be entitled to more than 21 days, regardless of the number of years of continuous employment. 
For purposes of this subsection (b), the term "annually" means a year commencing with the employee's date of employment. 
(c)  Subject to the terms and conditions hereinafter provided in this section and except as otherwise provided in this article, each employee in grades 15 and above shall be entitled to and shall receive vacation as follows: 
(1)  For such employees with less than ten years of continuous employment, 15 working days annually; 
(2)  For such employees with ten or more years of continuous employment, 15 working days, plus one additional working day for each additional continuous year of employment; provided, however, in no event shall the employee be entitled to more than 21, days regardless of the number of years of continuous employment. 
For purposes of this subsection (c), the term "annually" means a year commencing with the employee's date of employment. 
(d)  Employees shall be permitted to accrue a maximum of two years' vacation. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 7, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 99-402, § 2, 10-12-1999; Ord. No. 2008-81, § 1, 3-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-74. - Holidays. 
(a)  In addition to any annual vacation, each employee is hereby allowed the following holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day. 
(2)  Martin Luther King Day. 
(3)  President's Day. 
(4)  Memorial Day. 
(5)  Independence Day. 
(6)  Labor Day. 
(7)  Columbus Day. 
(8)  Veteran's Day. 
(9)  Thanksgiving Day. 
(10)  Day after Thanksgiving. 
(11)  One-half day before Christmas. 
(12)  Christmas Day. 
(13)  Floating holiday. 
(b)  All holidays above provided shall be with pay. If any of the above holidays fall on Saturday or Sunday, it shall be observed, if Saturday, on the immediately preceding Friday, and if Sunday, on the immediate Monday following. 
(c)  If Christmas occurs on Saturday, thereby being observed on the immediately preceding Friday, the one-half day on December 24 shall be observed on the immediately preceding Thursday, commencing at 12:00 noon EST. 
(d)  In order to qualify for payment for any of the holidays above listed, the employee must work his last scheduled day before and the first scheduled day after the holiday unless the employee's absence is occasioned by vacation, illness, bereavement or other cause approved by the city manager. 
(e)  The police chief shall be entitled to substitute a personal, vacation, or compensatory day for a designated holiday. In December of each year, the police chief shall be paid at the rate of his base salary for each holiday for which he substituted a personal, vacation or compensatory day and for each holiday he has worked during the immediately preceding 12 months provided that, at the police chief's election, the police chief may accrue up to 20 holiday days and upon termination of employment or upon retirement be paid for said accrued holidays at the base salary in effect upon termination or retirement. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 8, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 2000-150, § 1, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 2009-238, § 1, 6-8-2009) 
Sec. 2-75. - Termination payment other than upon retirement. 
(a)  Upon an employee's termination of employment for any reason other than retirement, the employee or his estate shall be paid the following up to the maximum amounts set forth and subject to the conditions herein provided for: 
(1)  Vacation. Accrued vacation subject to the maximum amount of vacation permitted to be accrued pursuant to section 2-73; 
(2)  Sick leave. If the employee has more than ten continuous years of employment at the time of termination, the employee shall be paid for 50 percent of his accrued sick leave; provided, however, an employee terminated because of incompetency or misconduct shall not be entitled to payment for accrued sick leave; 
(3)  Compensatory time. Accrued compensatory time subject to the maximum amount of compensatory time permitted to be accrued pursuant to section 2-69. 
(b)  In calculating the payments set forth in subsection (a) of the section, the employee's salary at the date of termination shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 9, 10-13-1998) 
Sec. 2-76. - Terminal payment and insurance upon retirement. 
(a)  Upon an employee's retirement from city employment, the employee shall be paid the following, subject to the maximum amount herein set forth: 
(1)  Vacation. Accrued vacation subject to the maximum amount of vacation permitted to be accrued pursuant to section 2-73; 
(2)  Sick leave. 50 percent of the employee's accrued sick leave unless the employee elects to utilize this payment in accordance with subsection (c) of this section; 
(3)  Compensatory time. Accrued compensatory time subject to the maximum amount of compensatory time permitted to be accrued pursuant to section 2-69. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2003, an employee who retires after ten continuous years of service with the city and who will immediately after retirement begin to actually receive retirement payments from the New York State Retirement System shall receive health insurance coverage under the city's then existing health insurance plan, if any, at the city's expense for the first ten years immediately following his retirement; provided, however, such health insurance shall terminate upon the employee's death if such death occurs within the first ten years of retirement. The type of coverage, family or individual, shall be the same type of coverage that the employee had at the time of retirement; provided, however, if at any time after retirement the retired employee becomes ineligible for family coverage, said employee then will receive individual coverage during the remainder of the first ten years of retirement. If a retired employee dies within the ten-year coverage period, the surviving spouse shall be entitled to the fully paid health insurance coverage for the remainder of the ten-year period; provided, however, the surviving spouse's coverage will cease upon said spouse's remarriage or if said spouse has available health insurance coverage through his permanent fulltime employment. 
(c)  In lieu of receiving a cash payment for accrued sick leave pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section, an employee eligible for health insurance coverage under subsection (b) of this section may elect at the time of retirement to designate that the city shall apply the cash value of 100 percent of accrued sick leave, calculated at the time of retirement, towards the cost of continuing the employee's health insurance coverage after the employee has exhausted his coverage provided pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  In calculating the payments set forth in this section, the employee's salary at the time of retirement shall be used. 
(e)  Any person who has retired or does retire from the city and who is receiving or will receive post retirement health insurance coverage under the city's then existing health insurance plan pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, may elect annually in writing to decline such coverages or portions thereof. Following the exercise of such election, the city shall pay the person an amount equal to one-third of the city's cost of the premiums applicable to the city insurance coverages which the person has elected to decline; provided, however, if the person is or could be covered under any city insurance coverages of a city employee, the person may not make the election and shall not receive the payment provided for herein. The written election may be made only once each year in the month of December, and it shall be applicable to the immediately subsequent calendar year and it shall be irrevocable during the entire applicable year. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 10, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 2002-417, § 4, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2005-320, § 1, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 2-77. - Transition. 
    Upon adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived, certain employees will have accrued compensatory time in excess of the maximum amount permitted by this division. To provide for the fair and orderly transition to the provisions set forth in this division, an employee with accrued compensatory time in excess of the maximum permitted by this division shall elect upon a form provided by the city and delivered to the city's personnel director no later than December 31, 1998, to convert up to 50 percent of the excess compensatory time into sick leave, vacation days or a combination of both, subject to the maximum accruals permitted by sections 2-69(d) and 2-71(b). Any employee with accrued compensatory time in excess of the maximum amount permitted by section 2-69, regardless of whether the employee has converted any portion as herein permitted, shall use the accrued excess compensatory time by July 1, 2000. No employee shall be permitted to have accrued compensatory time in excess of the maximum amount permitted by this division on or after July 1, 2000. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 11, 10-13-1998) 
Sec. 2-78. - Benefits and payments not to create contractual obligation of city. 
    The payments and benefits provided pursuant to this division shall not create or be deemed to create any contractual right of an employee to receive, or impose any contractual obligation on the city to pay, such payments and benefits, and at any time any said payments or benefits or both or portions thereof may be modified or discontinued in the sole discretion of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-423, § 12, 10-13-1998) 
Sec. 2-79. - Police chief, police deputy chiefs and fire chief. 
(a)  Compensation and benefit plan. The compensation and benefit plan for the police chief shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Police chief. The following benefits apply to the police chief: 
a.  Salary. The police chief shall be paid a salary as set forth in the salary plan approved by city council. The salary of the police chief shall be adjusted whenever the base salary of the permanent full time police officer who is a member of a negotiating unit and who is the highest ranking subordinate to the police chief is increased, such that the salary of the police chief is increased by at least the same dollar amount of the base salary increase received by the highest ranking subordinate. 
b.  Other benefits. With respect to the following enumerated benefits, the city shall provide to the police chief the same compensation benefits which a city police officer who is a member of a negotiating unit and who is the highest ranking subordinate to the police chief in such unit receives: vacation, health, dental and optical insurance, bereavement leave, personal leave, sick leave, retirement benefits (including health insurance benefits and options, if any), voluntary termination benefits, involuntary termination benefits, death benefits, leave of absence, longevity and compensation time (comp time) accrual and usage. 
(b)  Compensation and benefit plans. The compensation and benefit plan for deputy chiefs in the police department and for the fire chief shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Police deputy chief. The following benefits apply to deputy chiefs in the police department: 
a.  Salary for deputy chief. A deputy chief shall be paid a salary as set forth in the salary pay plan approved by the city council. Said salary shall be adjusted in accordance with General Municipal Law § 207-m. 
b.  Other benefits. With respect to the following enumerated benefits, the city shall provide to each deputy chief, the same compensation benefits which a city police officer who is a member of a negotiating unit and who is the highest ranking subordinate to the deputy chief in such unit receives: vacation, health, dental and optical insurance, bereavement leave, personal leave, sick leave, retirement benefits (including health insurance benefits and options, if any), voluntary termination benefits, involuntary termination benefits, death benefits, leave of absence, longevity and compensation time (comp time) accrual and usage. 
c.  Insurance at retirement. A deputy chief at the time of retirement shall receive health insurance coverage to the extent and for the same term as a police officer then retiring would be entitled to receive under the provisions of the police collective bargaining agreement then in effect at the time of the deputy chief's retirement. To receive the health insurance coverage at the time of retirement, a deputy chief must have 20 years of continuous service with the city; provided, however, if a deputy chief has transferred laterally into the police department, he must have ten years of continuous service with the city, and immediately after retirement actually begin to receive retirement payments from the New York State Police and Firefighter Pension System. If the police collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time of the deputy chief's retirement provides its members with an alternative benefit in lieu of the health insurance coverage, the city shall provide the same alternative benefit upon the deputy chief's electing such alternative at the time of retirement. 
(2)  Fire chief. The following benefits apply to the chief of the fire department: 
a.  Salary for fire chief. The fire chief shall be paid a salary as set forth in the salary pay plan approved by the city council. The salary of the fire chief shall be adjusted whenever the base salary of the permanent fulltime deputy fire chief who is a member of a negotiating unit and is the highest ranking subordinate to the fire chief in such unit is increased, such that the salary of the fire chief shall be increased by at least the same dollar amount of the base salary increase received by such next subordinate deputy fire chief. 
b.  Other benefits. With respect to the following enumerated benefits, the city shall provide to the fire chief the same benefits which a deputy fire chief who is a member of a negotiating unit and who is the highest ranking subordinate to the fire chief in such unit receives: vacation, health, dental, and optical insurance, bereavement leave, personal leave, sick leave, retirement benefits (including health insurance benefits and options if any), voluntary termination benefits, involuntary termination benefits, death benefits, leave of absence, longevity, and compensation time (comp time) accrual and usage; provided, however, that the chief on active duty at the time of the adoption of this ordinance shall be entitled to health, dental and optical insurance coverage at no cost to said chief until October 1, 2023. 
c.  Holiday benefits. All holiday benefits for the fire chief shall be the same as the holiday benefits that nonunion city employees and nonelected officers receive in section 2-74. 
(3)  In lieu of benefits. The benefits provided to a deputy police chief and fire chief pursuant to this section are in lieu of any and all benefits granted to nonunion city employees and nonelected officers in accordance with all other provisions of this article. 
(c)  No employment contract. It is not intended by the provisions of this section to create, confer, grant or otherwise give to a deputy police chief or the fire chief any collective bargaining rights or rights of any kind which a city police officers or city firefighter who is a member of a negotiating unit has or may have under or pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement; it is the city council's intention to grant to the deputy police chiefs and fire chief only those benefits pertaining to compensation as provided for herein. Nothing in this section shall be construed to create an employment contract between the city and any individual holding the position of deputy police chief or fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 2002-151, § 2, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 2004-028, § 1, 1-26-2004; Ord. No. 2005-250, § 1, 7-25-2005; Ord. No. 2009-239, § 1, 6-8-2009; Ord. No. 2013-42, §§ 1, 2, 1-28-2013; Ord. No. 2014-276, § 1, 8-11-2014; Ord. No. 2016-11, §§ 1, 2, 1-11-2016) 
Sec. 2-80. - Administration. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized, at his discretion, to regulate the granting of the benefits under this division so that the functions of government may be properly administered, including, but not limited to, emergencies which endanger the public safety, health, the property of the city or the residents of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-35; Ord. of 11-16-1970, § 9; Ord. No. 98-423, § 13, 10-13-1998) 
Secs. 2-81-2-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-104-2-134. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-135. - Established. 
(a)  There shall be an emergency preparedness commission established for the city, appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council. The commission shall consist of: 
(1)  The civil defense director of the county; 
(2)  The director of public works of the city; 
(3)  The executive director of the American Red Cross; 
(4)  One member of the city council; 
(5)  Two citizens of the city; and 
(6)  One business person, owning a business in and paying taxes to the city. 
(b)  The term of office of the members of the emergency preparedness commission shall be three years. 
(Code 1973, § 2-81; Ord. No. 80-575, § 1, 10-6-1980; Ord. No. 85-272, § 1, 5-28-1985) 
Sec. 2-136. - Compensation. 
    The commissioners shall receive no payment for their services as members of the commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-82; Ord. No. 80-575, § 1, 10-6-1980) 
Sec. 2-137. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The emergency preparedness commission shall meet on a regular basis, at least twice a year, to: 
(1)  Review the city's flood plan; 
(2)  Prepare emergency plans to deal with other natural disasters and emergencies which might occur in the city; and 
(3)  Review the emergency plans and to monitor and evaluate regional decisions which may have an import on the health and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  The commission shall report their recommendations to the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-83; Ord. No. 80-575, § 1, 10-6-1980) 
Secs. 2-138-2-157. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CITY PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of the city, General City Law § 23. 

Sec. 2-158. - Sale approval by council. 
    Any real estate belonging to the city may be offered for sale at public auction by the city chamberlain or the deputy city chamberlain when so authorized by resolution adopted by the affirmative vote of three-fourths of all the members of the council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-55; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 1) 
Sec. 2-159. - Determining minimum amount. 
    In any resolution authorizing the sale of real estate owned by the city, the council shall determine the minimum amount for which such real estate may be sold. 
(Code 1973, § 2-56; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 2) 
Sec. 2-160. - Notice of sale; publishing description of property. 
    Public notice of the sale of real estate shall be prepared by the city chamberlain or deputy city chamberlain and published once in each week for three successive weeks preceding such sale in the official paper, which notice shall designate the place and time where the sale shall be held and the minimum sum for which the property will be sold. The notice shall also contain a brief description of the property to be sold, the street and number, where available, being sufficient and whether the property is improved or unimproved. 
(Code 1973, § 2-57; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 3) 
Sec. 2-161. - Auctioning to highest bidder; terms of purchase. 
    At the time and place provided in the notice of sale, the city chamberlain or the deputy city chamberlain shall sell such property at public auction to the highest bidder who shall be required to pay to the city chamberlain or the deputy city chamberlain at the time of sale, 20 percent of the amount bid as security for the performance of the terms of sale in the event that said sale is approved by the council and the mayor. The highest bidder shall also at the time of sale be required to sign a memorandum of purchase which shall provide for the payment of the balance of the purchase price in the event of a sale within 30 days after the approval of such sale as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1973, § 2-58; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 4) 
Sec. 2-162. - Report to council; authorization. 
    At the next regular meeting of the council succeeding said sale, the city chamberlain or the deputy city chamberlain shall submit a report thereof with a copy of the notice of sale and memorandum signed by the highest bidder and the council may at that or any succeeding meeting by a vote of three-fourths of all the members thereof authorize such sale if approved by the mayor. 
(Code 1973, § 2-59; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 5) 
Sec. 2-163. - Executing deed to property sold. 
    When said sale shall have been duly authorized by the council and approved by the mayor, the mayor shall execute, on behalf of the city, a deed to the real estate sold. 
(Code 1973, § 2-62; Ord. of 11-12-1946, § 8) 
Sec. 2-164. - Sale of property purchased by community development funds and property acquired by special act of the state legislature. 
    Notwithstanding the other sections in this article, the city is authorized to sell, lease, donate or otherwise dispose of, without public auction or bid, any real property acquired with community development block grant funds from the Department of Housing and Urban Development of the United States of America or any such property acquired by a special act of the state legislature, provided that the proceeds from any such disposition shall be utilized according to federal and state law, rules and regulations. Any such sale must be authorized by resolution adopted by the affirmative vote of three-fourths of all the members of the council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-63; Ord. No. 84-591, § 1, 11-13-1984) 
Secs. 2-165-2-181. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Grievance procedures, General Municipal Law § 682 et seq.; local government grievance procedures, Civil Service Law § 212. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-182-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRIEVANCE BOARD 

Sec. 2-201. - Established. 
(a)  A grievance board of five members, none of whom shall be directly or indirectly connected with the government of the city, is hereby established to hear appeals from decisions of department heads on grievances and to hear appeals from decisions of the city manager on claimed violations, misinterpretations or inequitable application of treatment of handicapped persons by the city. 
(b)  The members of this board shall be appointed by the city manager with the approval of council. Two shall be appointed for a term of one year, two shall be appointed for a term of two years, and one shall be appointed for a term of three years, and at the expiration of such terms, the terms of office of their successors shall be three years. All appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term. No member of the board shall hold public office or be a member of any other board or commission in the city. The board shall appoint its own chairperson. 
(c)  A hearing of any matter before the grievance board may be conducted by a majority of the members of the board; provided, that if less than the full board presides at such hearing, the member or members thereof conducting such hearing shall render a report thereon to the full board and the full board shall thereupon make its report. 
(d)  Three concurring votes shall be necessary to determine any official report or action of the grievance board. 
(e)  Necessary funds, supplies and facilities to implement the operation of the grievance board shall be provided by the city. Each member of the board shall receive compensation of $25.00 for each meeting attended, not to exceed $400.00 per year per member. 
(f)  The grievance board may make and amend rules and regulations for the conduct of its proceedings not inconsistent with the provisions of this division. A complete and up-to-date set of such rules and amendments shall be kept on file in the city manager's office. 
(Code 1973, § 2-131; Ord. No. 84-186, § 5, 4-2-1984; Ord. No. 84-545, § 4, 10-15-1984) 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as the city has advised that the grievance board established in Ordinance No. 84-186, § 5, adopted April 2, 1984, and Ordinance No. 84-545, § 4, adopted October 15, 1984, is a single board dealing with both unrepresented employees' grievances and handicapped grievances, such sections of the above-mentioned ordinances have been combined and codified herein as section 2-201. 
Secs. 2-202-2-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EMPLOYEES NOT REPRESENTED BY EMPLOYEE ASSOCIATIONS 

Sec. 2-226. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Days means all days other than Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in computing the number of days within which action must be taken or notice given within the terms of this division. 
    Department means any office, department, board, commission or other agency of the government of the city. 
    Employee means any person directly employed and compensated by the city, except persons employed in the legislative or judicial branch thereof. 
    Grievance means any claimed violation, misinterpretation or inequitable application of the existing laws, rules, procedures, regulations, administrative orders or work rules of the city or a department thereof, which relate to or involve employee health or safety, physical facilities, materials or equipment furnished to employees or supervision of employees; provided, that such term shall not include any matter involving an employee's rate of compensation, retirement benefits, disciplinary proceeding or any other matter which is otherwise reviewable pursuant to law or any rule or regulation having the force and effect of law. 
    Immediate supervisor means the employee or officer on the next higher level of authority above the employee in the department wherein the grievance exists and who normally assigns and supervises the employee's work and approves his time record or evaluates his work performance. 
(Code 1973, § 2-136; Ord. No. 84-186, § 1, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-227. - Declaration of basic principle. 
    Every employee of this city shall have the right to present his grievance in accordance with the procedures provided herein, free from interference, coercion, restraint, discrimination or reprisal, and shall have the right to be represented by a person of his own choosing at all stages of the grievance procedure. 
(Code 1973, § 2-137; Ord. No. 84-186, § 2, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-228. - Initial presentation. 
(a)  An employee who claims to have a grievance shall present his grievance to his immediate supervisor, orally, within two days after the grievance occurs. 
(b)  The immediate supervisor shall discuss the grievance with the employee, shall make such investigation as he deems appropriate and shall consult with his superior to such extent as he deems appropriate, all on an informal basis. 
(c)  Within three days after presentation of the grievance to him, the immediate supervisor shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative, if any. 
(Code 1973, § 2-138; Ord. No. 84-186, § 3, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-229. - Second stage. 
(a)  If an employee presenting a grievance be not satisfied with the decision made by his immediate supervisor, he may, within five days thereafter, request a review and determination of this grievance by the department head. Such request shall be in writing and shall contain a statement to the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. Such request shall be served upon both the department head and the immediate supervisor to whom the grievance was originally presented. Thereupon, and within two days after receiving such request, the immediate supervisor shall submit to the department head a written statement of his information concerning the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. 
(b)  The department head, or his nominee, may, and at the request of the employee shall, hold a hearing within five days after receiving the written request and statement from the employee. The employee and his representative, if any, may appear at the hearing and present oral statements or arguments. 
(c)  Within five days after the closing of the hearing, or within eight days after the grievance has been submitted to him if there be no hearing, the department head, or his nominee, shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative, if any. 
(Code 1973, § 2-139; Ord. No. 84-186, § 4, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-230. - Appeals to grievance board. 
(a)  An employee may appeal from the decision of the department head, or nominee of the department head, within 15 days after notice of such decision. The appeal shall be taken by submitting to the grievance board a written statement signed by the employee taking the appeal addressed to the chairperson, city hall, containing: 
(1)  The name, residence, address and department of employment of the employee presenting the grievance; 
(2)  The name, residence, address and department of employment of the employee or official involved in the grievance; 
(3)  The name and address of the employee's representative, if any, and his department of employment if he is a fellow employee; 
(4)  A concise statement of the nature of the grievance, the facts relating to it, and the proceedings and decisions on the grievance up to the time of the appeal; 
(5)  A request for a review of the decision of the department head or his nominee. 
(b)  The grievance board may request the department head to submit a written statement of facts, including a summary of the record of the hearing, if there was a hearing, and the original or a true copy of any other record or document used by the department head or his nominee in making his decision. Such written statement shall be submitted within three days after request by the grievance board. 
(c)  The grievance board shall hold a hearing within ten days after receiving the written request for review. It shall give at least three days' notice of the time and place of such hearing to the employee, the employee's representative, if any, and the department head or his nominee, all of whom shall be entitled to be present at the hearing. 
(d)  The hearing on the appeal may be held in public or in private as determined by the grievance board. 
(e)  New evidence, testimony or argument, as well as any documents, exhibits or other information submitted to the department head or his nominee at the hearing held by him may be introduced at the hearing by the employee, by the department head, or his nominee or upon the request of the grievance board. 
(f)  The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the grievance board if in its judgment such adjournment is necessary in order to obtain material evidence. The total of all adjournments, however, shall not exceed ten days, except that adjournments consented to by both the employee and the department head shall not be counted in determining the total days of adjournments as limited in this subsection. 
(g)  The grievance board shall not be bound by formal rules of evidence. 
(h)  A written summary shall be kept of each hearing held by the grievance board. 
(i)  The grievance board shall make its report in writing within five days after the close of the hearing. It shall immediately file its report and the written summary of the proceedings with the city manager and shall at the same time send a copy of its report to the employee, the employee's representative, if any, the department head, and the local civil service commission if appropriate. The report shall include a statement of the board's findings of fact, conclusions and advisory recommendations. 
(j)  The report of the grievance board shall be final. 
(Code 1973, § 2-140; Ord. No. 84-186, § 6, 4-2-1984) 
Secs. 2-231-2-253. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY CIVIL SERVICE EMPLOYEES ASSOCIATION 

Sec. 2-254. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Days means all days other than Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in computing the number of days within which action must be taken or notice given within the terms of this division. 
    Department means any office, department, board, commission or other agency of the government of the city. 
    Employee means any person directly employed and compensated by the city, except persons employed in the legislative or judicial branch thereof. 
    Grievance means any claimed violation, misinterpretation or inequitable application of the collective bargaining agreement between the parties, existing laws, rules, procedures, regulations, administrative orders or work rules of the city or a department thereof, which relate to or involve employee health or safety, physical facilities, materials or equipment furnished to employees or supervision of employees. 
    Immediate supervisor means the employee or officer on the next higher level of authority above the employee in the department wherein the grievance exists and who normally assigns and supervises the employee's work and approves his time record or evaluates his work performance. 
(Code 1973, § 2-146; Ord. No. 84-187, § 1, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-255. - Declaration of basic principle. 
    Every employee of this city shall have the right to present his grievance in accordance with the procedures provided herein, free from interference, coercion, restraint, discrimination or reprisal, and shall have the right to be represented by a person of his own choosing at all stages of the grievance procedure. 
(Code 1973, § 2-147; Ord. No. 84-187, § 2, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-256. - Initial presentation. 
(a)  An employee who is a member of the bargaining unit shall present in writing the basis for the member's dispute to the member's association representative. 
(b)  If the dispute is not resolved within two working days from said presentation, the association representative shall submit the basis of the dispute in writing to the department head involved. 
(c)  In the event that said dispute is not satisfactorily adjusted by the procedure outlined in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the association representative shall present the same in writing to the city manager's designee. 
(d)  In the event that said dispute is not settled within ten calendar days from the date it is referred to the city manager, either party may resort to compulsory arbitration. 
(Code 1973, § 2-148; Ord. No. 84-187, § 3, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-257. - Arbitration. 
(a)  If the employee or the association is dissatisfied with the outcome of the dispute after referral to the city manager, the employee or the association may submit the grievance to single-person arbitration by filing a demand with the city within 15 days after receipt of the decision of the city manager as set forth in section 2-256(d). 
(b)  The employee or the association shall, within the same time period file a request with the American Arbitration Association requesting a panel for the selection of an arbitrator in accordance with its rules. 
(c)  The arbitration shall thenceforth be pursued in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association. 
(d)  The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding upon all parties. However, the arbitrator shall not have authority to vary the terms of the bargaining agreements between the parties. 
(e)  All costs related to the arbitration process shall be equally shared by the association and the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-149; Ord. No. 84-187, § 4, 4-2-1984) 
Secs. 2-258-2-277. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY PROFESSIONAL FIREFIGHTERS ASSOCIATION 

Sec. 2-278. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Days means all days other than Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in computing the number of days within which action must be taken or notice given within the terms of this division. 
    Department means any office, department, board, commission or other agency of the government of the city. 
    Employee means any person directly employed and compensated by the city, except persons employed in the legislative or judicial branch thereof.
