    Grievance means any claimed violation, misinterpretation or inequitable application of the collective bargaining agreement between the parties, existing laws, rules, procedures, regulations, administrative orders or work rules of the city or a department thereof, which relate to or involve employee health or safety, physical facilities, materials or equipment furnished to employees or supervision of employees. 
    Immediate supervisor means the employee or officer on the next higher level of authority above the employee in the department wherein the grievance exists and who normally assigns and supervises the employee's work and approves his time record or evaluates his work performance. 
(Code 1973, § 2-156; Ord. No. 84-188, § 1, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-279. - Declaration of basic principle. 
    Every employee of this city shall have the right to present his grievance in accordance with the procedures provided herein, free from interference, coercion, restrain, discrimination or reprisal, and shall have the right to be represented by a person of his own choosing at all stages of the grievance procedure. 
(Code 1973, § 2-157; Ord. No. 84-188, § 2, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-280. - Initial presentation. 
(a)  An employee who is a member of the bargaining unit shall present his grievance to his immediate supervisor, orally, within two days after the grievance occurs. 
(b)  The immediate supervisor shall discuss the grievance with the employee, shall make such investigation as he deems appropriate and shall consult with this superior to such extent as he deems appropriate, all on an informal basis. 
(c)  Within three days after presentation of the grievance to him, the immediate supervisor shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative, if any. 
(Code 1973, § 2-158; Ord. No. 84-188, § 3, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-281. - Second stage. 
(a)  If an employee presenting a grievance is not satisfied with the decision made by his immediate supervisor, he may, within five days thereafter, request a review and determination of his grievance by the department head. Such request shall be in writing and shall contain a statement to the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. Such request shall be served upon both the department head and the immediate supervisor to whom the grievance was originally presented. Thereupon, and within two days after receiving such request, the immediate supervisor shall submit to the department head a written statement of his information concerning the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. 
(b)  The department head or his nominee, may, and at the request of the employee shall, hold a hearing within five days after receiving the written request and statement from the employee. The employee and his representative, if any, may appear at the hearing and present oral statements or arguments. 
(c)  Within five days after the closing of the hearing, or within eight days after the grievance has been submitted to him, if there is no hearing, the department head, or his nominee, shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative. 
(d)  In the event that said dispute is not satisfactorily adjusted by the procedure outlined in subsections (a) through (c) of this section, employee shall present the same, in writing, to the city manager or his designee. 
(e)  The city manager or his designee shall make a decision within ten days after the receipt of the appeal. He shall immediately file his decision with the employee, the employee's representative, if any, the association, and the department head. 
(Code 1973, § 2-159; Ord. No. 84-188, § 4, 4-2-1984) 
Sec. 2-282. - Arbitration. 
(a)  If the outcome or the association is dissatisfied with the outcome of the dispute after referral to the city manager, the employee or the association may submit the grievance to single person arbitration by filing a demand with the city within 15 days after receipt of the decision of the city manager as set forth in section 2-281(e). 
(b)  The employee or the association shall, within the same time period file a request with the American Arbitration Association requesting a panel for the selection of an arbitrator in accordance with its rules. 
(c)  The arbitration shall thenceforth be pursued in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association. 
(d)  The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding upon all parties. However, the arbitrator shall not have authority to vary the terms of the bargaining agreements between the parties. 
(e)  All costs related to the arbitration process shall be equally shared by the association and the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-160; Ord. No. 84-188, § 5, 4-2-1984) 
Secs. 2-283-2-312. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED BY POLICE BENEVOLENT ASSOCIATION 

Sec. 2-313. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Days means all days other than Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in computing the number of days within which action must be taken or notice given within the terms of this division. 
    Department means any office, department, board, commission or other agency of the government of the city. 
    Employee means any person directly employed and compensated by the city and represented by the Elmira Police Benevolent Association. 
    Grievance means any claimed violation misrepresentation or inequitable application of the collective bargaining agreement between the parties, existing laws, rules, procedures, regulations, administrative orders or work rules of the city or a department thereof, which relate to or involve employee health or safety, physical facilities, materials or equipment furnished to employees or supervision of employees. 
    Immediate supervisor means the employee or officer on the next higher level of authority above the employee in the police department and who normally assigns and supervises the employee's work and approves his time record or evaluates his work performance. 
(Code 1973, § 2-166; Ord. No. 85-88, § 1, 2-19-1985) 
Sec. 2-314. - Declaration of basic principle. 
    Every employee who is a member of the Elmira Police Benevolent Association shall have the right to present his grievance in accordance with the procedures provided herein, free from interference, coercion, restraint, discrimination, or reprisal, and shall have the right to be represented by a person of his choosing at all stages of the grievance procedure. 
(Code 1973, § 2-167; Ord. No. 85-88, § 2, 2-19-1985) 
Sec. 2-315. - Initial presentation. 
(a)  An employee who claims to have a grievance shall present his grievance to his immediate supervisor, orally, within two days after the grievance occurs. 
(b)  The immediate supervisor shall discuss the grievance with the employee, shall make such investigation as he deems appropriate and shall consult with this supervisors to such extent as he deems appropriate, all on an informal basis. 
(c)  Within three days after presentation of the grievance to him, the immediate supervisor shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative, if any. 
(Code 1973, § 2-168; Ord. No. 85-88, § 3, 2-19-1985) 
Sec. 2-316. - Second stage. 
(a)  If an employee presenting a grievance is not satisfied with the decision made by his immediate supervisor, he may, within five days thereafter, request a review and determination of his grievance by the department head. Such a request shall be in writing and shall contain a statement to the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. Such request shall be served upon both the department head and the immediate supervisor to whom the grievance was originally presented. Thereupon, the immediate supervisor shall submit to the department head a written statement of his information concerning the specific nature of the grievance and the facts relating to it. 
(b)  The department head, or his nominee, may, and at the request of the employee shall, hold a hearing within five days after receiving the written request and statement from the employee. The employee, and his representative, if any, may appear at the hearing and present oral statements or arguments. 
(c)  Within five days after the close of the hearing, or within eight days after the grievance has been submitted to him, if there is no hearing, the department head, or his nominee, shall make his decision and communicate the same to the employee presenting the grievance, and to the employee's representative, if any. 
(Code 1973, § 2-169; Ord. No. 85-88, § 4, 2-19-1985) 
Sec. 2-317. - Appeals to city manager. 
(a)  An employee or the association may appeal the decision of the department head or the nominee of the department head, within 15 days after notice of such decision. The appeal shall be taken by submitting to the city manager a written statement containing the following information signed by the employee taking the appeal and addressed to the city manager: 
(1)  The name, residence address and department head of employment of the employee presenting the grievance; 
(2)  The name, residence address and department of employment of each other employee or official involved in the grievance; 
(3)  The name and address of the employee's representative, if any, and his department of employment if he is a fellow employee; 
(4)  A concise statement of the nature of the grievance, the facts relating to it, and the proceedings and decisions on the grievance up to the time of the appeal; 
(5)  A request for a review of the decision of the department head or his nominee. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee may request the department head to submit a written statement of facts, including a summary of the record of the hearing, if there was a hearing, and the original or a true copy of any other record or document used by the department head or his nominee in making his decision. Such written statement shall be submitted within three days after request by the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  The city manager or his designee shall hold a hearing within ten days after receiving the written request for a review. It shall give at least three days' notice of the time and place of such hearing to the employee, the employee's representative, if any, the association and the department head or his nominee, all of whom shall be entitled to be present at the hearing. 
(d)  The hearing on the appeal will be held in private. 
(e)  New evidence, testimony or argument, as well as any documents, exhibits or other information submitted to the department head or his nominee at the hearing held by him may be introduced at the hearing by the employee, by the department head or his nominee, or upon the request of the city manager, or his designee. 
(f)  The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the city manager or his designee if in his judgment such adjournment is necessary in order to obtain material evidence. The total of all such adjournments, however, shall not exceed ten days, except that adjournments consented to by both the employee and the department head shall not be counted in determining the total days of adjournments as herein limited. 
(g)  The city manager or his designee shall not be bound by formal rules of evidence. 
(h)  A written summary shall be kept of each hearing held by the city manager or his designee. 
(i)  The city manager or his designee shall make his report in writing within five days after the close of the hearing. He shall immediately file his report and written summary of the proceedings with the employee, the employee's representative, if any, the association, the department head and the local civil service commission, if appropriate. The report shall include a statement of the city manager's or his designee's findings of fact, conclusions and decision. 
(Code 1973, § 2-170; Ord. No. 85-88, § 5, 2-19-1985) 
Sec. 2-318. - Arbitration. 
(a)  If the association is dissatisfied with the second stage decision, they may submit the grievance to single person arbitration by filing a demand with the city within 15 working days from receipt of the second stage decision. 
(b)  The employee or the association shall, within the same time period, file a request with the American Arbitration Association requesting a panel for the selection of an arbitrator in accordance with its rules. 
(c)  The arbitration shall thenceforth be pursued in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association. 
(d)  The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding upon all parties. However, the arbitrator shall not have authority to vary the terms of the collective bargaining agreement between the parties. 
(e)  All costs related to the arbitration process shall be equally shared by the association and the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-171; Ord. No. 85-88, § 6, 2-19-1985) 
Secs. 2-319-2-339. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - HANDICAPPED PERSONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Human rights, Executive Law § 290 et seq. 

Sec. 2-340. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Days means all days other than Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in computing the number of days within which action must be taken or notice given within the terms of this division. 
    Department means any office, department, board, commission or other agency of the government of the city. 
    Grievance means any claimed violation, misinterpretation or inequitable application of treatment of handicapped persons by the city, existing rules, procedures, regulations, administrative orders to work rules of the city or a department thereof, which relate to or involve health, safety, physical facilities or equipment. 
    Grievant means all persons, in addition to employees, including the general public, participants in and beneficiaries of services and job applicants who wish to file a compliant concerning handicapped discrimination by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-176; Ord. No. 84-545, § 1, 10-15-1984) 
Sec. 2-341. - Declaration of basic principle. 
    Every grievant shall have the right to present his grievance in accordance with the procedures provided herein, free from interference, coercion, restraint, discrimination or reprisal, and shall have the right to be represented by a person of his own choosing at all stages of the grievance procedure. 
(Code 1973, § 2-177; Ord. No. 84-545, § 2, 10-15-1984) 
Sec. 2-342. - Initial presentation. 
(a)  A grievant shall present in writing the basis for his complaint to the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager shall forward his decision to the grievant within ten calendar days from the date it is referred to him. If the grievant disagrees with the decision of the city manager, either party may request that the matter be forwarded to the grievance board of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 2-178; Ord. No. 84-545, § 3, 10-15-1984) 
Sec. 2-343. - Appeals to grievance board. 
(a)  A grievant may appeal from the decision of the city manager within 15 days after notice of such decision. The appeal shall be taken by submitting to the grievance board a written statement signed by the grievant making the appeal and addressed to the Chairperson, City Hall, 317 E. Church Street, Elmira, N.Y., containing: 
(1)  The name and residence address of the person presenting the grievance; 
(2)  A concise statement of the nature of the grievance, the facts relating to it, and the proceedings and decision on the grievance up to the time of appeal; 
(3)  A request for a review of the decision of the city manager; 
(4)  The name and address of grievant's representative, if any. 
(b)  The grievance board may request the city manager to submit a written statement of facts. Such written statement shall be submitted within three days after request by the grievance board. 
(c)  The grievance board shall hold a hearing within ten days after receiving the written request for review. It shall give at least three days' notice of the time and place of such hearing to the grievant, the grievant's representative, if any, and to the city manager, all of whom shall be entitled to be present at the hearing. 
(d)  The hearing on the appeal may be held in public or in private as determined by the grievance board. 
(e)  New evidence, testimony or argument, as well as any documents, exhibits or other information submitted to the city manager may be introduced by him at the hearing or upon the request of the grievance board. 
(f)  The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the grievance board if in its judgment such adjournment is necessary in order to obtain material evidence. The total of all such adjournments, however, shall not exceed ten days, except that adjournments consented to by both the grievant and the city manager shall not be counted in determining the total days of adjournments as herein limited. 
(g)  The grievance board shall not be bound by formal rules of evidence. 
(h)  A written summary shall be kept of each hearing held by the grievance board. 
(i)  The grievance board shall make its report in writing within five days after the close of the hearing. It shall immediately file its report and the written summary of the proceedings with the city manager and shall at the same time send a copy of its report to the grievant, or grievant's representative, if any. The report shall include a statement of the board's findings of fact, conclusions and advisory recommendations. 
(j)  The report of the grievance board shall be final. 
(Code 1973, § 2-179; Ord. No. 84-545, § 5, 10-15-1984) 
Secs. 2-344-2-374. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Local government records management, Arts and Cultural Affairs § 57.13 et seq. 

Sec. 2-375. - Intent. 
    The city council finds that city records are essential to the administration of city government. City records document policies, activities and decisions, provide continuity with past operations, illustrate the evolution of government and its services and protect the rights of citizens. City records need to be systematically managed to promote efficient and economical operation of government. To accomplish this it is desirable to have a records management program in place on a continuing basis. To achieve this objective it is desirable that a comprehensive records management program be enacted. 
(Code 1973, § 2-184; Code 1973, § 2-1; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-376. - Program established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a records management program. The coordination of the development and ongoing oversight of this program shall be carried out by the records management officer. 
(b)  The objectives of the records management program shall include: 
(1)  The creation of accurate, complete and necessary records; 
(2)  Cost-effective administration of information resources; 
(3)  Prompt access to and retrieval of records; 
(4)  Legal disposition of obsolete records; 
(5)  Permanent retention and protection of archival records; and 
(6)  Compliance with local, state and federal laws and regulations. 
(Code 1973, § 2-185; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-377. - Records management officer (RMO). 
    The city manager shall designate a public officer of the city to be records management officer, subject to the approval of the city council. The records management officer or his designee, shall be responsible for the records management program established by this article and subsequent amendments thereto. Such officer will be responsible for administering the noncurrent (inactive) and archival public records for the city in accordance with local, state and federal laws and guidelines. Such officer shall also be responsible for overseeing micrographics and technology projects involving city records according to quality control specifications and guidelines. 
(Code 1973, § 2-186; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-378. - Powers and duties of records management officer. 
(a)  The records management officer or his designee shall have all the necessary powers to carry out the efficient administration of records, the determination of value, use, preservation, storage and disposition of the noncurrent (inactive) and archival public records kept, filed or received by the offices and departments of the city. 
(b)  The records management officer or his designee shall establish guidelines for proper records management in any department or agency of the city in accordance with local, state and federal laws, regulations and guidelines. 
(c)  The records management officer or his designee shall report annually to the city council on the powers and duties herein mentioned including, but not limited to, efficiencies and administrative economies of programs implemented by the records management officer or his designee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-187; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-379. - Records center. 
    The records management officer shall have at his disposal adequate designated space dedicated specifically for the storage, processing and servicing of noncurrent (inactive) and archival records for all city government departments and agencies. The records center will be administered by the records management officer or his designee. 
(Code 1973, § 2-188; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-380. - Disposition of records. 
(a)  The records management officer, or designee, shall be the sole officer with authority over the disposition of city government records in consultation with the respective city officer or department head who has custody of the records of his respective office or department, and with the local records advisory board. 
(b)  Records shall be transferred to the city archives upon the recommendation of the records management officer, with the approval of the head of the department which has legal custody of the records and the approval of the records advisory board. Records of city agencies now or in the future defunct, shall pass to the legal custody of the city archives. 
(Code 1973, § 2-189; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-381. - Replevin. 
    The corporation counsel, in consultation with the records management officer, may take steps to recover local government records which have been alienated from proper custody and may, when necessary, institute actions of replevin or any other legal action or proceeding. 
(Code 1973, § 2-190; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Sec. 2-382. - Records advisory board. 
(a)  The city council shall appoint a records advisory board of five members based on recommendations by the city manager. The records advisory board shall be composed of the records management officer, the corporation counsel, the city chamberlain, the city manager and the city's historian. One member of the city council shall serve as an ex-officio member of the records advisory board. 
(b)  The function of the records advisory board shall be to advise and make suggestions to the records management officer or his designee, on future improvements of the city's records management program. The board shall meet at least twice a year. 
(c)  The records management officer or the records management officer's designee shall call all meetings of the records advisory board, presenting progress reports of the program to the board, reviewing local government records management and archives policies with the records advisory board, and examining and discussing recommendations offered by the records advisory board. 
(Code 1973, § 2-191; Ord. No. 95-34, § 1, 1-23-1995) 
Secs. 2-383-2-407. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-408-2-427. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Department of police generally, § 186 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-428. - Fee for fingerprint cards and arrest searches. 
(a)  All fingerprint cards that are requested by citizens for civil purposes will be prepared by the detective bureau of the city police department for a fee of $10.00 for a full card containing a full set of fingerprints. A fee of $1.00 will be charged for each additional card, up to a maximum of $5.00 for the cards. The fingerprint cards may be obtained from the detective bureau of the city police department during the hours of 8:00 a.m. through 4:00 p.m. 
(b)  All photographs, film or digital, that are requested by citizens for civil purposes will be prepared by the detective bureau of the city police department for a fee of $15.00 for the first photograph and $5.00 for each additional photograph. Compact disk recordings (CDR) and video recordings will be prepared at a fee of $25.00 per disk or cassette. 
(c)  Any person other than a governmental or municipal entity, who submits a request for the city to conduct a search of its police arrest records, shall first pay to the city a fee of $5.00 for each name for which a search is requested. 
(Code 1973, § 20-2; Ord. No. 82-185, § 1, 4-5-1982; Ord. No. 93-196, § 1, 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 96-67, § 1, 2-5-1996; Ord. No. 2005-104, § 1, 3-21-2005) 
Sec. 2-429. - Fees for special patrol and extra police services. 
    A fee of $45.00 per hour per police officer is hereby established to be charged to any person requesting the assignment of one or more police officers to assist in the security and safety of an event or activity held, sponsored or participated in by such person. Upon written request, the city manager may modify or waive this fee upon good cause. 
(Code 1973, § 20-3; Ord. No. 91-184, § 1, 4-8-1991; Ord. No. 98-284, § 1, 6-22-1998) 
Secs. 2-430-2-456. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Property[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Lost and found property, Personal Property Law § 2541 et seq.; abandoned unclaimed property, Abandoned Property Law § 101 et seq.; abandoned vehicles, Vehicles and Traffic Law § 1224. 

Sec. 2-457. - Records clerk designated property clerk; duties; security. 
(a)  The records clerk in the police department shall, in addition to his other duties, take charge of all property and money hereinafter described. 
(b)  All such property and money shall be described and registered by the property clerk in a record kept for that purpose, which shall contain a description of such property or money, the name and address of the owner or claimant if ascertained, the date and place where obtained or found, the name and address of the person from whom taken or obtained, with the general circumstances, the name of the officer by whom recovered or obtained, the date when received by the property clerk, the names and addresses of all claimants thereto, and any final disposition of such property or money. 
(c)  The city manager may require and take security for the faithful performance of the duties of the property clerk. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-16) 
Sec. 2-458. - Custody of property and money. 
    Any of the following that shall come into the custody of any member of the police force, recorder or criminal court in the city shall be given, as soon as practicable, into the custody of and kept by the property clerk: 
(1)  All property or money taken from the person or possession of a prisoner; 
(2)  All property or money suspected of having been unlawfully obtained or stolen or embezzled or of being the proceeds of crime or derived through crime or derived through the conversion of unlawfully acquired property or money or derived through the use or sale of property prohibited by law from being held, used or sold; 
(3)  All property or money suspected of having been used as a means of committing crime or employed in aid or in furtherance of a crime or held, used or sold in violation of law, except when inconsistent with any other provisions of law; 
(4)  All property or money taken by the police as evidence in a criminal investigation or proceeding; 
(5)  All property or money taken from or surrendered by a pawnbroker on suspicion of being the proceeds of crime or of having been lawfully obtained, held or used by the person who deposited the same with the pawnbroker; 
(6)  All property or money which is lost or abandoned, except as otherwise provided in the abandoned property law; 
(7)  All property or money taken from the possession of a person appearing to be insane, intoxicated or otherwise incapable of taking care of himself. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-17) 
Sec. 2-459. - Return of property and money to person accused. 
    Whenever property or money taken from any person arrested shall be alleged to have been feloniously obtained, or to be the proceeds of crime, and brought, with all ascertained claimants thereof and the person arrested, before the recorder or acting recorder for adjudication, and the recorder or acting recorder shall be satisfied from the evidence that the person arrested is innocent of the offense alleged, and that the property rightfully belongs to him, then such recorder or acting recorder thereupon, in writing, may order such property or money to be returned. The property clerk, if he has it, is to deliver such property or money to the accused person himself, and not to any attorney, agent or clerk of such accused person. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-18) 
Sec. 2-460. - Disputed ownership. 
    If any claim to the ownership of such property or money shall be made on oath before the recorder or acting recorder, by or in behalf of any other persons than the person arrested, and such accused person shall be held for trial or examination, such property or money shall remain in the custody of the property clerk until the discharge or conviction of the person accused and until it is lawfully disposed of. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-19) 
Sec. 2-461. - Disposition of property and money. 
(a)  All moneys or property that shall remain in the custody of the property clerk for a period of three months without a lawful claimant entitled thereto appearing and claiming same shall, in the case of moneys, be paid into the police pension fund and in the case of property, be sold at private sale or public auction after having been advertised once in the official city paper and the proceeds of such sale shall be paid into such fund, except that all property or money of a deceased person that shall come into the custody of the property clerk shall be delivered to a representative of the estate of such decedent and if there is no such representative, to the public administrator of the county where the decedent resided. Where moneys or property have been unlawfully obtained or stolen or embezzled or are the proceeds of crime or derived through crime or derived through the conversion of unlawfully acquired property or money or derived through the use or sale of property prohibited by law from being held, used or sold, or have been used as a means of committing a crime or employed in aid or in furtherance of a crime or held, used or sold in violation of law, a person who so obtained, received or derived any such moneys or property, or who so used, employed, sold or held, or who was a participant or accomplice in any such act, or a person who derives his claim in any manner from or through any such person, shall not be deemed to be the lawful claimant entitled to any such moneys or property. 
(b)  The city manager, may direct and empower the property clerk to destroy each and every article, where the property consists of any property: 
(1)  That has been used as a means of committing a crime or employed in aid or in furtherance of a crime; 
(2)  That has been held, used or sold, in violation of the law, any of the following: 
a.  Burglar tools of any description; 
b.  Firearms, cartridges or explosives; 
c.  Armored or bulletproof clothing; 
d.  Wines, fermented liquors and other alcoholic beverages and the receptacles thereof; 
e.  Soiled, bloody or unsanitary clothing; 
f.  Solids and liquids of unknown or uncertain composition; 
g.  Opium, morphine, heroin, cocaine or any or its admixtures or derivatives, and other narcotics; 
h.  Hypodermic syringes and needles; 
i.  Obscene pictures, prints, books, publications, effigies, or statues; or 
j.  Any poisonous, noxious or deleterious solids or liquids; 
(3)  Which in the opinion of the city manager is of slight value or the sale of which might result in injury to the health, welfare or safety of the public. 
If, in the opinion of the city manager, any such property may be used or converted to use for the purpose of the police department or any city, state or federal agency, such property may in the discretion of the city manager be used or converted to use for any such purpose, and the same need not be sold or destroyed as this section provides. 
(c)  Perishable property may be sold as soon as practicable on the best terms available and the proceeds of such sale shall be disposed of as this subdivision provides. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-20) 
Sec. 2-462. - Establishment of lawful property right. 
    In any action or proceeding against the property clerk for or on account of any property or money in his custody, a claimant from whose possession such property or money was taken or obtained, or any other claimant, shall establish that he has a lawful title or property right in such property or money and lawfully obtained possession thereof and that such property or money was held and used in a lawful manner. In any such action or proceeding, a claimant who derives his title or right by assignment, transfer or otherwise from or through the person from whose possession such property or money was taken or obtained, shall further establish that such person had a lawful title or property right in such property or money and lawfully obtained possession thereof and that such property or money was held and used in a lawful manner. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-21) 
Sec. 2-463. - No action for property or money held as evidence. 
    No action or proceeding may be brought against the property clerk for or on account of any property or money held as evidence in any criminal investigation or proceeding until the termination thereof. Such property shall be surrendered upon request to the chief of police, any judge of general or special sessions, district attorney or assistant district attorney. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-22) 
Sec. 2-464. - Preservation of property. 
    Where the property consists of furs or other valuable property that may be subject to deterioration or damage if stored by the property clerk, the property clerk in his discretion may store such property with a private concern having special facilities for such storage, and the cost thereof shall be a lien upon such property to be paid by the owner thereof prior to the recovery of such property. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-23) 
Sec. 2-465. - Towing and storage charges for motor vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever an abandoned motor vehicle, or a motor vehicle involved in an accident, which is in the custody of the property clerk, shall be claimed by the owner or other person lawfully entitled to possession thereof, such owner or other person shall not be entitled to the return thereof unless he shall first pay to the property clerk the towing and storage charges, and if the car is left in the city parking area, the charge for storage shall be $20.00 for each day or fraction thereof. 
(b)  Whenever a stolen motor vehicle which is in the custody of the property clerk, shall not be removed by the owner or other person lawfully entitled to possession thereof within three days after notice by registered mail from the property clerk, such owner to other person shall not be entitled to the return thereof unless he shall first pay to the property clerk the storage charges, and if the car is left in a city parking area the charge for storage shall be $20.00 for each day or fraction thereof, after the expiration of such three-day period. 
(c)  The towing and storage charges provided by this section shall be a lien upon such motor vehicle and the property clerk shall refuse to return such motor vehicle until such charges are paid, except that where such motor vehicle is the property of an estate administered by a public administrator, the towing charge and the storage charge shall be general claims against the estate of the deceased. 
(d)  The property clerk shall not require the payment of any charges provided by this section for the towing or storage of any motor vehicle in his custody while it is held as evidence in a criminal investigation or proceeding. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the property clerk to keep a complete record of the moneys collected pursuant to this section. Such moneys shall be paid into the police pension fund. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as in conflict with any of the provisions of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 60. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-24; Ord. No. 2016-60, § 2, 2-16-2016) 
Sec. 2-466. - Property and money desired to be produced in recorder's court or other criminal court. 
    If any property or money placed in the custody of the property clerk shall be desired to be produced as evidence in any recorder's court or other criminal court, such property or money shall be delivered to any officer who shall present an order to that effect from such court. Property or money used as evidence in any recorder's or other criminal court shall not be retained in such court but shall be turned over as soon as practicable to the property clerk to be disposed of according to the provisions of this subdivision. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-25) 
Sec. 2-467. - Public administrators not affected. 
    Nothing in this subdivision shall in any way contravene, modify or repeal any existing provision of law, general, special or local, relating to the jurisdiction, powers, privileges, personnel, duties and functions of any public administrator. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.1; Code 1973, § 20-26) 
Sec. 2-468. - Reporting and depositing lost money or property. 
(a)  Any person who finds any lost money or property exceeding the value of $10.00 shall report such finding to and deposit such money or property with the city manager within ten days after the finding thereof. Such money or property shall thereupon be transmitted to the property clerk who shall make entry of such deposit in his records. Such money or property shall remain in the custody of the property clerk until claimed by the lawful owner. After a period of three months without a lawful claimant entitled thereto appearing and claiming same, the money or property shall be turned over to the person who found and deposited it. If the person who found and deposited such money or property shall not appear and claim it within 30 days after notice, by registered mail, of the expiration of said three-month period, such money or property shall, in the case of money, be paid into the fund described in section 2-465(e), and in the case of property be sold at public auction or private sale after having been advertised once in the official city paper and the proceeds of such sale shall be paid into such fund. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate, or refuse or neglect to comply with any provision of this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 85.2; Code 1973, § 20-27) 
Chapter 4 - AMUSEMENT AND ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license, General Municipal Law § 185 et seq.; games of chance, General Municipal Law § 185 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 4-1-4-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CARNIVALS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Carnivals, fairs, amusement parks, Labor Law § 870-A et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carnival means any traveling show, other than a circus as defined in section 4-68, offering in the city, in a tent or other temporary structure or enclosure, any one or combination of the following types of entertainments or amusements to the general public, for which an admission or other fee is charged: Vaudeville performances, sideshows, midways, exhibitions of natural or artificial curiosities, animal exhibitions or performances, games of chance or skill, mechanical moving devices for passengers, or other such attractions. A carnival shall be generally distinguished from a circus in offering the entertainments and amusements enumerated in this definition as separate attractions in separate tents or other enclosures, and which, unlike a circus, does not offer one main show for the exhibition of human or animal performances. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 21.1; Code 1973, § 4-16) 
Sec. 4-20. - Exceptions. 
    The terms of this article shall not apply to any carnival which is given or sponsored by any religious organization, educational organization, veterans' organization, benevolent or charitable society or other local charity, or by the fire or police departments' benefit societies or associations. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 21.4; Code 1973, § 4-17) 
State Law reference- Exception, Labor Law § 870-m. 
Sec. 4-21. - Penalty. 
    No person not excepted by section 4-20 shall operate or cause to be operated any carnival without being duly licensed, under a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each day such person shall operate or cause to be operated any such carnival without such license. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 21.5; Code 1973, § 4-18) 
Secs. 4-22-4-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 4-46. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated in the city any carnival without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 21.2; Code 1973, § 4-24) 
Sec. 4-47. - Application; fee; contents; expiration. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a license required by this division shall make written application therefor to the mayor. The application shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of the amount of fees for a license as shall be determined by the mayor, which amount, in the discretion of the mayor, depending upon the size of the carnival to be operated, the number and nature of attractions to be offered, the types of admission or other fees to be charged, shall not be less than $25.00 or more than $300.00 per day. 
(b)  Such license shall specify the days and location where such carnival may operate, and shall expire at the end of such days. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 21.3; Code 1973, § 4-25) 
Secs. 4-48-4-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIRCUSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-68. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Circus means any traveling show, other than a carnival as defined in section 4-19, offering in the city, in a tent or other temporary structures or enclosures, any of the following exhibitions to the general public for which a general admission or other fee is charged: Feats of horsemanship, feats of trained animals, wild west shows, menageries, feats of acrobatics, clowns, ropewalkers, or other such exhibitions. A circus shall be generally distinguished from a carnival in offering, in addition to sideshows or collateral attractions, one main show where the exhibitions enumerated in this definition are performed, usually in a large tent or other enclosure or arena. 
    First-class circus means a circus where the price charged for admission and/or reserved seats, if any, is $0.75 or more. 
    Second-class circus means a circus where the price charged for admission and/or reserved seats, if any, is less than $0.75 but more than $0.50. 
    Third-class circus means a circus where the price charged for admission and/or reserved seats, if any, is $0.50 or less. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 22.1; Code 1973, § 4-36) 
Sec. 4-69. - Exceptions. 
    The terms of this article shall not apply to any circus which is given or sponsored by any religious organization, educational organization, veterans' organization, benevolent or charitable society, or other charity, or by the fire or police departments' benefit societies or associations. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 22.4; Code 1973, § 4-37) 
Sec. 4-70. - Penalty. 
    No person, not excepted by section 4-69, shall operate or cause to be operated any circus without being duly licensed, under a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each day such person shall operate or cause to be operated any such circus without a license. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 22.5; Code 1973, § 4-38) 
Secs. 4-71-4-98. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 4-99. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated in the city any circus without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 22.2; Code 1973, § 4-44) 
Sec. 4-100. - Application; fees; contents; expiration. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a license required by this division shall make written application therefor to the mayor. The application shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of the amount of fees for a license, which amount, in the discretion of the mayor, depending upon the size of the circus and the number and nature of exhibitions or attractions to be offered, shall be determined within the following limits: 
(1)  First-class circus, not less than $150.00, or more than $300.00 per day; 
(2)  Second-class circus, not less than $75.00, or more than $250.00 per day; 
(3)  Third-class circus, not less than $50.00, or more than $200.00 per day. 
(b)  Such license shall specify the days and location where such circus may operate, and shall expire at the end of such days. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 22.3; Code 1973, § 4-45) 
Secs. 4-101-4-128. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOVING PICTURE SHOWS AND THEATERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of public entertainment, Arts and Cultural Affairs § 19.01 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-129. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Moving picture show means any auditorium where motion pictures are exhibited on a screen for the purpose of public amusement or entertainment, and for which an admission or other fee is charged. 
    Theater means any auditorium where dramatic, vaudeville or burlesque exhibitions are performed on a stage by the performers in person, and for which an admission or other fee is charged. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 23.1; Code 1973, § 4-56) 
Sec. 4-130. - Exceptions. 
    The terms of this article shall not apply to any moving picture or theatrical performance which is given or sponsored by any religious organization, educational organization, veterans' organization, benevolent or charitable society or other charity, or by the fire or police departments' benefit societies or associations. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 23.4; Code 1973, § 4-57) 
Sec. 4-131. - Penalty. 
    No person not excepted by section 4-130, shall conduct or operate any moving picture show or theater without being duly licensed, under a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each day such moving picture show or theater shall be conducted or operated without such license. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 23.5; Code 1973, § 4-58) 
Secs. 4-132-4-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 4-161. - Required. 
    No person shall conduct or operate any moving picture show or theater in the city without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 23.2; Code 1973, § 4-64) 
Sec. 4-162. - Application; fee; expiration. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a license required by this division shall make written application therefor to the mayor. The application shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of the amount of fees for the license, which fees shall be $300.00 per year for each movie screen. 
(b)  Such license shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 23.3; Code 1973, § 4-65; Ord. No. 85-522, § 1, 11-25-1985) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animals and fowl generally, Agriculture and Markets Law § 350 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Keeping fowl prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or cause to be kept any live fowl, such as, but not limited to, chickens, ducks and geese, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-1) 
Sec. 6-2. - Keeping farm animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or cause to be kept any farm animal, such as, but not limited to, cows, horses and pigs, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(1912 Sanitary Code, Art. XXXVII, §§ 1-7; Code 1973, § 5-2(a); Ord. No. 2008-408, § 1, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-3. - Manure storage regulations. 
    All manure stored on any truck farm or garden shall be stored at a distance of not less than 25 feet from any dwelling and shall be stored in a way so as to prevent access of flies thereto. 
(1912 Sanitary Code, Art. XXXVII, §§ 1-7; Code 1973, § 5-2(b); Ord. No. 2008-408, § 1, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-4. - Cremation fees. 
    Any person or entity requesting the cremation of an animal by the city by and through its animal control program shall pay to the city the following fee: 
0 to 75 pounds ..... $35.00 
76 to 150 pounds ..... 40.00 
151 to 250 pounds ..... 55.00 
(Ord. No. 2003-337, § 1, 10-6-2003) 
State Law reference- Disposal of dead animals, Agriculture and Markets Law § 377. 
Sec. 6-5. - Resisting an animal enforcement officer. 
    No person shall interfere with or oppose an animal enforcement officer in the performance of his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2004-316, § 2, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-6. - Penalties. 
(a)  City's right to prosecute. Any violations of this chapter shall be prosecuted as a violation under the penal law or, at the city's election, the city may commence an action to recover a civil penalty. 
(b)  Prosecution of violation pursuant to penal law; appearance ticket. 
(1)  If the city elects to prosecute a violation pursuant to the penal law, an appearance ticket may be issued by the animal enforcement officer or police officer, and such officer shall file an accusatory instrument as provided for under the criminal procedure law. 
(2)  If a person charged with a violation denies the violation, the person shall appear in city court as required by the appearance ticket and answer the violation. 
(3)  If a person charged with a violation chooses to admit the violation, the person may enter a plea of guilty by signing the plea of guilty form and mailing it to the city court. 
(4)  A conviction under the penal law shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $25.00, except that: 
a.  Where the person was found to have committed any violation referred to in subsection (a) of this section within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00; and 
b.  Where the person was found to have committed two or more such violations within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00, or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both. 
(c)  Prosecution of violation pursuant to civil penalty; summons and complaint. 
(1)  If the city elects to prosecute a violation by an action to recover a civil penalty, the city authorizes the issuance of a summons and complaint pursuant to the civil practice laws and rules for any violation referred to in subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  If the person alleged to have violated any of the violations set forth in subsection (a) of this section denies any or all parts of the violation as charged in the summons, he shall serve an answer within ten days from the service of such summons upon the defendant. The answer shall be mailed to the office specified on the summons. Service of the answer may be made by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(3)  If a person against whom a violation has been claimed admits to such violation, such person shall be subject to a civil penalty. The person may complete the appropriate form authorized by the municipal regulations and forward such form and summons to the office specified on such summons with a check or money order in the amount of $25.00; except that when the person was found to have committed any violation referred to in subsection (a) of this section within the preceding five years, such check or money order shall be in the amount of $50.00; except that where the person was found to have previously committed two or more such violations referred to in subsection (a) of this section within the preceding five years, the amount of the check or money order shall be in the amount of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2004-316, § 3, 10-4-2004) 
Secs. 6-7-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, Agriculture and Markets Law § 106 et seq.; local dog control ordinances, Agriculture and Markets Law § 104. 

Sec. 6-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal enforcement officer means any individual appointed by the city to assist in the enforcement of this article or and authorized officer, agent or employee of an incorporated Humane Society or similar incorporated dog protective association under contract with the city to assist in the enforcement of this article. 
    At large means any dog that is unleashed and on property open to the public or that is on private property not owned or leased by the owner of the dog unless permission for such presence has been obtained. No dog shall be deemed to be at large if it is: 
(1)  A guide, hearing or service dog actually assisting a person who is blind, hearing impaired or disabled; 
(2)  A police work dog in use for police work; 
(3)  Accompanied by its owner or other responsible person and is actively engaged in hunting or training for hunting on unposted land or on posted land with the permission of the owner of the land and said dog is under the control of said owner or other responsible person; or 
(4)  Accompanied by its owner or other responsible person at a public dog run or designated area designed for unleashed dogs' exercise. 
    Dog includes any member of the species Canis familiaris, whether male or female, whether the latter is spayed or not. 
    Dog run means a public area designated by the city where unleashed dogs can run without restraint while accompanied by an owner or responsible person. 
    Guide dog means any dog that is trained to aid the blind and is actually used for such purpose, or any dog owned by a recognized guide dog training center located within the state during the period such dog is being trained or bred for such purpose. 
    Harbor means to provide food or shelter to any dog. 
    Hearing dog means any dog that is trained to aid a person with a hearing impairment and is actually used for such purpose, or any dog owned by a recognized training center located within the state during the period such dog is being trained or bred for such purpose. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog. 
    Police work dog means any dog owned or harbored by any local government, state or federal law enforcement agency which has been trained to aid law enforcement officers and is actually being used for police work purposes. 
    Restraint means a dog is under restraint within the meaning of this article if he is licensed and the dog is equipped with a collar of sufficient strength to restrain the dog, to which is attached a leash of sufficient strength and not more than six feet long, which leash shall be held by a competent person having the ability to control and restrain the dog by means of the collar and leash. A harness worn by a guide dog for the blind shall be considered a suitable leash hereunder. A dog is also under restraint when it is within a vehicle being driven or parked on the street or when the dog is so restrained within the property owned or leased by its owner or keeper, or so restrained on the property of another who has given permission for the dog to be there. 
    Service dog means any dog that has been or is being individually trained to do work or perform tasks for the benefit of a person with a disability, provided that the dog is or will be owned by such person or that person's parent, guardian or other legal representative. 
    Unlicensed means any dog not bearing a license on his collar shall be considered an unlicensed dog. Licenses shall not be necessary for dogs under four months of age which are not at large. 
(Code 1973, § 5-19; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 87-434, § 1, 8-17-1987; Ord. No. 2008-409, §§ 1, 2, 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2009-305, § 1, 8-3-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, Agriculture and Markets Law § 108. 
Sec. 6-32. - Penalties. 
    Any violations as such are set forth in the provisions of Agriculture and Markets Law § 118, and any violations of any additional restrictions upon the keeping or running at-large of dogs and the seizure thereof, as established by the city pursuant to the Agriculture and Markets Law shall be prosecuted as a violation under the penal law or, at the city's election, the city may commence an action to recover a civil penalty. 
(1)  a.  If the city elects to prosecute a violation pursuant to the penal law, an appearance ticket may be issued by the animal enforcement officer or police officer, and such officer shall file an accusatory instrument as provided for under the criminal procedure law. 
b.  If a person charged with a violation denies the violation, the person shall appear in city court as required by the appearance ticket and answer the violation. 
c.  If a person charged with a violation chooses to admit the violation, the person may enter a plea of guilty by signing the plea of guilty form and mailing it to the city court. 
d.  A conviction under the penal law shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $25.00 but not more than $50.00 for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $25.00 but not more than $100.00 for an unneutered or unspayed dog except that: 
1.  Where the person was found to have committed any violation referred to in this section within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00 but not more than $100.00 for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $50.00 but not more than $200.00 for an unneutered or unspayed dog; and 
2.  Where the person was found to have committed two or more such violations within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 but not more than $200.00 or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $100.00 but not more than $400.00 or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both for an unneutered or unspayed dog. 
(2)  Any person found guilty of any violation of any of the provisions of this article, other than a violation stated above in this section, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 but not more than $50.00 for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $25.00 but not more than $100.00 for an unneutered or unspayed dog except that: 
a.  Where a person was found to have violated any of the provisions of this article, other than a violation stated above in this section, within the preceding five years, the person shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 but not more than $100.00 for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $50.00 but not more than $200.00 for an unneutered or unspayed dog; and 
b.  Where the person was found to have previously committed two or more such violations of any of the provisions of this article, other than a violation stated above in this section, within the preceding five years, the person shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 but not more than $200.00 or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both for a neutered or spayed dog and not less than $100.00 but not more than $400.00 or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both for an unneutered or unspayed dog. 
(3)  a.  If the city elects to prosecute a violation by an action to recover a civil penalty, the city authorizes the issuance of a summons with notice or a summons and complaint pursuant to the Civil Practice Law and Rules for any violation referred to above in this section or any provision of this article. 
b.  If the person alleged to have violated any of the violations set forth above in this section denies any or all parts of the violation as charged in the summons, he shall serve an answer within ten days from the date of service of such summons upon the defendant. The answer shall be mailed to the office specified on the summons. Service of the answer may be made by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
c.  If a person against whom a violation has been alleged is found to have committed to such violation, such person shall be subject to a civil penalty. The person may complete the appropriate form authorized by the municipal regulations and forward such form and summons to the office specified on such summons with a check or money order in the amount of $25.00 for a neutered dog and $50.00 for an unneutered dog; except that when the person was found to have committed any violation referred to above in this section within the preceding five years, such check or money order shall be in the amount of $50.00 for a neutered dog and $100.00 for an unneutered dog; except that where the person was found to have previously committed two or more such violations referred to above in this section within the preceding five years, the amount of the check or money order shall be in the amount of $100.00 for a neutered dog and $200.00 for an unneutered dog. 
(Code 1973, § 5-27; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 79-616, § 1, 12-17-1979; Ord. No. 80-187, § 1, 3-24-1980; Ord. No. 89-683, § 1, 12-18-1989; Ord. No. 2002-423, § 1, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2003-298, § 2, 8-25-2003; Ord. No. 2004-317, §§ 4-6, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 2010-392, §§ 8-12, 12-6-2010) 
Sec. 6-33. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article shall be to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the city, including the protection and preservation of the property of the city and its inhabitants and of the peace and good order, by: 
(1)  Adopting and enforcing certain regulations and restrictions on the privileges of the owners of dogs and the rights and privileges of the residents of the city; and 
(2)  Imposing restrictions upon the keeping and running at large of dogs within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-18; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1) 
Sec. 6-34. - Restraint. 
(a)  No person who owns, possesses or harbors a dog shall permit or allow such dog to run loose or at large in any place in the city unless such dog shall be restrained as herein provided, or is in an area designated as a dog run as defined in section 6-31. 
(b)  No person who owns, possesses or harbors a dog shall tether the dog to a front porch, front steps, front stoop or any other device, or to a side or back porch, side or back steps, side or back stoop or any other device which side or back porch, side or back steps or side or back stoop provides access to a residential unit not accessed through the front door, such that the dog can interfere with a person's approach to the front door, side or back door of the residence of the person who owns, possesses or harbors a dog. 
(Code 1973, § 5-20; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 2008-409, § 3, 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2015-230, §§ 1, 2, 7-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 6-35. - Dogs creating disturbances prohibited. 
    No person shall keep, suffer or permit to be kept on the premises occupied by such person, any dog which by its repeated barking, howling or whining or other frequent or long continued noises shall unreasonably disturb the comfort or repose of any person other than the owner or harborer of such dog. 
(Code 1973, § 5-21; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1) 
State Law reference- Authority, Agriculture and Markets Law § 124. 
Sec. 6-36. - Destructive dogs prohibited; assessing and reporting dog damage to domestic animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to allow or permit such dog to cause damage or destruction to property not owned by the dog owner or to commit a nuisance upon the premises of any person other than the owner or harborer of such dog. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or possessing a dog to permit a dog to go upon property, public or private, not owned or possessed by such person, to defecate thereon without the permission of the owner of such premises; provided, however, no violation of this subsection shall occur if such person immediately removes the excrement to a designated receptacle or to the property owned or possessed by such person. This subsection shall not apply to a person who is visually handicapped and utilizes a Seeing-Eye dog, or is confined to a wheelchair. 
(c)  All reports of damage done to domestic animals by dogs in the city shall be reported to the director/commander of the city's animal control office. 
(Code 1973, § 5-22; Ord. of 12-18-1978; Ord. No. 80-64, § 1, 1-29-1980; Ord. No. 96-304, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 2008-409, §§ 4, 5, 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2010-392, § 1, 12-6-2010) 
State Law reference- Indemnification for damage, Agriculture and Markets Law § 125. 
Sec. 6-37. - Premises to be kept clean, sanitary. 
    No person who owns a dog shall permit the premises, structure or enclosure in which such dog is kept to be unclean or unsanitary. 
(Code 1973, § 5-23; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1) 
Sec. 6-38. - Animal enforcement officer; duties. 
    The city council of the city shall appoint an animal enforcement officer as needed pursuant to the appropriate statutes of the state. It shall be the duty of any animal enforcement officer or officers as well as all peace officers within the city to enforce the provisions of this article as well as of the Agriculture and Markets Law, with respect to dogs in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-24; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1) 
Sec. 6-39. - Licensing of dogs and owning or harboring unlicensed dogs. 
(a)  (1)  Individual license. The owner of any dog having obtained the age of four months or older, shall obtain a license for said dog by making an application to the city clerk or his designee. The said license shall be issued or renewed on a one-, two- or three-year basis as requested by the owner, except that no license shall be issued for a period expiring after the expiration date of the current rabies certificate for the dog being licensed. 
(2)  Purebred license. The owner of one or more purebred dogs registered by a recognized registry association, as defined in Agriculture and Markets Law § 108, may annually make an application for a purebred license, in lieu of the individual licenses required by subsection (a)(1) of this section. A purebred license shall be valid for a period of one year and shall only be renewable annually. 
(3)  Rabies vaccination required. At the time of issuances of the license, the owner shall present a statement certified by a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog has been vaccinated to prevent rabies or, in lieu thereof, a statement certified by a licensed veterinarian stating that because of old age or other reason, the life of the dog would be endangered by the administration of the vaccination. 
(b)  Fees for license. 
(1)  The fee for an individual license issued for each dog, pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section, shall be: 
a.  For each license year for each spayed or neutered dog, $7.50. 
b.  For each license year for each unspayed or unneutered dog, $15.50. 
c.  For each license year for each unspayed or unneutered dog, which is less than four months old or for a dog whose owner provides a certified statement from a licensed veterinarian stating that he or she examined the said dog and found that because of old age or other reason, the life of the dog would be endangered if spayed or neutered, $12.50. 
(2)  The fee for a purebred license issued, pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section, shall be: 
a.  For one through ten dogs for each license year, $25.00; 
b.  For 11 through 25 dogs for each license year, $50.00; or 
c.  For 26 or more dogs for each license year, $100.00. 
(3)  Animal population control program surcharge. In addition, to the license fees and assessments, an animal population control program surcharge shall be paid by the owner in the amount of: 
a.  For each license year for each neutered or spayed dog, $1.00; or 
b.  For each license year for each unspayed, or unneutered dog or each dog which has a purebred license, $3.00. 
(4)  Enumeration-census surcharge. In addition to any license fees, assessments and surcharges, an enumeration-census surcharge of $5.00 per dog shall be assessed for the purpose of recovering costs associated with any enumeration conducted, pursuant to Agriculture and Markets Law Art. 7, should a dog be identified as unlicensed during such enumeration. 
(5)  License lapse fee. If the license of any dog has lapsed more than one year, no new or renewed license shall be issued for that dog until the owner has paid in full all current fees, as well as all fees that would have been paid had the dog been properly licensed during the period in which the license had lapsed. 
(6)  A dog owner who is 65 years old or older shall receive a discount of $5.00 off of the license fees in this section. The discount shall not apply to any additional assessments, surcharges or tag replacement costs. 
(7)  There shall be no fee, surcharge or assessment, except the animal population control program surcharge, for any license issued for any guide dog, hearing dog, service dog, war dog, working search dog, detection dog, police work dog or therapy dog. Each copy of any license for such dogs shall be conspicuously marked "Guide Dog," "Hearing Dog," "Service Dog," "Working Search Dog," "War Dog," "Detection Dog," "Police Work Dog," or "Therapy Dog," as defined in Agriculture and Markets Law § 108 and, as may be appropriate, by the clerk or authorized dog control officer. 
(c)  Upon issuing said license, the city clerk or his designee shall provide a permanent identification tag for said dog. In the event that said identification tag is ever lost or destroyed, the city clerk or his designee shall issue a replacement identification tag to the dog owner at a fee of $3.00 per tag. 
(d)  After a license has been issued, at the request of the owner of said dog, the city animal control officer or his qualified designee may implant a microchip identification component in said dog. The owner shall pay a fee of $20.00. The microchip identification component, whether implanted by the city animal control officer, his designee or any other entity, is in addition to the identification tag issued above, and nothing herein shall be construed as allowing the microchip identification module to be used in lieu of the identification tag. 
(e)  Pursuant to the provisions of Agriculture and Markets Law § 118, owning or harboring a dog within the city, unless said dog is licensed as required by the provisions of this article and the state Agriculture and Markets Law, shall be an offense punishable by a fine as further provided for in section 6-32. 
(Code 1973, § 5-25; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 79-616, § 1, 12-17-1979; Ord. No. 80-646, § 1, 11-17-1980; Ord. No. 86-110, § 1, 3-3-1986; Ord. No. 98-212, § 1, 4-27-1998; Ord. No. 2003-202, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 2008-409, §§ 6, 7, 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2009-305, §§ 2, 3, 8-3-2009; Ord. No. 2010-392, §§ 2-7, 12-6-2010) 
Sec. 6-40. - Seizure, redemption of unrestrained dogs; fees. 
(a)  Any city animal control officer or any peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or police officer in the employ of or under contract with the city, shall seize any dog: 
(1)  Which is found at large within the city in violation of this article; 
(2)  Otherwise violating any of the provisions of this article; or 
(3)  Otherwise required to be seized under and by virtue of the Agriculture and Markets Law. 
(b)  Each dog seized which is not identified, whether or not licensed, shall be held for a period of five days from the day seized, during which period the dog may be redeemed by the owner as provided for in subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)  Where a dog is identified, the record owner of said dog will be promptly notified personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested of the facts of seizure and the procedure for redemption. If notification is personally given, such dog shall be held for a period of seven days after the day of notice, during which period the dog may be redeemed by its owner as provided for herein. If such notification is made by mail, such dog shall be held for a period of nine days from the date of the mailing, during which period the dog may be redeemed by its owner as provided for in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Whether the dog seized is identified or not identified, the owner may redeem such dog by producing proof that the owner has paid, to the city, the following impoundment fees, as well as the cost of seizure, plus any veterinarian expenses and rabies shot fees pursuant to subsection (d)(4) of this section and the purchase of a license, if applicable: 
(1)  For the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person, the fee is: 
a.  Neutered, $10.00; and 
b.  Unneutered, $65.00; 
(2)  For the second impoundment within one year of the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person, the fee is: 
a.  Neutered, $20.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; and 
b.  Unneutered, $75.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; 
(3)  For the third and any subsequent impoundments within one year of the first impoundment of any dog owned by that person, the fee is: 
a.  Neutered, $30.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; and 
b.  Unneutered, $85.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; 
(4)  The rabies shot fee for the city shall be $15.00 and must be paid by the owner before redeeming his dog unless the owner furnishes a certificate of current rabies vaccination for the dog; or 
(5)  In the event the city transported an identified dog to a veterinarian, because of illness or injury, the owner of the animal shall pay the city the sum of: 
a.  $10.00, if the transport occurred during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.; and 
b.  $20.00, if the transport occurred after 4:00 p.m. and prior to 8:00 a.m. 
(e)  If not so redeemed, the owner shall forfeit all title to the seized dog at the end of the appropriate redemption period and the dog shall then be made available for adoption or euthanized. No dog shall be sold and delivered for adoption unless it has been licensed prior to its release to the purchaser. The adoption purchase price for a dog that is: 
(1)  A neutered dog shall be $20.00; and 
(2)  An unneutered dog shall be $25.00; plus the fee for a rabies shot and/or license, if applicable, shall be $15.00. 
(f)  Pursuant to provisions of Agriculture and Markets Law § 118, no liability in damages or otherwise shall be incurred on account of the seizure, euthanization or adoption of any dog pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(g)  The owner of each dog seized that is not spayed or neutered will be subject to an additional charge of $100.00 at the time of redemption. This charge will be waived if the owner or responsible party has caused the dog to be spayed or neutered within seven days of redemption. 
(Code 1973, § 5-26; Ord. of 12-18-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 79-616, § 1, 12-17-1979; Ord. No. 86-317, § 1, 7-7-1986; Ord. No. 97-516, § 1, 12-8-1997; Ord. No. 2004-317, §§ 1-3, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 2008-409, § 8, 12-8-2008) 
State Law reference- Seizure, redemption period, fees and adoption of dogs, Agriculture and Markets Law § 118. 
Sec. 6-41. - Dangerous dogs. 
(a)  Definition. For the purposes of this section the term "dangerous dog" means a dog that has been declared to be dangerous by a court of competent jurisdiction, pursuant to Agriculture and Markets Law §§ 108 and 121. 
(b)  Enclosure, insurance and photographs. The city clerk shall issue, upon payment of all fees under subsection (c) of this section and the issuance of a statement of compliance from the city's department of animal control, a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog. Such certificate of registration shall be valid for one year from the date of issue. The owner of a dangerous dog living in the city shall have 30 days from the date the court determines the dog to be dangerous, or 30 days from the date that the owner moves into the city with a dog that has been adjudicated as a dangerous dog in another jurisdiction, to provide the city's department of animal control with sufficient evidence of: 
(1)  A proper enclosure to confine a dangerous dog as specified in the state Agriculture and Markets Law § 121(4) now and as may hereinafter be amended, and the posting of the premises with a clearly visible warning sign that there is a dangerous dog on the property. In addition, the owner shall conspicuously display a sign with a warning symbol that informs children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Notwithstanding the requirements of article V of the city's zoning ordinance set forth in appendix B to this Code, such sign shall measure two feet by two feet. 
(2)  Insurance. 
a.
