A policy of liability insurance issued by an insurer authorized to do business within the state in the amount of at least $50,000.00, insuring the owner for any person injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog. The policy shall contain a provision requiring the city to be named as certificate holder for the sole purpose of being notified by the insurance company of cancellation, termination or expiration of the liability insurance policy; or 
b.  A surety bond in the amount of $50,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to do business within the state, payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog. 
The city's department of animal control shall have the authority to photograph every dog which is the subject of an application for an annual certificate of registration for a dangerous dog. Upon a showing of sufficient evidence of the requirements set forth in this subsection (c), the city department of animal control will issue a statement of compliance to the owner of the dangerous dog. 
(c)  Fee. The registration fee for a dangerous dog certificate shall be $25.00 to cover the costs of issuing this registration and enforcing this section. This registration fee shall be in addition to any other fees collectable under the state Agriculture and Markets Law. 
(d)  Uniform identifiable symbol. The city's department of animal control shall have the authority to establish identifiable symbol for visual recognition of dangerous dogs. The "UGH DOG" symbol developed by Animal-Vues may be adopted as the standard symbol to identify dangerous dogs. 
(e)  Other requirements. The owner shall sign a statement attesting that: 
(1)  The owner shall maintain and not voluntarily cancel the liability insurance or surety bond required by this section during the period for which registration is sought unless the owner ceases to own the dangerous dog prior to expiration of the one-year registration period. 
(2)  The owner of a dangerous dog shall notify the city department of animal control and the local police department immediately if a dangerous dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked another animal, has attacked a human being, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dangerous dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the city department of animal control with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dangerous dog. 
(f)  Penalties. In addition to any penalties set forth in this article, the general penalty provisions set forth in section 1-14, now and as hereafter may be amended, shall apply to any violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2003-298, § 1, 8-25-2003) 
State Law reference- Dangerous dog, Agriculture and Markets Law §§ 108, 121; notification of dangerous dogs, General Municipal Law § 209-cc. 
Secs. 6-42-6-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CATS 

Sec. 6-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cat means any member of the animal species Felis catus six months or more in age. 
    Owner means any person as the term "person" is defined in section 1-2 who: 
(1)  Has the right of property in any cat; 
(2)  Keeps or harbors a cat; 
(3)  Has a cat in his care or custody; or 
(4)  Knowingly permits a cat to remain on or about any premises occupied by the person. 
    Running at large means any cat that is on property open to the public or that is on private property not owned or leased by the owner of the cat unless permission for such presence has been obtained. 
(Code 1973, § 5-36; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 2008-410, §§ 1, 2, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-72. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any violations of this article shall be prosecuted as a violation under the penal law or, at the city's election, the city may commence an action to recover a civil penalty. 
(b)  If the city elects to prosecute a violation by an action to recover a civil penalty, the city authorizes the issuance of a summons pursuant to the civil practice law and rules for any violation referred to in subsection (a) of this section. Such summons may be issued by any animal enforcement officer. 
(c)  An answer to such summons may be made by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, within ten days from the date of service of such summons upon the defendant, following the procedure provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section. Such answer will be in lieu of a personal appearance at the time and court specified as the return date of such summons, if the procedure provided in subsection (e) of this section is followed. 
(d)  If a person charged with the violation denies any or all parts of the violation as charged in the summons, he shall appear in city court as required by the summons and answer the charges against him. 
(e)  If a person against whom a violation has been claimed admits to such violation, such person shall be subject to a civil penalty. He may complete the appropriate form authorized by the municipal regulations and forward such form and summons to the office specified on such summons: 
(1)  With a check or money order in the amount of: 
a.  $25.00 for a neutered cat; and 
b.  $50.00 for an unneutered cat; 
(2)  If within the preceding five years, the person was found to have violated this article, such check or money order shall be in the amount of: 
a.  $50.00 for a neutered cat; and 
b.  $100.00 for an unneutered cat; 
(3)  If within the preceding five years, the person was found to have committed two or more such violations, the amount of the check or money order shall be in the amount of: 
a.  $100.00 for a neutered cat; and 
b.  $200.00 for an unneutered cat. 
(f)  If the city elects to prosecute a violation pursuant to the penal law, an appearance ticket may be issued by the animal enforcement officer or such officer may file an accusatory instrument as provided for under the criminal procedure law. 
(g)  An answer to the appearance ticket may be made by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, within ten days from the date of service of such summons upon the defendant, following the procedure provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section. Such answer will be in lieu of a personal appearance at the time and court specified as the return date of such summons if the procedure provided in subsection (e) of this section is followed. 
(h)  A conviction under the penal law shall be punishable by: 
(1)  A fine of not more than: 
a.  $25.00 for a neutered or spayed cat; and 
b.  $50.00 for an unneutered or unspayed cat; 
(2)  The fine shall be not more than the following, where the person was found to have violated this article within the preceding five years: 
a.  $50.00 for a neutered or spayed cat; and 
b.  $100.00 for an unneutered or unspayed cat; 
(3)  Where the person was found to have committed two or more such violations within the preceding five years, a fine of not more than: 
a.  $100.00 for a neutered or spayed cat; and 
b.  $200.00 for an unneutered or unspayed cat or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both. 
(Code 1973, § 5-40; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 2004-317, §§ 5, 6, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 2008-410, § 4, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-73. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the city, including the protection and preservation of the property of the city and its inhabitants, and providing security to residents from annoyance, intimidation, injury and health hazards by enforcing certain regulations and restrictions on the privileges of the owners of cats and by imposing restrictions upon the keeping and running at large of cats within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-35; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996) 
Sec. 6-74. - Identification. 
(a)  Every person owning or harboring any cat who shall have obtained the age of six months or older, shall have said cat bear an identification tag which shall be affixed to said cat a all times and on which tag shall be the name of the cat and the name and address of the owner of said cat. 
(b)  In lieu of the identification tag requirement as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, an owner or person harboring a cat may have a microchip identification component implanted in said cat; provided, however, that in the event such microchip identification tag is implanted by an entity other that the city animal control officer or his qualified designee, the owner of said cat must: 
(1)  Notify the city clerk or animal control officer of such implantation within ten days after implantation; and 
(2)  Obtain confirmation by the city clerk or animal control officer that said microchip identification component is compatible with the microchip identification system employed by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 5-37; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 98-213, § 1, 4-27-1998) 
Sec. 6-75. - Prohibitions. 
    No person who owns, possesses or harbors a cat shall permit or allow such cat to run loose or at large in any place in the city unless such cat is spayed or neutered or part of a trap/neuter/spay return program. 
(Code 1973, § 5-38; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 2008-410, § 3, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-76. - Seizure. 
(a)  Any city animal control officer or any peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or police officer in the employ or under contract with the city, shall seize any cat which is found at large within the city in violation of this article, as well as any cat or cats otherwise violating any of the provisions of this article or any cat or cats otherwise required to be seized under and by virtue of the state Agriculture and Markets Law. 
(b)  Each cat seized shall be held for a period of five days from the day seized, during which period the cat may be redeemed by the owner as provided for herein. 
(c)  If the owner of a seized cat is identified, said owner will be promptly notified personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested of the facts of seizure and the procedure for redemption. If notification is personally given, such cat shall be held for a period of seven days after day of notice, during which period the cat may be redeemed by its owner as provided for herein. If such notification is made by mail, such cat shall be held for a period of nine days from the date of the mailing, during which period cat may be redeemed by its owner as provided for herein. 
(d)  In any case, the owner of a seized cat may redeem such cat by paying to the city the following impoundment fees, as well as the cost of seizure, plus any veterinarian expenses and rabies shot fees pursuant to subsection (d)(4) of this section: 
(1)  For the first impoundment by that person of any cat owned: 
a.  $10.00 neutered; and 
b.  $55.00 unneutered; 
(2)  For the second impoundment of any cat owned by that person, within one year of the first impoundment, that is: 
a.  Neutered, $20.00, for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; and 
b.  Unneutered, $65.00, for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; 
(3)  For the third and any subsequent impoundments of any cat owned by that person, within one year of the first impoundment: 
a.  Neutered, $30.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; and 
b.  Unneutered, $75.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $3.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof; 
(4)  The rabies shot fee for the city shall be $15.00 and must be paid by the owner before redeeming his cat unless said owner furnishes a certificate of current rabies vaccination for said cat; or 
(5)  In the event the city transport an identified cat to a veterinarian because of illness or injury, the owner of said animal shall pay the city the sum of: 
a.  $10.00, if the transport occurred during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.; and 
b.  $20.00, if the transport occurred after 4:00 p.m. and prior to 8:00 a.m. 
(e)  If not so redeemed, the owner shall forfeit all title to the seized cat at the end of the appropriate redemption period and the cat shall then be made available for adoption or euthanized. The adoption purchase price for an unneutered cat shall be $15.00, plus the fee for a rabies shot and/or license, if applicable. The fee for the rabies shot shall be $15.00. 
(f)  No liability in damages or otherwise shall be incurred on account of the seizure, euthanization or adoption of any cat pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 5-39; Ord. No. 96-303, § 1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 97-517, § 1, 12-8-1997; Ord. No. 2004-318, §§ 1-4, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-77. - Humane capturing of lost, stray, abandoned or feral cats. 
(a)  Any resident of the city may employ the use of humane traps or other humane mechanisms to capture lost, strayed, abandoned, or feral cats within the city provided that said traps or mechanisms pose no threat to the health, safety, or welfare of any person or animal including such lost, stray, abandoned or feral cats. 
(b)  The city animal shelter, animal control officers or their designees may offer the use of city-owned humane traps or other mechanisms to any resident of the city for the human capture of lost, stray, abandoned, or feral cats as follows: 
(1)  There shall be a refundable deposit fee of $10.00 on every city-owned trap or other mechanism released to the custody of a resident. Upon the return of the trap or mechanism in substantially the same condition as when it was released to the custody of the resident, the city shall refund the $10.00 deposit fee. 
(2)  Any city-owned trap or mechanism may be released only into the custody of a city resident for exclusive use within the city and shall be used exclusively for the humane capturing of lost, stray, abandoned or feral cats. No trap or mechanism shall be released to a resident for more than seven consecutive days. For purposes of this section, a fractional part of a day shall be considered as one full day. Not more than three traps or mechanisms shall be released to any one resident at a time and not more than three traps or mechanisms may be used on a given parcel of property at any one time. 
(3)  At the time of requesting the use of a city-owned trap or mechanism, the resident shall offer proof of identification, indicate at which address the trap or mechanism will be utilized, the number of days, not to exceed seven, for which the trap shall be in the custody of said resident and the return date. There shall be a usage fee of $1.00 per day, or any part thereof, when such trap or mechanism is in the possession of the resident. Said daily usage fee is to be paid by the resident in advance. 
(4)  In the event that a resident returns said trap or mechanism after the return date indicated pursuant to subsection (b)(3) of this section, said resident shall be charged a late fee of $5.00 per day for each additional day, which late fee shall be in addition to the daily usage fee. 
(5)  Regardless of the number of days a trap or mechanism is in the possession of any resident, the city reserves the right to retrieve said trap or mechanism at any time, without prior notice to the user, provided that the user shall not be charged the user fee for the day said trap or mechanism was retrieved by the city. The user of the city-owned trap or mechanism, as a condition of such use, shall permit any animal control officer, or peace officer in the employ of the city to enter onto the user's property for the sole purpose of retrieving said trap or mechanism. A user shall immediately and peaceably relinquish custody of any city-owned trap or mechanism at the request of any animal control officer or peace officer in the employ of the city. 
(6)  The resident in whose custody the trap or mechanism is released is charged with the duty to inspect said trap or mechanism at least once every 12 hours and to immediately notify the animal control officer if a cat or other animal is captured by said trap or mechanism. Unless exigent circumstances exist, no animal shall be kept so confined in said trap or mechanism for more than 12 hours after first being noticed by the resident, and said resident shall have the duty to immediately release said animal after the expiration of 12 hours or sooner if the life or safety of the animal is in jeopardy, unless to do so would likely result in injury to any person or other animal. The resident is otherwise charged with the duty to humanely care for such captured animal until it is released from said trap or mechanism. 
(7)  The city, at its sole discretion, may deny releasing any city-owned trap or mechanism into the custody of a resident based upon a good-faith belief that said individual has committed acts of cruelty to animals, misuse, destruction or theft of city-owned property, or other good cause. 
(8)  Any cat captured in a city-owned trap or mechanism shall be confined and redeemed as provided in section 6-76. 
(c)  The use of any trap or mechanism, whether owned by the city or not, for any purpose other than the humane capturing of lost, stray, abandoned or feral cats (or other animals as may be the intended use and design of a particular non-city-owned trap or mechanism) shall constitute a misdemeanor offense and be punishable by no more than one-year incarceration and/or a $1,000.00 fine for each and every occurrence thereof. 
(d)  The intentional damaging of, theft of, or tampering with a trap or other mechanism designed and employed to humanely capture stray, lost, abandoned or feral cats (including the premature release of said cats except under exigent circumstances) shall constitute a misdemeanor and be punishable by up to 90 days incarceration and/or a $500.00 fine for each and every occurrence of such damaging, theft or tampering. 
(Ord. No. 98-235, § 1, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2008-410, §§ 5-7, 12-8-2008) 
Secs. 6-78-6-97. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXOTIC ANIMALS 

Sec. 6-98. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Exotic animal means any animal that is not listed as domestic under the state agriculture and markets law, that is nonnative to the state, and that in its adult stage, has the reasonable ability to cause a threat to the public. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping or harboring an exotic animal or animals. 
    Unconfined exotic animal means any exotic animal that is not restrained in a container or device capable of preventing physical contact with the public. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 3, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-99. - Penalties. 
    Any violations of this article shall be prosecuted as a violation under the penal law or, at the city's election, the city may commence an action to recover a civil penalty as follows: 
(1)  Prosecution of violation pursuant to penal law; appearance ticket. 
a.  If the city elects to prosecute a violation pursuant to the penal law, an appearance ticket may be issued by the animal enforcement officer or police officer, and such officer shall file an accusatory instrument as provided for under the criminal procedure law. 
b.  If a person charged with a violation denies the violation the person shall appear in city court as required by the appearance ticket and answer the violation. 
c.  If a person charged with a violation chooses to admit the violation the person may enter a plea of guilty by signing the plea of guilty form and mailing it to the city court. 
d.  A conviction under the penal law shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $25.00, except that where the person was found to have committed: 
1.  Any violation of this article referred to in subsection (1) of this section within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $50.00; and 
2.  Two or more such violations within the preceding five years, it shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00 or imprisonment for not more than 15 days, or both. 
(2)  Prosecution of violation pursuant to civil penalty; summons and complaint. 
a.  If the city elects to prosecute a violation by an action to recover a civil penalty, the city authorizes the issuance of a summons and complaint pursuant to the civil practice laws and rules for any violation referred to in subsection (1) of this section. 
b.  If the person alleged to have violated any of the provisions of this article set forth in subsection (1) of this section denies any or all parts of the violation as charged in the summons, he shall serve an answer within ten days from the service of such summons upon the defendant. The answer shall be mailed to the office specified on the summons. Service of the answer may be made by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
c.  If a person against whom a violation has been claimed admits to such violation, such person shall be subject to a civil penalty. The person may complete the appropriate form authorized by the municipal regulations and forward such form and summons to the office specified on such summons: 
1.  With a check or money order in the amount of $25.00; 
2.  When the person was found to have committed any violation of this article referred to in subsection (1) of this section within the preceding five years, such check or money order shall be in the amount of $50.00; 
3.  Where the person was found to have previously committed two or more such violations of this article referred to in subsection (a) of this section within the preceding five years, the amount of the check or money order shall be in the amount of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 11, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-100. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the city, by providing for the licensing and identification of exotic animals, the control and protection of the exotic animal population and the protection of persons, property and domestic animals from exotic animal attacks and damage. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 2, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-101. - Licensing of exotic animals. 
(a)  Any person owning, possessing, or harboring an exotic animal within the city shall possess a valid license pursuant to this section. 
(b)  Within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the owner of any exotic animal harbored within the city, shall make an application for an exotic animal license to the city clerk. After the expiration of said 30 days, the owner of any exotic animal shall be subject to the licensing provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  A license shall be renewed after a period of one year beginning with the first day of the month following the date of issuance and shall be renewable annually thereafter prior to the expiration date. 
(d)  Application for an exotic animal license shall be made to the city clerk on a form provided by the city clerk. In the case of a seized exotic animal being redeemed from the city animal shelter, the shelter manager or animal control officer in charge of the animal shelter is authorized to accept such applications. 
(e)  The application shall state the sex, actual or approximate age, breed, color, and official identification number of the exotic animal and any identification marks, if any, and the name, address, and telephone number of the owner or owners. 
(f)  The application shall be accompanied by the license fee prescribed by section 6-102. 
(g)  Subsequent to the application, a photograph of the exotic animal shall be taken by an animal control officer for the city at the residence of the owner, or at the city animal shelter. A copy of said photograph shall be retained by the city along with a copy of the exotic animal license application. 
(h)  Upon validation by the city clerk or shelter manager or animal control officer, the application shall become a license for the exotic animal described therein. Once an application has been validated, no refund shall be made. 
(i)  The city clerk or shelter manager or animal control officer shall provide a copy of the license to the owner and retain a copy for use by the clerk and animal control officers and/or shelter manager. 
(j)  No license shall be transferable. Upon the transfer of ownership of any exotic animal, the new owner, if a city resident, shall immediately make an application for a license for such exotic animal. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 4, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-102. - License fees. 
(a)  The annual fee for each exotic animal license issued pursuant to this article shall be $25.00 for each exotic animal. 
(b)  On or before the fifth day of each month, the city clerk and shelter manager shall remit to the city chamberlain, all license fees collected for the preceding month. The remittance will be accompanied by a report of licenses issued during said month. 
(c)  All fees collected shall remain the property of the city and shall be used exclusively for the controlling of exotic animals and enforcing this article, including public education programs in responsible exotic animal ownership. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 5, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-103. - Identification of exotic animals. 
(a)  Each exotic animal licensed pursuant to this article shall be assigned, at the time the exotic animal is first licensed, a permanent official identification number. 
(b)  The official identification number shall constitute the official identification of the exotic animal to which it is assigned, regardless of changes in ownership, and the number shall not be reassigned to any other exotic animal during the lifetime of the exotic animal to which it was assigned. 
(c)  At the time the exotic animal is first licensed, a photograph of the animal shall be taken by an animal control officer for the city. A copy of said photograph shall be retained by the city along with a copy of the exotic animal license and official identification number. 
(d)  At the owner's option and expense, any exotic animal may be microchipped by a veterinarian or shelter worker. 
(e)  Animal control officers of the city shall be empowered to enforce this article and any rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. In lieu of the city animal control officer, the city may contract for exotic animal control services with any other municipality or with any incorporated Humane Society or similar incorporated animal protective organization or shall appoint, jointly with one or more other municipalities, animal control officers having jurisdiction in each of the cooperating municipalities. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 6, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-104. - Prohibitions. 
    No person who owns, possesses or harbors an exotic animal shall permit or allow such exotic animal to be unconfined or run at large in any place in the city unless such exotic animal is confined as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 7, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-105. - Public events. 
    No person shall possess or display an exotic animal in public streets, public rights-of-way, public parks or on any other municipal property unless said animal is safely restrained and poses no danger to any person. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 8, 10-4-2004; Ord. No. 2008-411, § 1, 12-8-2008) 
Sec. 6-106. - Seizure/destruction of unconfined exotic animals; fees. 
(a)  Any city animal control officer or any peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or police officer in the employ of or under contract with the city, shall immediately seize or destroy any exotic animal which is unconfined or at large within the city in violation of this article, as well as any exotic animal otherwise violating any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any exotic animal that poses an immediate danger to the public or any city animal control officer, peace officer acting pursuant to his special duties, or police officer in the employ of or under contract with the city, shall be immediately destroyed. 
(c)  Each exotic animal seized, whether or not licensed, shall be held for a period of five days from the day seized, during which period the exotic animal may be redeemed by the owner as provided for herein. 
(d)  The owner may redeem such exotic animal by producing proof that the exotic animal has been licensed and, further provided, that the owner pays the following city impoundment fees, as well as the cost of seizure, plus any veterinarian expenses, transport fees, and the purchase of a license, if applicable: 
(1)  $50.00 for the first impoundment of any exotic animal owned by that person; 
(2)  $100.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $5.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof for the second impoundment within one year of the first impoundment, of any exotic animal owned by that person; 
(3)  $200.00 for the first 24 hours or part thereof, and $5.00 for each additional 24 hours or part thereof for the third and any subsequent impoundments within one year of the first impoundment, of any exotic animal owned by that person; 
(4)  In the event the city transports an exotic animal to a veterinarian because of illness or injury, the owner of said animal shall pay the city the sum of: 
a.  $25.00 if the transport occurred during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
b.  $50.00 if the transport occurred after 4:00 p.m. and prior to 8:00 a.m. 
(e)  If not so redeemed, the owner shall forfeit all title to the seized exotic animal at the end of the five-day redemption period and the exotic animal shall be immediately destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 9, 10-4-2004) 
Sec. 6-107. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Animal control officers appointed by the city shall have the power to issue an appearance ticket pursuant to Criminal Procedure Law § 150.20, to serve a summons and to serve and execute any other order or process in the execution of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any animal control officer or any peace officer, when acting pursuant to his special duties, or police officer may serve any process, including an appearance ticket, a uniform appearance ticket and a uniform appearance ticket and simplified information, related to any proceeding, whether criminal or civil in nature undertaken in accord with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The animal control officer when acting pursuant to his duties or a police officer shall promptly make and maintain a complete record of any seizure and subsequent disposition of any exotic animal. Such record shall include, but is not limited to, a description of the exotic animal, the date and hour of the seizure, the official identification number of such exotic animal, if any, the location where seized, the reason for seizure and the owner's name and address, if known. 
(d)  Disposition of fines. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, all moneys collected as fines or penalties by the court as a result of any prosecution for violations of the provisions of this article or any rules or regulations thereof, and all bail forfeitures by persons charged with such violations shall be the property of the city and shall be paid to the city chamberlain. Such moneys shall be used only for the controlling of exotic animals and enforcing this article, including the subsidizing of spaying or neutering of exotic animals and subsidizing public education in responsible exotic animal ownership. 
(Ord. No. 2004-320, § 10, 10-4-2004) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS AND HOUSING STANDARDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Erection of buildings in city, § 175. 
State Law reference- Power of city to construct and maintain public buildings, etc., General City Law § 20(11); authority to regulate and limit the height, bulk and location of buildings, etc., General City Law § 20(24); authority to regulate and restrict the location of buildings, etc., General City Law § 20(25); authority to adopt a local law or ordinance compelling the repair or removal of any building or structure that endangers the health, safety or welfare of the public, General City Law § 20(35); state building code, Executive Law § 370 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Applicability of state uniform fire prevention and building code. 
    The City Council hereby acknowledges, accepts, administers, and enforces the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code in effect at the time of the administration and enforcement of this Chapter in accordance with the provisions of Executive Law § 381 and the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, now and is hereinafter amended or any newly enacted state code. 
(Code 1973, § 8-1; Res. of 6-18-1956; Ord. No. 88-229, § 1, 4-25-1988; Ord. No. 2010-146, § 1, 4-26-2010; Ord. No. 2010-407, § 1, 12-20-2010; Ord. No. 2016-316, § 1, 10-3-2016) 
State Law reference- Uniform fire prevention and building code act, Executive Law § 370 et seq. 
Sec. 8-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-3. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any violation of this chapter and/or the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code of 2010 or of any regulations promulgated pursuant thereto will be dealt with in accordance with the terms and provisions embodied in division 31 of article II of this chapter, as amended. 
(Code 1973, § 8-3; Ord. No. 88-661, § 1, 12-5-1988; Ord. No. 2010-146, § 1(2), 4-26-2010; Ord. No. 2010-407, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-4. - Exterior surfaces. 
    The owner of a structure shall maintain the exterior surfaces including, but not limited to, doors, door and window frames, cornices, porches, trim, balconies, decks and fences in good condition. If the owner applies, causes or permits to be applied paint to a portion or portions of any exterior surface, the color of which paint differs from the paint color of the exterior surface immediately prior to the application of the recently applied paint, within 60 days immediately following the application of the paint, the owner shall paint or cause to be painted with a finish coat the entire exterior surface to which the recent paint had been applied. 
(Ord. No. 2005-344, § 1, 10-3-2005) 
Secs. 8-5-8-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-18. - Short title; scope of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall constitute and be known as "the Building Code," and may be cited as such, and presumptively provides for all matters concerning, affecting or relating to the construction, equipment, alteration, repair or removal of buildings or any structure whatsoever erected or to be erected in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 8-18; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 1) 
Sec. 8-19. - Application of article. 
    Unless existing buildings or structures are specifically mentioned, the provisions of this article shall apply to all structures presently existing, or hereafter erected or altered. 
(Code 1973, § 8-19; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 1; Ord. of 12-19-1966) 
Sec. 8-20. - Interpretation of article. 
    This article is hereby declared to be remedial, and is to be construed liberally to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 8-20; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 1) 
Sec. 8-21. - Extra hazardous districts. 
    The following are hereby declared to be extra hazardous districts and are set aside for mercantile, manufacturing and industrial purposes. The districts composed of that portion of the city outside the extra hazardous districts and bounded by the fire limits shall be known as residential and the board of fire commissioners shall have the full power to regulate and restrict the location of all trades and industries and the location of buildings designed for such purposes: 
    Beginning at the center of the Chemung River at the point of intersection therewith of the extension of the west line of Dewitt Avenue and running thence in a northerly direction to the south line of East Water Street; thence in a westerly direction along the south line of East Water Street to a point 150 feet west of Madison Avenue; thence in a northerly direction on a line parallel with Madison Avenue to the south line of East Church Street; thence west along the south line of East Church Street to the west line of Lake Street; thence along the west line of Lake Street in a northerly direction to the south line of East Second Street; thence in a westerly direction along the south line of East Second Street to the west line of Baldwin Street; thence in a northerly direction along the west line of Baldwin Street to a point opposite the south line of East Seventh Street; thence in a westerly direction parallel with East Washington Avenue and along the south line of East Seventh Street to the Erie Railroad right-of-way; thence in a southerly direction along the east line of the Erie Railroad right-of-way to the center of the Chemung River; thence following the center of the Chemung River in an easterly direction to the place of beginning. 
    Beginning at the northeast corner of Lake and East Clinton Streets and running thence in a northerly direction along the east side of Lake Street, to the Lackawanna right-of-way; thence in a southeasterly direction along the Lackawanna right-of-way to the west side of Oak Street; thence in a southerly direction along the west side of Oak Street to the north side of East Clinton Street; thence in a westerly direction along the north side of East Clinton Street, to the point of beginning. 
    Beginning at a point of intersection of the centerline of the Chemung River and the Erie Railroad; thence west along the centerline of Chemung River to a point intersecting the centerline of College Avenue extended; thence north along the said extension and the centerline of College Avenue, to a point 150 feet south of the southerly line of West Gray Street; thence east to a point 150 feet west of Main Street; thence north to a point 150 feet west of the junction of Park Place and Main Street, continuing along a line 150 feet west of Park Place to a point 150 feet north of Fourth Street; thence east along a line 150 feet north of Fourth Street to the Erie Railroad; thence south along the Erie Railroad to the point of beginning. 
    Beginning at a point of intersection of the Erie Railroad and the centerline of Woodlawn Avenue; thence west along the centerline of Woodlawn Avenue to the centerline of College Avenue; thence north along the centerline of College Avenue to a point 150 feet north of Westside Avenue; thence east to the Erie Railroad to the point of beginning. 
    Beginning at a point in the center of the Chemung River 150 feet west of South Main Street, and running thence in a southerly direction to a point 150 feet west of the west line of Pennsylvania Avenue at the intersection thereof with said South Main Street, and of Franklin Street; thence in a southeasterly direction along the center of Franklin Street to a point 150 feet east of the east line of South Main Street; thence north along the line 150 feet east of South Main Street, to the center of the Chemung River. 
    Beginning at a point in the center of the Chemung River 150 feet west of the Erie Railroad right-of-way; running thence south on a line 150 feet west of the Erie Railroad right-of-way to the center of West Miller Street; thence east along the center of West Miller Street to the center of Erie Street; thence northwest along the center of Erie Street to the point on Pennsylvania Avenue 150 feet east of the Erie Railroad property; thence north along a line 150 feet east of the Erie Railroad property to the Chemung River. 
    Beginning at a point in the center of the Chemung River on a line projected north from George Street; running thence south through the center of George Street and to the center of Chemung Place to a point 150 feet west of Pennsylvania Avenue; thence east to a point 150 feet west of Pennsylvania Avenue; thence along the line 150 feet west of Pennsylvania Avenue, to the center of Pulford Place; thence east to the center of Pennsylvania Avenue; thence northeast to and along the center of Sly Street to the center of the Chemung River. 
    Beginning at the south line of Stowell Place a point where the same intersects the Erie Railroad right-of-way; running thence in an easterly direction along Stowell Place and thence across the Lehigh Valley right-of-way and across the right-of-way of the DL&W Railroad to the west line of Lackawanna Avenue; thence in a general easterly direction to the northeast corner of Lackawanna Avenue and Stephens Place; thence along the north line of Stephens Place to the west side of Grand Central Avenue; thence north along the west side of Grand Central Avenue to the south line of Maxwell Place; thence west along the south line of Maxwell Place to the west line of Lackawanna Avenue; thence north along the west line of Lackawanna Avenue to the south line of Division Street; thence in a westerly direction along the south line of Division Street to the west line of Baldwin Street; thence in a northerly direction along the west line of Baldwin Street to the intersection of Baldwin Street, and East Thurston Street; thence in a northeasterly direction along the Lackawanna and Lehigh Valley rights-of-way to the north line of Clover Street; thence in an easterly direction along the north line of Clover Street to the west line of Lake Street; thence in a northerly direction along the west line of Lake Street to the Elmira town line; thence following said Elmira town line in a general westerly direction to the east side of Erie right-of-way; thence in a southerly direction along the east side of the Erie Railroad right-of-way to the point of intersection of the north line of the Eldridge Park property, so-called, owned by the city; thence in an easterly direction along said north line of Eldridge Park property to the west side of Grand Central Avenue; thence south to the intersection of the west side of Grand Central Avenue and the west side of Lackawanna right-of-way; thence in a general southerly direction along the west side of the DL&W Railroad right-of-way to the north side of Warren Street; thence in a westerly direction along the north side of Warren Street to the east side of the Erie Railroad right-of-way; thence south along the east side of Erie Railroad right-of-way to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1973, § 8-21; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 2) 
Sec. 8-22. - Fire limits. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire limit, fire limits A, fire limits B and outside the fire limits shall have the same meaning and characteristics as defined in the state uniform fire prevention and building code as may be from time to time amended. 
(b)  Fire limit A. Fire limit A shall be comprised of and follow the exact boundaries of the following zoning districts, as they may be amended from time to time, in the zoning ordinance as set forth in appendix B to this Code: Business B, Industrial A, Industrial B, Industrial P, Planned Residential, HA Hospital and HED Higher Education; provided, however, except for setback requirements applicable to fire limit A, in any industrial zoned district, the building requirements of fire limit A shall not apply to any building occupied or to be occupied by a not for profit fraternal or veterans' corporation or association and used exclusively for the purposes of such corporation or association. 
(c)  Fire limit B. Fire limit B shall be comprised of and follow the exact boundaries of the following zoning districts, as may be from time to time amended in the zoning ordinance as set forth in appendix B to this Code: Business A, Business C, Business D, Business E and Business G. 
(d)  Outside the fire limits. Outside the fire limits shall be comprised of and follow the exact boundaries of all other zoning districts, as may be from time to time amended in the zoning ordinance as set forth in appendix B to this Code, not included in fire limit A or fire limit B in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 8-22; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 2; Ord. No. 98-270, § 1, 6-8-1998; Ord. No. 99-151, § 1, 4-12-1999; Ord. No. 2002-460, § 1, 12-30-2002; Ord. No. 2004-085, § 1, 3-8-2004) 
Sec. 8-23. - Administration of building permits. 
(a)  No wall, structure, building, or parking lot, nor any part thereof, shall be built constructed, erected, moved, razed, altered, added to or enlarged, and no excavation, lot grading, or tree removal for any such wall, structure, building, or parking lot, nor any part thereof, shall be commenced until a building permit for such work has been issued by the superintendent of buildings or his designee, in such a manner as is further provided for herein. 
(1)  No building permit, nor any amendment thereto, shall be issued verbally. 
(2)  In the event adequate plans and statements are presented, the superintendent may, at his discretion, issue written approval for the construction of a specified portion of the work described therein to begin before the approval of the full application and plans. Such preapproval should be in no way construed as committing the fire marshal, superintendent of buildings or the city, to approve the remaining plans and specifications in whole or in part, and the applicant commences work under such preapproval at his own risk with respect to said further approval or disapproval of the full application. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued by the superintendent of buildings or his designee, except where all provisions of this division, the state uniform fire prevention and building code, and all applicable rules, regulations and requirements of the city and the state have been met and complied with, or under specific written order of the zoning board of appeals. 
(c)  No building permit shall be issued, where natural watercourses or drainage areas are to be altered by filling, excavating, tree removal or in any other way, unless the written approval of the director of public works has first been obtained. 
(d)  This chapter shall be administered and enforced including the inspection of buildings, by the superintendent of buildings, any police officer or sworn firefighter and said superintendent, police officer or sworn firefighter may call upon the corporation counsel for assistance when necessary for advice, or to enjoin or prosecute violations hereof. The superintendent of buildings, any police officer or sworn firefighter shall have the power to make inspections of buildings or premises necessary to carry out his duties in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 8-23; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 3; Ord. No. 2000-149, § 1, 4-10-2000) 
Sec. 8-24. - Building permit application; form and processing of; violations and penalties. 
(a)  Form. 
(1)  The owner of the real property upon which any work described in section 8-23(a) is desired to be conducted, shall submit a building permit application, in triplicate, to the superintendent of buildings on a form prescribed by said superintendent. Ordinary repairs of buildings or structures, the cost of which shall not exceed $2,000.00, may be made without notice to the department of buildings, but such ordinary repairs shall not be construed to include repairs which: 
(i)  Materially affect structural features, including, but not limited to, changing or closure of any staircase, or opening in an exterior wall; 
(ii)  Affect fire safety features such as smoke detectors, sprinklers, required fire separations and exits; 
(iii)  Involve the installation, repair, replacement, or extension of electrical systems; and 
(iv)  Involve the installation, replacement, or extension of any heating appliances and associated chimneys and flues or ventless heating appliances. 
(2)  Said building permit application shall, at a minimum, contain the following information to be provided and sworn to by said applicant or his duly authorized representative for such purpose: 
(i)  Address of the property upon which said work is contemplated; 
(ii)  Name and residence address of the owner of said property; 
(iii)  The location of the wall, structure, building, or parking lot which is the subject of the application which shall be accompanied by a plot plan, drawn to scale, showing the size and shape of the lot and buildings together with dimensions and also showing the dimensions of required yards; 
(iv)  A detailed statement of the specifications, including the maximum live load for which each floor is designed (when floor construction is involved); 
(v)  Complete copy (in triplicate) of all plans, drawings, and written specifications of such proposed work; 
(vi)  The maximum number of persons to be accommodated at one time on each floor above the first story; 
(vii)  The proposed use or purpose for which each story is intended; 
(viii)  Name and address of the responsible party or parties to whom notice shall be sent for any violation of this article which may occur during construction or alteration; 
(ix)  Name and address of the architect, contractor, and any other representative duly authorized to perform such work or cause same to be performed; 
(x)  The superintendent of buildings may require such additional information, other than that called for on the application form, as may reasonably be needed for him to determine if the proposed project, the use of the building and the use of the land are in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Processing. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the superintendent to approve or reject any plan filed with him pursuant to the provisions of this section within 30 days from the date of submission of all required documents, plans and detailed drawings. 
(2)  The superintendent shall have the power to revoke the approval of any application when the work being conducted pursuant thereto materially departs from the approved applications, plans and detailed drawings, or in the event any false statement or representation as to a material fact relating to the information provided in or in support of said application has been made. 
(3)  The original copy of the aforesaid application and plans as approved by the superintendent shall be kept on file in the office of the superintendent and shall be open to the public, and a duplicate copy thereof shall be kept at the location which is the subject of the application during the progress of the work and shall be open to inspection of the officials of the department of buildings. 
(4)  Amendments to applications, plans and detailed drawings may be made and the superintendent shall approve them provided the applications, plans and detailed drawings, when so amended, shall be in conformity with the provisions of this article and requirements of the superintendent in relation thereto. 
(5)  All approvals of applications, plans and detailed drawings, and amendments thereto, shall expire by limitation one year from the date of the original approval of the application, plans and detailed drawings. However, such expiration shall not apply to the erection of a new building under approved applications, plans and detailed drawings, when work thereunder has been begun and carried on with reasonable continuity within one year from the original approval thereof. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or who fails to comply with any order or regulation made hereunder, or in contradiction to any approved detailed statement or plans submitted by him and approved under the provisions of this article shall be, upon conviction of a violation, subject to a fine not exceeding $500.00, or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding 15 days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  Undertaking construction of any kind before the issuance of a building permit shall subject the owner of the property which is the subject of the application to a civil penalty of $100.00 and the doubling of all applicable fees. 
(3)  Each calendar month's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense. If the violation persists beyond three calendar months from the date of first written notification of a violation by the superintendent of buildings, each offense is then subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 30 days or both. 
(4)  The proper local authorities of the city, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent or correct such violation or to enjoin the continuation of any violation. 
(Code 1973, § 8-24; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 4; Ord. No. 2000-149, § 2, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 2004-066, § 1, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 8-25. - Fees. 
(a)  All fees for required permits, plan reviews, applicable inspections, and certificates of occupancy for all commercial and residential construction (including new residential construction), repair and remodeling, and construction of accessory structures or additions, shall be paid for at the time of filing applications or requests with the superintendent and said fees shall be calculated as provided for hereunder. 
(b)  Inspections requested outside normal business hours of the department (two-hour minimum) shall be $37.50 per hour. 
(c)  All costs of construction are subject to verification. If accurate and reasonable cost estimates are not provided by the applicant, the superintendent shall establish said costs using current local market information as available. 
(d)  Fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Repair, remodeling or new construction permit fee. 
a.  Notwithstanding subsections (d)(1)b and c of this section, the permit fees due for residential: 
(i)  Fences shall be $15.00; 
(ii)  Swimming pools shall be $30.00; and 
(iii)  Sheds of less than 144 square feet of floor area shall be $15.00. 
Residential sheds of greater than 144 square feet of floor area shall be subject to the permit fees below; 
b.  For repair, remodel or new construction, there shall be a base fee of $30.00 for residential and $55.00 for commercial, plus there shall be the fees set out in subsection (c) of this section for either residential or commercial; 
c.  In addition to the base fees required in subsection (d)(1)b of this section, there shall be a permit fee of $2.00 per $1,000.00 cost of construction and a fee of $0.10 per square foot of construction; 
d.  All projects are subject to plumbing, electrical and other permit fees where appropriate. 
(2)  Certificate of occupancy fee. 
a.  Change of occupancy when no construction is involved is $35.00. 
b.  Temporary certificate for 30 days is $50.00. 
c.  New certificate when construction is involved.
