It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any building or land or part thereof hereafter erected, moved, substantially improved, added to or enlarged in whole or in part until a certificate of occupancy shall have been applied for and issued by the superintendent of buildings. The certificate of occupancy shall state that the buildings or land and proposed use thereof comply with the provisions of this land and other applicable statutes, laws, ordinances and regulations governing the use of occupancy of land and buildings. A certificate of occupancy may be obtained on application from the superintendent of buildings and may be issued only after the completion of the building or the alteration thereof. The superintendent of buildings shall make or cause to have made an inspection of each building or lot for which the certificate of occupancy has been applied before issuing such certificate. Such inspection shall be made within ten days from the date of application for such certificate, Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays excepted. Upon written agreement by the applicant, such a period of time may be extended. Certificates of occupancy shall be considered public record and a record of all certificates shall be maintained by the superintendent of buildings. 
(3)  Flood ordinance review (as required by L.L. No. 1987-2). 
a.  Plan review fee is $60.00, plus engineering review fees, at cost, if required. 
b.  Inspection/certificate of compliance fee is $60.00. 
(4)  Demolition permit. 
a.  Residential. 
1.  Value to $1,000.00, the minimum fee is $25.00. 
2.  Value from $1,001.00 to $5,000.00, the minimum fee is $30.00. 
3.  Value over $5,000.00, per $1,000.00, the minimum fee is an additional $5.00. 
b.  Commercial, including fuel tanks. 
1.  Value to $3,000.00, the minimum fee is $50.00. 
2.  Value from $3,001.00 to $10,000.00, the minimum fee is $60.00. 
3.  Value over $10,000.00 per $1,000.00, the minimum fee is an additional $5.00. 
(5)  Letter of compliance (residential only). 
a.  The fee for a one- and two-family is $30.00. 
b.  The fee for a three-family or more is $60.00. 
(6)  Sign permit fee. 
a.  Nonilluminated is $25.00, plus $1.00 per square feet in excess of 20 square feet. 
b.  Illuminated is $35.00, plus $1.00 per square feet in excess of 20 square feet. 
c.  Billboard is $50.00. 
(7)  Tanks. The permit fee for the installation of oil burners, storage tanks, sprinkler systems, standpipe or refrigeration systems shall be the same as for construction work as set forth herein. 
(Code 1973, § 8-25; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 5; Ord. of 10-5-1925; Ord. of 5-17-1943; Ord. of 7-5-1966; Ord. of 2-26-1968, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 88-42, § 1, 1-19-1988; Ord. No. 88-462, § 1, 8-15-1988; Ord. No. 2000-149, § 3, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 2007-78, § 1, 2-5-2007; Ord. No. 2008-271, § 1, 8-4-2008) 
Sec. 8-26. - Demolition or removal of buildings or structures. 
(a)  Before the demolition or removal of any building or structure is begun, a verified application shall be prepared by the owner, architect, builder or contractor, on appropriate blanks furnished by the superintendent of building construction containing a statement of the facts in relation thereto, and as to the location and ownership thereof. The application shall be filed with the superintendent of building construction, and a written permit obtained from him. Such permit shall expire by limitation two months from date of its issue. The superintendent of building construction shall be given not less than 24 hours' notice before the demolition of any building or structure is begun. 
(b)  Before any permit is issued for the demolition of a principal structure, as that term is defined in the city's zoning ordinance, set forth in appendix B to this Code, now and as hereinafter amended, the person or entity undertaking the demolition work shall send notice of the proposed demolition to all property owners within 200 feet from the boundaries of the lot or lots on which the demolition will occur and to a newspaper of general circulation within the city for publication once. Such notice shall be by first class mail and it shall state the applicant's name and address, the nature of the proposed demolition, the location of the property on which the demolition will occur, and the proposed date and time of the demolition. Such notices shall be mailed at least 16 calendar days prior to the date of commencement of the demolition. Publication shall occur at least 14 days prior to the proposed demolition date. The person or entity seeking a demolition permit must file with the superintendent of building construction proof of said mailing and publication on a form provided by the city in order to receive a demolition permit. In the case of an emergency as determined by the superintendent of building construction, the city manager can waive any or all notice requirements set forth herein. Failure to provide proper notification will constitute a violation of this article and subject the applicant to penalties or fines. 
(c)  Before any permit is issued granting authority to wreck a building or structure for which such permit is required, the person engaged in the work of wrecking the same shall file, when required, with the superintendent of building construction, a bond or public liability insurance containing personal injury and property damage provisions, which bond or insurance policy shall be approved by the corporation counsel, to indemnify, keep and save harmless the city against any loss, cost, damage, expense, judgment or liability of any kind whatsoever which may accrue against, be charged to or recovered from the city, or any of its officials from or by any reason or on account of accidents to persons or property during any such wrecking operations, and from or by reasons or on account of anything done under or by virtue of any permit granted for any such wrecking operations. 
(d)  Such bond or public liability insurance shall be in amounts to be determined by the superintendent of building construction, who may require additional sums as protection for the city, as may be necessary from time to time thereafter. 
(e)  Prior to demolishing any building, extermination measures will be taken to ensure extermination of rodents and insects within that building so as to prevent the spread of such pests to adjacent properties. After extermination measures have been taken, the superintendent of buildings shall cause an inspection to be made to assure adequacy of measures taken prior to commencement of actual demolition work. 
(f)  In demolishing any building or structure or part thereof, story after story shall be completely removed. No material shall be placed upon a floor of any building in the course of demolition; the bricks, timbers and other parts of each story shall be lowered to the ground immediately upon displacement. The material to be removed shall be properly wet to lay the dust incident to its removal. The person engaged in the demolition shall have the duty of keeping public rights-of-way reasonably free from dirt, mud and other debris so as not to cause a hazardous condition. In demolishing any building, debris shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the superintendent of building construction. Foundation walls, if any, shall be broken down to at least one foot below grade. Basements and/or cellars shall be cleaned of all debris and filled with run-of-bank gravel to at least six inches above grade. Where a communal wall shall be left exposed by the person demolishing the building or any part of a structure, the communal wall shall be left safe, sided or covered with an appropriate material to match the exterior finish of the portion of the building left standing. 
(g)  When any building or structure over 40 feet in height is demolished, a shed covering shall be provided as required by section 8-252. 
(h)  Furthermore, before any permit is issued as aforesaid, the superintendent of building construction shall determine the reasonable time required for the demolition or removal of the building or structure involved, and the permit shall be issued on the condition that demolition or removal is completed within the time limitation specified and the contractor shall be required to provide security in the form of a surety bond or certified check to insure compliance with the time limitation as set by the superintendent of building construction in amounts to be determined by the superintendent of building construction and in a form to be approved by the corporation counsel. In addition, before any permit is issued as aforesaid, the superintendent of building construction shall determine that the person demolishing the building has disconnected utility and sewer connections and proof of said disconnects shall be submitted to the superintendent of building construction. 
(i)  In addition to the penalty provided in section 1-14, the person, corporation, partnership or limited liability company who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a civil penalty of $1,500.00. 
(Code 1973, § 8-26; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 6; Ord. of 4-16-1962; Ord. of 8-28-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 79-307, § 1, 6-18-1979; Ord. No. 98-518, § 1, 12-21-1998; Ord. No. 99-103, §§ 1, 2, 3-15-1999; Ord. No. 99-216, § 2, 5-24-1999; Ord. No. 2009-271, § 1, 6-22-2008; Ord. No. 2009-422, §§ 1, 2, 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 8-27. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-28. - Certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  Upon the completion of such building, structure or alteration, provided no violations of this article exists, the superintendent shall issue to the owner a certificate of occupancy of the proposed building or part thereof, stating the purposes for which the building or structure may be used; also the maximum live load, and maximum number of persons that may be accommodated on each floor thereof. 
(b)  The superintendent shall upon application issue a temporary certificate of occupancy allowing the use of a portion of any building, provided no violation of this article exists against that portion and provided such temporary use of such portion would not endanger life or property. 
(c)  No building, structure or part thereof shall be altered or converted in a manner to affect its occupancy, or used for any purposes whatsoever until the issuance of a certificate of occupancy; nor shall any building, structure or part thereof be occupied or used for any other purpose, or in any manner other than that prescribed in such certificate of occupancy; nor shall any building or structure or part thereof be burdened by any greater load, or be occupied by a greater number of persons than designated in such certificate. 
(d)  The owner of every building of classes B, E and F, shall post in a conspicuous place in each story, one or more signs giving maximum number of persons, purposes of use, and maximum live load for which certificate has been issued for that particular story. 
(Code 1973, § 8-28; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 8) 
Sec. 8-29. - Change of occupancy. 
(a)  No change in the manner of occupancy shall be made in any story of any building or structure, or portion thereof, tending to increase the floor loads or the number of persons to be accommodated therein until there shall have been issued by the superintendent a certificate of occupancy covering such new use or manner of occupancy; nor the purpose for which any building or structure or portion thereof is used be changed, except in conformity with the requirements of this article, as to exits and floor loads. 
(b)  The superintendent shall cause any building or story therein to be vacated whose occupancy has been changed, or floor loads increased in violation of subsection (a) of this section, and it shall not be occupied until made to conform with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 8-29; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 9) 
Sec. 8-30. - Vacant building registry. 
(a)  Legislative findings and purpose. It is the finding of the city council that buildings which remain vacant and not maintained are unsightly, unsafe and have a negative impact on their surroundings by contributing to the decline of neighborhoods and business development within the city. Many buildings, once boarded, remain so for many years. The purpose of this section is to establish a program for identifying and registering vacant buildings; to establish the responsibilities of owners of vacant buildings and structures; and to expedite the rehabilitation of vacant properties. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this section, have the meanings indicated: 
    City. The City of Elmira, New York. 
    Code. The Code of Ordinances of the City of Elmira, New York. 
    Enforcement officer. Any duly authorized city employee of the code enforcement office (hereinafter "enforcement officer"). 
    Owner. The person, persons, or entity shown to be the owner or owners according to the records of the city's assessor's office, those identified as the owner or owners on a vacant building registration form, a mortgagee in possession, a mortgagor in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, administrator, trustee, lessee, other person, firm, corporation or entity in control of the premises. A municipal entity and a not for profit corporation formed pursuant to section 1411 of the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law shall not be considered an owner for purpose of this section. Any such person shall have joint and several obligations for compliance with the provisions of this section. 
    Secured by other than normal means. A building secured by means other than those used in the design and approved plans for the building. 
    Unoccupied. A building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, including buildings ordered vacated by an enforcement officer. In determining whether a building is unoccupied, the enforcement officer may consider these factors, among others: (i) whether lawful residential or business activity has ceased; (ii) the percentage of the overall square footage of the occupied to unoccupied space or the overall number of occupied and unoccupied units; (iii) whether the building is substantially devoid of contents or the minimal value of fixtures or personal property in the building; (iv) whether the building lacks utility services; (v) whether the building is subject to a foreclosure action; (vi) whether the lawful occupants are residing temporarily elsewhere; (vii) the duration of vacancy; and (viii) the presence or reoccurrence of Code violations. 
    Unsecured. A building or portion of a building which is open to entry by unauthorized persons without the use of tools, the opening(s) to said building being less than 40 feet above ground level. 
    Vacant building. A building, a portion of a building, or a structure which is any one or more of the below: 
(a)  Unoccupied and unsecured as determined by an enforcement officer; 
(b)  Unoccupied and an unsafe building as determined by an enforcement officer; 
(c)  Unoccupied and enforcement officer has issued an order to correct code violations; 
(d)  Illegally occupied; or 
(e)  Unoccupied for a period of time exceeding 90 consecutive days, except buildings listed or offered for sale and residential buildings whose lawful occupants are residing temporarily elsewhere but not for more than five consecutive months. 
(c)  Vacant building registration and fees. 
(1)  The owner of a vacant building shall register with the code enforcement office no later than 30 days after any building becomes a "vacant building", as defined above, or no later than 30 days after being notified by an enforcement officer of the requirement to register. An enforcement officer may identify vacant buildings through his/her routine inspection process as well as through notification by residents, neighborhood associations and other community groups that a building may be eligible for inclusion on the registry. A notice to register will be served upon, or sent by first class mail to, the owner, and any registered property manager, and to the property address. Notice will be deemed received by the owner and property manager, as the case may be, upon personal delivery or five days after service by first class mail. The city shall post a notice to register at the property and the city may post notices on the city's website to provide additional notice to the public. However, the city's failure to post such notices on the city's website shall not constitute a defense to any enforcement proceeding or collection of fines. 
(2)  The registration shall be submitted on forms provided by the enforcement office, shall include the following information and shall be notarized: 
a.  A description of the premises, including the street address, approximate age and square footage of the building, number of stories, and the most recent use of the building. 
b.  (i)  Name, principal residence address, principal business address, telephone number and email address of each owner. 
(ii)  If the owner is an association, partnership, limited liability partnership, joint tenancy, tenancy in common, tenancy by the entirety or other entity, the name of each and every owner, partner or general partner and addresses. 
(iii)  If the owner is a corporation or a limited liability company, the principal place of business of the corporation or company must be provided and the name, title and residence address of all officers, directors, managing or general agents must be included. 
c.  The street number of the building. 
d.  If applicable, the name of the owner's designated agent with the agent's principal residence address, principal business address, telephone number and email address. 
e.  If said owner's principal place of business is not located within Chemung County, or is located within Chemung County but none of the business's officers or directors or members reside in said county, or the owner's principal place of residence is not located in said county, the owner must designate on the registry form a natural person 18 years of age or older who resides in Chemung County as owner's agent whom the owner authorizes to make decisions regarding the management and maintenance of the building and upon whom service of legal process and all notices may be served or delivered. The owner's designation of an agent shall authorize and empower the agent to make such decisions on behalf of the owner. 
f.  It shall be the responsibility of the owner to properly register any change of address, agent or any other registration information which occurs after the filing of the registry within 60 days of the date of change. 
g.  The owner shall specify the address to which all notices, violations and invoices are to be delivered. 
h.  The names and addresses of all known lien holders. Each address must include a street address. 
i.  For purposes of this subsection (c)(2), a post office box shall not be accepted as the owner's or agent's address. 
j.  A vacant building plan as described in subsection (3) below. 
(3)  The owner shall submit a vacant building plan which must meet the approval of the code enforcement office. The plan, at a minimum, must contain information from one of the following three proposals for the building: 
a.  If the building is to be demolished, a demolition plan indicating the proposed time frame for demolition, which demolition must be completed no later than six months from the date of the submission of the plan. 
b.  If the building is to remain vacant, a plan for the securing of the building in accordance with standards provided in section 8-30(d) below, together with the procedure that will be used to maintain the property and a statement of the reason(s) why the building will be left vacant; or 
c.  If the building is to be returned to a permitted occupancy or use, rehabilitation plans, if required, for the building. The time period to complete the rehabilitation plans shall not exceed 365 days from the date of submission and the plan shall include progress benchmarks at four-month intervals, unless the code enforcement office grants an extension for good cause shown, upon receipt of a written statement from the owner submitted prior to the expiration of the time period detailing the reasons for the extension. Any repairs, improvements or alterations to the property must comply with any applicable zoning, historic preservation and building codes. The building must be secured in accordance with section 8-30(d) below during the rehabilitation period. 
(4)  The owner shall comply with all applicable laws and codes. The owner shall notify the code enforcement office of any changes in information supplied as part of the vacant building registration within 60 days of the change. If the plan or timetable for the vacant building is revised in any way, the revisions must be in writing and must be approved by the code enforcement office. 
(5)  The owner and any subsequent owner shall keep the building secured and safe and the building and grounds properly maintained as provided in section 8-30(d) below. 
(6)  Failure of the owner or any subsequent owner to maintain the building and premises as required herein shall be grounds for the city (i) to remediate the building and bill the costs of same to the owner as provided in section 8-277 of this chapter, or (ii) revoke the rehabilitation plans, or both, and the owner shall be subject to fees and penalties as provided herein. 
(7)  The owner shall notify the code enforcement office of any transfer of ownership within 60 days of the date of transfer. The new owner shall comply with the approved plan and timetable submitted by the previous owner until any proposed changes are submitted and approved by the code enforcement office. 
(8)  Vacant building registration fees. 
a.  The owner shall pay no registration fee if the owner registers the building no later than 30 days after the building becomes a "vacant building", as defined above, or no later than 30 days after being notified by an enforcement officer of the requirement to register. If the owner fails to timely register the building, the owner shall pay at the time of registration a fee of $50.00. 
b.  If the building remains continuously vacant pursuant to section 8-30(c)(3)b. above for one year or more from the date of registry, the owner shall pay to the city on each annual anniversary date the following annual vacant building fee until the building is demolished or rehabilitated: First anniversary date, $500.00; each anniversary date thereafter, the fee for the immediately preceding year plus $100.00; but in no event shall the annual fee exceed $1,000.00. 
c.  If the building is to be returned to a permitted use pursuant to section 8-30(c)(3)c. above and if the rehabilitation plan has not been completed by the deadline stated in the rehabilitation plan or the extension date granted by the enforcement officer, unless the delay was due to an event outside the control of the owner, the owner shall pay to the city on the deadline date the following vacant building fee until the building rehabilitation is completed: $500.00 on the first deadline date; on each annual anniversary date of the initial deadline date, the fee for the immediately preceding year plus $100.00, but in no event shall the annual fee exceed $1,000.00. 
d.  If the owner of a vacant building fails to register and pay the fees in a timely manner, then the owner shall be subject to the penalty set forth in section 8-30(i) below. 
e.  All delinquent fees shall be paid by the owner prior to any transfer of an ownership interest in any vacant building. The owner shall give a purchaser or grantee written notice that the building being transferred is a vacant building under this section. If the fees are not paid prior to transfer, the new owner shall pay the annual fee no later than 30 days after the date of transfer and subsequent annual fees shall be due on the new anniversary date. 
f.  The vacant building registration fees and annual vacant building fees as set forth in section 8-30(c)(8)a., b. and c. above are to be delivered, by mail or in person, to the Chamberlain's Office, City Hall, 317 East Church Street, Elmira, New York 14901. A late charge of one and one half percent per month shall be assessed on any invoice which is unpaid after 30 days from the date of the demand for payment or an invoice. A replacement payment for a check returned due to insufficient funds shall be made in cash, money order, or by bank or certified check. Delinquent, unpaid registration and annual vacant building fees shall be a lien on the real property on which the building is situated and shall be added as a separate line item on the property owner's real property tax bill. 
g.  If a building permit, other than one to solely replace or repair a roof, is issued for the vacant building to be restored to a permitted use, the annual vacant fee coming due, pursuant to section 8-30(c)(8)c. above, after the date of the issuance of the building permit shall be waived if the restoration of the building is completed in accordance with the provisions of section 8-30(c)(3)c. above. If the owner fails to comply with said provisions, the owner shall pay the annual vacant fee which would have been due pursuant to section 8-30(c)(8)c. had it not been initially waived. In no event shall more than two years of the annual vacant fee be waived. The amount of the annual vacant fee coming due after the waiver of one or two annual vacant fees shall be in accordance with section 8-30(c)(8)c. calculated as though there had been no prior waiver of the annual vacant fee. No building permit shall be issued unless all unpaid delinquent registration fee and annual vacant fees have been paid in full. 
(9)  The code enforcement office shall include in the file any written statements from community organizations, other interested parties or citizens regarding the history, problems, status or blighting influence of a vacant building. 
(d)  Maintenance. 
(1)  The owner of a vacant building shall take such steps and perform such acts as may be required to ensure that the building and its grounds remain safe and secure and do not present a hazard to the adjoining property or the public. Owners shall be responsible for maintaining their buildings and structures so that they do not become an unoccupied hazard. In any building or floor area that is vacant or about to become vacant, there will be at least one access which meets the approval of the enforcement officer. 
(2)  The owner shall protect and maintain the exterior of the building as follows: 
a.  Exterior walls, including foundations, shall be maintained so that water does not penetrate into basements, cellars, or other interior areas. All exterior walls and foundations must be free of holes and crevices. 
b.  Exterior doors, windows, skylights and similar openings shall be maintained weather tight. 
c.  Exterior stairs, porches, entrance platforms, fire escapes and railings thereon shall be maintained in a safe and sound condition. 
d.  Roofs shall be maintained in a weather tight condition. 
e.  Exterior surfaces shall be maintained in good condition. Surfaces not inherently resistant to deterioration shall be treated with a protective coating of paint or other suitable preservative. 
f.  Glass coverings for windows and doors shall not consist of any substance sprayed onto the glass doors or windows. All enclosures shall be properly fitted and be of such material and surface that they are neither unsightly nor materially detract from the general appearance of the building or the neighborhood and, when possible, are secured by normal means. 
g.  The covering for broken doors and cracked or broken windows shall consist of replacement glass, plexiglass, plywood or similar materials finished and maintained in accordance with the provision of section 8-279(g) of this Code. 
h.  Windows that are not cracked or broken may be covered with interior blinds, curtains, or shades. 
i.  The premises shall be kept free of insects and vermin. 
j.  Any excavations, swimming pools, or other conditions creating an attractive nuisance must be filled in or properly enclosed. 
(3)  In addition to the standards prescribed above, vacant commercial and retail buildings shall comply with the following standards: 
a.  Any and all first floor windows shall be replaced by glass or plexiglass, which coverings shall be maintained. 
b.  All exterior signs, awnings, lighting systems and supporting framework, if not removed, shall be maintained in a non-deteriorated and safe condition. 
(4)  The owner shall protect and maintain the interior of the building as follows: 
a.  Structural members shall be maintained to resist and prevent deterioration. 
b.  Unheated attics, spaces below flat roofs, and crawl spaces shall be ventilated to minimize deterioration. 
c.  Ceilings, walls, floors and stairways shall be maintained in a safe and sound condition. 
(5)  The owner shall maintain the premises as follows: 
a.  The owner shall not permit garbage and refuse to accumulate. 
b.  Buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insects, vermin and rodent harborage and infestation. 
c.  Chimneys, smokestacks, flues, gas vents, smoke pipes and connectors shall be maintained structurally safe and smoke tight. 
d.  If the building is to be demolished, then, within ten days of registering the building as a vacant building, all fuel gas, water, and utilities must be disconnected at the mains and water pipes drained. If the building is going to be rehabilitated, then the building must be heated or winterized to avoid freezing pipes; fuel gas pipe systems must be maintained gastight, safe and operative condition, and water pipes must be maintained to avoid leaks and/or breakage. 
e.  Fuel tanks will be maintained so as not to be a hazard or shall be discontinued in a manner consistent with New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code. 
f.  The domestic water supply system of the building will be connected to an approved source, will not be subject to contamination and will not be connected to unsafe water supplies; alternatively, the system shall be disconnected at the main and completely drained. 
g.  Stormwater drainage systems shall be maintained so as to function properly and shall be kept free from obstructions, leaks and defects. Sewage systems shall be similarly maintained or shall be sealed so as to prevent accumulation of sewage gases in buildings. 
h.  Electrical fixtures, devices, wiring and systems shall be maintained in safe working condition in a manner which shall avoid a potential source of ignition or shock; alternatively, the service shall be discontinued at the supply. 
i.  Elevators, dumbwaiters and escalators shall be maintained or taken out of service, in accordance with ANSI A17.1. 
j.  The owner shall provide for snow and ice removal on the premises and on adjoining sidewalks and shall comply with chapter 14, article VI of the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(6)  Whenever the owner of a vacant building fails to comply with a notice from an enforcement officer to take steps and perform acts as are required of the owner to ensure that a building and the premises remain safe and secure and do not present a hazard to adjoining property, the city may enter onto the building and the property and take steps and perform acts to render the building and the premises safe, secure and free from hazards to adjoining property and the public. These acts may include but not be limited to removal of dangerous conditions, properly replacing or boarding up windows and doors, shutting off utilities, capping plumbing to prevent leakage of water or sewer gas, or removing flammable or otherwise hazardous material and debris. The owner shall be personally liable to the city for all expenses incurred by the city in rendering the building and premises safe and secure. In addition, the city's expenses shall be a lien on the real property on which the building is situated and shall be added as a separate line item on the property owner's real property tax bill. This liability shall be in addition to any fines or penalties imposed pursuant to section 8-30(i) below. 
(e)  Demolition surety. 
(1)  If the vacant building plan submitted pursuant to section 8-30(c)(3)a. above provides for the building to be demolished, the owner shall deposit or deliver to the city a surety in an amount sufficient to cover the costs of demolishing the building. 
(2)  If the vacant building plan submitted pursuant to section 8-30(c)(3)b. and c. above provides for the building to remain vacant or for the building to be returned to a permitted occupancy and use, and the owner fails to secure and maintain the building in accordance with the standards set forth in section 8-30(d) above and the violation or violations of such standards has continued for more than one year or the owner fails to return the building to occupancy and use within the time period provided in the rehabilitation plan and any extension thereof, then the city may require the owner to deposit or deliver to the city chamberlain a surety in an amount sufficient to cover the costs of demolition. If, after expiration of 18 months from the date of submission of the vacant building plan, there are outstanding violations of the standards set forth in section 8-30(d) above or the building rehabilitation plan has not been substantially completed, the city may issue an order directing the owner to demolish the structure. In the event such an order is issued, the owner shall be entitled to a hearing held in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 8-275(f) of this chapter. 
(3)  The surety required herein shall be in one of the following forms, subject to the review and approval of the corporation counsel: 
a.  Cash; 
b.  Irrevocable letter of credit; or 
c.  Insurance bond. 
The surety shall be released or returned to the owner only upon the correction of all outstanding violations of section 8-30(d) above or upon substantial completion of the rehabilitation plan. 
(4)  In the event the owner refuses, fails or neglects to comply with the demolition order issued under subsection (2) above, the city may enter upon such property and demolish or cause to be demolished the vacant building. The city first shall recover the city's cost for demolition by executing upon any demolition surety posted pursuant to this section. The owner shall be personally liable for all demolition costs incurred by the city in excess of the surety bond amount in accordance with section 8-277 of this chapter. Any costs incurred by the city shall be a lien on the real property on which the building is situated and said costs shall be added as a separate line item on the property owner's real property tax bill. 
(f)  Exemptions. A building which has suffered fire damage or damage caused by extreme weather conditions shall be exempt from the registration requirement for a period of 90 days after the date of the fire or extreme weather event if the property owner submits a request for exemption in writing to the code enforcement office. This request will include the following information supplied by the owner: 
(1)  A description of the premises, including the street address, approximate age and square footage of the building, number of stories, and the most recent use of the building. 
(2)  The reason for an exemption. 
(3)  The names, principal residence address, principal business address, telephone number and email address of each owner. If the owner is an association, partnership, limited liability partnership, joint tenancy, tenancy in common, tenancy by the entirety or other entity, the name of each and every owner, partner or general partner and addresses. If the owner is a corporation or a limited liability company, the principal place of business of the corporation or company must be provided and the name, title and principal residence address of all officers, directors, managing members must be included. A post office box is not acceptable. 
(4)  A statement of intent to repair and reoccupy the building in an expedient manner, or the intent to demolish the building. 
(g)  Inspections. By registering a vacant building, an owner consents to an enforcement officer inspecting the premises for the purpose of enforcing and assuring compliance with the provisions of this section. Upon the request of the enforcement officer, an owner will provide access to all interior portions of a vacant building in order to permit a complete inspection. Nothing contained herein, however, shall diminish the owner's right to insist upon the procurement of an administrative search warrant from a court of competent jurisdiction by the enforcement officer or his or her designee in order to enable such inspection, and the enforcement officer shall be required to obtain an administrative search warrant whenever an owner refuses to permit a warrantless inspection of the premises after having been advised of his or her constitutional right to refuse entry without same. In the case of an emergency, this paragraph shall not apply. 
(h)  Annual reports. Annually, the code enforcement office shall send to the city council a list of all buildings in the city declared vacant under the provisions of this section, as well as a list of all previously declared vacant buildings which are no longer subject to the provisions of this section. This information may be published on the city's website. 
(i)  Penalties for offenses. 
(1)  In addition to the penalties provided by section 1-14 of this Code of Ordinances, a person violating any provision of this section 8-30 or providing false information to the enforcement officer will be subject to the following fines: (i) such person shall be subject to a fine of not less than $250.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or imprisonment not exceeding six months, or both such fine and imprisonment; or (ii) such person shall be subject to a civil penalty of $500.00 per day for each day the person is in violation of any provision of this section. 
(2)  The term "person" as used in this subsection shall include the owner, occupant, mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, administrator, trustee, lessee, agent or any other person, firm, corporation or other entity directly or indirectly in control of the building or part thereof. 
(3)  Each day a violation exists shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. 
(j)  Separability. The provisions of this section shall not infringe, impair or diminish in any way the right of the city to declare a building unsafe and to demolish it pursuant to section 8-275 of the City's Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-43, § 1, 1-28-2013, eff. 2-15-2013; Ord. No. 2018-180, § 1, 7-23-2018) 
Secs. 8-31-8-37. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATIONS AND FOUNDATIONS 

Sec. 8-38. - Excavations. 
(a)  The person causing any excavation to be made for a building shall properly guard and protect the same at his own expense. 
(b)  Whenever an excavation for buildings or other purposes shall be carried below the curb, the person causing the excavation shall at all times, if accorded the necessary license to enter upon the adjoining property, and not otherwise, at his own expense, preserve any adjoining or contiguous wall, structure, yard or bank of earth or rock from injury in any approved manner so that the wall, structure, yard or bank of earth or rock shall be practically as safe as before such excavation was commenced. For this purpose such approved foundations or retaining walls may be built upon the property upon which the wall, structure, yard or bank of earth or rock is situated. If the necessary license is not accorded to the person making such excavation, then it shall be the duty of the owner refusing to grant such license at his own expense to make the adjoining or contiguous wall, structure, yard or bank of earth or rock safe, and support the same in an approved manner so that the adjoining excavations may be made, and shall be permitted to enter upon the premises where such excavation is being made for that purpose when necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 8-38; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 13) 
Sec. 8-39. - Foundations adjoining party walls. 
(a)  In case a party wall is intended to be used by the person causing an excavation to be made and the footings and foundations of such wall are in good condition and sufficient for the uses of both the existing and the new building, then the person causing the excavation to be made, shall, at his own expense, preserve such party wall so that such party wall shall be as safe as before the excavation was begun. 
(b)  In case the footings and foundations of such party wall are not in good condition, or not sufficient for the uses of both the existing building and the new one, it shall be the duty of the person causing such excavation to be made to properly replace such footings or foundations in an approved manner. 
(c)  In case any excavation or the removal of any existing building, shows any adjoining wall or structure unsafe at the time the excavation was begun, it shall be the duty of the person causing the excavation to be made, or the building to be removed, to forthwith report the fact in writing, to the superintendent, who shall cause an inspection of such premises to be made, and if aforesaid wall or structure is found unsafe, the superintendent shall declare such wall or structure unsafe and cause the same to be repaired as herein provided. 
(d)  If the person whose duty it shall be to preserve or protect from injury any wall or structure shall neglect or fail to do so within 24 hours after receipt of a notice from the superintendent, then the superintendent may enter upon the premises and employ such labor, and furnish such materials and take such steps as, in his judgment, may be necessary to make the premises safe and secure at the cost of the person whose duty it is to keep the same safe and secure. 
(Code 1973, § 8-39; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 14) 
Sec. 8-40. - Bearing capacity of soil. 
(a)  When doubt arises as to the safe sustaining power of the soil upon which a building is to be erected, the superintendent may order tests or borings by and at the owner's expense and as approved. 
(b)  The safe bearing capacity of different soils in the absence of tests shall not exceed the values given in the following enumeration: 
(1)  Soft clay, one ton per square foot. 
(2)  Firm clay, fine sand or layers of sand and clay wet, two tons per square foot. 
(3)  Clay or fine sand, firm and dry, three tons per square foot. 
(4)  Hard clay, coarse sand gravel, four tons per square foot. 
(5)  Hard pan, eight to 15 tons per square foot. 
(6)  Rock, 15 to 72 tons per square foot. 
(Code 1973, § 8-40; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 15) 
Secs. 8-41-8-43. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-44. - Regulating drilling and maintenance of oil and gas wells within the city limits. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall drill for oil or gas within the limits of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation desiring a permit to drill for oil or gas within the city shall file with the superintendent of buildings a verified petition containing the name, address and business of the petitioner, the location of the proposed well and the kind and nature of the drilling derrick, machinery, equipment and power proposed to be used, and the kind and size of any building to be erected. The petition shall also describe the method to be followed in the drilling operations and in the disposal of mud and sludge resulting from the drilling operations and in the event that gas or oil is secured, the contemplated method of storing or disposing of the same. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of a permit to drill for oil or gas within the city, the superintendent of buildings shall require the petitioner or the contractor to obtain public liability insurance in form to be approved by the corporation counsel with minimum limits for personal injury of $25,000.00/$100,000.00, and property damage of $25,000.00/$100,000.00. The superintendent of buildings may, in his discretion, require petitioner or his contractor to furnish insurance with limits not to exceed $300,000.00. The superintendent of buildings shall, prior to the issuance of a permit, require that certificates of insurance be filed in his office showing the existence of the public liability policy and also showing workmen's compensation insurance on the employees of the petitioner or of his contractor. This insurance must be maintained throughout the period of drilling and during the use and operation of the well. 
(d)  A fee of $100.00 shall accompany the petition for the permit. 
(e)  No person, firm or corporation receiving a permit to drill an oil or gas well within the city shall drill or operate in any way except during the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., except as the council may hereafter determine in case of the drilling of wells not proximate to inhabited dwellings. 
(f)  Every person, firm or corporation obtaining a permit to drill for gas or oil wells within the city shall comply with all regulations, ordinances and statutes dealing with the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1973, § 8-44; Ord. of 5-17-1943; Ord. of 6-1-1943) 
Secs. 8-45-8-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ILLUMINATION 

Sec. 8-50. - Exterior lighting 
(a)  Excessive or obtrusive lighting. All exterior artificial lighting devices shall be constructed and maintained in such a way so as to avoid direct illumination of adjacent residential properties. 
(1)  For purposes of this section, the term "exterior artificial lighting devices" means any illuminating device, whether powered by electricity, battery or other means, and whether portable or permanently affixed, which is being used, employed or operated for outdoor illumination. Such devices shall include, but not necessarily be limited to the following: search lights, floodlights, yard lights, bug lights, and lights engaged by motion detectors. 
(2)  For the purposes of this section, the term "direct illumination" means illumination which is emanating directly from the exterior artificial lighting device at such an angle that such light proceeds directly to the adjacent property, thereby illuminating it, as opposed to illumination created by light emanating from the exterior artificial lighting device being reflected off the ground or nearby structures or surfaces and thereby traveling to an adjacent property and illuminating it. 
(b)  Exemption. For the purposes of this section, any and all municipal lighting devices including streetlights shall be exempt. 
(Ord. No. 97-210, § 1, 5-12-1997; Ord. No. 2005-13, § 1, 1-10-2005) 
Secs. 8-51-8-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISIONS 4-8. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-75-8-111. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - ROOFS AND ROOF STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-112. - Roof leaders. 
    All buildings shall be provided with proper metal leaders, which shall be connected to the sewer where possible, or by pipes below the surface to a cesspool, detached dwellings, or other one story buildings, may be exempted at the discretion of the superintendent. 
(Code 1973, § 8-112; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 51) 
Secs. 8-113-8-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - FIRE DOORS, FIRE WINDOWS, FIRE SHUTTERS AND SMOKE DETECTORS 

Sec. 8-125. - Protection of interior wall openings. 
    All openings in interior walls shall be protected by fire doors and fire windows where required by this article and in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1973, § 8-125; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 59) 
Sec. 8-126. - Residential smoke detectors. 
    A single station smoke detecting alarm device shall be required in the following structures or buildings used for residential occupancies: 
(1)  In a nonowner occupied single-family dwelling and in a two-family dwelling, the detector shall be located on or near the ceiling in the following areas of the building or structure: 
a.  Adjacent to and audible in the sleeping areas of the dwelling units; and 
b.  In the basement and/or cellar. 
(2)  In multiple-family dwellings, the detectors shall be located on or near the ceiling in the following areas of the building or structure: 
a.  In each dwelling unit adjacent to and audible in the sleeping areas; and 
b.  In each common area; and 
c.  In each basement and cellar. 
(3)  The single station smoke detecting alarm device may be hardwire electric or battery operated as described in reference standard NFPA 74. 
(4)  The owner of a dwelling or multiple dwelling covered under this section shall: 
a.  Initially provide and install the smoke detecting devices; 
b.  Replace within 30 days after the receipt of written notice any such device which becomes inoperable within one year of the installation of such device due to defect in the manufacture of such devices and through no fault of the occupant of the dwelling or dwelling unit; 
c.  Upon the occurrence of a vacancy, replace or properly equip any such device which has been removed or rendered inoperable so as to provide operational smoke detecting devices for any new tenant; and 
d.  Notify tenants in writing, individually or through posting of a notice in his common area of the building, of the respective duties of owners and tenants under this section. 
(5)  Upon lease or rental of a dwelling or dwelling unit, the owner shall obtain from the tenant confirmation that the owner is in compliance with this division and such confirmation shall contain a statement certifying whether the owner or the tenant is to be responsible for the maintenance of the smoke detecting devices. 
(6)  The owner of every building or structure subject to the provisions of this division shall keep such records as the state fire prevention and building code council shall prescribe relating to the installation and maintenance of smoke detecting devices in any building and make such records available to any local code enforcement officer on request. 
(7)  No person shall render smoke detecting devices inoperable or inaccessible except during drills, maintenance, emergencies or prescribed testing. 
(8)  Definitions for the terms in this section shall be as defined or noted in the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code. 
(Code 1973, § 8-126; Ord. No. 88-201, § 1, 4-11-1988; Ord. No. 91-76, §§ 1, 2, 2-11-1991; Ord. No. 94-356, § 1, 6-27-1994) 
Sec. 8-127. - Appeals. 
    Any property owner may appeal rulings based on section 8-126 to the zoning board of appeals, pursuant to section 810.5 of the zoning ordinance as set forth in appendix B to this Code, for a review of such appeal or grievance, based upon one or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Undue economic hardship or burden; 
(2)  Restriction from the achievement of a valid state or federal policy; 
(3)  Physical or legal impossibility; 
(4)  Impediment to the intended objective of the regulation; or 
(5)  Unnecessary, in light of viable alternatives which meet the intended objective of the more restrictive ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 8-127; Ord. No. 94-356, § 1, 6-27-1994) 
Secs. 8-128-8-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-131-8-143. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - MISCELLANEOUS CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 8-144. - Special flood hazard districts, general provisions. 
(a)  Lands to which this section applies. This section shall apply to all areas of special flood hazards within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(b)  Basis for establishing the areas of special flood hazard. The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in a scientific and engineering report entitled the "Flood Insurance Study for the City of Elmira, of Chemung County, New York," with accompanying flood insurance rate maps and flood boundary-floodway maps is hereby adopted and declared to be a part of this section. The flood insurance study and maps are on file at the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Interpretation, conflict with other laws. This section is adopted in response to revisions to the National Flood Insurance Program, and shall supersede all previous laws adopted for the purpose of establishing and maintaining eligibility for flood insurance. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this section shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety and welfare. Whenever the requirements of this section are at a variance with the requirements of any other lawfully adopted rules, regulations or ordinances, the most restrictive, or that imposing the higher standards, shall govern. 
(d)  Regulations. All new construction within a special flood hazard area shall be subject to all of the rules and regulations in section 401 of the zoning ordinance set forth in appendix B to this Code, governing any construction within the designated areas as set forth on the latest flood insurance rate map and flood boundary-floodway maps as prepared by the Flood Insurance Administration, and Charter § 243. 
(Code 1973, § 8-144; Ord. No. 84-594, § 1, 11-13-1984; Ord. No. 87-257, § 1, 5-11-1987) 
Secs. 8-145-8-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - AREAWAYS AND PROJECTING STRUCTURES 

Sec. 8-151. - Areaways and projections beyond building line. 
(a)  Areaways or openings covered with iron gratings or with iron doors not more than three feet in width, with rough surface set flush with sidewalk, may project not more than four feet beyond the building line. If gratings is used, they shall have a wire screen of not more than one-half-inch mesh attached to the underside. 
(b)  No open areaways, railings, steps, or any portion of a building or structure shall project beyond the building line at any point less than ten feet above the curb. 
(c)  Water tables, beltcourses, sills, bases, columns, pilasters, capitals or other decorative features, which are part of the construction, shall not project more than six inches beyond the building line. Such projection may be erected only upon a revocable permit issued by the superintendent. 
(d)  No bay, oriel or show windows shall project beyond the building line at any point. When erected within the extra hazardous districts they shall be constructed of incombustible material, except that on a dwelling such window may be permitted of wooden framework covered with incombustible material, provided it does not extend more than three feet above the second story floor. Cornices of show windows more than ten feet above the curb level may project not more than 18 inches beyond building line. 
(e)  Alterations or repairs to areaways, steps, storefronts or projecting show windows shall be subject to the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 8-151; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 70) 
Sec. 8-152. - Street encroachments. 
(a)  Marquees. Marquees at entrances to buildings may extend beyond the street line and across the street line and across the sidewalk to a point projected vertically from a point one foot inside the curb; providing they are not less than ten feet above the curb level at all points and within the extra hazardous districts are constructed of iron and glass or other incombustible materials. They shall be so drained that the water therefrom shall not drop or flow on public property and shall be securely supported from the building with no posts, supports or other members in or on the public property in connection with the marquee. No marquee shall extend along the street wall of a building for more than 50 percent of the length of such wall, nor, in any case more than 25 feet, and there shall be a clear distance of four feet between any two marquees on the same building. 
(b)  Doors. No door shall be hung hereafter so as to project, when fully open, beyond the street line. 
(c)  Cloth awnings. Drop awnings attached to buildings may extend beyond the street line not exceeding ten feet but in no case beyond a point projected vertically from a point 12 inches inside the curb; provided that such awnings are securely supported by iron brackets or iron framework and a clear space of eight feet is maintained below all parts of such supporting framework and that every part of such awning shall be at least seven feet above the sidewalk. No cloth awnings hereafter erected shall be supported in such a manner that they sag below the clearances required in this subsection. 
(d)  Fixed awnings. 
(1)  Requirements. Fixed awnings constructed entirely of incombustible material, if not less than eight feet six inches above the sidewalk level at the lowest point, may project over the sidewalk. Such awnings shall not project more than one-half the width of the sidewalk, nor more than ten feet. All fixed awnings shall be supported entirely on the building on which they are erected and there shall be no posts, brackets or other obstacles located on public property. The top deck of a fixed awning shall be of at least one-eighth-inch steel or of other incombustible material of equal strength. Fixed awnings shall be so drained that the water therefrom shall not drop on public property. No sign shall be erected on or attached to or suspended from a fixed awning. 
(2)  Bond. The owner or person in control of a fixed awning suspended over a street or extending into a street more than one foot beyond the street line shall execute a bond or obtain insurance covering personal injury and damage to property of others at his option and furnish a certificate thereof, in a sum to be fixed by the superintendent of building construction and of a form and with sureties or insurance company approved by the corporation counsel indemnifying and saving harmless the city, in the case of a bond, against all loss, cost, damage or expense incurred or sustained by or recovered against the city, or providing for the payment of any injury or damage to persons or property, in the case of insurance, by reason of the construction or maintenance of such fixed awning. The bond or insurance shall remain in force until the fixed awning is removed. 
(3)  Permit. No fixed awning shall hereafter be erected, so as to project over public property until a permit for the same has been issued by the superintendent of building construction. No permit for a fixed awning shall be issued until the required bond has been filed and approved. 
(e)  Temporary covered walkways. Temporary covered ways across sidewalks or public property may be permitted for periods not to exceed 48 hours. Such covered ways shall afford a free passage of six feet in the middle of the sidewalk. Permits for such covered ways shall not be required but the superintendent of building construction shall be notified in writing prior to the erection of such covered way and the control and regulation shall be under the police department. 
(f)  Stands on public property. No stands of any kind, including stands for review or observation, shall be placed upon public property, without the prior written consent of the city manager or his designee. No stand may be erected which shall occupy more than two-thirds of the width of a sidewalk measured to the curbline unless otherwise approved by the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1973, § 8-152; Ord. of 12-3-1934; Ord. of 5-31-1949; Ord. No. 88-69, § 1, 2-1-1988) 
Secs. 8-153-8-157. - Reserved. 
DIVISIONS 14, 15. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-158-8-173. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - REINFORCED CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 8-174. - Specifications for materials, etc. 
    The specifications for materials, factors controlling design, monuments, general design requirements for beam and slab constructing, design of columns and walls, provisions for design of girderless floors or flat slabs, requirements for reinforcement and workmanship shall be as required by this chapter and state law. 
(Code 1973, § 8-174; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 77)

DIVISIONS 17-19. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-180-8-204. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 20. - EXISTING BUILDINGS RAISED, ALTERED, REPAIRED OR MOVED 

Sec. 8-205. - Generally. 
(a)  Within the extra hazardous districts every building having a combustible roof, if raised to produce an additional story, shall be provided with an incombustible roof. 
(b)  No building within the extra hazardous districts having masonry walls shall be enlarged or built upon unless the addition to the exterior walls is of approved incombustible materials. 
(c)  No existing building shall be altered to exceed the limits of height or area provided by this article for new buildings of the same class as that to which the additions are made. 
(d)  No existing frame building shall be raised to a height exceeding 30 feet, except that dwellings occupied by not more than one family may be raised to 35 feet. Buildings so raised shall comply with subsection (a) of this section and all the requirements of this article relating to frame buildings. 
(e)  Within the extra hazardous limits no frame building more than two stories high shall be altered to be used as a factory, warehouse or stable. 
(f)  No frame building within the extra hazardous districts shall be increased in area by frame additions, except that frame extensions used exclusively for toilet purposes may be permitted, but any such extension shall have an approved roof covering. 
(g)  Any frame building which may hereafter have the first story converted into a store, shall have the walls, partitions and ceiling of such first story covered with metal lath or plasterboard and plastered to a total thickness of at least three-quarter inch; or the plasterboard may be covered with sheet metal. Fire stops shall also be provided at the line of the ceiling to cutoff all connection to stories above through hollow stud partitions or side walls. 
(h)  Any existing frame building within the fire limits which may hereafter be damaged by fire, decay or otherwise to an amount greater than one-half of its value exclusive of the foundation, shall not be repaired or rebuilt, but shall be immediately removed. 
(1)  Upon the superintendent's determination that any existing building within the fire limits is damaged by fire, decay or otherwise to an amount greater than one-half of its value, exclusive of the foundation, the superintendent shall forthwith order the owner to immediately remove such building. 
(2)  Unless the owner of such building notifies in writing the superintendent within ten days from the date of the superintendent's order, that the owner is dissatisfied with the superintendent's decision, the superintendent's decision shall be final and conclusive, and the owner of such building shall not repair or rebuild such building, but shall immediately remove same. 
(3)  If the owner of such building notifies in writing the superintendent within ten days from the date of the superintendent's order, that the owner is dissatisfied with the superintendent's decision, the amount and extent of such damage shall be determined by an examination of the building by three competent persons: one appointed by the superintendent, one appointed by the owner and one appointed by the chief of the fire department of the city. 
(4)  If such appointments are necessary under section 8-205(h)(3), these three appointees shall file their decisions, sworn to and in writing, with the superintendent within 20 days from the date of the superintendent's original order, and the majority of these decisions shall be final and conclusive; and if the majority of these decisions concludes that said building is damaged by fire, decay or otherwise to an amount greater than one-half of its value, exclusive of foundation, the owner of said building shall immediately remove said building. 
(i)  No frame building shall be moved from without to within the extra hazardous limits. 
(j)  No building shall be moved until a permit has been obtained from the superintendent, and he shall not issue a permit if in his judgment the proposed new location of the building would seriously increase the fire hazard of the surrounding buildings. 
(Code 1973, § 8-205; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 88; Ord. No. 80-507, § 1, 8-25-1980) 
Secs. 8-206-8-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISIONS 21-23. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-211-8-232. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 24. - PLUMBING, DRAINAGE AND ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 8-233. - Generally. 
    The licensing of plumbers, the issuance of plumbing permits and the plumbing and drainage of buildings, both public and private, shall be performed in accordance with L.L. No. 1990-2 (subpart D, article XX). 
(Code 1973, § 8-233; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 96; Ord. No. 90-334, § 1, 5-21-1990) 
Sec. 8-234. - Specific requirements. 
(a)  Installation. No electric wiring for light, heat or power, except temporary wiring and other work installed for test purposes at power stations and manufacturing plants, shall be installed hereafter in a building or structure, nor shall an alteration or extension of an existing electric wiring system be made, except in conformity with the provisions of this section and rules that may be adopted and promulgated by the superintendent of building construction under the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Inspector. The office of electrical inspector shall be occupied and the duties performed by the person holding the position of electrical inspector for the city. Such electrical inspector shall be assigned to the office of the superintendent of building construction and subject to his general direction and supervision. The superintendent of building construction through such electrical inspector, is charged with the administration and enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Use and maintenance. It shall be unlawful to maintain and use electric wiring except in conformity with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Application and permit. Any person desiring to do any electrical work shall file a written application with the superintendent of building construction on a blank form prepared by him for that purpose, and such applicant shall file with the application a drawing, diagram or other written description of the work desired to be done, setting forth in the application, drawing or other written description the name of such person, the location of the building or structure on or in which such work is desired to be done, and the name of the owner of such building or structure. If such work, so desired to be done complies with the requirements of this section, and is not in conflict with the other valid ordinances of the city, the superintendent of building construction shall issue a written permit therefor upon a standard form prepared by him for that purpose. 
(e)  Inspection. It shall be the duty of any person doing any work referred to in this section to notify the electrical inspector in writing at such time or times as may enable the electrical inspector to properly inspect the work within a reasonable length of time. No work in connection with an electric wiring system shall be covered or concealed until it has been inspected as prescribed in this subsection and permission to do so has been given by the electrical inspector. 
(f)  Reinspection. The superintendent shall cause to be made a reinspection of an electric wiring installation whenever he deems it necessary in the interest of public safety. If an electric wiring system upon reinspection is found to be defective and unsafe, the electrical inspector shall revoke all certificates in effect at that time relating to such system; and the use of such system shall be discontinued until it has been made to conform to this division and the rules and a new certificate has been issued by the electrical inspector. 
(g)  Certificate. Upon completion of an electrical installation or alteration and its approval as to compliance with this section and rules, it shall be the duty of any electrical inspector to issue to such person, firm or corporation which did such work, a certificate approving such work and forward a copy of the record of such certificate to the superintendent, and such certificate shall be available for public inspection during business hours. 
(h)  Supplying current. It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of, or to supply current for, electric wiring for light, heat or power in a building or structure, unless the required certificate of inspection and approval has been issued. The electrical inspector may, in his discretion, give temporary permission for a reasonable time to supply and use current in part of an electric installation before such installation has been fully completed and the certificate issued. 
(i)  Methods and practice. All methods and practices shall meet the requirements of the Building Code of New York State. 
(j)  Fees. All fees for required permits and inspections shall be as follows and shall be paid for at the time of filing said application:

The term "substantial" means work effectively more than 50 percent of the structure. 
(k)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this division, or who fails to comply with any order or regulation made hereunder, or in contradiction to any approved detailed statement or plans submitted by him and approved under the provisions of this division shall be, upon conviction of a violation, subject to a fine not exceeding $500.00, or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding 15 days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  Undertaking electrical work of any kind before the issuance of a written electrical permit shall subject the owner of the property which is the subject of the application to a civil penalty of $100.00 and the doubling of the applicable permit fees. 
(3)  Each calendar month's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense. If the violation persists beyond three calendar months from the date of first written notification of a violation by the superintendent of building construction, each offense is then subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 30 days, or both. 
(4)  The proper local authorities of the city, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent or correct such violation or to enjoin the continuation of any violation. 
(Code 1973, § 8-234; Ord. of 7-2-1923, § 97; Ord. of 12-3-1934; Ord. No. 97-353, §§ 1-4, 8-18-1997; Ord. No. 2004-260, §§ 2-6, 8-9-2004; Ord. No. 2004-374, § 1, 12-13-2004) 
Sec. 8-235. - Plumbing permit fees. 
(a)  Permit fees for one- and two-family residential are as follows: 
(1)  New construction, initial and final inspection is $45.00, plus $25.00 for each additional bath per dwelling. 
(2)  Fixture replacement without roughing charge is $15.00, plus $3.00 per fixture. 
(b)  Permit fees for multiple-family dwellings and commercial buildings are as follows: 
(1)  New construction for initial and final inspections are $75.00 base fee plus $3.00 per fixture. 
(2)  Fixture installation or replacement without roughing charge is $15.00 plus $3.00 per fixture. 
(3)  Fixture installation or replacement with roughing charge is $20.00 per fixture (initial and final inspections). 
(c)  The permit fee for a hot water tank replacement is $15.00. 
(d)  Permit fees for additional inspections are $20.00 per fixture. 
(e)  Miscellaneous plumbing fees for items not specifically detailed in this schedule will be determined by the basis of actual costs to perform inspection and review services. 
(Code 1973, § 8-235; Ord. No. 90-490, § 1, 7-30-1990; Ord. No. 2000-149, § 4, 4-10-2000; Ord. No. 2002-161, § 1, 4-22-2002) 
Secs. 8-236-8-239. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 25. - RESERVED 

Secs. 8-240-8-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 26. - SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS AND FENCES 

Sec. 8-246. - Generally. 
(a)  Permit. 
(1)  No display sign shall hereafter be erected, or attached to, suspended from or supported on a building or structure until a permit for the same has been issued by the superintendent of building construction. 
(2)  No permit for a display sign shall be issued until the required bond has been filed. 
(3)  All display signs, temporary signs or signs listed as exemptions must be in compliance with the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(b)  Exemptions. 
(1)  Display signs illuminated by electricity or equipped with electric devices or appliances, or temporary cloth signs or banners shall not be exempt under the provisions of this subsection (b). 
(2)  The provisions of this section, except as to safety, shall not apply to a wall sign not exceeding eight square feet in area or two feet in height, a projecting sign not exceeding two square feet in area, when erected with a clear space of not less than eight feet below all parts of the sign and projecting not over one foot beyond the street line, on or over a show window or door of a store or business establishment, announcing without display or elaboration, only the name of the proprietor and the nature of his business; or to a sign not exceeding two square feet in area attached to the main wall of a residence building stating merely the name and profession of an occupant; or to a sign not exceeding six square feet in area on a public building giving the name and nature of the occupancy and information as to the conditions of use or admission; or to a wall sign not exceeding three square feet in area, nor a ground sign, not exceeding 12 square feet in area, advertising in either case the sale or rental of the premises upon which it is maintained, nor to street signs erected by the city; or any signs painted directly on a wall, the hanging border of any awning, or incorporated in the construction of any marquee; or to temporary signs or banners authorized by the council of the city. 
(c)  Insurance. The owner or person in control of a display sign suspended over a street or extending into a street more than one foot beyond the street line shall obtain and keep in force insurance covering personal injury, death and damage to property of others and furnish a certificate thereof, in a minimum sum of $250,000.00 per person per occurrence and $50,000.00 property damage, and of a form and with an insurance company approved by the corporation counsel and with the city as a named assured therein. The insurance shall remain in force until such sign is removed. 
(d)  Alterations. No display sign shall hereafter be altered, rebuilt, enlarged, extended or relocated except in conformity with the provisions of this section. The changing of movable parts of signs that are designed for changes or the repainting of display matter shall not be deemed to be alterations within the meaning of this subsection (d). 
(e)  Existing signs. Nothing in this section shall require the removal or discontinuance of a legally existing display sign that is not altered, rebuilt, enlarged, extended or relocated. 
(f)  Wall signs. 
(1)  Display signs placed against the exterior walls of buildings shall not extend more than six inches outside of the wall surface. 
(2)  Such signs shall not exceed 50 square feet in area, unless made of incombustible materials, provided that mouldings and cappings may be of wood. 
(3)  Such signs shall not extend beyond the top or ends of the wall surface on which they are placed. 
(g)  Projecting signs. 
(1)  Display signs fastened to, suspended from or supported by a building or structure so as to project therefrom at an angle shall not extend more than six feet beyond the street line; provided that display signs not exceeding two feet high, and supported directly on marquees may extend to the permissible outer limits of such marquees. The permitted projection of six feet shall be measured along the sign in the direction of projection, and in no case shall a projecting sign extend beyond a point projected vertically from a point one foot inside the curb. A clear space of not less than nine feet shall be provided below all parts of such signs. No display sign projecting over public property shall be supported from the street or sidewalk in any manner. Projecting display signs requiring permits shall be constructed of incombustible materials except that wood mouldings and cappings may be permitted. 
(2)  The above shall not be construed as prohibiting an approved projecting display sign supported by an approved metal post or column placed not closer than one foot to the street line or not closer than two feet from the inside edge of a pedestrian walkway and further provided that the nine-foot height limitation set forth in subsection (g)(1) of this section is maintained except for the space occupied by the supporting post or column and that other limitations applying to projecting display signs are complied with. 
(h)  Ground signs. Display signs shall not exceed 20 feet in height above the ground upon which they rest. Such signs shall be located not less than ten feet back from a street line and not closer than five feet to a lot line. An open space at least two feet high shall be maintained between the bottom of the sign and the ground; provided that necessary supports extending through such space, and the filling of such space with lattice or slats leaving at least 50 percent of the space open shall not be prohibited. Such signs, when more than 15 feet high, shall be built of incombustible materials, provided that mouldings and cappings may be of wood. 
(i)  Roof signs. 
(1)  Display signs that are placed above or supported on the top of a building or structure shall be constructed of incombustible materials, provided that mouldings and cappings may be of wood. 
(2)  Such signs shall be set back from the street line or building line at least eight feet and shall be not more than 25 feet high above that part of the roof on which they rest. 
(3)  An open space not less than six feet shall be maintained below the bottom of the sign, except for necessary vertical supports. 
(4)  No roof sign shall be supported by or braced to wooden beams or other wood construction of a building or structure over 40 feet in height. 
(5)  Complete structural plans and details shall be submitted for all roof signs showing the construction of the sign and of the building on which the sign is to be placed. The maximum stresses in the frame of the sign, as well as those in the supporting structure, shall not exceed the safe stresses as permitted in this article. 
(j)  Location. No display sign shall be so erected as to obstruct any window, door, fire escape, balcony, platform, stairway, vent, ingress or egress to, from or of any building. 
(k)  Construction. Display signs shall be so constructed that they will withstand a wind pressure of at least 30 pounds per square foot of surface, will be otherwise structurally safe, and shall be securely anchored or otherwise suspended or supported so that they will not be a menace to persons or property. 
(l)  Illumination. Display signs illuminated by electricity or equipped in any way with electric devices or appliances, shall conform with respect to wiring and appliances, to the provisions of this article relating to electrical control. 
(m)  Grounding of metal parts. Adequate provision shall be made for grounding metallic parts of roof signs exposed to lightning. 
(n)  Temporary signs.
