    Goods means any goods, wares, works of art, commodity, compound or thing, chattels, merchandise or personal property which may be lawfully kept or offered for sale, but shall not include: goods damaged at sea or by fire and sold or to be sold for the benefit of the owners, insurers or for the account of whom it may concern or goods sold by virtue of judicial decree. 
(b)  Contents of recordkeeping. Every auctioneer or person engaged in the business of selling goods at auction, whether acting in his own behalf or as the officer, agent or representative of another, shall, upon the receipt or acceptance by him of any goods for the purpose of sale at auction, and before offering the same or any part thereof for sale at auction, write or cause to be written in a book to be kept by him for the purpose of recordkeeping: 
(1)  The name and address of the person who employed him to sell such goods at auction; 
(2)  The name and address of the person for whose benefit, behalf or account such goods are to be sold at auction; 
(3)  The name and address of the person from whom such auctioneer received or accepted such goods; 
(4)  The name and address of the person who was the owner, the authorized agent of the owner or the consignor of such goods immediately prior to the receipt or acceptance for the purpose of sale at auction of the same by such auctioneer; 
(5)  The location, with street and number, if any, of such goods immediately prior to the receipt or acceptance of the same by such auctioneer for the purpose of sale at auction; 
(6)  The date of the receipt or acceptance by such auctioneer of such goods for the purpose of sale at auction; 
(7)  The place, with street and number, if any, in which such goods are to be held, kept or stored until sold or offered for sale at auction; 
(8)  The place, with street and number, if any, in which such goods are to be sold or offered for sale at auction; 
(9)  A description of such goods, the quantity thereof and the distinctive marks thereon, if any; 
(10)  The terms and conditions upon which such auctioneer receives or accepts such goods for sale at auction. 
The records set forth in this subsection shall be in addition to any other records required to be kept pursuant to the uniform commercial code. 
(c)  Section not applicable to sale of real property. Nothing in this section shall apply to the sale of real property at auction. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.7; Code 1973, § 6-3) 
State Law reference- Records to be kept, General Business Law § 25. 
Secs. 10-74-10-104. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-105. - Required. 
    No person shall act as auctioneer in the city or conduct the business of auctioneering or conduct any auction for himself or for another without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a license therefor as provided in this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.2; Code 1973, § 6-16) 
Sec. 10-106. - Application; fee; issuance; expiration. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a license required by this article shall file with the mayor a written application containing the name and residence and business addresses of the applicant. Such application shall be signed and verified by the applicant, and shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of the amount of the fee for the license, which fee shall be $50.00 per year. 
(b)  The mayor, upon receipt of such an application and such fee, shall grant a license authorizing the applicant to act as, and engage in the business of, auctioneer in the city, which license shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.3; Code 1973, § 6-17) 
Sec. 10-107. - Use by another prohibited. 
    No license issued under this article shall be used by any person other than the original licensee, and if any holder of such license permits it to be used by another person, or any person who uses such license granted to another person, shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.4; Code 1973, § 6-18) 
Sec. 10-108. - Revocation. 
    If the violator of any of the terms or provisions of this chapter is a licensee under this article, or if any licensee hereunder violates any state law or regulation pertaining to auctions or auctioneers, the mayor shall have the power to revoke his license. In the event of such revocation, the license fee paid by such licensee shall be forfeited. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.5; Code 1973, § 6-19) 
Sec. 10-109. - Fees payable to chamberlain. 
    The mayor shall, on or before the fifth day of each month, remit to the city chamberlain all moneys received for licenses granted under this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 11.9; Code 1973, § 6-20) 
Secs. 10-110-10-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAMES OF CHANCE 

Sec. 10-132. - Sunday bingo. 
    Pursuant to General Municipal Law § 485, effective January 1, 1958, as amended, licensed games of bingo shall be permitted on the first day of the week, commonly known and designated as Sunday within the city, unless it shall be otherwise provided in the license issued for the holding, operating and conducting thereof pursuant to the provisions of a local law or an ordinance duly adopted by the governing body of the municipality issuing the license. 
(Code 1973, § 14-1; Res. No. 86-475, § 1, 8-18-1986) 
State Law reference- Bingo on Sunday, General Municipal Law § 485. 
Secs. 10-133-10-162. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DISTRESS SALES OF MERCHANDISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Going out of business sales, General Business Law § 580 et seq. 

Sec. 10-163. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief of police means the head of the police department of the city. 
    Damaged goods sale means the sale, or any offer to sell to the public, goods on hand and in stock so advertised or conducted as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
    Goods means any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
    License means a license issued pursuant to this article. 
    Licensee means any person to whom a license has been issued pursuant to this article. 
    Sale includes termination sales and damaged goods sales, as herein defined. 
    Termination sale means the sale, or any offer to sell to the public, goods on hand and in stock in connection with a declared purpose, as set forth by advertising, that such sale is anticipatory to the termination, closing, liquidation, discontinuance, abandonment or conclusion of the business at its present location or so advertised or conducted as to reasonably convey to the public that upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be discontinued at its present location. 
(Code 1973, § 14-16; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-164. - License required. 
    No person shall hereafter advertise or conduct any sale as defined in this article without a license. 
(Code 1973, § 14-17; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-165. - Application for license. 
    The city clerk is hereby authorized and empowered to supervise and regulate sales and to issue licenses therefor. Such licenses shall be issued at the discretion of the city clerk and application therefor shall be made on forms approved by the city clerk. The application shall be verified by the applicant if an individual, by one of the partners if a partnership, or by a duly authorized officer if a corporation, and shall be filed with the city clerk. Such application shall: 
(1)  Indicate the place where such sale is to be held. Only one place shall be named. 
(2)  Indicate the date on which the proposed sale is to begin. 
(3)  Specify the means to be employed in and the terminology to be used in advertising the sale. 
(4)  Contain a statement that ownership of the goods to be offered for sale is vested solely in the applicant. 
(5)  Include an itemized inventory of the goods to be offered for sale, together with the source from which, dates on which, and manner in which each item was acquired, and if acquired by purchase, the price paid therefor. 
(6)  Clearly indicate whether the proposed sale is a termination sale or a damaged goods sale as these terms are defined in this article, or both such sales, setting forth facts showing a reason for urgent and expeditious disposal of the goods. 
(7)  Indicate, in the case of a termination sale, the nature of the occupancy and the date of termination of right to occupancy. 
(8)  Contain, in the case of a termination sale, a statement of intention to discontinue the business in the city, immediately upon the expiration of the license applied for, or any renewal thereof, and that the applicant will in fact discontinue the business at such time. 
(9)  Contain such additional information as the city clerk may require. 
(Code 1973, § 14-18; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-166. - Investigation and issuance of license. 
    On receipt of the application and payment of the fee prescribed in this article, the city clerk shall cause the application to be examined and the statements therein investigated. If after such investigation the city clerk is satisfied as to the truth of the statements contained in the application, and as to the form and terminology of the advertising proposed in connection with such sale, he shall issue a license permitting the publication and conduct of the sale; provided, however, that such license shall not be issued until five days have elapsed from the time the application was filed with the city clerk. Such license shall be for a period not exceeding 30 consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded; provided, however, that if the stock in the original application has not been disposed of within such 30 days period, the applicant may apply for a renewal of such license. The application for renewal shall be on forms approved by the city clerk, shall be verified, shall contain an itemized inventory of stock remaining on hand at the time of such renewal application, and such other information as the city clerk may require, and it shall be accompanied by the renewal fee. The city clerk shall cause the renewal application to be examined and the statements therein investigated and, if satisfied as to the truth of the statements therein, the city clerk may issue a renewal license for one period not exceeding 30 consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded. No more than one renewal license shall be issued for any one sale. 
(Code 1973, § 14-19; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-167. - Revocation of license. 
    The city clerk shall have the power, upon recommendation of the chief of police, to suspend or revoke at any time, for cause, any license granted in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1973, § 14-20; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-168. - Refusal to issue license. 
(a)  The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license for a termination sale to any applicant who has not owned the business of which the goods are part for the period of one year or more immediately preceding the date on which the application is filed with the city clerk, or for a damaged goods sale to any applicant who did not own the goods at the time the goods were damaged. However, the aforesaid restrictions shall not be imposed upon beneficiaries or representatives of a deceased person, seeking to liquidate the business of such deceased person and to sell goods connected therewith. 
(b)  The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license for a termination sale to any applicant who has held such a sale, at the same location, within the one-year period immediately preceding the date on which the application is filed with the city clerk. 
(c)  The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license for a sale where the application lists more than one place of sale. If a sale is to be conducted in more than one place, a separate license shall be required for each place and a separate application for each shall be filed. 
(d)  The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license where the application shows that part of the goods to be sold were purchased on consignment or purchased for resale on other than bona fide orders without cancellation privileges. Any order made in contemplation of the sale shall be considered not bona fide. Any unusual purchase or addition to the stock of goods made within 30 days prior to the filing of the application shall be considered an order made in contemplation of the sale. 
(e)  The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license for a termination sale where the application shows that the goods proposed to be sold include goods which are not the regular stock of the business to be terminated at the conclusion of the sale. 
(Code 1973, § 14-21; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-169. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city clerk is empowered to make such rules and regulations for the advertisement and conduct of such sales as in his opinion will serve to prevent deception and to protect the public. 
(Code 1973, § 14-22; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-170. - Fees. 
    On filing an original application for a license to advertise and conduct a sale under this article, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee in the sum of $50.00. On filing a renewal application under this article, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee in the sum of $25.00. If any application or renewal application be disapproved, the fees paid hereunder shall be forfeited to the city for the cost of investigating and processing such application. 
(Code 1973, § 14-23; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-171. - Enforcement. 
    On commencement of any sale, as defined in this article, the license issued by the city clerk shall be prominently displayed near the entrance to the premises. A duplicate original of the application and stock list pursuant to which such license was issued shall at all times be available to the city clerk and the license shall permit the city clerk to examine all merchandise on the premises for comparison with such stock list. All advertisements or advertising and the language contained therein shall be in accordance with the purpose of the sale as stated in the application pursuant to which a license was issued and the wording of such advertisements shall not vary from the wording as indicated in the application. Such advertising shall in no manner or form whatsoever, either directly or indirectly, indicate that such sale is held with the approval of the city clerk. Such advertising shall contain a statement in these words and no others: "Sale held pursuant to License No. _____ issued by the City Clerk of the City of Elmira, on the ___ day of _______, 20___" and in such blank spaces shall be indicated the license number and the date of issuance of the license. Suitable books and records as prescribed by the city clerk shall be kept by the licensee and they shall at all times be available to the city clerk. At the close of business each day the stock list attached to the application shall be revised and those items disposed of during each day shall be so marked on such list. No additional merchandise shall be added to the stock in the establishment of the licensee after issuance of the first license. 
(Code 1973, § 14-24; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-172. - Termination of business. 
    Any person who shall publish or conduct any sale pursuant to a license issued under this article on an application indicating that the proposed sale is anticipatory to the termination, closing, liquidation, discontinuance or abandonment of the business, such person shall discontinue the operation of the business in the city immediately upon the expiration of the license or any renewal thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 14-25; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-173. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officers, such as sheriffs and marshals. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(Code 1973, § 14-26; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-174. - Chief of police to aid city clerk. 
    The chief of police shall render such aid and assistance to the city clerk as the latter may require in the administration and enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 14-27; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Sec. 10-175. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and any person guilty of such violation shall be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. Each day such violation continues shall be considered as a separate violation and punishable as such. 
(Code 1973, § 14-28; Ord. of 11-13-1961) 
Secs. 10-176-10-203. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, Alcoholic Beverage Control Law § 1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-204-10-229. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR CONSUMPTION AREAS 

Sec. 10-230. - Definitions. 
(a)  Generally. Unless otherwise specifically defined in subsection (b) of this section, words or phrases used in this division shall be interpreted so as to attribute to them the meaning they have in common usage and to accord this division its broadest and most reasonable application. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Establishment means any business possessing a license duly issued by the state liquor authority or its designee or successor, granting authority to said business to serve alcoholic beverages. 
    Open-air means any area not completely enclosed by a roof and walls. 
    Outdoor consumption area means any designated, open-air area, owned or operated by an establishment, wherein the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages may occur. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.A, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-231. - Operating without a license prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any establishment to serve alcoholic beverages, or allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages, in any outdoor consumption area without having first obtained a license as hereinafter provided. 
(1)  Special event excluded. The term "special events" as that term is defined and regulated under article III, chapter 18, as may be from time to time amended, shall not be regulated by the terms and conditions of this division. 
(2)  Preexisting outdoor consumption areas. Where an establishment lawfully owned and/or operated an outdoor consumption area prior to the effective date of this division, said establishment shall have 30 calendar days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived, to apply for said license, at which time the establishment must be in compliance with the requirements of this division. The outdoor consumption area of said establishment may continue to be operated until the establishment's application is either approved or denied. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.B, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-232. - License application required. 
    Any establishment desirous to own and/or operate an outdoor consumption area within the city shall file with the city clerk, an outdoor consumption area license application on a form as prescribed and amended from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.C, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-233. - Contents of application. 
    The outdoor consumption area license application shall, at a minimum, contain the following information: 
(1)  Name. The complete, legal name of the establishment applying for said license, as well as the names of all owners (to any degree) of said establishment, and including any and all aliases of said establishment and owners. 
(2)  Address. The establishment's legal address, as well as the address where the outdoor consumption area is to be located, if different from said legal address; and if the establishment is a corporation: 
a.  The address of its principal place of business; 
b.  The name and address of the person authorized to be served with process; and 
c.  A copy of its certificate of incorporation and good standing with the state or certificate of ability to operate in the state. 
(3)  Copy of DBA. If the establishment is or plans to conduct business under any other name, the exact name thereof as well as a copy of the establishment's doing business as (DBA) form. 
(4)  Schematic. A drawing, schematic, blueprint, or the like, depicting: 
a.  The lot dimensions; 
b.  The building locations; 
c.  The location and dimensions of the outdoor consumption area; and 
d.  Distances to the nearest building on all abutting lots. 
(5)  Ownership or operation of other outdoor consumption areas. A statement as to whether the establishment or any owner thereof, is now, or has within the past five years been the owner (to any degree) or operator of any outdoor consumption area or establishment which served alcoholic beverages within the city or elsewhere; and if so, provide the name and address of said establishment and/or outdoor consumption area. 
(6)  Prior suspensions or revocations. A statement as to whether the license of any owner of said establishment, to own or operate an establishment which services alcoholic beverages or outdoor consumption area with the city or elsewhere, has been denied, revoked or suspended within the past 12 months and the reasons therefor. 
(7)  Landlord not to be currently under suspension or revocation. A statement as to whether the real property on which the outdoor consumption area is to be located, including any buildings thereon, is owned, rented, leased, or subleased by or from any entity which has had its license to own or operate an establishment which serves alcoholic beverages or outdoor consumption area within the city or elsewhere denied, suspended or revoked within the past 12 months. 
(8)  Prior criminal convictions. A statement as to whether any of the owners of said establishment has ever been convicted of a crime associated with, or arising out of, the operation of an establishment which serves alcoholic beverages or outdoor consumption area within the city or elsewhere and the date, location and description of said convictions. 
(9)  Verification. The truthfulness, accuracy and completeness of the application shall be sworn to by an owner of the establishment which shall own and operate the outdoor consumption area. 
(10)  Documentation. Prior to consideration of the application by city council, said establishment must supply to the city clerk a copy of the current license issued by the state authorizing said establishment to operate an establishment which serves alcoholic beverages. 
(11)  Continuing duty to notify city of changes. The establishment shall have a continuing duty to notify the city clerk within five calendar days of any change of any information provided in the application process. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.D, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-234. - Processing of license application. 
(a)  Processing by city clerk. Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall review the application for facial completeness and factual correctness to the best of his knowledge, and shall, within five business days, notify the entity by way of regular mail, of any errors or omissions and allow said entity ten additional business days to correct or supply said information and initial same as true without reapplying; provided, however, that if each and every error or omission is not corrected or supplied within said ten business days, the license application must be denied by the city clerk, and the outdoor consumption area shall not be allowed to begin operating nor continue to operate without correcting or supplying said information. 
(1)  Investigation. If the application is facially in order, the city clerk shall immediately cause an investigation to be conducted, which said investigation, at a minimum, shall include the number and type of complaints received within the past 12 months by the city relating to the establishment applying for said license, or any owners thereof, as well as complaints specifically related to the operation of any outdoor consumption areas by said establishment or owners; and that the outdoor consumption area does not violate any zoning ordinance of the city. 
(2)  Report. The city clerk shall, within 15 business days from the commencement of the investigation, forward said application, together with a report detailing the findings of the investigation, a statement of his intended decision regarding issuance or denial of said license, as well as any additional requirements to be met by the applicant as a condition of issuance of said license, to the city council and mayor. The time within which to conduct said investigation and deliver said report may be extended by the city manager for a period of up to 15 additional business days upon good cause shown by the city clerk. 
(b)  City council consideration of license. If a member of city council disagrees with the intended decision of the city clerk to issue or deny said license, or disagrees with the proposed requirements conditioning the issuance thereof, said city councilmember may cause, within 30 calendar days after receiving the application and report, said application to be placed on the council agenda for consideration by the city council. If the city council fails or refuses to undertake any of the actions as outlined in subsection (c) of this section, within the 30 calendar days from receipt of the city clerk's report, the decision and conditions, if any, of the city clerk shall not be subject to further consideration by the city council. 
(c)  Overriding city clerk's decision. Within 30 calendar days from receipt of the of the city clerk's report, the city council may, by resolution, override the proposed decision of the city clerk as indicated in said report, and direct either that a license be issued or that the application or continuance thereof be denied, and/or amend, delete, add to, or impose requirements as conditions for the issuance or continuance of said license. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.E, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-235. - Denial, suspension or revocation of license. 
    In no case shall a license be issued, nor renewal or extension thereof granted, and in addition, a suspension or revocation of any existing license shall be supportable, in the event of any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Incomplete or fraudulent application. 
a.  Knowingly false information. Any knowingly false, misleading, incorrect, and/or incomplete information provided by said establishment in the application process shall be grounds for denial of said application and/or revocation of said license; 
b.  Nonmaterial errors. An establishment submitting an application containing errors of a clerical nature and/or errors which would have no material effect on the decision to issue said license shall be given notice thereof and the ability to correct same as provided in section 10-234. 
(2)  Previous suspension or revocation. The establishment or any owner thereof, applying for an outdoor consumption area license has, within the past 12 months, had its license to own and/or operate an establishment which serves alcoholic beverages or an outdoor consumption area within the city or elsewhere revoked or suspended. 
(3)  Previous criminal conviction. Any owner of said establishment has, within the past five years, been convicted of a crime associated with, or arising out of, the operation of an establishment which services alcoholic beverages or an outdoor consumption area within the city or elsewhere. 
(4)  Landlord not to be currently under suspension or revocation. The real property on which: 
a.  The outdoor consumption area is located, including any buildings thereon, is owned, rented, leased, or subleased by or from any entity which has had its license to own or operate an establishment which serves alcoholic beverages or outdoor consumption area within the city or elsewhere revoked or suspended within the past 12 months; and 
b.  Said entity has any ownership, managerial, or pecuniary interest (other than receiving rents under a lease agreement) in said establishment or outdoor consumption area. 
(5)  Attempt to transfer. Any attempt by the establishment to whom a license is issued hereunder, to transfer, sell, lease or assign said license to any other entity or establishment shall render said license null-and-void as to both the transferor and transferee. 
(6)  Failure to comply. The establishment applying for said outdoor consumption area license has failed and/or refused to comply with the mandates of this division and/or any other applicable statute, law, ordinance or regulation. 
(7)  Denial, suspension or revocation of state liquor license. The establishment fails to obtain a license from the state, or said license is suspended or revoked at any time during the term of the outdoor consumption area license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.F, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-236. - Interim review, suspension and revocation of license. 
(a)  By city clerk. If, at any time during the term of an issued license, the city clerk maintains that there is good cause to review whether or not to suspend, revoke, or impose restrictions on any license issued hereunder, the city clerk shall immediately transmit a communication to the city council and the mayor as to the facts supporting such a review and requesting that a hearing thereto be held. Such good cause may include, but is not necessarily limited to, the nature, number, and frequency of complaints, arrests, and other unruly activity relating to the operation of the outdoor consumption area. 
(b)  By city council. The city council may, on its own volition by way of resolution, direct that a hearing be held, as provided for hereunder, to review the current status of any outdoor consumption area license within the city, and may, for good cause shown, after notice and hearing as provided for herein, direct the city clerk to condition the continuation of said license on certain stipulations, or suspend or revoke said license. 
(c)  Notice of hearing. Within 30 business days of receipt of a communication from the city clerk requesting that a hearing be conducted to review the current status of an outdoor consumption area license within the city, or within 30 business days after passage of a resolution by the city council directing such a hearing; written notice of the date, time and place said hearing is to be held, together with a detailed description of the charges or other causes supporting such hearing shall be mailed to the licenseholder at the address designated as the place where postmarked no later that 15 business days prior to the date of the hearing, and shall indicate thereon that the license holder or his designee may appear there and present all forms of evidence, refute any charge or opportunity to be heard and, additionally, that if said licenseholder or his designee fails and/or refuses to so appear at said hearing, that the city council may act on any evidence presented thereat and may suspend, revoke, or condition the continuance of said license without according the licenseholder further opportunity to be heard. 
(d)  Hearing. The hearing shall be conducted by the city council according to its established rules for the conduct of hearings, but at a minimum, the licenseholder shall be afforded the opportunity to present evidence, cross examine witnesses, refute any charges or evidence presented against him and have an opportunity to be heard. After the notice and hearing as provided in this subsection and subsection (b) of this section, the city council may, in its discretion, direct the city clerk to suspend, revoke or condition the continuations of said license on certain stipulations, or any combination as set forth in this subsection. 
(e)  Hearing not required for applications. The requirement for notice and hearing as outlined in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, is intended to vest only in an establishment which is the holder of a valid outdoor consumption area license or is in the process of renewing said license, and nothing herein shall be construed to mandate that the city notify an establishment of any pending consideration of an application, as opposed to a license, by either the city clerk or city council; and further, nothing herein shall be construed to mandate that the city provide the establishment a formal or informal hearing as to the status and disposition of an application, as opposed to a license. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.G, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-237. - Issuance of license. 
    If no action is taken by city council within 30 business days after receipt of the city clerk's report as provided for in section 10-234(a)(2), the city clerk shall implement the decision as outlined in the city clerk's report. 
(1)  Only one license. The city clerk shall issue only one license per property site. Each property site containing a proposed outdoor consumption area must separately apply for an outdoor consumption area license regardless of whether it is owned and/or operated by the same establishment or entities and/or under the same business name as the business which is the subject of the current applications. 
(2)  Nonassignable. The license shall not be transferable or assignable, in whole or in part, to any other establishment or any other location that the one described therein. 
(3)  Display of license. The license shall be conspicuously displayed in the outdoor consumption area. The license shall be available at all times of operation for inspection by the public. The license shall be protected form the elements and no person shall mutilate, cover, obstruct or remove a license so displayed. In the event that any information portrayed by said license becomes unreadable to the general public, the entity shall request, and the city clerk shall provide a new license in conformity with the city's normal course of operations for such issuances. 
(4)  Term of license. All licenses issued hereunder shall be for a term of one calendar year and shall commence on the date of the granting of same and continue until and including the same day and month of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.H, 6-22-1998) 
Sec. 10-238. - Yearly review and renewal process. 
(a)  Failure to renew. The failure of the establishments to apply for renewal of its outdoor consumption area license within five business days after its expiration shall be treated as a suspension of said license and the establishment shall cease all operations relating to its outdoor consumption area until such time as said establishment completes the renewal application as provided for herein. 
(b)  Notice not required. Nothing herein shall be construed to mandate that he city notify the establishment of the pending expiration of its license. 
(c)  Renewal application. The establishment shall apply to renew its license by completing an outdoor consumption area license application form if there are any changes in the information provided in relation to its original outdoor consumption area application. If there are no such changes, it shall be so indicated in a verified, written statement to be attached to the original outdoor consumption area license application. 
(d)  Processing of license renewal application. Upon the receipt of the (renewal) application, the city clerk shall commence and follow the procedure used for the processing of a license application as provided for in section 10-234. 
(e)  Continued operation. Provided that the establishment is in conformance with all applicable law, coded, ordinances, rules and regulations, the outdoor consumption area may continue to be operated under the previous outdoor consumption area license until such time as its renewal application is either approved or denied by city council. 
(f)  Retroactivity of new license. The renewed license shall be retroactive to the date of expiration of the previous license. 
(Ord. No. 98-297, § 1.I, 6-22-1998) 
Secs. 10-239-10-268. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - REGISTRATION OF RENTAL HOUSING 

Sec. 10-269. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means a person 18 years of age or older or entity designated by the owner on the registry form who, by such owner designation, shall have the authority to make decisions regarding the management and maintenance of any and all dwelling units owned by the owner and located within the city. 
    Building means a structure containing one or more dwelling units rented or being offered for rental. 
    Code means the state uniform fire prevention and building code, as amended. 
    Department means the city's code enforcement department. 
    Dwelling unit means a residential accommodation which is arranged, designed, used or, if vacant, intended for use exclusively as a domicile or residence of one or more persons. 
    Fire marshal means the fire marshal of the city or his designee. 
    Owner means the owner of the freehold of the premises or lesser estate therein, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, administrator, trustee or agent. 
    Person means an individual or any entity which lawfully can be the fee owner of real property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-41), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-270. - Violation. 
(a)  In addition to any other remedies available under law, any owner failing to comply with the requirements of this article shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-14. 
(b)  If there be any violation of this article with respect to any building containing one or more dwelling units, which dwelling units are occupied in whole or in part for human habitation, no rent shall be recovered for such dwelling units for any period during which such violation exists, and in any action or proceeding to collect rent owing for any period during which such violation exists or to recover possession of the dwelling units for nonpayment of such rent, proof of violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be an absolute defense to such action or proceeding. 
(c)  No owner, agent or person in charge shall collect rents during any period of noncompliance with the provisions of this article which would otherwise be due and owing for the rental of a dwelling unit unless and until he shall have complied with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  In addition to subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section, any owner failing to comply with the requirements of this article must apply for and obtain a probationary certification pursuant to article VIII of this chapter. In the event an owner fails to apply for and obtain a probationary certification, the superintendent of buildings may cause to be posted conspicuously on any or all of the owner's buildings containing a rental dwelling unit a notice stating substantially as follows: 
"These premises are uncertified pursuant to article VIII of chapter 10 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Elmira, NY, and the use and occupancy of the building is prohibited effective 30 days from the date of this notice, and thereafter no person shall enter the building except for the purpose of making repairs, maintenance and security until the owner registers in accordance with chapter 10, article VII, and complies with the provisions of chapter 10, article VIII, of the Code of Ordinances." 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-45), 11-23-2009; Ord. No. 2010-409, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 10-271. - Legislative findings and intent. 
    The city council of the city hereby finds and declares that the rental of dwelling units constitutes a business which impacts upon the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city. The intent of this article is to promote the orderly and timely management and maintenance of rental dwelling units in order to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city and to further achieve the following beneficial purposes: 
(1)  The protection of the character and stability of residential areas; 
(2)  The correction and prevention of housing conditions that adversely affect or are likely to adversely affect the life, safety, general welfare and health, including the physical, mental and social well-being of persons occupying dwellings; and 
(3)  The preservation of the value of land and buildings throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-40), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-272. - Rental housing registry of owner; exemptions. 
(a)  In addition to any registry requirements pursuant to the state's multiple residence law, no person shall allow to be occupied, or rent to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit unless the owner first has registered the building with the city in accordance with the provisions of section 10-273. 
(b)  Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  A municipal housing authority; 
(2)  Hotels; 
(3)  Motels; 
(4)  Bed and breakfast establishments; 
(5)  Hospitals and colleges, except for a building containing a dwelling unit being rented for other than direct hospital or college use; 
(6)  Nursing homes; or 
(7)  Other buildings which offer or provide medical or nursing services if such buildings are subject to state or federal licensing or regulations concerning the safety of the users, patients or tenants. 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-42), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-273. - Registration. 
(a)  Within 90 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the owner of each building existing on such effective date shall file with the department a registry form. The owner of each building constructed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall file with the department a registry form as herein provided prior to any initial occupancy. Such application shall be made on a form furnished by the department and shall set forth the following information, in addition to other information required by the fire marshal from time to time which may be necessary to administer, enforce and ensure compliance with the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Name, principal residence address, principal business address, telephone number and email address of each owner of record. 
(2)  If the owner is an association, partnership, limited liability partnership, joint tenancy, tenancy in common, tenancy by the entirety or other entity, the name of each and every owner, partner or general partner and addresses in accordance with subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(3)  If the owner is a corporation or a limited liability company, the principal place of business of the corporation must be provided and the name, title and residence address of all officers, directors, managing or general agents must be included. 
(4)  The street number of each building. 
(5)  The number of dwelling units in each building. 
(6)  If applicable, the name of owner's designated agent with the agent's principal residence address, principal business address, phone numbers and email address. 
(7)  The types of any fire protection systems located in each building. 
(8)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner to properly register any change of address, agent or any other registration information which occurs after the filing of the registry within 60 days of the date of change. 
(9)  For purposes of this section, a post office box shall not be accepted as the owner's or agent's address. Further, the building intended to be registered shall not be accepted as the owner's or agent's address unless it is the principal place of business or residence of the owner or agent. 
(10)  The owner shall specify the address to which all notices, violations, and invoices for fees are to be delivered. 
(b)  If said owner's principal place of business is not located within the county, or is located within the county but none of the business's officers or directors or members reside in said county, or the owner's principal place of residence is not located in said county, the owner must designate on the registry form a natural person 18 years of age or older who resides in the county as owner's agent whom the owner authorizes to make decisions regarding the management and maintenance of the building and upon whom service of legal process and all notices may be served or delivered. The owner's designation of an agent shall authorize and empower the agent to make such decisions on behalf of the owner. 
(c)  Within 60 days of the date of transfer of the legal or equitable title to any building required to be registered by this article, the new owner shall file with the department a new registry form. 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-43), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-274. - Fee. 
(a)  There shall be no filing fee for an owner filing a registry form within 90 days after the effective date of this article. Thereafter, an owner who owned a building during said 90-day period but failed to file a registry form during such period shall pay at the time of filing a registry fee of $125.00 for each building being registered. 
(b)  If the owner was not the owner of a building during said 90-day period, there shall be no filing fee for said owner, provided the owner files a registry form within 60 days of acquiring legal or equitable title to the building as required by section 10-273(c). If said owner files a registry form after the expiration of the 60-day period, the owner shall pay at the time of filing a registry fee of $125.00 for each building being registered. 
(c)  There shall be no filing fee for an owner filing an amended registry form pursuant to section 10-273(a)(8). 
(Ord. No. 2009-423, § 1(14-44), 11-23-2009) 
Secs. 10-275-10-298. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CERTIFICATION OF RENTAL HOUSING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 10-299. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent means a person or entity designated by the owner on the registry form who by such owner designation shall have the authority to make decisions regarding the management and maintenance of any and all dwelling units owned by the owner and located within the city. 
    Building means a structure containing one or more dwelling units rented or being offered for rental. 
    Code means the state uniform fire prevention and building code, as amended. 
    Department means the city's code enforcement department. 
    Dwelling unit means a single residential accommodation which is arranged, designed, used or, if vacant, intended for use exclusively as a domicile or residence of one or more persons. 
    Fire marshal means the fire marshal of the city or his designee. 
    Owner means the owner or owners of the fee of the premises or lesser estate therein, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, trustee or agent. 
    Person means an individual or any entity which lawfully can be the fee owner of real property. 
    Probationary certification means as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-51), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-300. - Penalty. 
    It shall be an unclassified misdemeanor for any person or owner to violate the provisions of this article and such violation shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $250.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or up to six months in jail, or both. In addition to any other civil right or remedy, the city also may commence a civil action seeking a civil penalty not to exceed $10,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-57), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-301. - Legislative findings and intent. 
    The city council hereby finds and declares that the rental of dwelling units constitutes a business which impacts upon the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city. The intent of this article is to regulate the offering for rental of dwelling units by owners who have demonstrated a disregard for the timely management and maintenance of rental dwelling units in an effort to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city and to further achieve the following beneficial purposes: 
(1)  The protection of the character and stability of residential areas; 
(2)  The correction and prevention of housing conditions that adversely affect or are likely to adversely affect the life, safety, general welfare and health, including the physical, mental and social well-being of persons occupying dwellings; 
(3)  The enforcement of minimum standards for heating, plumbing and other sanitary equipment necessary for health and safety; 
(4)  The enforcement of minimum standards for light and ventilation necessary for health and safety; 
(5)  The enforcement of minimum standards for the maintenance of existing residential buildings and the prevention of slum and blight conditions; 
(6)  The preservation of the value of land and buildings throughout the city; 
(7)  The protection of responsible owners of rental dwelling units who responsibly and timely manage and maintain their rental dwelling units. The city council finds that responsible owners not in violation of this article shall not be subject to the probationary certification procedure contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-50), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-302. - Certification and probationary certification. 
(a)  Rental housing certification. Upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, all owners of rental housing in the city shall be deemed not to be in violation of the provisions of this article and, therefore, shall be considered to be certified to rent rental dwelling units in the city. 
(b)  Probationary certification required. A person must obtain a rental housing probationary certification before such person shall allow to be occupied, or rent or lease to another for occupancy, any dwelling unit if the building in which the dwelling unit is located or the building premises, after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived: 
(1)  Has been issued by the city three or more initial notices and orders to remedy within any consecutive 12-month period when no substantial progress in remedying the violations was made within the time period set forth in the initial notice and order; 
(2)  Had three or more nuisance abatements including but not limited to miscellaneous refuse, grass or safety and health abatements conducted by the city within any consecutive six-month period; 
(3)  Has been determined to be a "public nuisance" as that term is defined by the city L.L. No. 2005-1; or 
(4)  Has not been registered in accordance with article VII of this chapter. 
(c)  Hearing. Within ten days after receipt of the probationary certification order letter, the owner may request in writing a hearing with the superintendent of buildings to contest the determination that the owner must obtain a rental housing probationary certificate. 
(1)  If requested, upon conclusion of the hearing at which the owner may present relevant evidence regarding the necessity of obtaining a probationary certificate, the superintendent of buildings shall affirm the requirement or vacate the requirement that the owner must obtain a rental housing probationary certificate. 
(2)  In the event that the superintendent of buildings shall affirm his original determination, notice thereof shall be served upon the owner by first class mail or personal service within five business days after the hearing, and the order to obtain a rental housing probationary certificate shall remain in full force and effect. If the determination is upheld the owner shall have five business days from the date of service of the hearing determination in which the owner must obtain a rental housing probationary certificate. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-52), 11-23-2009; Ord. No. 2014-260, § 1, 7-28-2014; Ord. No. 2016-138, §§ 1, 2, 4-18-2016) 
Sec. 10-303. - Probationary certification-Surety; fee. 
(a)  The owner of a building meeting any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302 must obtain a rental housing probationary certification for each rental housing building meeting any such criterion within 20 days of becoming subject to this certification requirement. The certification application shall be on a form furnished by the department and shall set forth the following information, in addition to other information required by the fire marshal. Failure to provide such information shall be grounds to deny the probationary certification. 
(1)  Designation by street address of all buildings owned by the owner within the city containing rental housing units. 
(2)  Owner's name, principal residence address, principal business address, phone numbers (post office box address is not permitted to be used) and email address. 
(3)  Proof that the owner is in compliance with this Code pertaining to registration of rental housing. 
(b)  Before issuance of a probationary certification, the owner shall: 
(1)  Pay in full all unpaid abatement charges owed the city pertaining to any of the owner's buildings and premises, which charges were incurred after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived; and 
(2)  Deposit or deliver to the city a surety in an amount equal to twice the total paid and any unpaid abatement charges for all of the owner's buildings during the immediately preceding 12 consecutive months prior to the date of submission of the certification application if the owner is required to obtain a certification because the owner is in violation of the provisions of section 10-302(b)(2). Upon transfer of a probationary certification pursuant to section 10-302, the new owner shall deposit or deliver to the city a surety if after acquiring ownership said owner is in violation of the provisions of section 10-302(b)(2), said surety to be in an amount as set forth hereinabove. The surety shall be either cash, an irrevocable letter of credit, or an insurance bond in a form acceptable to the corporation counsel. The city shall have the right to recover the cost of any future abatement pertaining to any of owner's rental housing buildings from the surety. 
(c)  At the time of submission of the certification application form, the owner shall pay to the city a certification fee of $1,000.00; provided, however, this fee shall not be due if the owner is applying for a probationary certification solely due to the owner's failure to register a building pursuant to article VII of this chapter. 
(d)  Upon compliance with subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section, the fire marshal shall issue to the owner a probationary certification for the rental housing building or buildings which met any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b). 
(e)  If an owner fails to act in accordance with subdivisions 10-302(c) or 10-303(a), then after 20 days from the date of the order to certify the property as probationary, the property shall be deemed a probationary property by default. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-53), 11-23-2009; Ord. No. 2014-382, § 1, 11-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 10-304. - Same-Term. 
    A certification issued pursuant to this article shall expire two years after the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked pursuant to section 10-306. If during the term of the certification the rental housing building subject to the certification is not in violation of any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b), then the owner will not be required to reapply for a new probationary certification and any surety balance will be returned by the city to the owner at the end of the term. If, however, during the term of the probationary certification the rental housing building subject to the certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b), then the probationary certification is automatically extended for two years from the date of the new determination unless sooner revoked pursuant to section 10-306. If the extension occurs solely or partly because of the occurrence of the criterion set forth in section 10-302(b)(2), then the owner must comply with section 10-303(b)(1). If the certification is extended, the owner shall pay to the city a renewal certification fee of $1,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-54), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-305. - Same-Transfer. 
    Upon a change in ownership of any building or premises which is the subject of a probationary certification at the time of transfer, said certification shall continue to apply to the building or premises for the remaining term of said certification as determined by section 10-304. The new owner shall comply with the city's ordinance pertaining to rental housing registration. The city shall return to the grantor the balance of any surety being held pursuant to section 10-303(b)(2). 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-55), 11-23-2009) 
Sec. 10-306. - Same-Revocation. 
(a)  Probationary certification. During the probationary certification term, if any residential housing building subject to the certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, the city may seek revocation of the certification pursuant to the procedures set forth in said paragraph (b) hereinbelow. Prior to commencing court action, the city shall serve on the owner by certified mail, return receipt and first class mail, or by personal service a notice of the city's intent to revoke the certification with respect to the rental housing buildings subject to the certification. The notice shall specify whether the proposed revocation applies to all or some of the owner's residential housing buildings; if to some, the specific address of the potentially impacted building; and the grounds for the proposed revocation. 
(b)  If any residential housing building subject to probationary certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, the corporation counsel may commence and maintain a civil action or proceeding in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city seeking a temporary closing order, closing order, temporary restraining order, temporary injunction, permanent injunction, civil penalties and any other applicable remedies, either in law or equity. The existence of an adequate remedy at law shall not prevent the granting of temporary or permanent injunctive relief. 
(c)  The action or proceeding shall be commenced against the owner or owners of the residential building. The owner or owners of the premises shall be presumed to be the person in whose name the premises is recorded in the office of the City of Elmira's assessor. Whenever there is evidence that a person was the manager, operator, supervisor, or in any other way in charge of the premises meeting any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, such evidence shall be presumptive that the person was an agent or employee of the owner or lessee of the premises. 
(d)  If the court finds that the residential housing building subject to probationary certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, the court may award to the city a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $1,500.00. Upon recovery, such penalty shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(e)  In addition to the civil penalty provided herein, the court may issue a temporary closing order, a closing order for a period of time determined by the court, which period shall not be less than three months, temporary restraining order, temporary injunction and a permanent injunction. 
(i)  Upon commencement of the action or proceeding and at any time thereafter while the matter is pending before the court, the city may request the court to issue a temporary closing order. Upon the city's showing by a preponderance of evidence that the residential housing building subject to probationary certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, and that the public health, safety or welfare immediately requires a temporary closing, the court may issue without notice a temporary order closing all or a part of the premises. Upon issuance of such an order, the court shall hold a hearing for the issuance of a closing order at the earliest possible date. Service of the temporary closing order shall be in the manner as directed by the court. A copy of the order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises. Temporary closing orders shall be enforced by the city's police department and the corporation counsel. Upon service and posting of the order, all persons occupying the premises subject to the order shall vacate such premises. 
(ii)  Following issuance of a temporary closing order, upon the city's application and showing by a preponderance of evidence that a residential housing building subject to probationary certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, the court may grant injunctive relief; however, a bond or other security shall not be required of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-424, § 1(14-56), 11-23-2009; Ord. No. 2014-98, § 2, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 10-307. - Enforcement. 
(1)  Any temporary closing order, closing order, and any type of injunctive order shall be served upon each named defendant in the manner and within the time specified by the court. In addition, any such order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises. 
(2)  It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to use or occupy or to permit any other person to use or occupy any premises or portion thereof following the issuance of an order of closure or temporary order of closure or any injunctive order directing closure of all or a portion of the premises. Mutilation or removal of a posted order shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or by imprisonment not to exceed 15 days, or both, provided such order contains therein a notice of such penalty. Following issuance of a temporary order of closure, an order of closure, or injunctive order directing closure, the court may grant permission to a person to enter upon the premises subject to the order on a designated date or dates and during specified times solely for purposes of maintaining the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2014-98, § 3, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 10-308. - Noncompliance with order. 
    Any person who intentionally fails to comply with the provisions of this ordinance or an order issued pursuant hereto, or any person who intentionally resists, impedes or interferes with the enforcement of any such order, in addition to any other punishment or remedy prescribed or permitted by law, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 30 days, or both. A second offense within ten years of the first shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 and not more than $2,500.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 2014-98, § 4, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 10-309. - [Temporary closing order.] 
(a)  In the event of the issuance of a temporary closing order, closing order, or injunctive order by reason that a residential building subject to probationary certification meets any of the criteria set forth in section 10-302(b)(1), (2), (3), or (4) without the requirement of the police chief ordering probationary certification, the court also may issue an order to the owner or occupant or both of the premises to immediately abate the violation. The owner or occupant or both shall promptly cause to be undertaken appropriate environmental testing and remediation of the violation. The owner or occupant shall provide written documentation which shall include a statement from the remediation contractor that the premises is safe for human occupancy and that the remediation was conducted in accordance with the laws of the State of New York. 
(b)  The owner and each adult occupant of the premises shall be responsible jointly and severally for all costs and expenses incurred for the testing and remediation of the violation. 
(c)  If after service of a temporary closing order, closing order, or injunctive order containing an order to abate and the expiration of ten calendar days the owner has failed to cause to be undertaken appropriate testing followed by remediation, the city may undertake to cause to be performed such testing and remediation. In the event the city causes such work to be undertaken, the owner and each adult occupant of the premises shall be liable jointly and severally to the city for: 
(1)  All costs and expenses incurred by the city for such work; and 
(2)  Public costs incurred by the city including, but not limited to, posting of the premises, notification of required persons, and laboratory fees, together with an administrative charge equal to 25 percent of the total costs incurred by the city. Upon the owner's or occupant's failure to pay these charges to the city, the city may recover the costs by civil action against the owner and adult occupants, and such costs shall become a lien on the premises and may be collected in the same manner as special assessments levied against the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2014-98, § 5, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 10-310. - Invalidity. 
    If any provisions of this ordinance or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the remainder of the ordinance and the application of such provisions to other persons and circumstances shall not be rendered invalid thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2014-98, § 6, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 10-311. - [Remedy.] 
    This ordinance, [sections 10-306-10-311], shall not be construed to exclude or prohibit any other remedy provided by law for the protection, health, safety and welfare of the people of the City of Elmira. 
(Ord. No. 2014-98, § 7, 3-24-2014) 
Secs. 10-312-10-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PEDDLERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Peddlers, General Business Law § 32 et seq. 

Sec. 10-331. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nonprofit organization means and includes charitable organizations and service organizations such as Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Little Leagues, or March of Dimes, etc. 
    Peddler means and includes, except as hereinafter expressly provided, any person, either principal or agent, who, in any public street or public place or by going from house to house, or place of business to place of business, on foot or from an animal or vehicle standing in the street, sells or barters, offers for sale or barter or carries or exposes for sale or barter, any goods, wares or merchandise, except milk, newspapers or periodicals. 
(Code 1973, § 18-1; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-332. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be held to apply to any sales conducted pursuant to statute or by order of the court, to farmers or truck gardeners who themselves or through their employees vend, sell or dispose of products of their own farms and gardens, to dealers of heating oil, to any honorably discharged soldier, sailor or marine who has procured a license as provided by General Business Law § 32. All peddlers must comply with section 10-339. 
(b)  This article shall also not apply so as to unlawfully interfere with interstate commerce. 
(c)  Nonprofit organizations, such as Boy Scouts, Little League, Girl Scouts, March of Dimes, etc., are not required to obtain a peddlers permit, but are requested to contact the office of the city clerk and notify the city clerk's office when their sale or fund drive will be taking place. 
(Code 1973, § 18-2; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
State Law reference- License for certain veterans, General Business Law § 32. 
Sec. 10-333. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall act as a peddler or carry on the business of peddling in the city, without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect a license therefor as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  A license shall not be assignable and unauthorized use thereof either by a holder of such license or by any other person shall be termed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 18-3; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-334. - Application for license. 
    Every applicant for a license is required to submit to the city clerk a written application under affidavit setting forth the following information: 
(1)  State in detail the particular business, trade or occupation for which the license is required. 
(2)  State the manner or means of conveyance in which the business or trade shall be conducted. 
(3)  State the name of such person or the residence of the person composing any such firm or the principal place of business of any such corporation and the name of the officer in the case of a corporation upon whom process or other legal notice may be served. 
(Code 1973, § 18-4; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-335. - License fee. 
    The license fee to peddlers shall be $50.00 for one year. 
(Code 1973, § 18-5; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-336. - Expiration. 
    The city clerk, upon receipt of said application and such fee, shall grant a license authorizing the applicant to act as a peddler in the city, which license shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1973, § 18-6; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-337. - License to be carried on person. 
    Every person licensed under this chapter shall carry on his person a copy of the license so issued which shall bear the license number assigned and every licensee exercising his license shall exhibit the same upon demand to any police officer or citizen. 
(Code 1973, § 18-7; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-338. - Revocation of license. 
    The city clerk may at any time for violation of this or any other ordinance or any law, revoke any license. When a license is revoked, no refund of any unearned portion of the license fee shall be made. Notice of such revocation and the reason or reasons thereof, in writing, shall be served upon the person named in the application or by mailing the same to the address given in the application and a copy of such notice shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 18-8; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-339. - Restrictions. 
    A licensed peddler shall: 
(1)  Not falsely or fraudulently misrepresent the quantity or quality of any article offered for sale, or offer for sale any unwholesome, tainted or diseased provisions or merchandise. 
(2)  Keep the vehicles and receptacles used by him in a clean and sanitary condition and the foodstuffs and edibles offered for sale well covered and protected from dirt, dust and insects. 
(3)  Not stand or permit the vehicle used by him to stand in one place in any public street or place for more than 20 minutes, or in front of any premises for any time if the owner of or lessee of the ground floor thereof objects. 
(4)  Not sell any confectionery, or ice cream within 250 feet of any school between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on school days. 
(5)  Not permit any vehicle used by him to stop or remain on any cross walk. 
(6)  Not permit any vehicle used by him to obstruct any sidewalk or interfere with pedestrians thereon. 
(7)  Not stand or permit vehicles used by him to stand on any street, sidewalk, or park within the central business district defined as follows: Bounded west by College Avenue; north by Second Street; east by Lake Street; and south by the Chemung River. 
(Code 1973, § 18-9; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1; Ord. No. 85-189, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Secs. 10-340-10-366. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - TRANSIENT RETAIL BUSINESSES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Itinerant merchants, General Business Law § 37 et seq. 

Sec. 10-367. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient retail business means one conducted in a store, hotel, house, building or structure for the sale at retail of goods, wares or merchandise excepting food products, and which is intended to be conducted for a temporary period of time and not permanently. If a place in which the business is conducted is rented or leased for a period of six months or less, such fact shall be presumptive evidence that the business carried on therein is a transient retail business. 
(Code 1973, § 18-10; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-368. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating the provision of this section shall be guilty of disorderly conduct and shall be deemed a disorderly person and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $150.00 for each offense, and every day that a violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1973, § 18-17; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-369. - Article not applicable to certain sales. 
    This article shall not include an auction sale conducted under any law relating to insolvent debtors, or to the sale of food products. 
(Code 1973, § 18-11; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
State Law reference- Going out of business sales, General Business Law § 580 et seq. 
Sec. 10-370. - Permit required. 
    No person shall conduct a transient retail business in the city until he shall make written application to the city clerk and a permit has been granted to conduct such business. 
(Code 1973, § 18-12; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-371. - Application for permit. 
    The application for a permit shall be verified and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and present address of the applicant. 
(2)  The length of time for which the permit is desired. 
(3)  A description of the goods, wares and merchandise to be offered for sale. 
(4)  The name under which such business is to be conducted. 
(5)  The location of the premises within the city where such business is to be conducted. 
(6)  The term for which the premises in which said business is to be conducted have been leased, and the name and address of the person from whom said premises have been leased. 
(Code 1973, § 18-13; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-372. - Possession of permit, display upon request. 
    Every person holding a permit under this article shall keep the same at his business premises while engaged in the business licensed and must produce the license on the request of any official of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-14; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-373. - Fee. 
    There shall be a fee of $100.00 per day for the permit. 
(Code 1973, § 18-15; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Sec. 10-374. - Bond. 
(a)  Before such permit is issued by the city clerk, the applicant will be required to post a surety bond in an amount of not less than $500.00, which bond shall be executed by a bonding company duly authorized to do business in the state. 
(b)  The condition of such bond shall be that said transient merchant will pay all state and local taxes applicable to his transactions entered into in this city, that he will well and truly perform any and all contracts or sales orders made within the city, and more particularly, that if said merchant takes orders for merchandise to be delivered at a future date and accepts payment in part or in full therefor, he will deliver said merchandise in a satisfactory condition within a period of four months from the date of said contract, a copy of which contract or sales order with full particulars is to be delivered to the purchaser at the time of sale. 
(c)  There shall be no forfeiture in respect to the four months limitation where there is proof that nondelivery was due to strikes or other extraordinary events beyond the control of said merchant; however, in such event, the merchant upon demand shall promptly return in full the purchaser's deposit; and if he fails so to do, the surety will be required to make restitution under said bond. 
(Code 1973, § 18-16; Ord. No. 85-188, § 1, 4-15-1985) 
Secs. 10-375-10-391. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SPECIAL EVENTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Peddlers, General Business Law § 32 et seq.; itinerant merchants, General Business Law § 37 et seq. 

Sec. 10-392. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Outdoor vendor 
(1)  The term "outdoor vendor" means and includes any person, either principal or agent, who, in any public street or public place, on foot or from an animal or vehicle standing in the street, sells or barters, offers for sale or barter or carries or exposes for sale or barter any goods, wares or merchandise during and at any special event. 
(2)  The term "outdoor vendor" does not include any nonprofit organization. 
    Special event means and includes any public outdoor event, spectacle or show staged or intended to take place partly or entirely within the corporate limits of the city and which is intended to take place entirely or partly upon city property, a city sidewalk, a city street or right-of-way and which is intended to draw participants, spectators or the general public. 
    Special event policy or policy means the written policy adopted by the city council, as amended from time to time, regarding special events. 
(Code 1973, § 18-18; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-393. - Committee created. 
    There is hereby created a special events committee.
