The function of this committee shall be to review and approve each special event's application in accordance with the special events policy then in effect and to grant variances upon good cause shown from the requirements set forth in the special events policy. The city manager shall appoint the members annually and shall have the authority to remove any member at any time. 
(Code 1973, § 18-20; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-394. - License-Required. 
    No person shall stage a special event in the city without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force and effect an event license therefor as provided in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 18-19; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 95-65, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-395. - Same-Application. 
(a)  Every applicant for a special event license is required to submit to the city clerk a written application on a form provided by the city. The application shall include but not be limited to information regarding the nature, time and duration of the special event; the geographic location of the special event; the agenda or program offered; the names and addresses of all persons and organizations sponsoring or staging the event; whether the event will require the temporary closing of public streets; whether police protection or other security is required; and whether the organizers have obtained general liability insurance naming the city as a co-insured. 
(b)  Upon receipt, the city clerk shall forward the application to the special events committee. 
(Code 1973, § 18-21; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 90-104, § 1, 2-12-1990; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-396. - Same-Fee. 
(a)  The fee to organizers of persons staging a special event shall be $50.00 payable to the city. 
(b)  Additionally, any organizer issuing permits to outdoor vendors as provided in this article shall pay, per vendor per day, to the city a fee in the amount of: 
(1)  $15.00 for each food vendor; and 
(2)  $10.00 for nonfood vendors. 
(Code 1973, § 18-22; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 90-104, § 1, 2-12-1990; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-397. - Proof of insurance. 
    No application for an event license shall be issued except upon approval of the application by the city clerk and upon proof by the organizers of the special event of an insurance policy naming the city as a co-insured. The amount of said insurance shall be set by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-23; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-398. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the application, fee and proof of insurance, and upon approval by the special events committee, the city clerk may grant an event license authorizing the applicant to stage a special event in the city in accordance with the description set forth in the application. The event license shall expire at the earliest of the following times: 
(1)  The conclusion of the event; 
(2)  The time set forth in the application; or 
(3)  Upon revocation of the license by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-24; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-399. - Restrictions. 
    The special event license is intended to be a temporary license and is nontransferable. The city clerk may, in his discretion, deny such license for good cause and may revoke any license granted should any terms and conditions of the license be violated or should it be determined by the special events committee that the applicant made a misrepresentation on its application. 
(Code 1973, § 18-25; Ord. No. 88-356, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 88-400, § 1, 7-18-1988; Ord. No. 89-118, § 1, 2-27-1989; Ord. No. 95-73, § 1, 2-6-1995) 
Sec. 10-400. - Outdoor vendors. 
    No person shall hereinafter act as an outdoor vendor or carry on the business of vending outdoors within three city blocks of a special event without the express permission of the organizers of said event. Each outdoor vendor shall obtain a permit from the license holder and shall produce such permit upon request by the license holder or any law enforcement official enforcing this article. The license holder may collect a fee for the issuance of such permit as follows: 
(1)  A food vendor permit is $15.00; 
(2)  A nonfood vendor permit is $10.00. 
(Code 1973, § 18-26; Ord. No. 88-350, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 88-400, § 1, 7-18-1988; Ord. No. 89-118, § 1, 2-27-1989) 
Secs. 10-401-10-428. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Junk dealers, General Business Law § 60 et seq.; secondhand watch dealers, General Business Law § 392. 

Sec. 10-429. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer means a person who buys for their own use or for the use of another, but not for resale. 
    Person means any natural person, firm, partnership, limited liability partnership, association, corporation, limited liability company, or any other type of business entity. 
    Purchase of a secondhand item includes an exchange or trade for a secondhand item. 
    Secondhand business means a business which engages in the purchase for resale of any secondhand gold, silver, platinum, diamonds or other precious gems or any of the following 
(1)  Items containing gold, silver, platinum, diamonds or other precious gems; 
(2)  Bicycles; 
(3)  Radios; 
(4)  Televisions; 
(5)  Stereo equipment; 
(6)  Jewelry; 
(7)  Watches; 
(8)  Cameras and video equipment and accessories; 
(9)  Furniture; 
(10)  Appliances; 
(11)  Typewriters, calculators, office equipment; 
(12)  Computer hardware equipment; 
(13)  Computers and computer equipment; 
(14)  Video games; 
(15)  Stamps; 
(16)  Coins; 
(17)  Automotive parts or equipment; or 
(18)  Motor vehicles. 
    Secondhand dealer means any person who conducts a secondhand business in the city for purchasing, selling, trading or dealing in any secondhand articles, other than a licensed collateral loan broker, junk, automobile or automobile parts dealer, furniture or antique dealer, a person engaged in estate transactions, or a person purchasing goods not previously sold to a consumer. 
(Code 1973, § 21-1; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 1(21-1), 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-430. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Code 1973, § 21-11; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-11, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-431. - License-Required. 
    No person shall carry on the business of secondhand dealer in the city without first obtaining a license. 
(Code 1973, § 21-2; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-2, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-432. - Same-Application; issuance. 
(a)  An application for a secondhand dealer license shall be made to the chief of police of the city, on forms prescribed by the city clerk. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application for a secondhand dealer license, and after approval of the zoning code compliance by the code enforcement officer, the code enforcement officer shall cause an inspection to be made of the applicant's business premises to determine whether public safety problems exist, and the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the background of the owner and operator of the business. Before the issuance of a license, the chief of police and his representatives shall have the right to enter upon such premises during normal business hours for the purpose of making inspections. Further inspections of the premises may be made after a license has been issued to ensure compliance with the laws, ordinances and rules and regulations relating to secondhand business. 
(c)  The owner, operator and employees of any secondhand business shall be of good character and shall maintain good order on the business premises at all times. 
(d)  The chief of police may promulgate rules and regulations to govern the operation of secondhand businesses so as to provide for the orderly operation of the businesses and to ensure the public safety and the peace and tranquility of the neighborhoods where the businesses are located. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of all holders of a secondhand dealer license to notify the chief of police of any changes in information supplied on their license applications within 20 days of such change. 
(f)  The chief of police may deny a license or deny the renewal of a license to any applicant who is not of good character, who is not a fit and proper person to hold a license issued under this article, or who makes a material misrepresentation on the license application. The chief of police shall give the applicant written notification of the reason for denial of a license. 
(g)  The chief of police shall have the power to investigate and inquire into the license applicants under this article and to require and enforce by subpoena the attendance of witnesses at such investigation. 
(Code 1973, § 21-3; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 1(21-3), 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-433. - Same-Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A secondhand dealer license may be revoked or suspended at any time for cause, after a hearing conducted by the chief of police, if the secondhand dealer is in violation of this article, or any ordinance or law, or for any false statement of material fact in the application for license. 
(b)  When the license is suspended or revoked, the license shall be returned to and retained by the chief of police and shall be returned only after the expiration of the suspension period. 
(c)  Before suspending or revoking a license, the chief of police or his designee shall give the holder of the license written notice of the charges constituting cause for the suspension or revocation of the license, together with notice setting forth the date, time and place that a hearing will be had upon such charges before the chief of police or his designee and informing the holder of the license of the right to answer such charges. The notice of charges and notice of hearing shall not be less than ten days from the date of personal service of said notices. 
(Code 1973, § 21-4; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-4, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-434. - Same-Expiration. 
    Each secondhand dealer license shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
(Code 1973, § 21-5; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-5, 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-435. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual fee for a secondhand dealer license shall be $100.00. 
(Code 1973, § 21-6; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 1(21-6), 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-436. - Recordkeeping, tagging and holding requirements. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall keep a record book in which shall be written, at the time of the dealer's purchase of any item, the date and time when the purchase was made, a description thereof, the name, age and personal description of the person from whom the purchase was made, and a description of the means of identification and the identification number required pursuant to section 10-437(a). All such record books shall be open to any member of the police department of the city. The record books shall be securely bound, not less than six inches in either length or width, legibly written in the English language and shall show the amount paid for each item and the number attached to each item. No entry in such book shall be erased, obliterated, altered or defaced. 
(b)  Every secondhand dealer shall, at the time of making any purchase, attach a tag to or otherwise legibly number each item bought and make entry of such number in the record book required by subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Every secondhand dealer shall make out each business day, a written record containing the details of all purchases of secondhand items during the preceding business day. The dealer shall deliver such record to the chief of police or his representative, by mail facsimile transmission, electronic mail, or in person, on the same day in which the record is completed. The details to be reported on each purchase shall be prescribed by regulations promulgated by the chief of police. 
(d)  If several items are purchased from the same person in a single transaction, they may be reported and tagged as a group, provided that each item is accurately described. Items may be described in commonly accepted terms of trade. 
(e)  No secondhand dealer shall permit any item which has been purchased or received by him to be sold, defaced or wholly or partly dismantled until 30 business days have elapsed after the giving of the notice of the purchase of such article as required in subparagraph (c). Items purchased or received from another secondhand dealer licensed under this chapter shall be exempt from this provision, provided that such items had been held for the required time period by the secondhand dealer disposing of the items. During the 30-day holding period, the secondhand dealer shall store the item in an area designated by the secondhand dealer, which area must be separate and apart from the secondhand dealer's area for the resale of inventory and said designated area must be in or on the premises where the item was purchased. 
(f)  The following activities shall be exempt from the requirement of this section: 
(1)  The purchase of items from a single individual for an aggregate price of less than $10.00. 
(2)  The purchase of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1973, § 21-7; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 1(21-7), 11-19-2001; Ord. No. 2004-354, §§ 1-2, 11-15-2004; Ord. No. 2011-105, §§ 1, 2, 3-28-2011) 
Sec. 10-437. - General regulations. 
(a)  No secondhand dealer shall receive or purchase any item unless the person selling or trading the item identifies himself by means of a driver's license, state picture identification card or other means of identification approved by the chief of police. A sheriff's department identification card or college or school identification card by itself shall not be sufficient for purpose of identification. The secondhand dealer shall make and retain a photocopy of the picture identification card. 
(b)  No secondhand dealer shall receive or purchase any item from any intoxicated person. 
(c)  No secondhand dealer shall receive or purchase any item from a person who is under 18 years of age, unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(d)  No secondhand dealer shall have his place of business open for the transaction of business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(e)  Every secondhand dealer shall post his secondhand dealer license in a conspicuous location in the place of business. 
(f)  No secondhand dealer shall conduct his business at any place other than the premises indicated on his application for a secondhand dealer's license. 
(Code 1973, § 21-8; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 1(21-8), 11-19-2001) 
Sec. 10-438. - Exemptions from licensing requirements. 
(a)  Garage sales, basement sales, porch sales, yard sales and other such events at which a person desires to sell or trade his personal used items, household goods, furniture or equipment upon his premises, said premises not being a regular place of business for the purchase or sale of secondhand items, shall be exempted from the license requirement of this chapter. No more than two such sales shall be conducted by the same person upon the same premises within one calendar year, and each sale shall not exceed three consecutive days. 
(b)  Sales conducted for charitable purposes shall be exempted from the license requirement of this article. The determination of whether a sale is being conducted for a charitable purpose shall be made by the chief of police. 
(c)  This article shall not apply to the refund of secondhand items for credit, exchange or refund to the person from whom said items were originally obtained, provided that the items were not secondhand items when originally obtained. 
(Code 1973, § 21-9; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-9, 11-19-2001; Ord. No. 2003-273, § 1, 8-11-2003) 
Sec. 10-439. - Method of payment. 
    Payment for all items purchased by a secondhand dealer shall be made by means of a check drawn on the secondhand dealer's account and made out in the name of the person selling the item. The secondhand dealer shall record on the face of the check the number affixed to the item purchased pursuant to section 10-436(b). This section shall not apply to items purchased from a single individual for an aggregate price of less than $10.00. 
(Code 1973, § 21-10; Ord. No. 95-247, § 1, 5-1-1995; Ord. No. 2001-393, § 21-10, 11-19-2001) 
Secs. 10-440-10-461. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - WEIGHTS AND MEASURES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Weights and measures, Agriculture and Markets, § 176 et seq. 

Sec. 10-462. - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall use or maintain or otherwise employ any weights or measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards or other instruments or apparatuses used in weighing or measuring any goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale in the city, which have not been inspected and sealed or marked by the city sealer within one year next preceding the date any such goods, wares or merchandise are so offered for sale. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.2; Code 1973, § 30-1) 
Sec. 10-463. - Duty of city sealer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city sealer at least twice in each year, and as much oftener as he may deem it necessary, or whenever required by the mayor, to inspect at the place or places where used all such weights, measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards and other instruments and apparatuses used in weighing or measuring any goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale in the city, and to seal the same when they are found to conform to the standards prescribed therefor by the laws of the state. If any be found which do not conform to such standards, they shall, upon order of the city sealer, forthwith be made so to conform by the owner thereof, and shall not be used after such notice to weigh or measure any goods, wares, or merchandise offered for sale until they are made so to conform. It shall be the duty of the city sealer to inspect any such weights, measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards or other instruments or apparatuses brought to him at any reasonable time during any weekday, and, when found to conform to the standards, to seal the same. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.3; Code 1973, § 30-2; Ord. of 8-16-1976, § 1) 
Sec. 10-464. - Records to be kept by city sealer. 
    It shall be the duty of the city sealer to keep a written record in the form of a register, of inspections and sealings made by him under section 10-463, which record shall contain the date and place of such inspections, the name of the owner of the weights, measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards or other instruments or apparatus inspected, whether the same were sealed, and if not sealed whether notice of nonconformance was served. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.4; Code 1973, § 30-3) 
Sec. 10-465. - Fees not to be charged. 
    No fees of any kind shall be charged or received by the city sealer for inspecting or sealing or otherwise marking any weights, measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards or other instruments or apparatuses used in weighing or measuring goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.5; Code 1973, § 30-4) 
Sec. 10-466. - Weights and measures to be made available for inspection. 
    No owner or other person in control of any weights, measures, scale-beams, patent balances, steelyards or other instruments or apparatuses used in weighing or measuring goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale shall refuse to exhibit the same to the city sealer for the purpose of inspection, or in any manner hinder or delay such inspection or otherwise interfere with the city sealer in the performance of his duty. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.6; Code 1973, § 30-5) 
Sec. 10-467. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each such violation. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 71.7; Code 1973, § 30-6) 
Chapter 12 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 12-19-12-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE EMERGENCY ALARMS 

Sec. 12-40. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Police telephonic alarm system means any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to operate automatically through the use of public telephone facilities to transmit a signal, message or warning to another location. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1(a); Ord. No. 82-105, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 12-41. - Permit. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a telephonic alarm system which automatically transmits a signal, message or warning to the city police department without first obtaining a permit as required by this section. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1(b); Ord. No. 82-105, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 12-42. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for permits to install, maintain or operate a telephonic alarm system which is intended to automatically transmit a signal, message or warning to the police department shall be filed with the chief of police on forms supplied by the city, together with a fee of $100.00. The fee will cover the first year of the permit. The person installing the system must maintain an adequate service organization to repair, maintain or otherwise service the alarm system used. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1(c); Ord. No. 82-105, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 12-43. - Right of inspection. 
    The police chief or his representative shall have the right to inspect any telephonic alarm system on the premises where it is intended to function prior to issuance of any permit for its operation and he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any time after issuance of a permit to determine whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1(d); Ord. No. 82-105, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 12-44. - Annual permit fee. 
    Each permit holder shall pay to the city on or before January 1 of each year, a fee in the amount of $100.00 to reimburse the city for the cost of providing the line to receive calls and other expenses of operation, for all present and future installations. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1(e); Ord. No. 82-105, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Secs. 12-45-12-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES 

Sec. 12-62. - Authorization to recover costs. 
    In relation to the provision of emergency medical services, the city is authorized to effect the recovery of the costs of its respective services, tools, equipment and/or materials from any person for whom or for whose property such services were rendered or such tools, equipment or material were used, and from any insurance carrier or person providing insurance covering such persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 2, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-63. - Charges and invoicing. 
    The city shall charge and invoice: 
(1)  Any insurance carrier or other person providing insurance covering any person, vehicle, structure, business (profit or nonprofit) or other property; or 
(2)  Any person for whom or for whose property the city or any of its departments or employees performs emergency medical services or utilizes tools, equipment or materials, for the costs of such services rendered unto or tools, equipment or materials used for such persons or their property. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 3, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-64. - Schedule and fees. 
    The following schedule of fees or charges are to be paid in accordance with the provisions of this article: 
Light-duty rescue ..... $250.00 
Heavy-duty rescue ..... 500.00 
Industrial rescue ..... 1,000.00 
Hazardous materials response ..... 1,000.00 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 4, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-65. - Liability. 
    Where more than one person is served at a single incident, each person served shall be responsible for the cost of each such service. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 5, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-66. - Enforcement. 
    In the event that any insurance carrier or person fails to pay any invoice described herein within 30 days of mailing or delivery of such invoice or notice of charges, the city may recover and collect such charges and invoices from the insurance carrier or person to whom such invoice or notice of charges was given, together with interest, costs and attorney's fees, in any manner provided by law, including without limitation, a civil action at law. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 6, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-67. - Penalties and remedies not mutually exclusive. 
    The remedies provided herein for the enforcement of this article and all other remedies provided by law shall not be deemed mutually exclusive, rather; they may be employed simultaneously or consecutively, at the option of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 7, 3-19-2007) 
Sec. 12-68. - Third party contract. 
    The city may contract with a third party to aid in the billing, collection and remittance to the city of the fees set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2007-125, § 8, 3-19-2007) 
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Duties of city physician, § 37; expense of removing nuisance, § 78. 
State Law reference- Air pollution, Environmental Conservation Law § 19-0101 et seq.; regulation of junkyards, General Municipal Law § 136; health, Public Health Law § 1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - [Feeding wildlife prohibited.] 
    No person shall feed or otherwise provide sustenance to wildlife and fowl on any real property owned, leased or under the control of the city. 
( Ord. No. 2015-229, § 1, 7-27-2015 ) 
Secs. 14-2-14-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES 

Sec. 14-19. - Prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means: 
(1)  Whatever is dangerous to human life or health; 
(2)  Whatever building, or part or cellar thereof, is overcrowded or not provided with adequate means of ingress and egress, or is not sufficiently supported, ventilated, sewered, drained, lighted or cleaned; and 
(3)  Whatever renders soil, air, water or food impure or unwholesome. 
(b)  The situations set forth in the term "nuisance" in subsection (a) of this section are declared to be nuisances under the Public Health Law, and illegal. 
(1912 Sanitary Code, art. I; Code 1973, § 12-1) 
Secs. 14-20-14-41. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AIR POLLUTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Air pollution, Environmental Conservation Law § 19-0101 et seq. 

Sec. 14-42. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dense smoke means smoke which has a density of No. 2 or greater, as established by the Ringelmann chart. 
    Fuel-burning equipment means any furnace, incinerator, refuse-burning equipment, boiler, apparatus, device, mechanism, stack or structure, including steam locomotives used in the process of burning fuel or combustible material. 
    Ringelmann chart means the Ringelmann scale for grading the density of smoke, with instructions for use as now published by the U.S. Bureau of Mines. 
    Smoke means small gas and airborne particles consisting, essentially, of carbonaceous material in sufficient number to be observable. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 35.1; Code 1973, § 12-17) 
Sec. 14-43. - Emission of dense smoke prohibited. 
    No person shall cause, suffer or allow to be emitted into the open air from any fuel-burning equipment during normal operation, smoke the shade or density of which is equal to, or darker than the shade or density of No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, except for three minutes in any 15-minute period during which the smoke may be equal to No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, and except for one minute in any 30-minute period, during which the smoke may be greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, and except as provided in this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 35.2; Code 1973, § 12-18) 
Sec. 14-44. - Exceptions for emission of dense smoke. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer or allow to be emitted into the open air from any fuel-burning equipment during the building of new fires, except steam locomotives as hereinafter provided, cleaning operations, reversing gas producer cycles, or equipment breakdowns, smoke the shade or density of which is equal to or darker than the shade or density of No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart except for three minutes in any 15-minute period during which the smoke may be equal to No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, and except for two minutes in any 15-minute period during which the smoke may be greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart. 
(b)  No person shall cause, suffer or allow to be emitted into the open air from any steam locomotive during the building of a new fire, smoke the shade or density of which is equal to or darker than the shade or density of No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart except for three minutes in any 15-minute period during which the smoke may be equal to No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, and except for three minutes of which no period shall exceed two continuous minutes in any 15-minute period of the first 30 minutes of a new fire during which the smoke may be greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart, and except for two minutes in any 15 minute period of the second 30 minutes of such new fire during which the smoke may be greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 35.3; Code 1973, § 12-19) 
Secs. 14-45-14-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LITTER 

Sec. 14-62. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Elmira Antilitter Ordinance." 
(Code 1973, § 11-35) 
Sec. 14-63. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter includes garbage, refuse and rubbish as those terms are defined herein and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this article, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Park includes a park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises includes any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to any dwelling house, building or other structure. 
    Public place includes any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1973, § 11-36) 
Sec. 14-64. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a fine not exceeding $100.00 for each violation thereof, or 25 days imprisonment or both. In the alternative, and at the option of the city, any person who violates any regulation or provision contained in this article shall be liable to a penalty of $100.00 for the first violation and $300.00 for each subsequent violation, which shall be recovered by the city in a civil action. The corporation counsel is hereby authorized and directed, upon the request of the city manager, to institute and prosecute a civil action to recover such penalty. 
(Code 1973, § 11-49; Ord. No. 87-256, § 1, 5-11-1987) 
Sec. 14-65. - Unlawful use of public litter receptacles. 
    No person shall deposit household rubbish or garbage in public litter receptacles. 
(Code 1973, § 11-37) 
Sec. 14-66. - Littering streets and other public places. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city. 
(b)  No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or any litter from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(Code 1973, § 11-38) 
State Law reference- Throwing or depositing refuse on streets and land adjacent to streets, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1220. 
Sec. 14-67. - Littering parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city. Where public receptacles are not provided, all litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1973, § 11-39) 
Sec. 14-68. - Throwing litter from vehicle. 
    No person, being the driver of or a passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or public place within the city, or upon any private property. 
(Code 1973, § 11-40; Ord. No. 2002-187, § 1, 5-6-2002) 
State Law reference- Throwing or depositing refuse on streets and land adjacent to streets, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1220. 
Sec. 14-69. - Transportation of ashes, rubbish, boxes, etc. 
(a)  No person shall transport in any truck or other vehicle, or in any other manner, through the public streets of the city, streets to which the public has access, or over any land owned or controlled by the city, any ashes, waste material, rubbish, discarded boxes, barrels or other containers of merchandise or discarded material of any kind or description, consigned to a dump or to any other destination, unless the same is conveyed or transported in a truck, vehicle or other manner entirely covered or enclosed so that material cannot escape while being so transported. In the event the same shall be transported or conveyed other than in an entirely closed truck, vehicle or otherwise, such material being so transported and conveyed shall be covered by a canvas, or covering of a similar nature, securely fastened so as to prevent the material escaping from the truck, vehicle or otherwise onto the streets, sidewalks, ways, public land or private property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to so convey and transport ashes, rubbish, waste or discarded material of any nature through the public streets of the city, on ways open to the public or over land owned or controlled by the public, or willfully to deposit or negligently allow such material to escape onto the streets and other places while being so transported and conveyed. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every person transporting and conveying such material to stop and recover the same, in the event of any escape or loss thereof, irrespective of the cause of the escape or loss. 
(Code 1973, § 11-41) 
Sec. 14-70. - Unlawful deposits in ponds, etc. 
    No person shall throw or deposit in any pond, brook, or natural waterway within the limits of the city, any dead animal, dead fish or fish waste, rubbish, filth, foul or offensive substance, or any refuse matter whatsoever, fuel, lubricating oil, fish oil or other greasy substance, so that the same shall create a danger to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1973, § 11-42) 
Sec. 14-71. - Posting notices on utility poles, trees or public buildings. 
    No person shall knowingly post or affix any notice, poster, or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree, or upon any public structure or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Code 1973, § 11-43) 
Sec. 14-72. - Deposit of litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, in such a manner that it tends to create a danger to the public health, safety and welfare, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain private receptacles for collection, as authorized by this chapter. Litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements from any such occupied private property, to the street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1973, § 11-44) 
Sec. 14-73. - Deposit of litter on open or vacant private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, so that the same shall create a danger to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1973, § 11-45) 
Sec. 14-74. - Duty to maintain private property free of litter and bathroom fixtures. 
(a)  The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain his premises free of litter so that the same does not constitute a danger to the public health, safety and welfare. This section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles of collection. 
(b)  The owner or person in control of any private property within a residentially zoned district shall at all times maintain the front yard and side yard abutting a public right of way free of any fixture primarily designed for and commonly used in a bathroom; provided, however, a person may maintain a cast iron bathtub with claw feet for the sole purpose as a horticultural planter. 
(Code 1973, § 11-46; Ord. No. 2002-421, § 1, 11-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-75. - Notice to remove litter from open or vacant private property. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to request the owner of any open or vacant private property within the city, or the agent of such owner, to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such request shall be by registered mail, addressed to the owner at his last known address. 
(Code 1973, § 11-47) 
Sec. 14-76. - Duty of property owners or occupants to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Code 1973, § 11-48) 
Secs. 14-77-14-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Noise, Navigation Law § 79-d; Penal Law §§ 215.50, 215.54, 240.20; General Business Law § 7; Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 375(31), 386; Multiple Dwelling Law § 84. 

Sec. 14-96. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Noise Control Ordinance" of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 15-35; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-35), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-97. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Activity means any act or combination of acts which causes the production of sound. 
    Animals means any animal under the control of an individual, including birds. 
    Construction means any or all activity necessary or incidental to the erection, demolition, assembling, altering, installing or equipment of buildings, public or private highways, roads, premises, parks, utility lines (including such lines in already constructed tunnels) or other property, including land clearing, grading, excavating and filling. 
    Emergency means a public calamity or an exposure of any person or property to imminent danger. 
    Emergency signal device means any gong, siren, whistle, air horn or similar device, the use of which on emergency vehicles is permitted by Vehicle and Traffic Law § 375(26). 
    Excessive noise means any sound which endangers or injures the safety or health of humans or animals or annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivity or endangers or injures personal or real property. 
    Motor vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn, which is propelled by any power other than muscular power, except vehicles which run only upon rails or tracks. This definition shall include but is not limited to trucks, buses, automobiles, vans, motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, motor scooters, dune buggies, snowmobiles, all-terrain vehicles, go-carts, minibikes, trail bikes and all other types of motorized recreational vehicles. 
    Noise means any sound of such a level or duration: 
(1)  As to be or tend to be injurious to human health or welfare; or 
(2)  Which would unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property. 
    Owner means any person who has regular control of a device or site, including but not limited to, the owner of the freehold of the premises or lesser estate therein, or an agent of such person. 
    Real property line means an imaginary line along the surface of the ground and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, but not including intra-building real property divisions. 
    Sound reproduction device means a device intended for the production or reproduction of sound, including but not limited to any radio receiver, television receiver, tape recorder, compact disc player, musical instrument, phonograph or sound amplifying system. 
(Code 1973, § 15-37; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-37), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-98. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the general penalties set forth in section 1-14, any person violating any of the terms of this article shall be liable to a fine not to exceed $50.00 for each violation thereof. Each day of violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 15-59; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-55), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-99. - Policy. 
    Whereas excessive noise is a serious hazard to the public health and welfare, safety and quality of life and people have a right to and should be ensured an environment free from excessive noise, it is therefore declared to be the policy of the city to prevent excessive noise. It is further declared that the provisions and prohibitions hereafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the purpose of preserving, protecting and promoting the health, comfort, convenience, peace and quiet of the city and its inhabitants. This article shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate the purposes described in this section. 
(Code 1973, § 15-36; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-36), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-100. - Excessive noise prohibited. 
    No person shall make, continue or cause or permit to be made or continued any excessive noise. 
(Code 1973, § 15-39; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-38), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-101. - Sound reproduction devices for commercial or advertising purposes. 
    No person shall operate or use or cause to be operated or used any sound reproduction device for commercial or business advertising purposes or for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show or sale or display of merchandise in connection with any commercial or business enterprise, including those engaged in the sale of radios, television sets, phonographs, tape recorders, compact disc players, phonograph records, tapes or compact discs in front or outside of any building, place or premises or on or through any aperture of such building, place or premises abutting on or adjacent to a public street, park or place or in or upon any vehicle operated, standing or being in or on any public street, park or place where the sound therefrom may be heard upon any public street, park or place or from any stand, platform or other structure or from any airplane or other device used for flying, flying over the city or on a boat or on the waters within the jurisdiction of the city or anywhere on the public streets, parks or places; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prohibit vehicles from which ice cream products or similar products are sold from being equipped with a bell or bell-like device, nor prohibit the use thereof by the driver of such vehicle, provided that no such bell or bell-like device shall be capable of being heard from a distance greater than 400 feet and provided further that no such bell or bell-like device shall be used for any purpose between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. the following day nor be used as an ordinary warning signal at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-39), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-102. - Sound reproduction devices used for miscellaneous purposes. 
(a)  No person shall use or operate or permit to be used or operated any radio, television, phonograph, compact disc player, musical instrument or other machine or device for the producing, reproducing or amplification of sound with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person who are voluntary listeners thereto. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section if sound emanating from such machine or device is: 
(1)  Audible beyond the property lines of the premises upon which it is being used between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(2)  Audible at a distance of 50 feet beyond the property line of the premises upon which it is being used between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. of the same day. 
(3)  Audible at a distance of 50 feet from such machine or device if operated from within a motor vehicle on a public street. 
(4)  Audible at a distance of 50 feet from such machine or device when operated in a public park or other public place. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Funeral processions or use of such devices by a church. 
(2)  The production of music in connection with any parade authorized under any provision of law. 
(3)  Any musical performance upon a public place where a permit has been obtained from the city clerk for such purpose. 
(4)  The use of amplifiers or other sound producing instruments or equipment in connection with any religious or political activity or any permitted athletic competition or recreational event held on athletic fields, stadiums or public places in the city. 
(c)  Any motor vehicle used in connection with the commission of a violation of this section may be towed in accordance with section 25-137. 
(Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-40), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-103. - Animals and birds. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Barking dog which makes excessive noise means a dog that barks continuously for ten minutes or intermittently for 30 minutes. 
(b)  No person shall own, possess or harbor any animal or bird which, frequently or for continued duration, makes excessive noise which is audible across a real property boundary. 
(Code 1973, § 15-41; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-41), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-104. - Burglar alarms. 
    No person shall sound or permit the sounding of any exterior burglar alarm on any building or motor vehicle unless such alarm shall terminate its operation within 15 minutes of its being activated. Notwithstanding this provision, any member of the police department of the city shall have the authority to take such steps as may be necessary to disconnect any such alarm at any time when such alarm is operating. Any motor vehicle on which a burglar alarm has been installed and armed shall, when parked in a public highway, prominently display a telephone number at which communication may normally be made with the owner or operator of such motor vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 15-42; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-42), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-105. - Sound reproduction devices on public conveyances. 
    No person shall operate or use any radio, musical instrument, television, phonograph or other machine or device in or on any bus or public means of conveyance, other than taxicabs, in such manner that the sound emanating from such sound reproduction device is audible to another person. 
(Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-43), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-106. - Churches, courts, hospitals and schools. 
    No person shall cause or permit the creation of any excessive noise through the use of any device on any street, sidewalk or public place adjacent to any church, court or school while such church, court or school is in use, or adjacent to any hospital at any time, provided that signs are displayed so as to identify such church, court, school or hospital. 
(Code 1973, § 15-44; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-44), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-107. - Construction. 
    No person shall operate or permit the operation of any tools or equipment used in construction, drilling, or demolition work between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day on any day of the week. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Emergency work or action by public service utilities; 
(2)  Domestic power tools; 
(3)  By special variance issued pursuant to section 14-116; 
(4)  When the sound is not audible across a real property boundary. 
(Code 1973, § 15-45; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-45), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-108. - Domestic power tools. 
    No person shall operate or permit the operation of any motorized or mechanically powered saw, drill, sander, grinder, lawn or garden tool, or similar device used outdoors in residential areas between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. the following day on weekdays and from 8:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. the following day on weekends so as to be audible across a real property boundary. 
(Code 1973, § 15-46; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-46), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-109. - Use of signaling devices. 
    No person shall cause the sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, bicycle or other vehicle, except as a danger warning. 
(Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-47), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-110. - Emergency warning devices. 
    No person shall operate or use or cause to be operated or used any emergency signal device except: 
(1)  On an emergency vehicle when such vehicle is in the immediate act of responding to an emergency; 
(2)  To give notice as a warning of an emergency; or 
(3)  In order to reasonably test such device. 
(Code 1973, § 15-47; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-48), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-111. - Exhausts; mufflers and exhaust systems; prevention of noise. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Exhaust system means a series of mechanical devices for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine and expelling it into the atmosphere. 
    Muffler means a device consisting of a series of chambers or baffle plates, or other mechanical design for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine, and effective in reducing noise. 
(b)  Every motor vehicle, operated or driven upon the streets of the city, shall at all times be equipped with an adequate muffler and exhaust system in constant operation and properly maintained to prevent any excessive noise and no such muffler or exhaust system shall be equipped with a cutout, bypass or similar device. No person shall modify the muffler or exhaust system of a motor vehicle in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise emitted by the motor or exhaust system of such vehicle above that emitted by the muffler or exhaust system originally installed on the vehicle and such original muffler and exhaust system shall comply with all the requirements of this section. 
(c)  No person shall sell, install or use a motorcycle exhaust device without internal baffles, known as straight pipes. 
(Code 1973, § 15-48; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 87-12, § I, 1-5-1987; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-49), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-112. - Loading and unloading. 
    No person shall make or permit to be made excessive noise in conjunction with loading or unloading of any vehicle or the opening, unloading or destruction of bales, boxes, crates, containers or construction material. 
(Code 1973, § 15-49; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-50), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-113. - Motor vehicle repairs and testing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within any residential area of the city to repair, rebuild or test any motor vehicle, motorcycle or motorboat, in such a manner as to create sound audible beyond the property lines of the premises upon which it is being repaired, rebuilt or tested, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. the following day. 
(Code 1973, § 15-51; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-51), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-114. - Places of public entertainment. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 14-106, no person shall operate or permit to be operated a place of public entertainment, including but limited to, a restaurant, bar, cafe, discotheque or dance hall, in such a manner as to create sound audible beyond the property lines of the premises upon which it is being generated, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. the following day. 
(Code 1973, § 15-52; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-52), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-115. - Violation. 
    Any noise originating from a satisfactory property location which is heard at the property line from which the sound is emanating, or beyond, and found to be audible at a time or place prohibited in this article shall be considered a violation of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 15-57; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-53), 10-7-2002) 
Sec. 14-116. - Exceptions and variances. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to the emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency or in the performance of emergency work or action. 
(b)  The city shall establish regulations governing exceptions, variances and appeals; such regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city council prior to the promulgation thereof. 
(c)  The city shall have the authority to grant special variances which may be requested. 
(Code 1973, § 15-58; Ord. No. 83-229, § 1, 5-2-1983; Ord. No. 2002-375, § 1(15-54), 10-7-2002) 
Secs. 14-117-14-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - JUNK, DEBRIS, HIGH GRASS, BRUSH, UNSANITARY CONDITIONS 

Sec. 14-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    High grass means any grass, weeds or combination thereof, greater than six inches in height. 
    Miscellaneous refuse. 
(1)  The term "miscellaneous refuse" includes, but not necessarily be limited to: junk, trash, litter, debris, refuse, solid waste, hazardous waste, garbage, recyclable materials, salvage materials, construction materials, and household mechanisms or appliances including, but not limited to: televisions, air conditioners, refrigerators, washers, dryers, stoves, inoperable lawn mowers and such other large and/or bulky items. 
(2)  The term "miscellaneous refuse" does not include fenced-in compost piles consisting solely of biodegradable plant material, which are located on a lot with the owner's permission. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8; Code 1973, § 22-7(a); Ord. of 5-1-1972, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-1975, § 1; Ord. of 9-2-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 90-285, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 93-339, § 1, 6-28-1993; Ord. No. 2000-195, § 1, 5-22-2000; Ord. No. 2009-198, § 1, 5-11-2009) 
Sec. 14-147. - Penalties. 
(a)  Civil penalties. 
(1)  In the event the city undertakes to remove or abate high grass or miscellaneous refuse from any private lot, or high grass, miscellaneous refuse or obstructions of any kind from an abutting public right-of-way, the owner, lessee or other person in control thereof who failed to comply with notice as described in section 14-150 (or in the event that no notice was actually sent or received, then solely the owner of said lot), and/or any other person who actually caused or permitted such high grass or miscellaneous refuse to exist on said private lot, or high grass, miscellaneous refuse or obstructions of any kind to exist on an abutting public right-of-way, shall be in violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalties herein provided, which penalties may be in addition to the costs associated with such removal or abatement. 
(2)  Upon the first violation within a three-year period the penalty shall be not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00, and upon the second violation within a three-year period the penalty shall be not less than $300.00 nor more than $500.00, and upon any subsequent violation within a three-year period the penalty shall be not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $1,500.00. 
(b)  Other penalties. In lieu of the civil penalties provided herein, the city may elect to enforce a violation of this section in accordance with section 1-14. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8; Code 1973, §§ 22-7(f), (g); Ord. of 5-1-1972, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-1975, § 1; Ord. of 9-2-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 90-285, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 93-339, § 1, 6-28-1993; Ord. No. 2000-195, § 1, 5-22-2000) 
Sec. 14-148. - Regulations. 
(a)  Privately owned lots. The owner, lessee or other person in control of any lot located wholly or partially within the city shall keep such lot free from the accumulation of high grass or miscellaneous refuse of any kind. 
(b)  Public right-of-ways, streets, lots. Notwithstanding any other local law or ordinance, no person shall place, throw, or deposit, or cause to be placed, thrown, or deposited, any miscellaneous refuse or obstructions of any kind upon any street or any portion of a public right-of-way, or publicly owned lot, except as may otherwise be permitted for solid waste collection purposes under L.L. No. 1992-1, as may be from time to time amended or superseded. 
(c)  Private duty over public right-of-ways. The owner, lessee, or other person in control of any real property parcel located wholly or partially within the city, shall keep that portion of any public right-of-way immediately abutting said parcel and lying between the property line of said parcel and the street, which area is commonly referred to as the curb area, free from the accumulation of high grass, miscellaneous refuse or obstructions of any kind. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8; Code 1973, § 22-7(b); Ord. of 5-1-1972, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-1975, § 1; Ord. of 9-2-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 90-285, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 93-339, § 1, 6-28-1993) 
Sec. 14-149. - Abatement. 
(a)  If any owner, lessee or other person in control of any lot shall fail to remove or otherwise abate such high grass or miscellaneous refuse as described in section 14-146, within 48 hours after notice thereof is mailed or otherwise served by the city as hereinafter provided, the city may effect such removal or abatement of such high grass or miscellaneous refuse and thereafter assess to the real property a charge equal to the cost actually incurred by or on behalf of the city for labor, equipment, materials, an administrative fee in the amount of $70.00, and any other costs necessary to effectuate such removal or abatement. 
(b)  Such charges shall be a lien on said real property and shall be added to the tax bill for said real property. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed as requiring notice to the owner, lessee or other person in control of any such lot, if the high grass, miscellaneous refuse or obstruction as described in subsection (a) of this section shall be deemed by the city to pose a possible risk to the health, safety or welfare of any person or animal or is a public nuisance. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8; Code 1973, § 22-7(c); Ord. of 5-1-1972, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-1975, § 1; Ord. of 9-2-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 90-285, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 93-339, § 1, 6-28-1993; Ord. No. 2000-195, § 1, 5-22-2000; Ord. No. 2009-198, § 1, 5-11-2009) 
Sec. 14-150. - Notices. 
(a)  Notice to abate. Notice to remove or otherwise abate such high grass or miscellaneous refuse from a private lot, or high grass, miscellaneous refuse, or obstructions of any kind from an abutting public right-of-way, all as described in this article, may be made by mail, personal service, or by delivering such notice to a person of suitable age and discretion residing in any building located upon such lot or at the residence or principal place of business of the owner of said lot, or in the event of a vacant lot, by mailing the notice to the address and designee shown on the latest tax assessment roll of said parcel. Nothing herein shall be construed to require that the notice as described in this subsection actually be received by said owner, lessee or other person in control of such lot in order for the city to effectuate the removal or abatement thereof and levy the costs therefor against the lot, or exercise any other legal right or privilege granted to the city herein or elsewhere by law. 
(b)  Multiple notices violation. If any owner, lessee or other person in control of any lot shall actually be cited as provided for in subsection (a) of this section; any violation of section 14-148; or for more than three times in the aggregate, during any consecutive 12-month period; said person shall be subject to the civil penalties for such violations as set forth in section 14-147(a). Occurrences of such actual citations, wherein the city thereafter effects the removal or abatement of said high grass or miscellaneous refuse shall not constitute a violation of this section. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8; Code 1973, §§ 22-7(d), (e); Ord. of 5-1-1972, § 1; Ord. of 8-4-1975, § 1; Ord. of 9-2-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 90-285, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 93-339, § 1, 6-28-1993; Ord. No. 2000-195, § 1, 5-22-2000) 
Chapter 16 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of fire generally, § 167 et seq. 
State Law reference- State fire prevention and building code, Executive Law § 370 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Fires, miscellaneous outdoor burning, and smoke. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or other miscellaneous outdoor fire or authorize any such fire to be kindled or maintained within the city limits of the city without a permit from the chief of the fire department; provided, however, a person may kindle and maintain an outdoor fire if such fire is contained within a cooking grill or a burning device commonly known as a "chimenea" or similar device located outdoors and the fuel supply for the fire within the grill or "chimenea" is propane, natural gas or charcoal. 
(b)  Emissions prohibition. No person shall cause or allow emissions from an indoor or outdoor device used in the combustion of any organic or inorganic materials beyond the boundary lines of the property on or in which the fire or device is situated, the quantity and characteristic of which emissions unreasonably interferes with public safety and health. This prohibition applies but is not limited to any particulate, fume, gas, mist, odor, smoke, vapor, pollen, toxic or deleterious emission either alone or in combination with others. 
(Code 1973, § 9-1; Ord. of 9-3-1963, § 1; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 1, 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-2. - Telephonic fire alarm system. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Telephonic fire alarm system means any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to operate automatically through the use of public telephone facilities to transmit a signal, message or warning to another location. 
(b)  Permit. No person shall operate or maintain a telephonic alarm system which automatically transmits a signal, message or warning to the city fire department without first obtaining a permit as required by this section. 
(c)  Application for permit. Applications for permits to install, maintain or operate a telephonic alarm system which is intended to automatically transmit a signal, message or warning to the city fire department shall be filed with the fire chief on forms supplied by the city, together with a fee of $100.00. This fee will cover the first year of the permit. The person installing the system must maintain an adequate service organization to repair, maintain or otherwise service the alarm system used. 
(d)  Right of inspection. The fire chief or his representative shall have the right to inspect any telephonic alarm system on the premises where it is intended to function prior to issuance of any permit for its operation, and he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any time after issuance of a permit to determine whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this article. 
(e)  Annual permit fee. Each permit holder shall pay to the city on or before January 1 of each year, a fee in the amount of $100.00 to reimburse the city for the cost of providing the line to receive calls and other expenses of operation, for all present and future installations. 
(Code 1973, § 9-13; Ord. No. 82-104, § 1, 2-22-1982) 
Sec. 16-3. - Outdoor furnaces. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Outdoor furnace means any equipment, device or apparatus, or any part thereof, which is installed, affixed or situated outdoors for the primary purpose of combustion of fuel to produce heat or energy used as a component of a heating system providing heat for an interior space. 
(b)  Legislative intent. Certain manufacturers and retailers of outdoor furnaces contend that such devices may provide an economical alternative to conventional heating systems. Concerns have been raised regarding the safety and environmental impacts of these heating devices. State health and environmental agencies have received an increasing number of complaints from owners and tenants that these heating devices produce smoke that permeates buildings and homes causing not only a nuisance, but also environmental degradation and health problems. Given the density and proximity of residential units to other adjoining residential and commercial units within the city, the city council hereby finds that the existence of outdoor furnaces would create a nuisance and cause environmental degradation and health problems. 
(c)  Prohibitions. No person shall install, affix, situate or operate an outdoor furnace in the city. 
(d)  Exemptions; restrictions. Any outdoor furnace installed and operated prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, may not be extended or enlarged. No person shall cause, allow, maintain the use of, or operate an outdoor furnace installed or in operation prior to the effective date of this ordinance after October 31, 2006. Any person maintaining or operating an outdoor furnace in operation prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, shall comply with all laws and all ordinances and local laws of the city. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 2005-347, § 1, 10-3-2005) 
Secs. 16-4-16-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION 

Sec. 16-25. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bureau means the bureau of fire prevention and inspection services. 
    Owner, lessee, occupant, person or person in control of means any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, limited liability partnership and limited liability company. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.1; Code 1973, § 9-23; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-23), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-26. - Penalties. 
    Any owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of any building, premises or place violating any provision of this article, or neglecting to comply with any order issued pursuant to any section of this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.15; Code 1973, § 9-37) 
Sec. 16-27. - Created. 
    There is hereby created in the fire department of the city, a bureau of fire prevention and inspection services, which shall be known as the bureau, and shall be operated under the direction and supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.2; Code 1973, § 9-24; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-24), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-28. - Personnel. 
    The chief of the fire department is hereby authorized, empowered and ordered: 
(1)  To recommend to the city manager a member or members of the fire department for appointment to the position of fire marshal, who shall, as assistant to the chief, direct the operations of the bureau; and 
(2)  To assign such members of the fire department to make inspections and otherwise perform such functions of the bureau as are provided in this article, as may, in the opinion of the chief, from time to time be necessary. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.3; Code 1973, § 9-25; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-25), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-29. - Bureau-Duties. 
    The bureau is hereby charged with the duty of enforcing all laws and ordinances of the state, county and city, covering the following: 
(1)  Prevention of fires; 
(2)  Storage and use of inflammables and explosives; 
(3)  Installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment; 
(4)  The means and adequacy, in case of fire, of exits from schools, churches, hospitals, asylums, hotels, apartments, lodginghouses, factories, theaters, public halls, stores and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or congregate from time to time, for any purpose; 
(5)  The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fire; 
(6)  The conducting of fire prevention campaigns; and 
(7)  The enforcement of the building codes and fire codes of the state, and this Code and the zoning ordinance set forth in appendix B to this Code. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.4; Code 1973, § 9-26; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-26), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-30. - Same-Powers to inspect; fees. 
(a)  The bureau is hereby authorized and empowered to inspect: 
(1)  As often as necessary, but not less than once every three years, the following structures and contents as said structures are classified and defined in chapter 3 of the Building Code of New York State (hereinafter "BCNYS") of 2010, and as amended thereafter: 
a.  Classification R-2. Multiple dwelling, permanent occupancy (as defined in 3 BCNYS section 310). 
b.  Classification R-1. Multiple dwelling, transient occupancy (as defined in 3 BCNYS section 310). 
c.  Classification B. Business (as defined in 3 BCNYS section 304). 
(2)  As often as necessary, but not less than once every two years, the following structures and the contents thereof as said structures are classified and defined in chapter 3 of the BCNYS of 2010, and as amended thereafter: 
a.  Classification M. Mercantile (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 309). 
b.  Classification F. Industrial (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 306). 
c.  Classification S. Storage (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 311). 
d.  Classification I. Institutional (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 308). 
e.  Classification U. Miscellaneous (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 312). 
(3)  As often as necessary, but not less than once every two years, the following structures and the contents thereof as said structures are classified and defined in chapter 3 of the BCNYS of 2010, and as amended thereafter: 
a.  Classification A. Assembly (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 303). 
b.  Classification R-2. Multiple dwelling, senior citizen housing (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 310). 
c.  Classification I-1, R-3, R-4. Multiple dwelling, adult residential care facility (as defined at 3 BCNYS sections 308, 310). 
d.  Classification E. Educational, public and private (as defined at 3 BCNYS section 305). 
(b)  Fees for inspection. 
(1)  Upon completion of the inspection, the owner of each structure shall pay to the city an inspection fee in the amount of $50.00. This inspection fee shall cover up to one hour of inspection time. If an inspection goes beyond the first hour, the owner of the aforesaid structure shall pay the city an additional fee of $12.50 for each additional 15 minutes of inspection time. 
(2)  Should any inspection fee remain unpaid as of March 1, the city chamberlain shall add the unpaid fee as a separate line item to the city tax bill issued that year for the property upon which the structure is located and said unpaid fee shall constitute a lien upon such real property. If no city tax bill is issued to the owner, the corporation counsel is authorized to commence a civil action to recover the unpaid fee. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.6; Code 1973, § 9-27; Ord. No. 92-179, § 1, 4-20-1992; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-27), 6-14-2004; Ord. No. 2005-48, §§ 1-2, 2-7-2005; Ord. No. 2006-349, § 1, 10-16-2006; Ord. No. 2009-102, § 1, 3-2-2009; Ord. No. 2010-408, § 1, 12-20-2010; Ord. No. 2016-59, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-2016) 
Sec. 16-31. - Reports of inspections. 
    Members of the bureau conducting inspections pursuant to section 16-30, shall report in writing the result of such inspections to the fire marshal, who shall keep a record of the same. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.6; Code 1973, § 9-28; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-28), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-32. - Powers of bureau to order removal of fire hazards. 
    If it shall appear from any written report made pursuant to section 16-31, that the bureau member making the inspection found in any building, or upon any premises or other place inspected: 
(1)  Combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulations of rubbish or unnecessary accumulations of wastepaper, boxes, shavings; 
(2)  Any highly flammable materials likely to cause a fire, which are so situated as to create danger of fire; or 
(3)  Obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows, which might interfere with the operation of the fire department or with egress of occupants in case of fire; 
the fire marshal shall, in writing, order same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of any such building, or upon any such premises or other such place, as the case may be. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.7; Code 1973, § 9-29; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-29), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-33. - Power of bureau to order appliances installed or placed to proper condition. 
    If it shall appear from any written report made pursuant to section 16-31, that the bureau member making the inspection found in any building, or upon any premises or other place inspected that: 
(1)  The appliances thereon or therein for the protection against fire are not in proper condition, or are of insufficient size or number, or are otherwise insufficient for the purpose which the same were designed or intended; or 
(2)  Any additional appliances for the prevention of fire are reasonably necessary for the protection of any such building, or upon any such premises, or other such place; 
the fire marshal shall, in writing, order: in the case of any such improper condition or insufficiency, that the same be placed in proper condition and rendered sufficient to afford reasonable protection against fire; in the case of absence of any such appliances, where they are found to be reasonably necessary, that such necessary appliances be installed; and such order shall forthwith be complied. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.8; Code 1973, § 9-30; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-30), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-34. - Service of orders. 
    Any order issued by the fire marshal pursuant to sections 16-32 and 16-33, shall be directed to the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the building, premises or other place complained against; and service of any such order may be made either: 
(1)  By personal delivery of a copy thereof to the person named therein; 
(2)  By leaving a copy with the person in control of such premises; 
(3)  By mailing a copy to the person named in such order; 
(4)  By leaving a copy with any person of suitable age and discretion in charge or apparent charge of premises and mailing a copy to the person named in such order; or 
(5)  On absence of such person, by affixing a copy of such order in a prominent place on the exterior of such premises and mailing a copy to the person named in such order. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.9; Code 1973, § 9-31; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-31), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-35. - Right to appeal. 
(a)  If any owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the building, premises or other place complained against, shall consider himself aggrieved by any order issued under sections 16-32 and 16-33, he may, within 48 hours after such order has been served upon him, appeal from such order to the city manager, who shall thereupon order a hearing. 
(b)  The city manager shall have power to suspend the operation of any such order pending his consideration thereof, and to modify or reverse the same, but unless any such order is thus suspended, modified or reversed, it shall remain in full force and effect.
