(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.10; Code 1973, § 9-32) 
Sec. 16-36. - Duty of owner, etc. 
    The owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of any building, premises or other place complained against shall, except as he may otherwise be excused or directed by the city manager under section 16-35, promptly comply with the terms of any order issued by the fire marshal under section 16-32 and 16-33. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.11; Code 1973, § 9-33; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-33), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-37. - Additional powers of inspection. 
    The bureau, upon reasonable complaint of any person or entity, shall inspect any building, premises or other place complained against, including the interior of private dwellings; provided, however, that in case of a request for inspection of the interior of a private dwelling, the person requesting the same shall present to the bureau either: 
(1)  The written consent to such inspection by all persons whose consent therefor is or may be necessary; or 
(2)  A copy of an order or an administrative search warrant issued by a court of record, having requisite jurisdiction, directing that such inspection shall be made. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.12; Code 1973, § 9-34; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-34), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-38. - Liability for costs and expenses. 
    In the event any fire shall result directly or indirectly from any omission to comply properly with any order issued under section 16-32 and 16-33, the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of any building, premises or other place complained against in any such order, to whom such order shall have been directed, shall be liable to the city for the payment of all costs and expenses of the fire department incurred in and about the use of employees, apparatus and materials in the extinguishment of any such fire resulting from any such cause. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.13; Code 1973, § 9-35) 
Sec. 16-39. - All fires to be investigated. 
(a)  The bureau shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring in the city by which either persons or property have been injured or damaged, and, so far as possible, shall determine if the fire is the result of either carelessness or design. Such investigation shall be made during or immediately following such fire, and if it shall appear to the member making such investigation that such fire is of suspicious origin, the fire marshal or assistant fire marshal or their designee and the chief of the fire department shall be immediately notified of the fact, and they shall then take charge of the investigation and notify the proper authorities designated by law to pursue the investigation of such matters, and shall cooperate with the authorities in the collection of evidence and the prosecution of the cause. 
(b)  Every fire shall be reported in writing to the bureau, within two days after its occurrence, by the officer of the fire department in charge of the fire. Such report shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the fire chief and shall contain a statement of all facts relating to the cause, origin and circumstances of such fire, the extent of the damage caused thereby and the issuance, if any, upon such property, and such other information as may be required by the bureau. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 31.14; Code 1973, § 9-36; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 3(9-36), 6-14-2004) 
Secs. 16-40-16-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 16-68. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code adopted by this article or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the chief of the fire department or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed therein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of any penalty for such violations shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1973, § 9-55) 
Sec. 16-69. - Adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts the New York State Fire Code which is part of the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code of 2010 for the purposes of establishing the minimum requirements consistent with nationally recognized good practice for providing a reasonable level of life safety and property protection from the hazards of fire, explosion or dangerous conditions in new and existing buildings, structures and premises, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length in this chapter, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 9-48; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 4(9-48), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-70. - Enforcement. 
    The state fire code adopted by this article shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention and inspection services of the fire department of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 9-50; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 4(9-50), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-71. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the fire department shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code adopted by this article upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of such code, provided that the spirit of such code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the fire department thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1973, § 9-51) 
Sec. 16-72. - Permits in addition to those required by code. 
    The city manager and the chief of the fire department shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies which shall require permits in addition to those now enumerated in the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code adopted by the ordinance from which this article is derived. The chief of the fire department shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1973, § 9-52; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 4(9-52), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-73. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for under the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code adopted by the ordinance from which this article is derived, or when it is claimed that the provisions of such code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal pursuant to the process set forth in the New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code as provided. 
(Code 1973, § 9-53; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 4(9-53), 6-14-2004) 
Sec. 16-74. - Annual report of proceedings under code; recommendation as to amendments. 
    A report of the bureau shall be made annually and transmitted to the city manager. Such report shall contain all proceedings under the fire prevention code adopted by this article, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein. The chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1973, § 9-54; Ord. No. 2004-208, § 4(9-54), 6-14-2004) 
Chapter 18 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Refrigerators, iceboxes, etc. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Refrigerator or icebox or other container means any box or container which has a compartment of more than 11/2 cubic feet capacity and a door or lid which locks or fastens automatically when closed and which cannot easily be opened from the inside, which is large enough for a child to enter, and which has no other means for the admission of air adequate to sustain human life. 
(b)  Restriction on use. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling, or other place accessible to children, any refrigerator, icebox or other container unless the same shall be protected against entry by any child, or unless the door or lid or snaplock or other closing device be first removed. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, §§ 43.19-43.21; Code 1973, § 15-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Penal Law § 270.10. 
Sec. 18-2. - Bean shooters, slingshots, stones, etc. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall use any bean shooter, slingshot or other instrument for throwing bullets, stones or other missiles, or possess or carry the same with the intention of using it. No person shall cast or throw any stone, stick or other missile in, from or to any street or public place. 
(b)  Children under 16 not to be confined. No person under the age of 16 years arrested under subsection (a) of this section shall be placed in confinement, but may be detained by the police until the child's parents or guardians are notified of such arrest and arrange to take such child home. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person 16 years of age or older violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a fine of not more than $25.00 for each such violation, or by imprisonment not more than 15 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Any person under the age of 16 years shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of law relating to juvenile delinquents. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, §§ 84.2-84.4; Code 1973, § 15-2) 
State Law reference- Possession of slingshots or slungshots, Penal Law § 265.01; possession of certain weapons by persons under 16 years of age, Penal Law § 265.05. 
Sec. 18-3. - Parades. 
(a)  No procession containing more than 100 persons or 20 or more vehicles, excepting funerals, the military forces of the United States and the state, and the police and fire departments of the city, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in pursuance to a permit issued by the mayor. Upon application being made to him by the sponsor or sponsors of a parade, the mayor may issue a permit therefor specifying the date, hours and route such parade shall follow. In exercising his discretion on the issuance of a permit, the mayor shall consider the date and time of day of the proposed parade, the number of persons or vehicles involved, the route requested, and if in his opinion, based on a consideration of this section, unreasonable interference with traffic or the peace and quiet of the community will result, such permit may be denied. 
(b)  If less than 100 persons, the city clerk shall obtain a written statement from the person applying that there is less than 100 persons or less than 20 vehicles. 
(c)  Insurance to be filed for the permit shall be as follows: 
(1)  $100,000.00/$300,000.00 bodily injury; 
(2)  $5,000.00 property damage. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.1; Code 1973, § 15-4; Ord. of 3-16-1966) 
State Law reference- Parades, General City Law § 5; Vehicle and Traffic Law, §§ 1630, 1660. 
Sec. 18-4. - Shopping carts. 
(a)  Definitions. The following terms, whenever used in this section, shall be deemed to mean and include: 
    Person means a natural person of either sex, corporation, partnerships, associations, joint stock companies, societies and all other entities capable of being sued. 
    Public place means a street, avenue, road, alley, public passageway, land, highway, concourse, driveway, culvert, crosswalk and sidewalk, pedestrian mall and every class of road, square and municipal or private parking field used by the general public. 
    Shopping cart means any cart, basket, container or other device made of wire, metal, plastic or other material, mounted on wheels, manually operated, and identified as required herein, such as is generally provided by merchants for the conveyance of merchandise, foodstuffs and other property to automobiles and other places. 
(b)  Conspicuous identification. Every person who owns, or makes available to the public, in connection with the conduct of business and trade any shopping cart shall mark it or cause the same to be marked and identified conspicuously with the name of the owner. Such identification shall be in the form of metal tags securely fastened to the cart or a cutting or stamping on the frame of the cart or other means for permanently identifying the owner of the cart. 
(c)  Unlawful removal and possession. It shall be unlawful for any person, his agent or employee to take, remove or possess any shopping cart beyond the premises of the identified owner of the shopping cart without the express permission of the identified owner. 
(d)  Penalty for unlawful removal or possession. Any person who violates any provision of subsection (c) of this section shall be liable for and pay a penalty of: 
(1)  $10.00 for the first such violation; and 
(2)  Not less than $25.00 or more than $50.00 for each subsequent violation. 
Each removal or possession of a shopping cart shall constitute a separate violation. 
(e)  Unlawful abandonment. It shall be unlawful for any person, his agent or employee to leave or to suffer or permit to be left unattended any shopping cart, either: 
(1)  Owned by the person or in such person's possession, custody or control; 
(2)  At any public place within the city; or 
(3)  Upon the property of another; 
without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(f)  Remedy for abandoned shopping carts. 
(1)  The director of public works of the city is hereby authorized to seize and remove or cause to be removed any abandoned shopping cart within the city from: 
a.  Any public place without notice; and 
b.  Any private premises with the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises; and 
shall take or cause the same to be taken to a facility within the city for redemption or disposition as hereinafter provided. 
(2)  The director of public works is authorized to call upon other city agencies or departments to assist in enforcement of this section. 
(g)  Redemption. 
(1)  Notification. Whenever the director of public works shall take possession of any shopping cart as herein specified, and such shopping cart contains identification of ownership, a notice shall be sent by ordinary mail to the address of such person purported to be the owner of the cart as designated on the cart advising that such property is held by the city and advising the amount necessary to redeem. If the shopping cart does not contain identification of ownership, as required herein, then the same shall be disposed of in the same manner as unclaimed property as set forth in subsection (h) of this section. 
(2)  Procedure; costs; immunity of city. Any shopping cart may be redeemed by the owner thereof at any time prior to the sale, dismantling, destruction or disposal thereof upon tendering the sum of $25.00 for each cart to the director of public services. In addition, the person seeking to redeem shall be required to pay the cost of advertising the sale thereof, if any. No property shall be delivered to a person seeking to redeem the same unless proof establishing, to the satisfaction of the director or public services, such person's ownership is submitted. Any delivery to a person apparently entitled thereto shall be a good defense to the city against any other person claiming to be entitled thereto, but if the person to whom delivery is made is in fact not entitled thereto, the person to whom the same ought to have been delivered may recover the same, with interest and costs, from the person to whom the same shall have been delivered. 
(h)  Disposal of unclaimed property. 
(1)  When any shopping cart remains in the custody of the director of public services after the expiration of ten calendar days immediately following the date of the mailing of notification pursuant to subsection (g)(1) of this section and no person has redeemed the same, the director of public services may dispose of the shopping cart by delivering the cart to a scrap iron dealer within the city offering the highest scrap price at the time of disposal. Disposition of such property pursuant to this section shall be without liability on the part of the city to the owner of such property or other person lawfully entitled thereto or having an interest therein. 
(2)  All proceeds received from the disposal of shopping carts pursuant to this section shall be deposited to the city's general fund. 
(Code 1973, § 15-5; Ord. No. 86-546, § 1, 9-26-1986; Ord. No. 2005-309, § 1, 9-6-2005; Ord. No. 2008-272, § 1, 8-4-2008; Ord. No. 2008-330, § 1, 9-29-2008) 
State Law reference- Shopping carts, General Business Law § 399-q. 
Secs. 18-5-18-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW FOR MINORS 

Sec. 18-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency errand means a trip taken to perform a specific task to help to bring aid or comfort or to resolve an unexpected or sudden occurrence which immediately threatens private or public health or safety. 
    Guardian means any person other than a parent, who has legal guardianship of a minor. 
    Minor means a person 16 years of age or younger. 
    Parent means the natural or adoptive parent of a minor. 
    Public place means any street, alley, highway or other public thoroughfare, sidewalk, park, playground or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment or other lawful purpose in the city. The term "public place" includes, but is not limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, drugstore, pool room, shopping center and any other place devoted to amusement or open to the general public. The term "public place" also includes the front or immediate area of the places set forth in this definition. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 3, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 2, 5-3-2004) 
Sec. 18-28. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any minor under the age of 16 years of age violating the provisions of this article for the first or second time shall be dealt with in accordance with the procedures contained in section 18-33. Any such minor having violated the provisions of this article on more than two occasions shall be summoned in to the city's youth court; 
(b)  Any minor 16 years of age who is convicted for violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a violation punishable by a fine of not more than: 
(1)  $25.00 for the first conviction; 
(2)  $50.00 for the second conviction; and 
(3)  $100.00 thereafter, or by a term of imprisonment not to exceed 15 days, or be required to perform community service, or any combination thereof. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 8, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2003-239, § 2, 1-14-2003; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 7, 5-3-2004; Ord. No. 2011-273, § 1, 9-12-2011) 
Sec. 18-29. - Purpose. 
    The city council determines that a curfew is necessary to further the public health, safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city and specifically to further the following interests: 
(1)  The reduction of the incidence of juvenile criminal activity and vandalism; 
(2)  The protection of children from others on the street during the nighttime hours; and 
(3)  The promotion and enforcement or parental control and responsibility for the children. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 2, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 1, 5-3-2004) 
Sec. 18-30. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to remain in or upon any public street, park, vacant lot or other public place between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(Ord. No. 2004-151, § 3, 5-3-2004) 
Sec. 18-31. - Exceptions. 
    A minor shall not be in violation of the article: 
(1)  Any time that the minor is accompanied by his parent, legal guardian or other responsible person over the age of 21 years and approved in writing in advance by the minor's parent or legal guardian; 
(2)  If the minor is on an emergency errand as directed by his parent or legal guardian; 
(3)  If the minor is legally employed, for the period from one-half hour before to one-half hour after work, while going directly between his home and place of employment. This exception shall also apply if the minor is in a public place during the curfew hours in the course of his employment. To come under the exception, the minor must be carrying a written statement from the employer attesting to the place and hours of employment; 
(4)  Until the hours of 12:30 a.m., if the minor is on the property of or the sidewalk directly adjacent to the building in which he resides or the building immediately adjacent thereto, if the owner of the adjacent building has not objected to the minor and the place; 
(5)  If the minor is coming directly home from a school activity or an activity of a religious or other voluntary association or place of public entertainment such as a movie, play or sporting event. This exception will apply for one-half hour after the completion of such event, but in no case beyond 12:30 a.m. If the event is not commercial entertainment in nature and does not have a fixed, publicly known time at which it will end, the sponsoring organization must register the event with the police department at least 24 hours in advance, informing it of the time such event is scheduled to begin, the place at which it shall be held, the time at which it shall end, and the name of the sponsoring organization; and 
(6)  If the minor is exercising the First Amendment rights protected by the Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, speech or assembly, provided the minor first has given notice to the city manager or his designee by delivering a written communication signed by the minor and countersigned by a parent or guardian of the minor which specifies when, where, in what manner and for what First Amendment purpose the minor will be on the streets at night during the curfew period. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 4, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 4, 5-3-2004) 
Sec. 18-32. - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for a parent, legal guardian or person having the physical custody of the minor to knowingly permit or by inadequate supervision allow a minor to be in or upon any public place during the period of time prohibited by this article under circumstances not constituting an exception as specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 6, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 5, 5-3-2004) 
Sec. 18-33. - Enforcement. 
(a)  If a police officer reasonably believes that a person is in a public place in violation of this article, the officer shall notify the person of such violations and shall require the person to provide his name, address, telephone number and how to contact his parents. In determining the age of the person and in the absence of convincing evidence, such as a birth certificate or driver's license, the officer shall use his best judgment in determining age. 
(b)  The officer may issue an appearance ticket or tickets as the circumstances require. 
(c)  If the officer determines or has reason to believe that a person is in violation of this article, he may take the person to police headquarters where a parent shall be immediately notified and required to report to police headquarters and procure the person, whereupon the parent shall be questioned to ascertain, within constitutional limit, the relevant facts. The minor shall be released to the custody of a parent or guardian. If a parent or guardian cannot be located or fails to take charge of the minor, the minor may be temporarily entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will assume responsibility of caring for the minor pending availability of a parent. 
(d)  In the case of a first violation by a minor, the police department shall serve a parent, legal guardian or person having physical custody of the minor with written notice of the violation with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including enforcement of parental responsibility and applicable penalties. Service shall be made either by personal service upon the parent, legal guardian or person having physical custody of the minor, or by mailing, by first class mail, to the parent, legal guardian or person having physical custody of the minor at his last known residence address. 
(Ord. No. 2002-405, §§ 1, 7, 11-4-2002; Ord. No. 2003-239, § 1, 1-14-2003; Ord. No. 2004-151, § 6, 5-3-2004) 
Secs. 18-34-18-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC ORDER 

Sec. 18-55. - Open alcoholic beverages container prohibition. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this Code of Ordinances, it shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To possess any open container containing any alcoholic beverage on any public sidewalk, street, highway, public parking lot, public park or cemetery within the city under circumstances evincing an intent to consume the contents of said container upon any such public land; or 
(2)  To consume any alcoholic beverage on any public sidewalk, street, highway, public parking lot, public park or cemetery within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 15-26; Ord. No. 80-532, § 1, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 84-411, § 1, 7-23-1984; Ord. No. 90-660, § 1, 10-22-1990; Ord. No. 2017-99, § 1, 4-17-2017) 
Sec. 18-56. - Exceptions. 
    Sections 18-55 and 18-57 shall not apply to or within the boundaries of Grove Park or Eldridge Park during the times when said parks are open to the public, nor shall these sections apply to events within any public park authorized by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 15-27; Ord. No. 80-532, § 1, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 84-411, § 1, 7-23-1984; Ord. No. 93-531, § 1, 10-4-1993) 
Sec. 18-57. - Penalties. 
    In addition to the general penalties as set forth in section 1-14, any person violating any of the terms of sections 18-55 and 18-56 shall be liable to a fine not to exceed $25.00 for each violation thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 15-28; Ord. No. 80-532, § 1, 9-8-1980; Ord. No. 84-411, § 1, 7-23-1984) 
Sec. 18-58. - Skateboard use. 
(a)  Prohibited locations. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, use or otherwise operate a skateboard or roller skates in any of the following places in the city: 
(1)  Municipal parking garages; 
(2)  Upon the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or parking lots within the downtown business area bounded by Second Street on the north, Chemung River on the south, Lake Street on the east and College Avenue on the west. The sidewalks on both sides of the boundary streets shall be part of the prohibited area; 
(3)  Upon the municipal bridges spanning the Chemung River; 
(4)  Upon South Main Street or the sidewalks adjacent thereto from the Main Street Bridge to Franklin Street; 
(5)  On the properties owned by the Elmira Housing Authority, known as Bragg Towers (formerly known as Newtown Towers) and Edward J. Flannery Apartments (formerly Southport Towers), or the sidewalks immediately adjacent to such properties; 
(6)  Within Grove Park and Brand Park. 
(b)  Penalty. A violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, §§ 15-29, 5-30; Ord. No. 90-329, § 1, 5-21-1990) 
Sec. 18-59. - Disposition of skateboards and skates. 
    Upon issuance of a citation for the alleged violation of section 18-58(a), the alleged violator shall be subject to immediate seizure of the skateboard or roller skates being used. In the event of final disposition of the citation in favor of the alleged violator, the seized skateboard or roller skates shall be returned to the owner. In the event the alleged violator is found guilty of the violation, the city may return the skateboard or roller skates in the interest of justice and for good cause shown. 
(Code 1973, § 15-31; Ord. No. 90-329, § 1, 5-21-1990) 
Secs. 18-60-18-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VANDALISM 

Sec. 18-77. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Legal guardian means a person appointed as guardian or given custody of a minor child by a court, other than the local department of social services or foster parents. 
    Minor means a person who has obtained ten years of age but who has not yet reached 18 years of age. 
    Parent includes the lawful mother or father of an unemancipated minor, whether by birth or adoption. 
    Person means the city or any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, government unit, government agency or organization of any kind. 
    Property includes any real estate, including improvements thereon, and tangible personality. 
    Vandalism means: 
(1)  The willful or malicious damaging or defacing, within the corporate limits of the city, of another person's real or personal property without the person's consent; or 
(2)  Entry into or the obtaining control over any motor vehicle, bicycle, aircraft or watercraft of another person, without the other person's consent. 
(Code 1973, § 15-61; Ord. No. 89-626, § 1, 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 18-78. - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of an act of vandalism as defined in section 18-77 shall be subject to penalties as follows: 
(1)  A fine not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00; 
(2)  A period of conditional discharge pursuant to terms and conditions as permitted under the penal laws of the state, in effect at the time of the imposition of the conditional discharge; or 
(3)  Court costs. 
(Code 1973, § 15-64; Ord. No. 89-626, § 1, 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 18-79. - Prohibition. 
    All acts of vandalism are hereby declared to be unlawful. 
(Code 1973, § 15-62; Ord. No. 89-626, § 1, 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 18-80. - Issuance of complaint. 
    The city or any other person whose property is damaged may make a complaint for the enforcement of this article, provided the proceedings are brought in the name of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 15-63; Ord. No. 89-626, § 1, 11-6-1989) 
Sec. 18-81. - Liability of parent, legal guardian of minor offender. 
    The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for any fine or condition or restitution imposed by a court upon an unemancipated minor for violation of this article if such minor has not paid such fine or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court, and further, if such parent or legal guardian has been made a party defendant in all enforcement proceedings against the unemancipated minor for violation of the article and shall be served with all citations, summons, complaints, notices and other documents required to be served on the unemancipated minor defendant. 
(Code 1973, § 15-65; Ord. No. 89-626, § 1, 11-6-1989) 
ARTICLE V. - CITY BUILDINGS-DEADLY WEAPON 

Sec. 18-85. - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that: (1) deadly weapons often cause accidental deaths and injuries and are frequently used in the commission of crimes, particularly homicides and assaults; (2) physical possession of deadly weapons in city buildings by persons other than those on official business with authorization to carry such weapons poses a serious threat to the health, safety and general welfare of city public servants and other persons lawfully in city buildings; and (3) the presence of deadly weapons in city buildings, except by certain authorized officials, may seriously impair the performance of essential government functions by way of threat or intimidation to city public servants or others. Therefore, as owner or lessee of buildings in the city and in its proprietary capacity, the city desires to prohibit deadly weapons in city buildings, except as otherwise provided in section 18-88 below. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 1, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 18-86. - Definitions. 
    City Building(s) shall mean all buildings owned or leased by the City. The current list of city buildings shall be kept, updated and maintained by the County of Chemung/city's superintendent of buildings and grounds. 
    Deadly Weapon shall be defined as set forth in paragraph 12 of section 10 of the New York State Penal Law and means any loaded weapon from which a shot, readily capable of producing death or other serious physical injury, may be discharged, or a switchblade knife, gravity knife, pilum ballistic knife, metal knuckle knife, dagger, billy, blackjack, or metal knuckles. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 2, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 18-87. - Physical possession of deadly weapons in city buildings prohibited. 
    No person shall enter into and/or remain in a city building while in physical possession of a deadly weapon either openly or concealed unless such person is a person described in section 18-88 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 3, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 18-88. - Exceptions. 
    Prohibition of physical possession of deadly weapons in city buildings shall not apply to (1) a police officer or peace officer authorized to use the same while acting within the scope of employment; (2) a government employee or licensed security guard authorized or required by employment or office to possess the same while acting within the scope of such employment or office; (3) a person in the military service of the State of New York or the United States when duly authorized to possess the same and acting within the scope of such military service; (4) an elected city officer having a duly issued permit to possess a deadly weapon; and (5) a city official or city employee, specifically authorized by the city's chief of police to possess a deadly weapon in city buildings subject to any and all restrictions or limitations which the city council or city manager may place upon such authorization. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 4, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 18-89. - Signs. 
(a)  The city's superintendent of buildings and grounds shall post, on walls, windows or other locations as the superintendent shall deem most visible to members of the general public entering the city building, a sign with a red background and white lettering in no less than 9/16" size type reading as follows: 
  
NOTICE: 
NOTICE> 
CARRYING OR PHYSICALLY POSSESSING A FIREARM OR OTHER 
DEADLY WEAPON WHILE IN THIS BUILDING IS 
DEADLY WEAPON WHILE IN THIS BUILDING I> 
CARRYING OR PHYSICALLY POSSESSING A FIREARM OR OTHE> 
PROHIBITED BY LOCAL ORDINANCE 
(CHAPER 18, ARTICLE V, CODE OF ORDINANCES) 
(CHAPER 18, ARTICLE V, CODE OF ORDINANCES> 
PROHIBITED BY LOCAL ORDINANC> 
  
(b)  Neither the absence nor the location of a sign may be used as a defense to a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 5, 6-11-2018) 
Sec. 18-90. - Penalties. 
    Unless excepted from application of this article, any person who, in disobedience of this article, shall carry or otherwise be in physical possession of a deadly weapon in a city building shall be guilty of trespass, as an unclassified misdemeanor, and subject to punishment by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Violations of this article shall be prosecuted by the district attorney as any other crime. Each day or part of a day which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth herein, the city at its option may also maintain a civil trespass action and/or seek civil injunctions, to be prosecuted by the corporation counsel. 
(Ord. No. 2018-144, § 6, 6-11-2018) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of highways generally, § 77 et seq.; common counsel to be commissioner of highways, § 77; control over streets, etc., § 154. 
State Law reference- Power of city relative to streets, General City Law § 20(7); bridges, tunnels and ferries, and approaches thereto, General City Law § 20(9); public improvements, General City Law § 20(11). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Interference with construction prohibited. 
    No person shall hinder or obstruct or in any way interfere with any excavation or opening in, upon or under any street, sidewalk or alley in the city; nor shall any person in any manner interfere or tamper with any building or other materials placed therein or thereupon; nor shall any unauthorized person remove or in any way interfere with any guardrails, lamps, flares or other warning devices erected or placed for the public safety at any obstruction in any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.2; Code 1973, § 22-1) 
Sec. 20-2. - Guardrails and lights required at excavations. 
(a)  No person shall dig, or cause or permit to be dug, any excavation adjacent to or within four feet of the line of any street, sidewalk or alley in the city without placing and maintaining sufficient guardrails about such excavation to secure the public safety; and at all times between sunset and sunrise there shall be kept and maintained by such person at such excavation, on and along such guardrails, lighted red colored lamps or flares or other lighted warning devices so placed as to give reasonable and adequate warning to all persons using any such street, sidewalk or alley of the obstruction created by such excavation. 
(b)  If any person shall fail to maintain such guardrails or warning lights, or should any which are maintained be considered by the city manager to be inadequate to secure the public safety, the city manager, after 24 hours after giving notice of such inadequacy, may, if such inadequacy is not corrected, cause the placing of such additional guardrails and warning lights as are considered adequate, and the expense thereof shall be borne by the person in default. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.3; Code 1973, § 22-2) 
Sec. 20-3. - Obstructions on sidewalks, streets, right-of ways prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means any device having two or more wheels, upon which one or more persons as may ride and which is propelled by human power through a belt, chain or gears. 
    Operate means riding upon said bicycle in any manner whereby the operator's feet are not touching the ground. 
(b)  Recreational activities. No person shall engage in any activity on any public sidewalk, street or right-of-way, or place or caused to be placed, any item or object thereon, except as otherwise lawfully permitted to do so by this section, which would tend to interfere with the normal, intended use of said sidewalk, street or right-of-way, regardless of whether or not such interference actually takes place. 
(1)  Bicycles on sidewalks. No person, regardless of age, shall operate a bicycle upon any public sidewalk located within any business district of the city. In addition, no person 14 years of age or older shall operate a bicycle upon any public sidewalk within the city. 
(2)  Penalties. 
a.  Upon witnessing a violation of this section committed by a minor under the age of 16 years, any police officer in the city may immediately seize said bicycle which shall be relinquished only to the parent or legal guardian of said minor child in accordance with the redemption procedure as set forth herein. In no event however, shall such minor child be ticketed or placed under arrest for a violation of this section. 
b.  Upon witnessing a violation of this section committed by any individual 16 years of age or older, any police officer in the city may: 
1.  Immediately seize said bicycle which shall be relinquished to the accused in accordance with the redemption procedure as set forth herein; and/or 
2.  Issue an appearance ticket, citation or the like to the accused. 
c.  A violation of this section shall be deemed a violation of law for the first two occurrences within a one-year period and a misdemeanor for each consecutive violation thereafter within the same one-year period. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of: 
1.  $10.00 for the first such occurrence in a one-year period; 
2.  $25.00 for the second such occurrence within a one-year period; and 
3.  No less than $75.00 nor more than $250.00, and/or ten days incarceration for each consecutive violation thereafter within the same one-year period. 
(3)  Redemption of bicycles. Any police office who seizes a bicycle pursuant to this section shall retain custody of said bicycle in accordance with standard police procedures, and shall relinquish same to the parent or legal guardian of the accused minor, or to the accused individual if said individual is at the time of redemption 16 years of age or older, upon payment of an impoundment fee of: 
a.  $10.00 for the first such occurrence within a one-year period; 
b.  $25.00 for the second such occurrence within a one-year period; and 
c.  $75.00 for each consecutive violation thereafter within a one-year period. 
The impoundment fees set forth in this subsection are in addition to any fines or penalty as may be provided for in this section. 
(c)  Commercial activities. No person shall place, or cause to be placed, any merchandise, display rack, item or other object on any public sidewalk, street or right-of-way except as otherwise lawfully permitted to do so by this section. Unless otherwise prohibited, and the owner or agent of a duly licensed business establishment may place merchandise, display racks, items or other objects on city sidewalks directly in front of said business establishment; provided, however: 
(1)  A clear and unobstructed space of at least four feet on said sidewalk, as measured from its outermost edge, is left thereon through which pedestrian traffic may safely pass; 
(2)  Such objects so placed within the aforesaid area on any such sidewalk shall remain thereon only between the hours of sunrise and sunset; and 
(3)  Any such merchandise item, or object which stands less than two feet in height shall be placed on a sturdy table, stand or other riser not less than two feet in height. 
(d)  Telephone booths. The city council may authorize the mayor to enter into an agreement with a service provider to place telephone booths and related facilities upon the street and sidewalks and public grounds of the city under the supervision of the director of public services. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.4; Code 1973, § 22-3; Ord. of 4-30-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 98-210, § 1, 4-27-1998) 
Sec. 20-4. - Use of trap doors. 
    No subway trapdoor, manhole, grate or chute of any kind having an entrance in any street, sidewalk or alley, or which is adjacent to any street, sidewalk or alley in the city, shall be open at anytime except while being necessarily used for the purpose for which it was constructed, and during such time the same shall be surrounded by sufficient guardrails and warning lights to secure the public safety. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.5; Code 1973, § 22-4) 
Sec. 20-5. - Water conveyors leading to sidewalk to be kept clean. 
    The owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of any building in the city, shall, to protect any sidewalk adjacent to such building from any flow of water from such building, at all times keep and maintain in good repair all conductors, gutters, pipes, spouts and drains of every kind for receiving and conveying water from such buildings. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.6; Code 1973, § 22-5) 
Sec. 20-6. - Refuse not to be deposited in streets. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Deposit, place or scatter ashes, leaves or wastepaper or other refuse of any kind in or upon any street, sidewalk or alley in the city; or 
(2)  In or upon any such street, sidewalk or alley burn any leaves, wastepaper or refuse of any kind. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.7; Code 1973, § 22-6) 
Sec. 20-7. - Electrified or barbed-wire fences. 
    No person shall construct or maintain an electrified fence or a barbed-wire fence, or a fence of which barbed wire is a part, except that strands of barbed wire may be used on the top of a fence of other material when such fence is at least six feet in height. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.8(1); Code 1973, § 22-8) 
Sec. 20-8. - Construction of booths, etc. 
    No person shall erect or place, or cause to be erected or placed, upon any street, sidewalk or alley in the city, any stall or booth of any kind for the purpose of displaying, selling or offering for sale any goods, wares or merchandise, except that on holidays or other special occasions the mayor may by permit sanction the erection and use of such stalls or booths for limited periods of time. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.9; Code 1973, § 22-9) 
Sec. 20-9. - Fishing from bridges prohibited. 
    No person shall occupy any bridge within the city, except between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., for the purpose of fishing therefrom. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.10; Code 1973, § 22-10) 
Secs. 20-10-20-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-37. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  The person to whom a permit is issued under this article, upon completion of the purpose for which any such excavation or opening is made, and within the period of time specified in such permit, or any extension or extensions thereof, shall cause the surface of the street, sidewalk or alley in, upon or under which any such excavation or opening shall have been made, to be restored in all respects to its condition prior to such excavation or opening, as shall be approved by the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager shall prepare specifications for the refilling of trenches, for foundations and for wearing surfaces; and the person to whom such a permit is issued shall abide by such specifications in making such restoration. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.6; Code 1973, § 22-21) 
Sec. 20-38. - Use of lights and guardrails. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the person making or causing or permitting any excavation or opening in, upon or under any street, sidewalk or alley, pursuant to a permit issued under this article, to place and maintain sufficient guardrails about such excavation or opening to secure the public safety; and at all times between sunset and sunrise to keep lighted red colored lamps or red flares or other lighted warning devices on and along such guardrails, so placed as to give reasonable and adequate warning of the obstruction created by any such excavation or opening to all persons using any such street, sidewalk or alley. 
(b)  The requirements of this section shall be applicable to any person acting under contract with the city and to duly authorized city employees acting in the course of their employment. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.7; Code 1973, § 22-22) 
Sec. 20-39. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each such violation. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.8; Code 1973, § 22-23) 
Secs. 20-40-20-66. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 20-67. - Required. 
    No person, unless he is acting under a contract with the city, or unless he is a duly authorized city employee acting in the course of his employment, shall make, or cause or permit to be made, any excavation or opening of any kind in, upon or under any street, sidewalk or alley in the city, without having first obtained and having in full force and effect a permit so to do as provided in this division. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.2; Code 1973, § 22-29) 
Sec. 20-68. - Application. 
(a)  A person desiring to procure a permit required by this division shall file with the city manager a written application which shall contain: 
(1)  The name and residence or business address of the applicant; 
(2)  The exact location where it is desired to make the excavation or opening; 
(3)  The kind of surface thereon presently; 
(4)  The name and residence or business address, if other than the applicant, of the person for whom the proposed excavation or opening is to be made; and 
(5)  The estimated time it will take to make such proposed excavation or opening. 
(b)  The city manager, when he deems it necessary, may require that such application be supplemented by a sketch or tracing showing the location, character and dimensions of the proposed excavation or opening. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.3; Code 1973, § 22-30) 
Sec. 20-69. - Issuance; fee; term, etc. 
(a)  The city manager, upon receipt of an application for a permit under this division, may issue a permit authorizing the applicant to make, or cause or permit to be made, the excavation or opening in, upon or under the street, sidewalk or alley at the located specified therein; provided, however, that such applicant shall agree to indemnify the city against loss or damage resulting by reason of excavation or opening. There shall be no fees for such permits for new one- or two-family construction. For all other cases, such application shall be accompanied by the following fees for the permit: 
Location Fee  
If pavement area is: 
< 1-year old road ..... $250.00 
< 2-year old road ..... 225.00 
< 3-year old road ..... 200.00 
< 4-year old road ..... 175.00 
< 5-year old road ..... 150.00 
< 6-year old road ..... 125.00 
< 7-year old road ..... 100.00 
< 8-year old road ..... 75.00 
< 9-year old road ..... 50.00 
Any other pavement ..... 25.00 
In lawn area ..... 10.00 
(b)  Such a permit shall not be given for a longer period of time than ten days in the first instance, but upon application for extension it may be extended for such additional period of time as may be necessary to complete the work for which such excavation or opening is made. 
(c)  The city manager, when it is considered necessary in the public safety, shall have authority to require the person to whom such a permit is issued to construct a sufficient walk around the obstruction caused by the excavation or opening, so as to provide a safe and convenient passageway for pedestrians. 
(d)  The city manager also shall have authority to direct the manner in which the work shall be conducted, and, at any time, for cause, to cancel, rescind or alter any such permit. 
(e)  Sewer cap off permit. In addition to the permits and fees required in subsection (a) of this section, any party capping off a sewer line shall obtain a sewer cap-off permit and pay to the city a fee of $10.00 for same. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.4; Code 1973, § 22-31; Ord. of 6-3-1968, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1973, § 1; Ord. No. 2007-79, § 1, 2-5-2007; Ord. No. 2007-80, § 1, 2-5-2007) 
Sec. 20-70. - Display. 
    The person to whom a permit is issued under this division, upon demand being made by the city engineer or by the superintendent of streets or by a city inspector or by a police officer, shall display such permit at the location where such excavation or opening is being made. In the event of refusal, such city employee or employees making the demand shall immediately report such refusal to the city manager, who thereupon shall cancel such permit. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 41.5; Code 1973, § 22-32) 
Secs. 20-71-20-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLACEMENT OF MATERIALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-99. - Use of lights and guardrails. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the person placing, or causing to be placed, any building or other material of any kind in or upon any portion of any street, sidewalk or alley, pursuant to a permit issued under this article: 
(1)  To place and maintain sufficient guardrails about such material to secure the public safety; and 
(2)  At all times between sunset and sunrise to keep lighted yellow and/or red colored protection bulbs powered by electricity or batteries or yellow and/or red colored blinker lights operated by battery or electricity, on and along such guardrails; 
so placed as to give reasonable and adequate warning of the obstruction created by such materials to all persons using any such street, sidewalk or alley. No liquid fuel operated lighting devices may be used. 
(b)  The requirements of this section shall be applicable to any person acting under a contract with the city and to duly authorized city employees acting in the course of their employment. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.6; Code 1973, § 22-43; Ord. of 5-18-1970, § 1) 
Sec. 20-100. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each such violation. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.7; Code 1973, § 22-44) 
Secs. 20-101-20-128. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 20-129. - Required. 
    No person, unless he is acting under a contract with the city, or unless he is a duly authorized city employee acting in the course of his employment, shall place, or cause to be placed, any building or other material of any kind in or upon any portion of any street, sidewalk or alley within the city, without having first obtained and having in full force and effect a permit to do so, as provided in this division. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.2; Code 1973, § 22-50) 
Sec. 20-130. - Application. 
    A person desiring to procure a permit required by this division shall file with the city manager a written application which shall contain: 
(1)  The name and residence or business address of the applicant; 
(2)  The exact location where it is desired to place any building or other materials; 
(3)  The name and residence or business address, if other than the applicant, of the person for whom it is proposed to place such building or other materials; and 
(4)  The estimated time it will be necessary for such materials to remain at such location. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.3; Code 1973, § 22-51) 
Sec. 20-131. - Issuance; term, etc. 
(a)  The city manager, upon receipt of an application for a permit under this division, may issue a permit authorizing the applicant to place, or cause to be placed, such building or other materials in or upon that portion of any street, sidewalk or alley at the location specified therein; provided, however, that such applicant shall agree to indemnify the city against loss or damage resulting by reason of so placing any such building or other materials thereon. 
(b)  Such a permit shall not be given for a longer period of time than 90 days in the first instance, but upon application for extension it may be extended for such additional period or periods of time as may be necessary to complete the work for which such building or other materials were so placed. By the expiration of the time specified in any such permit or extension thereof, all such building or other materials shall be removed from that portion of any street, sidewalk or alley specified therein. 
(c)  The city manager shall have authority, when it is considered necessary in the public safety, to require the person to whom such a permit is issued to construct a sufficient walk around the obstruction, caused by the placing of such building or other materials, so as to provide a safe and convenient passageway for pedestrians. 
(d)  The city manager also shall have authority to direct the manner in which the work shall be conducted, and, at any time, for cause, to cancel, rescind, or alter any such permit. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.4; Code 1973, § 22-52) 
Sec. 20-132. - Display. 
    The person to whom a permit is issued under this division, upon demand being made by the city engineer or by the superintendent of streets or by a city inspector or by a police officer, shall display such permit at the location where any such building or other materials are placed. In the event of refusal, such city employee or employees making the demand shall immediately report such refusal to the city manager, who thereupon shall cancel such permit. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 42.5; Code 1973, § 22-53) 
Secs. 20-133-20-162. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-163. - Application of article. 
    This article shall apply only to driveways built after February 18, 1946, except that whenever the use of any lot served by a driveway or driveways that do not conform to the provisions herein shall be changed or be abandoned for a period of one year, the owner shall make such alterations as are necessary so that the requirements of section 20-185 shall be satisfied. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 47.3; Code 1973, § 22-64) 
Sec. 20-164. - Modifications. 
    Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship in the way of carrying out the strict letter of this article, the zoning board of appeals shall have the power to vary or modify any of the regulations or provisions of this article so that the spirit of the article shall be observed and public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 47.4; Code 1973, § 22-65) 
Sec. 20-165. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms and provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be liable to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14 for each such violation, and each day which the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 47.5; Code 1973, § 22-66) 
Secs. 20-166-20-183. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 20-184. - Required fees. 
(a)  No sidewalk or curb within a public street or other public space shall be altered without a permit issued by the city engineering department. The fees for such permits are: 
(1)  A $5.00 fee for a permit to build a sidewalk, except there shall be no fee or charge for new one- and two-family residential construction. 
(2)  A $3.00 fee for a permit to make a curb cut in a concrete, stone or asphaltic curb, except there shall be no fee or charge for new one- and two-family residential construction. 
(3)  For all other cases, the fees for such permits are: 
a.  For sidewalks 20 feet long and under, there shall be no fee; 
b.  For sidewalks greater than 20 feet long and less than 100 feet long, the fee shall be $25.00; 
c.  For sidewalks of 100 feet and greater in length, the fee shall be $35.00; 
d.  For curb cuts involving a granite or stone curb, the fee shall be $5.00 per foot; 
e.  For curb cuts involving a concrete curb, the fee shall be $3.00 per foot; and 
f.  For curb cuts involving a blacktop or macadam curb, the fee shall be $1.00 per foot. 
(b)  There shall be no fees for such permits for new one- or two-family construction. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 47.1; Code 1973, § 22-72; Ord. of 6-3-1968, § 2; Ord. of 5-14-1973, § 2; Ord. No. 88-464, § 1, 8-15-1988; Ord. No. 2007-81, § 1, 2-5-2007) 
Sec. 20-185. - Issuance. 
    A permit required by this division may be issued by the city engineering department only when the work proposed to be done conforms to the following standards: 
(1)  There shall be no more than four driveways giving access to any lot and no more than two driveways on any single frontage of any lot. 
(2)  Where there is only one driveway giving access to a lot the curb may not be lowered for a distance greater than 30 feet; where more than one driveway gives access to a lot, no curb may be lowered for a continuous distance greater than 24 feet. 
(3)  Between driveways on the same lot, there must be at least 20 feet of full curb. 
(4)  On a corner lot no curb shall be lowered within six feet of the corner of the lot, or in case the lot line is curved at the corner, no curb shall be lowered on the curve or within ten feet of the center of such curve. 
(5)  The grade of the ramp to the sidewalk elevation shall be subject to the approval of the city engineering department and, in general, should be within the park strip, if there is one, and where there is no park strip, the ramp should not exceed one-fourth of the width of the sidewalk. 
(6)  The curb shall not be cut lower than a point one inch above the gutter. 
(7)  Where the driveway is intended for a gasoline filling station, there shall be on the street line of the lot, opposite the full curb, a curb of at least six inches high. Such curb shall begin three feet from the driveway. 
(8)  No curb may be lowered or driveway constructed which may be in any way dangerous or hazardous to pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 47.2; Code 1973, § 22-73) 
Secs. 20-186-20-208. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARKS AND RECREATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Department of parks generally, § 205 et seq.; department of cemeteries generally, § 213 et seq. 
State Law reference- Power of city to lay out, establish, etc., parks, playgrounds and public places, General City Law § 20(7); playgrounds and neighborhood recreation centers, General Municipal Law § 240 et seq. 

Sec. 20-209. - Duties and powers of city manager. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized, empowered and ordered to erect signs for opening, closing and maintaining each individual park in the city, and by executive order establish the hours which city parks will be open. 
(Code 1973, § 16-; Ord. of 9-8-1959, § 1) 
Sec. 20-210. - Hours parks to be open. 
(a)  Except for emergencies, city parks shall be open to the public every day of the year during designated hours, except that portion of the Lackawanna Trail situated within the city and the Chemung River portage shall not be maintained by the city's building and grounds department during the period of November 1 of each year through April 1 of the immediately subsequent year. 
(b)  All parks will be operated between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. The midway and concession areas at Eldridge Park and Eldridge Stadium shall be operated from 7:30 a.m. until 12:30 a.m. 
(c)  The director of parks and recreation will cause to be erected and maintained signs in each park giving notice of hours the park will be open. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2; Ord. of 9-8-1959, § 2; Ord. No. 80-506, § 1, 8-25-1980; Ord. No. 83-433, § 1, 9-6-1983; Ord. No. 2012-320, § 1, 10-22-2012) 
Sec. 20-211. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the terms of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-14 for each violation thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 16-2.1; Ord. No. 83-433, § 1, 9-6-1983) 
Sec. 20-212. - Baseball playing in Washington Park. 
    The playing of hard baseball, as distinguished from soft baseball, on the public grounds in the city known as Washington Park is hereby prohibited, except for those persons 14 years of age and under engaged in supervised baseball activity. 
(Code 1973, § 16-3; Ord. of 3-19-1962, § 1) 
Sec. 20-213. - Minimum size limits and daily catch limits of trout in Eldridge Lake; prohibited hours; penalty. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of the state environmental conservation law with respect to the regulations contained herein, trout may be taken from the waters of Eldridge Lake as follows: 
(1)  Size limits and daily limits. Trout in any size permitted by state law may be taken from the lake in an aggregate of three per person per day. 
(2)  Prohibited hours. Fishing shall be prohibited between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(3)  Prohibited months. Fishing shall be prohibited between March 1 through and including the first Friday immediately following April 1 of each year. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties of the Environmental Conservation Law of the state, any person violating any of the terms of this section shall be liable to a fine as set forth in section 1-14 for each violation. 
(Code 1973, § 16-4; Ord. of 3-18-1974, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 97-136, § 1, 3-31-1997) 
State Law reference- Fishing, Environmental Conservation Law § 11-1301 et seq. 
Sec. 20-214. - Boats prohibited on Eldridge Lake, Weyer Pond and Miller's Pond; penalty. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Boat includes every surface vessel regardless of size, either self-propelled or propelled by mechanical devices. 
(b)  Legislative intent. No person except a public officer in the performance of his duty or a person duly authorized by the city, shall operate a boat or permit the same to be operated in any portion of Eldridge Lake, Weyer Pond, and Miller's Pond located in the city. 
(c)  Penalty. In addition to the general penalties as set forth in section 1-14, any person violating any of the terms of this section shall be liable to a fine not exceeding $25.00 for each violation thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 16-5; Ord. 3-18-74, § 1) 
Sec. 20-215. - Park fees. 
    The following fee schedule is established for use of Dunn Field: 
(1)  $105.00 per day without the use of lights; 
(2)  $315.00 per day with the use of lights. 
(Ord. No. 2005-142, § 1, 4-18-2005) 
Secs. 20-216-20-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC ART COMMISSION 

Sec. 20-230. - Creation. 
    The city council of the city hereby creates a commission to be known as the "public art commission" hereinafter referred to as "the commission". 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 1, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-231. - Purpose and duties. 
(a)  Purpose. The commission is formed to make decisions concerning the selection, acquisition and display of public art. 
(b)  Duties. the commission shall select and approve acquisitions and donations of public art that meet the selection criteria and guidelines established by the commission. The commission shall develop criteria and guidelines for the selection, acquisition, exhibition, and display of works of art, either temporary (on-loan) or permanent. The commission shall review all proposals for the exhibition and display of public art in the city's public spaces, public buildings, public facilities and infrastructure. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 2, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-232. - Membership. 
    The Commission shall consist of five (5) members, all of whom shall be voting members, appointed by the mayor. At least three (3) of the members shall be residents of the city. At least three (3) of the members shall have knowledge in the field of art education, design, visual arts, architecture, or landscape architecture. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 3, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-233. - Terms of office; vacancies. 
(a)  The five (5) members shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years with the exception of the initial term of two (2) of the members which shall be for one (1) year and two (2) of the members which shall be for two (2) years and one (1) member shall be for three (3) years. 
(b)  Vacancies on the commission shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, except that a vacancy occurring other than by expiration of term of office shall be filled only for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  There are established two (2) alternate commission member positions for purposes of substituting for a member in the event such member is unable to participate because of a conflict of interest or absence causing a lack of a quorum. Alternate members shall be appointed by the mayor and the term for such alternate position shall be two (2) years. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 4, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-234. - Removal. 
    Any member of the commission who fails to attend at least one (1) meeting per year, without good cause, may be removed from the commission by the mayor. The mayor shall have the power to remove any member of the commission for cause after a public hearing. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 5, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-235. - Meetings. 
    The commission members shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson. Meetings shall be called by the chairperson or the vice-chairperson on an as-needed basis. At a minimum, the commission shall meet at least twice each calendar year. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 6, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-236. - Quorum/voting. 
    The presence of a majority of the whole commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum. No action shall be taken without the vote of the majority of the whole commission. Minutes of the meetings shall be kept by the commission. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 7, 1-23-2017) 
Sec. 20-237. - Compensation. 
    The members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their services but may be reimbursed for reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of his/her duties within the appropriations made available therefore. 
(Ord No. 2017-14, § 8, 1-23-2017) 
Chapter 22 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of assessment and taxation generally, § 49 et seq.; powers and duties of assessor, § 49; assessment of taxes, § 52; imposition of city tax, § 53; time in which to pay city tax, § 54; tax sales, § 57; state and county taxes, § 74. 
State Law reference- Power of city to levy and collect taxes, General City Law § 20(4); Tax Law § 1 et seq. 

Sec. 22-1. - Tax exemption for eligible business facilities certified by the state urban job incentive board. 
(a)  The assessor of the city shall have the power and be charged with the duty to carry out the purpose and intent of the Real Property Tax Law § 485 and the other applicable laws of the state to grant business facility owners or operators, as defined by the aforesaid state laws, tax exemption or tax credits from taxes and special ad valorem assessments imposed to the extent of any increase in the value of the capital improvements, commencing on the effective date of this local law consisting of construction, reconstruction, erection or improvements of depreciable real property, as certified in the certificate of eligibility issued by the state urban job incentive board, provided that the owner or operator of the business facility files before the taxable status date with the assessor of the city an application on the form prescribed by the board of equalization and assessment, to which there shall be attached a copy of the certificate of eligibility so issued, and simultaneously therewith files the application with the state board of equalization and assessment and the state urban job incentive board. 
(b)  Upon submission of the aforesaid application and proof, the assessor, with or without a hearing, shall consider the application for such exemption and, if found to be in order, determine the assessed value of the exemption in accordance with the certificate of eligibility and enter such value on the exempt portion of the assessment roll. 
(c)  The assessor, in his determination, shall grant a 100 percent tax credit or exemption and the exemption so granted shall continue from year to year during the period of years so approved only if the certificate of eligibility is not revoked or modified and is renewed or extended by the state urban job incentive board. 
(d)  Any exemption so granted by the assessor shall commence with the assessment roll prepared on the next following taxable status date of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 24-2; L.L. No. 1976-1, § 1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Fees for tax clearance and satisfaction of city tax. 
(a)  A fee of $20.00 shall be and hereby is established to be charged to anyone requesting a tax clearance for property located in the city from the office of the city chamberlain. 
(b)  A fee of $20.00 shall be and hereby is established to be charged to anyone requesting a satisfaction of city tax sale for property located in the city from the office of the city chamberlain. 
(Code 1973, § 2-2; Ord. of 12-18-1978, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 98-135, § 1, 3-16-1998; Ord. No. 2006-377, § 1, 11-13-2006) 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Rules of the road, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 100 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be referred to as the "Traffic Code." 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 51.1; Code 1973, § 25-1) 
Sec. 25-2. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, whenever used in this chapter, except as may otherwise be specifically indicated, the singular of any term to include the plural, shall be deemed to mean and include: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle means vehicles of the fire and police departments of the city, and such ambulances and emergency vehicles of other municipal departments of the city or public service corporations as are designated by the city manager. 
    Bus stand means an area in a street marked off for buses to take on and discharge passengers. 
    City manager means the city manager of the City of Elmira. 
    Congested district means and includes all streets within and including the following boundaries: From Water Street north on College Avenue to Church Street; from College Avenue east on Church Street to Madison Avenue; from Church Street south on Madison Avenue to Water Street; from Madison Avenue west on Water Street (including the approaches to the bridges at Madison Avenue, Lake Street and Main Street) to College Avenue; and from Church Street north on Main Street to Third Street. 
    Crosswalk means that area of a street, whether marked or unmarked, between the lateral lines of a sidewalk extended. 
    Curb includes the boundaries of a roadway whether marked by a curbstone or not so marked. 
    Double parking means the parking of a vehicle upon any street opposite a parked vehicle, or a space intended for such purpose. 
    Driver includes a person who propels or operates or who is in charge of a vehicle. 
    Funeral procession means a procession of vehicles designated as such by the display on each vehicle, except the hearse, of an appropriate marker prescribed by the city manager. 
    Handicapped parking means and designates parking spaces where only vehicles displaying a valid handicapped parking permit on the dashboard or sun visor on the driver's side may park. 
    Intersection includes the area bounded by the sidelines, real or projected, of two or more streets which meet or cross each other. 
    One-way street means a street on which vehicular traffic shall travel only in the direction indicated by traffic signs. 
    Park, parking or parked means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
    Pedestrian includes all persons making use of a street for foot passage. 
    Person means any natural person, firm, copartnership, association or corporation. 
    Prohibited district means and includes such streets and parts of streets in which parking is prohibited by traffic signs. 
    Public highway includes any highway, road, street, avenue, alley, public driveway, or any other public way. 
    Restricted district means and include such streets and parts of streets in which parking is limited by traffic signs to specified periods of time. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a public highway outside of the street or roadway used or set apart for the use of pedestrians. 
    Stop or standing means the stopping or standing of a vehicle upon any street for any period of time, whether attended by an operator or not. 
    Street or roadway includes that part of a public highway intended for vehicular traffic. 
    Taxicab stand means an area in a street marked off for the parking of taxicabs. 
    Through street means a main artery of travel. 
    Traffic means the use of a street for the purpose of or incidental to, travel by any person, either on foot or in control of a vehicle or horse. 
    Traffic control signal means a signaling device, either hand-operated or electrically operated, in which one or more colors direct the movement of traffic. 
    Traffic infraction means the violation of any provision of this chapter. 
    Traffic sign means such sign, pavement marking, device or signal placed or erected in pursuance to this chapter, for the purpose of stopping, guiding, directing, warning or regulating traffic. 
    U-turn means the turning of a vehicle around or crossing from one side of a street to another so as to head in the opposite direction from which it was going prior to the turn. 
    Vehicle includes any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, except a baby carriage and devices used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 51.2; Code 1973, § 25-2; Ord. No. 79-536, § 1, 11-5-1979; Ord. No. 80-148, § 1, 3-10-1980) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 100 et seq. 
Sec. 25-3. - Required obedience to chapter. 
    No person shall do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required by any section of this chapter. The registered owner of a vehicle shall be responsible for the standing or parking of such vehicle in violation of the provisions of this chapter by any person operating the same with the permission, express or implied, of such registered owner. The violation of any section or provision of this chapter by means of a vehicle shall be prima facie evidence that such violation was committed by or with the authority and permission of the owner of such vehicle. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 52.1; Code 1973, § 25-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1101. 
Sec. 25-4. - Public employees subject to chapter. 
    The several sections of this chapter shall apply to and include the driver of any vehicle owned or used in the service of the United States Government, the state, the county and the city, and the driver of any such vehicle shall not violate any of the sections of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted by this chapter or by state statute. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 52.2; Code 1973, § 25-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1101. 
Sec. 25-5. - Exemptions.
