    The several sections of this chapter regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles, except that when the driver of such a vehicle is operating it in an emergency in the necessary performance of his duty, and while the gong or siren on such vehicle is continuously sounded while such vehicle is in motion, he may ignore any provision of this chapter; provided, however, that he shall not, by ignoring any such provision, endanger life or property or be relieved from liability for injuries resulting from the careless exercise of this right. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 52.3; Code 1973, § 25-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1104. 
Sec. 25-6. - Application to pushcarts, bicycles and animals. 
    A person propelling a pushcart or bicycle, or a person riding upon or driving a horse, shall be subject to the several provisions of this chapter, except those provisions which by their very nature have no application. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 52.4; Code 1973, § 25-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1105. 
Sec. 25-7. - Power and authority of police department. 
    The police department of the city is hereby authorized, empowered and ordered to enforce the several provisions of this chapter and all provisions of the vehicle and traffic law applicable to traffic in the city. Police officers shall direct all traffic in conformity with this chapter and the Vehicle and Traffic Law, except that during a fire or at the time of an accident or special emergency, or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, a police officer may temporarily direct traffic as such special conditions may require notwithstanding the several provisions of this chapter. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.1; Code 1973, § 25-7) 
State Law reference- Required obedience to police officers, etc., Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1102. 
Sec. 25-8. - Procedure upon arrest. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by the Vehicle and Traffic Law, a police officer, upon making an arrest for an infraction of any provision of this chapter or the vehicle and traffic law, shall take the violator's name, address, his operator's license number, and the registration number of the motor vehicle involved, and issue to him in writing, on a form to be prescribed by the chief of police, a notice to answer to the charge of infraction made against him within the time specified in such notice at city court. If such violator shall give his promise to answer such charge within such time by signing such notice, the arresting officer may release him from custody; if such violator shall refuse to give such promise, he shall immediately be taken to the police department or city court, to post bail or answer such charge, as the case may be. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.2; Code 1973, § 25-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 602, 155. 
Sec. 25-9. - Procedure in absence of operator. 
    If a vehicle without a driver is found stopped or parked in violation of any provision of this chapter or the Vehicle and Traffic Law, the police officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form to be prescribed by the chief of police, specifying such violation, directing the driver of such vehicle to answer such charge within the time specified in such notice at city court. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.3; Code 1973, § 25-9) 
Sec. 25-10. - Appearance of violators. 
    A person receiving a notice issued pursuant to section 25-8 or 25-9 may, within the time specified in such notice, and except as herein otherwise provided, answer such notice by appearance either in person or by agent at city court, and upon admitting the charge specified in such notice, pay the prescribed fine and receive a receipt therefor, which receipt shall be considered complete satisfaction for the infraction. A person who, in answer to such a notice, shall deny the charge specified in such notice, shall deposit cash bail in an amount equal to double the prescribed fine, whereupon the city court judge shall assign a day for trial of the matter. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.4; Code 1973, § 25-10) 
Sec. 25-11. - Procedure on default in appearance. 
    Any person charged with any infraction of this chapter or the vehicle and traffic law who fails to appear within the time and at the place specified in any notice issued pursuant to section 25-8 or 25-9, shall be subject to arrest for the infraction specified in any such notice upon a warrant issued pursuant to a sworn information or complaint made by the police officer issuing such notice; provided, however, that upon default in appearance to a notice issued pursuant to section 25-9, where the identity of the person having charge of the vehicle at the time of the infraction is unknown, the police department shall notify the registered owner of such vehicle by letter informing him of the time and place of the infraction and warning him that he will be held responsible for such infraction if such letter is disregarded for a period of five days from the date of such letter, after which such registered owner, if there then is a default in appearance to such notice, shall be subject to arrest as heretofore provided. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.5; Code 1973, § 25-11) 
Sec. 25-12. - Appearance in court. 
    Any person who is charged with an infraction of section 25-53, 25-54, 25-57 or 25-58, or who is arrested pursuant to section 25-11, or who has admitted or been found guilty of three or more infractions of other sections of this chapter within a year, or who is charged with violation of any provision of the vehicle and traffic law, shall appear in city court in person and not by agent to answer such charge, except that such person may be accompanied by his attorney. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.6; Code 1973, § 25-12) 
Sec. 25-13. - Records to be kept by chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall keep a complete record of all notices, which shall be serially numbered, assigned to police officers for issuance under sections 25-8 and 25-9, which record shall show the disposition of each notice so assigned and so issued, and the city court docket shall be open to inspection to the chief of police for the purpose of ascertaining the dispositions of such notices; and such record shall be available at all times to the city manager, who may order the chief of police to classify such notices as shall have been so issued according to the types of infractions charged therein, the locations where such infractions were alleged to have occurred, and those persons who have been charged with three or more infractions within any consecutive 12-month period. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.7; Code 1973, § 25-13) 
Sec. 25-14. - Penalties. 
    Any person admitting or who has been found guilty of violation of any section of this chapter may for first offense be punished by a fine not exceeding $50.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment, and for a second offense by a fine not exceeding $100.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 60 days, or both such fine and imprisonment, and for a third or subsequent offense within one year by a fine not exceeding $150.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 58.8; Code 1973, § 25-14) 
State Law reference- Penalties for traffic infractions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1800. 
Sec. 25-15. - Duties and powers of city manager. 
(a)  Duties. The city manager is hereby authorized, empowered and ordered: 
(1)  To erect, maintain and/or eliminate such traffic control signals and traffic signs as shall now, and from time to time hereafter, conform to the several sections of this chapter; all stop signs placed pursuant to section 25-53(b), shall conform to the requirements of the vehicle and traffic law, and so far as possible, shall be uniform in height and location at each intersection; 
(2)  To determine the times when traffic control signals shall be operated, and, so far as practicable, to synchronize electric control signals to each other; 
(3)  To designate and mark bus stands; 
(4)  To prescribe and, upon application, issue or cause to be issued suitable markers for use by vehicles in funeral processions; 
(5)  To prescribe and, upon application by the owner, lessee or agent of any hotel, theater or railroad, and upon receiving the cost therefor, to erect, or permit to be erected, at or near the curb, at each end of a space 30 feet in length directly in front of the entrance or entrances to such hotel or theater, or the depot or depots of any such railroad, uniform traffic signs prohibiting parking within such space or spaces. 
(b)  Powers. The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered: 
(1)  To designate safety zones, parking spaces and taxicab stands on streets and parts of streets, and to erect and maintain traffic signs at such zones, spaces and stands limiting or prohibiting stopping or parking therein; 
(2)  To mark parking meter spaces on the surface of streets and parts of streets designated by section 25-148, so as to indicate the boundary within which a vehicle shall be placed when in a parking meter space; 
(3)  To designate one-way streets and to erect and maintain one-way signs at intersections where movement of vehicular traffic in the opposite direction shall be prohibited; 
(4)  To designate prohibited districts and to erect and maintain traffic signs at such districts; 
(5)  To designate within the congested district streets where U-turns shall be prohibited and to erect and maintain traffic signs giving notice thereof on such streets; 
(6)  To designate upon what streets diagonal parking shall be permitted and mark spaces on the pavement of such streets within which vehicles shall so park; 
(7)  To designate intersections or any part of a street where slow signs shall be posted; 
(8)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places within the congested district as he shall determine, and to issue regulations therefor; 
(9)  To mark crosswalks on streets; 
(10)  To designate school zones, hospital zones, playground areas and factory areas, and erect and maintain traffic signs at such zones, giving notice of such parking regulations and limitations upon the movement of traffic within such zones as he shall determine; 
(11)  Upon application being made to him by the agent of any church or other building where public assemblages of persons may be held, and upon receiving the cost therefor, to erect, or permit to be erected, at or near the curb, at each end of a space 30 feet in length directly in front of the entrance or entrances to such church or other building, temporary traffic signs prohibiting parking therein which shall be displayed only upon the day or days when such assemblages of persons are to be held; 
(12)  To designate as authorized emergency vehicles such ambulances as may be necessary; and to revoke any such designations; 
(13)  To permit any vehicle at designated locations to park otherwise than is permitted by article VII of this chapter; provided, however, that the granting of such a permit will not create an unreasonable obstruction in a street, and to designate locations and periods of time in which passengers and freight may be loaded into or unloaded from any vehicle; 
(14)  To limit or prohibit traffic on any street where there is an authorized obstruction, or where any temporary condition on or along any street makes it advisable to limit or prohibit traffic while such condition continues; 
(15)  To designate districts in which no vehicle can stop or stand; 
(16)  To declare a snow removal emergency, which emergency shall be announced through the press, if possible, but in any event by an announcement on one or more local television or radio stations, whenever the city manager shall deem it advisable during a snow storm or in order to remove snow or to plow streets, and upon such declaration, to close any street or part thereof to vehicular traffic or prohibit, restrict or limit the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles and to institute odd/even parking requirements whereby no vehicle shall be or remain parked between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., except as follows: 
a.  On dates with even numbers according to the calendar, on the side of any street on which houses bear even numbers; 
b.  On days with odd numbers according to the calendar, on the side of any street in which the houses bear odd numbers; 
provided, however, such parking requirements shall not apply where parking is otherwise restricted by signs, and where parking is restricted or prohibited in a residential district for a full city block on one side of the street. 
(c)  Additional duties and powers of city manager. In addition to the powers granted the city manager above, subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the city manager is further empowered, with respect to the parking areas and driveways of a hospital or parking area of a shopping center or the parking area and private streets or roadways of a private apartment house complex or the parking areas and driveways of a private condominium complex, and pursuant to the written request of the owner, the person in general charge of the operation and control of such area or the fire chief of the city, may: 
(1)  Order stop signs, flashing signals or yield signs erected at specified entrance or exit locations to any such area or designate any intersection in such area as a stop intersection or as a yield intersection and order like signs or signals at one or more entrances to such intersection. 
(2)  Regulate traffic in any such area, including regulation by means of traffic control signals. 
(2a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1643, establish maximum speed limits in any such area at not less than 15 miles per hour. 
(3)  Prohibit or regulate the turning of vehicles or specified types of vehicles at intersections or other designated locations in any such area. 
(4)  Regulate the crossing of any roadway in any such area by pedestrians. 
(5)  Designate any separate roadway in any such area for one-way traffic. 
(6)  Prohibit, regulate, restrict or limit the sopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified areas of any such area. 
(7)  Designate safety zones in any such area. 
(8)  Provide for the removal and storage of vehicles parked or abandoned in any such area during snowstorms, floods, fires or other public emergencies, or found unattended in any such area: 
a.  Where they constitute an obstruction to traffic; or 
b.  Where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited, and for the payment of reasonable charges for such removal and storage by the owner or operator of any such vehicle. 
(9)  Adopt such additional reasonable rules and regulations with respect to traffic and parking in any such area as local conditions may require for the safely and convenience of the public or of the users of any such area. 
(10)  Make special provisions with relation to stopping, standing or parking of vehicles registered pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 404a, or those possessing a handicapped parking permit issued in accordance with the ordinance of the city. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, §§ 59.1, 59.2; Code 1973, § 25-15; Ord. of 3-18-1957; Ord. No. 81-66, § 1, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 94-81, § 1, 2-7-1994; Ord. No. 2000-125, § 1, 3-27-2000) 
Sec. 25-16. - Chemical blood content test on motor vehicle operators. 
    A minimum fee of $20.00 shall be and hereby is established to be charged to any other governmental unit requesting the use of the equipment, facilities or personnel of the city police department for the purpose of conducting a chemical blood content test on motor vehicle operators. 
(Code 1973, § 25-16; Ord. of 2-26-1968, § 1) 
Secs. 25-17-25-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC COORDINATING BOARD 

Sec. 25-27. - Established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a traffic coordinating board to serve without compensation which shall consist of the city manager or his/her designee, the fire chief or his/her designee, the director of the city's public services or his/her designee, the traffic sergeant, and one city resident appointed by the mayor. 
(b)  The persons named in subparagraph (a) above shall be members of the board so long as said persons hold the named positions. The city resident appointed by the mayor shall hold the position for three years from the date of appointment. 
(Code 1973, § 25-27; Ord. of 6-11-1962, § 1; Ord. of 10-25-1965, § 1; Ord. of 11-20-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 89-654, § 1, 12-4-1989; Ord. No. 2008-284, § 1, 8-18-2008; Ord. No. 2016-126, § 1, 4-4-2016) 
Sec. 25-28. - Purposes and duties of board. 
    The purposes and duties of the traffic coordinating board shall be to: 
(1)  Collect and compile traffic data and engineering studies and surveys in relation to vehicular and pedestrian traffic in the city. 
(2)  Coordinate traffic activities in the city. 
(3)  Supervise the preparation and publication of traffic reports. 
(4)  Receive complaints relating to traffic matters. 
(5)  Review proposals for the installation of traffic control devices and the establishment of traffic control measures. 
(6)  Prepare and submit to the city manager detailed reports in relation to traffic conditions in the city. 
(7)  Make recommendations to the council with relation to methods of ameliorating traffic conditions which adversely affect the welfare of the city. 
(8)  Submit to the council special proposals for amendment of ordinances, rules and regulations of the city which affect traffic conditions and proposed legislation which the committee deems necessary or proper to implement and effectuate its proposals. 
(9)  Prepare and submit to the council, the city manager and to other appropriate agencies and departments of the city, recommendations and proposals for improving traffic conditions and the administration and enforcement of traffic ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(10)  Better utilize the traffic engineering facilities available in the city, and to generally advise the council on procedures to improve all types of traffic conditions in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 25-28; Ord. of 6-11-1962, § 2) 
Sec. 25-29. - Board meetings. 
    The board shall schedule meetings as frequently as it deems necessary to carry out its purposes and duties. 
(Code 1973, § 25-29; Ord. of 6-11-1962, § 3) 
Secs. 25-30-25-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU 

Sec. 25-40. - Authorized. 
(a)  The city court is hereby authorized to establish a traffic violations bureau to assist it in the disposition of offenses in relation to traffic and parking violations. 
(b)  The traffic violations bureau so established is hereby authorized to dispose of violations of traffic laws, ordinances, rules and regulations designated by the court, except the offenses constituting the traffic infraction of speeding or a misdemeanor or a felony, by permitting a person charged with an offense within the limits herein stated, to answer, within a specified time, at the traffic violations bureau, either in person or by written power of attorney, by paying a fine and, in writing, waiving a hearing in court, pleading guilty to the charge and authorizing the person in charge of the bureau to make such a plea and pay such a fine in court. Acceptance of the prescribed fine and power of attorney by the bureau shall be deemed complete satisfaction for the violation, and the violator shall be given a receipt which so states. If a person charged with a traffic/parking violation does not wish to plead guilty and contest the said violation or wishes to address the court, he may do so at the designated time reflected on his parking violation information (parking ticket). If the person charged with a traffic/parking violation fails to answer or appear in court at the designated time, as it appears on his parking ticket, the traffic violations bureau shall request that the city court take steps to compel compliance from the person charged, including but not limited to the issuance of a criminal summons or warrant for arrest. Any person who shall have been, within the preceding 12 months, guilty of a number of specified parking violations in excess of such maximum number as may be designated by the court, or of three or more violations, other than parking violations, shall not be permitted to appear and answer to a subsequent violation at the traffic violations bureau, but must appear in court at a time specified by the bureau. 
(c)  The court shall designate the fines to be paid for offenses which may be satisfied at the bureau as hereinbefore stated, provided such fines are within the limits established as penalties for such offenses. 
(d)  The traffic violations bureau shall keep records as are directed by the General Municipal Law § 373, and such other records as shall be directed by the court. 
(e)  The traffic violations bureau shall be in charge of such person and shall be open at such hours as the court may designate. 
(f)  The city court is further authorized to make rules and regulations for the conduct of the traffic violations bureau, and to prescribe the forms of waiver, power of attorney and plea and any other papers which may be required to carry out the function of the said bureau as defined herein. 
(Code 1973, § 25-40; Ord. of 5-13-1957, § 1; Ord. No. 2006-222, § 1, 7-10-2006)

ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 25-51. - Snowmobiles. 
(a)  Legislative intent. The purpose of this section is to protect the public health, welfare and safety by regulating the operation of snowmobiles on public highways and places of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  The terms, words and phrases used in this section shall have the same meaning as such terms, words and phrases are defined in Environmental Conservation Law § 8-1015. 
(2)  Whenever the word "city" is used herein it shall mean the City of Elmira. 
(c)  Operation on public property. 
(1)  In city streets or highways. Operation of snowmobiles on roads, highways, sidewalks and public ways of the city is forbidden and hereby prohibited. 
(2)  In parks, playgrounds, public recreation places. No person shall operate a snowmobile in any public park, public playground or any other public recreation place within the limits of the city unless approved by the mayor or city manager of the city and built for the specific purpose of snowmobiling. 
(d)  Emergency. When authorized or directed by the mayor or city manager, or duly authorized representative of the city so designated by the mayor or city manager, a snowmobile may be operated on any portion of the highway for the purpose of an emergency as authorized by Environmental Conservation Law § 8-0303. 
(e)  Penalty. Any violation of the provisions of this section of any part thereof shall be a Class A misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 25-51; Ord. of 1-11-1971, § 1; Ord. No. 2-22-72, § 1) 
State Law reference- State registration of snowmobiles, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 2220 et seq.; operation of snowmobiles, Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation Law § 25.01 et seq. 
Sec. 25-52. - One-way streets. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall travel only in the direction indicated by traffic signs on designated one-way street. 
(b)  The following streets are hereby designated as one-way streets for the direction of travel indicated: North-South Arterial, each of the divided roadways of the North-South Arterial will be restricted to one-way traffic. The west half of the roadway shall be restricted to southbound traffic and the east half of the roadway shall be restricted to northbound traffic. 
(c)  The following portions of streets are hereby designated one-way and two-way as follows: Madison Avenue (two-way) running southerly from East Water Street over the Madison Avenue Bridge to Maple Avenue, with two lanes of traffic traveling northerly and one lane traveling southerly. The southerly lane of traffic must turn left onto Maple Avenue at its intersection with Madison Avenue. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.2; Code 1973, § 25-52; Ord. No. 79-463, § 1, 9-24-1979; Ord. No. 84-118, § 1, 3-5-1984) 
State Law reference- One-way roadways, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1127(a); power of city to designate highways or roadways for one-way traffic, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(4).

Sec. 25-54. - Operation of motor vehicles or motorcycles used for commercial purposes in cemeteries and parks. 
(a)  No motor vehicle or motorcycle used solely for commercial purposes shall be operated in any cemetery or grounds used for the burial of the dead, except for purposes of receiving and delivering goods, wares and merchandise in the cemeteries. 
(b)  No motor vehicle or motorcycle used solely for commercial purposes shall be operated in any park except for the purposes of receiving and delivering goods, wares and merchandise in the parks. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.5; Code 1973, § 25-54; Ord. of 10-14-1957) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prohibit or regulate the operations, etc., of vehicles in public parks, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(13). 
Sec. 25-55. - Stop when traffic obstructed. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not enter an intersection or marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate such vehicle without obstructing the movement of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal to proceed. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.6; Code 1973, § 25-55) 
Sec. 25-56. - Backing. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be made with safety and without interfering with other traffic. The driver of a vehicle shall not back it upon any shoulder or roadway of any controlled-access highway. The driver of a vehicle shall not back it into or across an intersection or crosswalk at any time or place, and shall not back it at any time or place unless such movement can be made in safety. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.7; Code 1973, § 25-56) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1211. 
Sec. 25-57. - Funeral processions. 
    The driver of a vehicle in a funeral procession shall drive as near the right-hand curb of the street as practicable and follow the vehicle ahead as close as is reasonably safe, and the driver of another vehicle, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, shall not drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession while they are in motion, providing such vehicles, except the hearse, are displaying markers prescribed and issued by the city manager pursuant to section 25-15(a)(4) hereof. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.8; Code 1973, § 25-57) 
State Law reference- Power of city to license, regulate or prohibit processions, assemblages or parades, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(12). 
Sec. 25-58. - Parades. 
    The driver of a vehicle, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, shall not drive through the procession of a parade authorized by the mayor pursuant to section 18-3. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.9; Code 1973, § 25-58) 
State Law reference- Power of city to license, regulate or prohibit processions, assemblages or parades, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(12).

(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.10; Code 1973, § 25-59; Ord. of 11-13-1962, § 1; Ord. of 11-12-1973, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 80-479, §§ 1, 2, 8-11-1980; Ord. No. 80-480, § 1, 8-11-1980; Ord. Sec. 25-59.1. - Right turns. 
    Pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(2), the driver of a vehicle is hereby prohibited from making a right turn into or from the following street, posted with "no right turn" signs, electrical or otherwise, and unless otherwise directed by a police officer: 
Beecher Street at Pennsylvania Avenue, vehicles exiting from Beecher Street southbound onto Pennsylvania Avenue may not turn right.

Pennsylvania Avenue at Herrick Street, no vehicle may make a right turn from Pennsylvania Avenue onto Herrick Street. 
(Code 1973, § 25-59.1; Ord. No. 84-463, § 1, 8-20-1984; Ord. No. 94-552, § 1, 10-3-1994) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prohibit the turning at certain intersections, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(2). 
Sec. 25-60. - Buses to stop at bus stands or at curb. 
    For the purposes of taking on or discharging passengers, buses shall be stopped as follows: 
(1)  Within the congested district within marked bus stands only; provided, however, that if any bus stand is occupied by another bus, or by another vehicle contrary to this chapter, a bus may be stopped immediately adjacent to such occupied bus stand; and provided, further, that in the absence of a marked bus stand a bus shall be stopped in conformity to the requirements of subsection (2) of this section. 
(2)  Outside the congested district at intersections or other designated stops at the curb only; provided, however, that if another vehicle is stopped or parked at the curb at such intersection or other designated stop where a bus otherwise would stop except for the presence of such vehicle, a bus may be stopped immediately adjacent to such stopped or parked vehicle. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.11; Code 1973, § 25-60) 
Sec. 25-61. - Turns. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle shall not make any turn, either right or left, at the intersection of any street when ordered not to do so by a peace officer or when a sign prohibiting turns is posted. 
(b)  Turns at the following intersections in the direction indicated are prohibited: 
Madison Avenue and East Water Street. Vehicles proceeding north on Madison Avenue shall not turn left onto East Water Street between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
East Market Street and North-South Arterial. Vehicles proceeding west on East Market Street shall not turn left onto the North-South Arterial. 
Second Street and State Street. Vehicles proceeding east on Second Street shall not turn right onto State Street. 
State Street and East Second Street. Vehicles proceeding north on State Street shall not turn left onto East Second Street. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.12; Code 1973, § 25-61; Ord. No. 79-460, § 1, 9-24-1979; Ord. No. 2000-339, § 1, 9-11-2000) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prohibit or regulate the turning of vehicles, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(2). 
Sec. 25-61.1. - Right turns on red. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1110, the city manager is hereby authorized to erect signs at those intersections he deems appropriate to prohibit a right turn when facing a steady red signal which signs shall prohibit vehicles from making such a turn. 
(b)  Signs erected pursuant to the provisions of this local law shall be in conformity with the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Code 1973, § 25-61.1; L.L. No. 1975-3, §§ 1-3; L.L. No. 1976-3, §§ 1, 2) 
Editor's note- See also section 25-93. 
State Law reference- Power of city to prohibit the turning at certain intersections, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(2). 
Sec. 25-62. - Temporary barricades. 
    Whenever a member of the traffic bureau of the police department shall deem it necessary for the proper movement of traffic, temporary barricades may be placed in the street to separate or channel lanes of traffic, or to create safety zones, or to indicate direction of travel. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.13; Code 1973, § 25-62) 
Sec. 25-63. - Passing at safety zones. 
    The driver of a vehicle, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, shall pass only to the right of a safety zone, except where permission is otherwise indicated by a sign displayed at the particular safety zone allowing passing to the left. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.14; Code 1973, § 25-63) 
Sec. 25-64. - Operation of vehicles where one-way sign displayed. 
(a)  At all intersections when traffic is controlled by traffic control signals, movement shall be made on the green light only, except as otherwise directed by a peace officer, or where a one-way sign with a green arrow flashing or lighted points the direction of travel. Such movement on the red light may be made only after the vehicle moving in each case shall have first come to a full stop and only when interference with vehicular or pedestrian traffic is not occasioned thereby. 
(b)  At all points where traffic is controlled by a one-way sign with a green arrow only, traffic may move in the direction of the green arrow whenever such arrow is flashing or lighted. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.15; Code 1973, § 25-64)

Sec. 25-66. - City truck route system. 
(a)  Streets Constituting the City Truck Route System. Pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(10), as amended, the following streets or portions thereof are hereby designated, and they shall constitute the city truck route system: 
(1)  State Route 17/I86 bypass within the city limits. 
(2)  Grand Central Avenue, from the city's north line to the Clemens Center Parkway. 
(3)  Clemens Center Parkway, entire length within the city limits. 
(4)  Clemens Center Parkway Extension, entire length. 
(5)  Lake Street, from the city's north line to its intersection with Clemens Center Parkway Extension. 
(6)  East Fifth Street, between Clemens Center Parkway and Judson Street Extension. 
(7)  Judson Street Extension, between East Fifth Street and East Church Street. 
(8)  Church Street, in an easterly and westerly direction on that portion of Church Street between the city's easterly boundary line and Clemens Center Parkway; only in a westerly direction on that portion of Church Street between Clemens Center Parkway and the city's westerly boundary line. 
(9)  Water Street, in an easterly and westerly direction on that portion of Water Street between the city's easterly boundary line and Clemens Center Parkway; only in an easterly direction on that portion of Water Street between Clemens Center Parkway and the city's western boundary line; 
(10)  Walnut Street, between Water Street and Church Street. 
(11)  College Avenue, from Woodlawn Avenue north to the city's northerly boundary line. 
(12)  Woodlawn Avenue, between College Avenue and Clemens Center Parkway. 
(b)  Motor vehicles in excess of 10,000 pounds prohibited. No motor vehicle, including: vans, trucks, tractors, tractor-trailer combinations, tractor-semitrailer combinations or tractor-trailer-semitrailer combinations, having a total gross weight in excess of 10,000 pounds shall travel and operate on any city street except as further provided for in this article. 
(1)  Vehicles specifically exempted. The following vehicles shall be exempt from the mandates of this article specifically as follows: 
a.  Municipal vehicles. Due to the nature of their work and the need to have unhindered access to all city streets, municipally owned or leased vehicles which would otherwise be regulated by this article are hereby specifically exempt therefrom. For the sake of clarification this shall include, but is not necessarily limited to, the following municipal vehicles: fire department, police department, public works department and vehicles of any agent thereof, provided said agent's vehicles are then engaged in official municipal business; 
b.  Single rear axle motor vehicles. Those motor vehicles containing no more than one rear axle located behind the driver's seat with a gross weight in excess of 10,000 pounds, provided said single rear axle motor vehicle is proceeding to or from a point of destination within the boundaries of the city. However, if said single rear axle motor vehicle has no point of destination within the boundaries of the city (through traffic), said vehicle must proceed as provided herein; 
c.  Recreational vehicles. Those motor vehicles commonly referred to as recreational vehicles or RVs and which would otherwise be regulated by this article. For the sake of clarification this shall include, but is not necessarily limited to, the following vehicles: motor homes, campers and boat/trailer combinations. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Motor vehicle includes any motorized vehicle lawfully permitted to operate on the highways of the state; and shall include not only the motorized portion of such vehicle but also any and all trailers, cargo-holds, and/or other appurtenances thereto being pulled, carried or otherwise transported by said motorized portion of said vehicle. 
(2)  Point of destination means the location on a given street where the driver is to load and/or unload any portion of his cargo. 
(3)  Truck route street means any particular, individual street or portion thereof as designated in subsection (a) of this section, which comprises any portion of the truck route system. 
(4)  Shortest route means that particular street or combination of intersecting streets, which, when compared to any other available route or routes traverses the least distance as measured from the truck route system to the point of destination (or between other points of measurement as may be specifically provided for hereunder). 
(d)  Regulation of vehicles in excess of 10,000 pounds. 
(1)  Point of destination on truck route street. If the point of destination is on a truck route street, then the driver shall proceed within the truck route system to the point of destination, and upon leaving said point of destination, the driver shall proceed within the truck route system until such time as he may deviate from said truck route system as provided for herein. 
(2)  Point of destination on nontruck route street. If the point of destination is located on a street which does not compose part of the truck route system, then the driver shall proceed within the truck route system until it intersects with the shortest route, and then shall proceed on said shortest route to the point of destination; and upon leaving said point of destination the driver shall proceed on the shortest route to the truck route system, and then shall proceed within the truck route system until such time as he may deviate from said truck route system as provided for herein. In the event that there are two or more possible shortest routes, then the driver shall proceed on one of said most shortest routes. 
(3)  Sullivan Street/Industrial Park Boulevard exception. If the point of destination is located on Sullivan Street or Industrial Park Boulevard, then the driver shall proceed within the truck route system until it intersects with either the northerly terminus or southerly terminus of Sullivan Street and then shall traverse Sullivan Street to the point of destination (whether said point of destination is on Sullivan Street or Industrial Park Boulevard), without further regard for the shortest route and upon leaving said point of destination, the driver shall proceed to either the northerly terminus or southerly terminus of Sullivan Street without further regard for the shortest route until the driver has so exited Sullivan Street at either the northerly terminus or southerly terminus. 
(4)  Multiple points of destination. If the driver has more than one point of destination within the city, then the driver shall proceed within the truck route system to the shortest route for any one of the points of destination, which shall then be known as the current point of destination, and then shall proceed on the shortest route to said current point of destination, and upon leaving said current point of destination the driver shall proceed on the shortest route as compared between the current point of destination to the next point of destination and the current point of destination to the truck route system. 
a.  Each successive point of destination shall then be known as the current point of destination for the purpose of determining the shortest route. 
b.  In the event that there are two or more possible shortest routes, then the driver must proceed on one of said shortest routes. 
(5)  No point of destination within city (through traffic). All motor vehicles having a total gross weight in excess of 10,000 pounds, and having no point of destination within the city, but rather intending to drive through the city to access points outside the city's boundaries shall proceed as follows: 
a.  Said motor vehicles entering the city from its southerly boundary and intending to access New York State Route 17/I86, once entering the city shall proceed on the shortest route to Clemens Center Parkway, and thence shall proceed on Clemens Center Parkway to its intersection with East Church Street, and thence shall proceed on East Church Street to its intersection with State Route 17/I86. 
b.  Said motor vehicles entering the city from New York State Route 17/I86 and intending to access any route lying south of the city's southerly boundary shall proceed on East Church Street to Clemens Center Parkway, and thence shall proceed on Clemens Center Parkway to the city's southerly boundary. 
c.  Said motor vehicles entering the city from any other point not heretofore mentioned, once entering the city shall proceed on the shortest route to the truck route system and then shall proceed within the truck route system until it exits the city's boundary. 
(e)  Penalty provision. Any person convicted of violating any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a violation within the meaning of the Penal Law § 55.10-3 of the state as from time to time amended, and shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $100,00 for the first such conviction, and no less that $300.00 nor more than $500.00 for the second such conviction, and not less than $1,000.00 for each subsequent conviction, or upon the first or subsequent convictions, imprisonment for up to 15 days. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.18; Code 1973, § 25-66; Ord. of 3-14-1955; Ord. of 6-15-1959; § 1; Ord. of 12-5-1960; Ord. of 8-3-1964, § 2; Ord. of 1-18-1965, § 1; Ord. of 2-1-1965, § 1; Ord. of 11-17-1969, § 1; Ord. of 3-9-1970, § 1; Ord. No. 80-267, § 1, 4-21-1980; Ord. No. 80-478, § 1, 8-11-1980; Ord. No. 84-432, § 1, 8-6-1984; Ord. No. 84-462, § 1, 8-20-1984; Ord. No. 84-479, §§ 1, 2, 9-4-1984; Ord. No. 85-339, § 1, 7-8-1985; Ord. No. 89-249, § 1, 4-24-1989; Ord. No. 90-522, § 1, 8-13-1990; Ord. No. 97-139, § 1. 3-31-1997; Ord. No. 99-25, § 1, 1-19-1999; Ord. No. 2000-233, §§ 1, 2, 6-19-2000; Ord. No. 2003-300, § 1, 8-25-2003; Ord. No. 2005-46, § 1, 2-7-2005; Ord. No. 2005-258, § 1, 7-25-2005; Ord. No. 2006-69, § 1, 2-21-2006; Ord. No. 2011-313, § 1, 10-24-2011; Ord. No. 2014-195, § 1, 6-2-2014; Ord. No. 2015-169, § 1, 6-1-2015 ) 
State Law reference- Power of city to exclude trucks, etc., in excess of designated weight from designated highways, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(5).

Sec. 25-68. - Use of horns. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not blast his horn or other audible signaling device for other than warning purposes in the normal course of traffic. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.2; Code 1973, § 25-68) 
State Law reference- Sounding horn, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1146. 
Sec. 25-69. - Use of sound trucks. 
(a)  No vehicle, except the public safety cars, equipped with an amplification or other device used for attracting attention shall be driven on any street while such device is being used. 
(b)  It shall be within the law to use paper megaphones; this section means some device that is properly mechanical; any vehicle equipped with a mechanical device. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.3; Code 1973, § 25-69) 
Sec. 25-70. - Parking of trucks, tractors, etc., on city streets. 
    Neither the driver nor the owner of a vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), as defined in the vehicle and traffic law, now and as hereinafter amended, of more than 10,000 pounds shall park or permit such vehicle to be parked on any city street for more than one hour. 
(Code 1973, § 25-70; Ord. of 11-5-1979, § 1; Ord. No. 2001-425, § 1, 10-17-2001; Ord. No. 2009-269, § 1, 6-22-2009) 
Sec. 25-71. - Unattended trucks, tractors, etc. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key from the vehicle, and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway; provided, however, the provision for removing the key from the vehicle shall not require the removal of keys hidden from sight about the vehicle for convenience or emergency. 
(Code 1973, § 25-71; Ord. of 11-5-1979, § 1) 
State Law reference- Unattended vehicles, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1210. 
Sec. 25-72. - Certain vehicles must stop at all railroad grade crossings. 
    In accordance with Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1171 certain vehicles must stop at all railroad grade crossings, unless otherwise specified. 
(1)  No stop needs to be made at any such crossing where a police officer or a traffic control signal or sign directs traffic to proceed. 
(2)  The following railroad grade crossings are exempt from this section, and shall be so identified by an exempt sign: 
Judson Street Extension, between Madison Avenue and Sullivan Street. 
Clemens Parkway, north of East Washington Avenue. 
Madison Avenue, just north of East Clinton Street. 
East Fifth Street, at Hatch Street. 
Hatch Street, just north of East Fifth Street. 
(Code 1973, § 25-72; Ord. No. 84-481, § 1, 9-4-1984) 
State Law reference- Certain vehicles to stop at all railroad crossings, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1171.

ARTICLE V. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic signs, signals and markings, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1110 et seq.; power of city to regulate traffic by means of traffic control signals, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(11). 

Sec. 25-80. - Traffic signs and signals. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall obey all traffic control signals and traffic signs. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 55.1; Code 1973, § 25-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1110. 
Sec. 25-81. - Types. 
    There shall be five types of traffic control signals, seven types of traffic signs and one type of pedestrian control signal which may be used to control the movement of traffic as follows: 
(1)  Electric control signals. Devices electrically or hand-operated in which the colors "red" and "green," or "red," "amber" and "green" alternately direct traffic to stop and go. 
(2)  Electric blinker signals. Devices electrically operated in which only the color red flashes at regular intervals, and upon which is printed the legend "stop then go," or devices electrically operated in which the colors red and amber flash at regular intervals on opposite sides and upon which is printed on the red lens stop and on the amber lens caution. 
(3)  Electric combination signals. Devices electrically operated which in the course of operation can be utilized either as an electric blinker signal as defined in subsection (2) of this section, or as an electric control signal as defined in subsection (1) of this section, or can perform an additional function or functions. 
(4)  Stop signs. Signs bearing the word "stop" indicating a main artery of travel. 
(5)  Slow signs. Signs bearing the word "slow" indicating a dangerous intersection. 
(6)  One-way signs. Signs in the shape of an arrow bearing the words "one-way" and pointing the direction in which vehicular traffic may travel. 
(7)  School signs. Signs limiting speed to 15 miles per hour when passing a school building or in school zones in the shape of a police officer or other sign indicating a school zone which signs may be placed on poles or in the traveled portion of the street during school hours or while children are going to or leaving school. 
(8)  Yield signs. Signs bearing the words "yield right-of-way" indicating a dangerous intersection. The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign if required for safety to stop shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or in the event there is no crosswalk, at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of the approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection and the right to proceed shall be governed as follows: The driver shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian legally crossing the roadway on which he is driving, or to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard. Such driver having so yielded may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching the intersection shall yield to the vehicle so proceeding. 
(9)  Pedestrian-control signals. Whenever special pedestrian-control signals exhibiting the words "Walk" or "Wait" or "Don't Walk" are in place such signals shall indicate as follows: 
a.  Walk. Pedestrians facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles. 
b.  Wait or don't walk. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety zone while the wait or don't walk signal is showing. 
(10)  Traffic-actuated signal. A traffic control signal which operates in accordance with a varying time schedule dependent upon the demands of traffic as registered by the actuation of vehicle detectors and/or pedestrian push buttons. 
a.  Semitraffic-actuated signal. A traffic-actuated signal provided with means for actuation on only some of the approaches. 
b.  Full-traffic-actuated signal. A traffic-actuated signal provided with means for actuation on all approaches. 
(11)  Fire and emergency control signals. An actuated traffic signal to be used for fire runs and emergency runs only; traffic will be stopped on a red signal and a green signal will show in favor of the direction of the fire or emergency vehicle, all other times light will be operated as an electric blinker signal. 
(12)  Overhead signs. 
a.  Lane designation. An overhead sign to be used to designate lane usage. 
b.  Overhead clearance signs. An overhead clearance sign to be used to inform persons of the legal overhead clearance for all bridges and structures within the city having less than 14 feet of measured clearance. (Manual of Traffic Control Devices, Cf. 212.8 and 233.9.) 
(13)  Do not enter. Signs to prevent traffic from entering the roadway in the wrong direction. 
(14)  Wrong way. This sign may be used to inform motorists that they are proceeding in the wrong direction on a one-way roadway. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 53.1; Code 1973, § 25-81; Ord. of 10-31-1955; Ord. of 11-17-1958, § 1; Ord. of 7-23-1962, § 1; Ord. of 10-24-1966, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-1966, § 1; Ord. of 5-17-1971, § 1; Ord. No. 80-713, § 1, 12-29-1980)
