(Code 1973, § 25-93; Ord. of 6-23-1975, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 25-94. - Right turn on a steady red signal prohibited; exceptions at certain times. 
    Pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(1), the following intersections are hereby added as intersections at which a right turn on a steady red signal is prohibited: 
(a)  South of river. 
South Main Street and Pennsylvania Avenue. All vehicles proceeding north or south on South Main Street at its intersection with Pennsylvania Avenue shall not turn right on a red signal. 
Pennsylvania Avenue and South Avenue. All vehicles proceeding north on Pennsylvania Avenue at its intersection with South Avenue shall not turn right on a red signal. 
Pennsylvania Avenue and Walgreen's parking lot. All vehicles exiting the Walgreen's parking lot onto Pennsylvania Avenue shall not turn right on a red signal. 
Sly Street and Maple Avenue. All vehicles proceeding north on Sly Street at its intersection with Maple Avenue shall not turn right on a steady red signal. 
Walnut Street and Hudson Street. All vehicles proceeding north on Walnut Street at its intersection with Hudson Street shall not turn right on a red signal. 
(b)  North of river. 
East Church Street and Madison Avenue. All vehicles proceeding west on East Church Street at its intersection with Madison Avenue shall not turn right on a steady red signal on Monday through Friday between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
Clemens Center Parkway and East Second Street. All vehicles proceeding south on Clemens Center Parkway shall not turn right onto East Second Street between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., and 2:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m., on all days when school is in session. 
Clemens Center Parkway and East Fifth Street. All vehicles proceeding north on Clemens Center Parkway shall not turn right onto East Fifth Street between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., and 2:00 p.m. and 3:00 p.m., on all days when school is in session. 
Davis Street and West Thurston Street. All vehicles proceeding north on Davis Street shall not turn right on red at its intersection with West Thurston Street and Crete Avenue. 
East Fifth Street and William Street and Lake Street. All vehicles proceeding East on East Fifth Street at its intersection with William Street and Lake Street, shall not turn right on a steady red signal. 
Grand Central Avenue and Division Street. Vehicles southbound on Grand Central Avenue may not make a right turn onto Division Street on a steady red signal. 
East Gray Street and Railroad Avenue. Vehicles westbound on East Gray Street may not make a right turn onto Railroad Avenue on a steady red signal. 
West Gray Street and West lane of Railroad Avenue. Running northerly from West Water Street to West Gray Street and exiting beside the Centertown parking garage. 
West Gray Street at Railroad Avenue, west lane. At the entrance/exit to and from Centertown parking garage. 
Judson Street extension. Vehicles northbound on Judson Street Extension shall not make a right turn onto Sullivan Street on a steady red signal. 
East Market Street and Baldwin Street. All vehicles proceeding west on East Market Street at its intersection with Baldwin Street shall not turn right on a red signal. 
Lake Street and Division Street. Vehicles southbound on Lake Street may not make a right turn on Division Street on a steady red signal. 
Lake Street and East Fifth Street. All vehicles proceeding north or south on Lake Street at its intersection with East Fifth Street shall not turn right on an red signal. 
Lake Street and East Second Street. All vehicles proceeding north on Lake Street shall not turn right on red at its intersection with East Second Street. 
East Second Street and Baldwin Street. Vehicles proceeding west on East Second Street shall not turn right on red signal at its intersection with Baldwin Street. 
Sullivan Street and East Fifth Street. All vehicles proceeding north on William Street at its intersection with East Fifth Street shall not turn right on a red signal. 
Sullivan Street and Judson Street. Vehicles southbound on Sullivan Street shall not make a right turn onto Judson Street Extension on a steady red signal. 
Sullivan Street and Judson Street. All vehicles proceeding through this intersection shall not turn right on a red signal between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. on days when school is in session. 
West Thurston and Davis Street. Vehicles proceeding west on West Thurston Street shall not turn right on a red signal at its intersection with Davis Street. 
Woodlawn Avenue and Clemens Center Parkway. All vehicles proceeding east on Woodlawn Avenue at its intersection with the Clemens Center Parkway shall not turn right on a steady red signal. 
Woodlawn Avenue and Clemens Center Parkway. All vehicles proceeding south of Clemens Center Parkway shall not turn right on a steady red signal. 
Union Place and East Second Street. Vehicles proceeding south on Union Place shall not turn right on red at East Second Street. 
Woodlawn Avenue and College Avenue. All vehicles proceeding west on Woodlawn Avenue at its intersection with College Avenue shall not turn right on a steady red signal. 
(Code 1973, § 25-94; Ord. of 12-20-1976, § 1; Ord. of 9-11-1978, § 1; Ord. No. 80-688, § 1, 12-15-1980; Ord. No. 81-168, § 1, 4-6-1981; Ord. No. 82-460, § 1, 10-4-1982; Ord. No. 83-186, § 1, 4-4-1983; Ord. No. 86-277, § 1, 6-9-1986; Ord. No. 86-642, § 1, 11-24-1986; Ord. No. 93-530, § 1, 10-4-1993; Ord. No. 95-158, § 1, 4-3-1995; Ord. No. 96-241, § 1, 5-13-1996; Ord. No. 98-176, § 1, 4-13-1998; Ord. No. 98-465, § 1, 11-23-1998; Ord. No. 2001-65, § 1, 2-26-2001; Ord. No. 2001-81, § 1, 3-12-2001; Ord. No. 2001-143, § 1, 4-23-2001; Ord. No. 2008-122, § 1, 3-31-2008; Ord. No. 2009-41, § 1, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 2009-217, § 1, 5-26-2009; Ord. No. 2010-327, § 1, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2013-20, § 1, 1-14-2013; Ord. No. 2012-376, § 1, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 25-95. - Do not enter signs. 
    Pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(1), the following streets are hereby designated as "do not enter": 
Transportation Center Drive and East Church Street (north of river). Vehicles proceeding west on East Church Street shall not enter the western drive of the Transportation Center. 
(Code 1973, § 25-95; Ord. No. 80-715, § 1, 12-29-1980) 
Sec. 25-96. - Wrong way designations. 
    Pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(1) of the state, the following intersection shall be designated "wrong way": 
Transportation Center Drive and East Gray Street. Vehicles proceeding south on the westerly drive of the Transportation Center shall not enter East Gray Street. 
(Code 1973, § 25-96; Ord. No. 80-716, § 1, 12-29-1980) 
Secs. 25-97-25-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPEED REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1180 et seq.; speed limits on highways in cities, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1643; special speed limits on bridges and other elevated structures in cities, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1644. 

Sec. 25-100. - Speed. 
(a)  The maximum speed at which a vehicle, as defined by the state vehicle and traffic law, shall be operated upon any public highway in the city, except such public highway upon which a different maximum speed has been established pursuant to this article, is 30 miles per hour. 
(b)  On the Clemens Center Parkway from East Second Street to Grand Central Avenue the maximum speed shall be 40 miles per hour. 
(c)  On public highways within the Woodlawn Cemetery, an area speed limit is established at which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater than 15 miles per hour. 
(d)  On public highways within the Hathorn Court and Hoffman Plaza, an area speed limit is established at which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater than ten miles per hour. 
(e)  On that designated area of the public highway known as Maple Avenue between its intersection with the southerly boundary line of Sly Street and its intersection with the northerly boundary line of Home Street, in which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater than 25 mph. 
(f)  On the following public highways, an area speed limit is established at which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater than 20 miles per hour: 
Roe Avenue, from Hoffman Street to Bonview Street. 
Bonview Street, from Hoffman Street to Fountain Drive. 
Fountain Drive, from Bonview Street to Reservoir Street. 
Reservoir Street, from Hoffman Street to Fountain Drive. 
(g)  On public highways within any city park, except Eldridge Park, and area speed limit is established at which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater that 15 miles per hour. 
(h)  On public highways within Eldridge Park, an area speed limit is established at which no vehicle shall be operated at a speed greater than five miles per hour. 
(i)  The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to post such traffic signs as are authorized by the state vehicle and traffic law and the state department of transportation's Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices to implement the above speed limits. 
(Code 1973, § 25-100; Ord. No. 88-517, § 1, 9-12-1988; Ord. No. 99-265, § 1, 6-21-1999; Ord. No. 2001-160, §§ 1-2, 4-23-2001) 
Sec. 25-101. - School speed zones. 
(a)  The maximum speed at which a vehicle, as defined by the state vehicle and traffic law, shall be operated upon any public highway in the city that has been designated as a school speed zone pursuant to this section is 20 miles per hour. 
(b)  The following schools are located within the city limits: 
Thomas K. Beecher School. 
Arthur W. Booth School. 
Parley Coburn School. 
Ernie Davis Junior High School. 
George M. Diven School. 
Elmira Christian Academy. 
Elmira Free Academy. 
Holy Family Catholic School. 
Riverside School. 
Southside High School. 
J. Sloat Fassett School. 
(c)  The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to establish the limits of school speed zones and post traffic signs as are authorized by the state vehicle and traffic law and the state department of transportation's Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices at each school within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 25-101; Ord. No. 88-517, § 1, 9-12-1988; Ord. No. 97-27, § 1, 1-21-1997; Ord. No. 2012-375, § 1, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 25-102. - Playground speed zones. 
(a)  The maximum speed at which a vehicle, as defined by the state vehicle and traffic law, shall be operated upon any public highway in the city that has been designated as a playground speed zone pursuant to this section is 25 miles per hour. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to establish the limits of playground speed zones and post traffic signs as are authorized by the state vehicle and traffic law and the state department of transportation's Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices at each such playground within the city limits. 
(Code 1973, § 25-102; Ord. No. 88-517, § 1, 9-12-1988; Ord. No. 2013-18, § 1, 1-14-2013) 
Secs. 25-103-25-118. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Special stops required, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1170 et seq.; stopping, standing and parking, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1200 et seq.; power of city to prohibit, restrict or limit the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(6). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 25-119. - Signs. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on a street contrary to or in violation of any traffic sign. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.1; Code 1973, § 25-119) 
Sec. 25-120. - No parking on left side of street. 
    No vehicle shall be stopped or parked with its left side to the curb, except on one-way streets. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.2; Code 1973, § 25-120) 
Sec. 25-121. - Prohibitions on bridges; in tunnels. 
    Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or when in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel unless otherwise indicated by official signs, markings or parking meters. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.3; Code 1973, § 25-121; Ord. No. 79-87, § 1, 2-13-1979) 
Sec. 25-122. - Prohibitions under overheads. 
    When traffic signs are displayed giving notice thereof, no vehicle shall be parked on a street under a railroad overhead crossing at any time; and no vehicle, except in a lane of traffic or because of an emergency, shall be stopped on a street under a railroad overhead crossing at any time. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.4; Code 1973, § 25-122) 
Sec. 25-123. - Prohibitions at schools. 
    When traffic signs are displayed which prohibit parking on that side of a street adjacent to any school property, no vehicle shall be parked in any such designated place. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.5; Code 1973, § 25-123) 
Sec. 25-124. - Double parking prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be double-parked at any time or place, except that when there is no available space at the curb a vehicle may be double-parked for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading freight; provided, however, that such parking does not unreasonably obstruct the movement of other traffic, and provided, further, that upon the direction of a police officer, a vehicle so parked shall promptly proceed from such position. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.6; Code 1973, § 25-124) 
Sec. 25-125. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 95-33, § 1, adopted January 23, 1995, repealed § 25-125, parking prohibited in congested district, derived from Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.9. 
Sec. 25-126. - Parking prohibited at driveways. 
    No vehicle shall be stopped or parked on a public highway across or in front of the entrance to any public or private driveway at any time, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.10; Code 1973, § 25-126) 
Sec. 25-127. - Diagonal parking permitted. 
    A vehicle may be parked diagonally to the curb only within spaces marked on the pavement for such purpose. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.12; Code 1973, § 25-127) 
Sec. 25-128. - Parking in public highways. 
    A vehicle shall not be parked in a public highway, so as to leave available less than ten feet of such highway for the free movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.13; Code 1973, § 25-128) 
Sec. 25-129. - Parking between sidewalk and curb prohibited. 
    No cars, trucks, motorcycles, bicycles or other vehicles, and no trailers or other vehicular appurtenances or parts may be parked wholly or partially in the space between the curb and the sidewalk, or where there is no curb, between the edge of the roadway and the sidewalk. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 43.23; Code 1973, § 25-129; Ord. of 12-30-1968, § 1) 
Sec. 25-130. - Parking prohibited in front of entrance to county jail. 
    When traffic signs are displayed giving notice thereof, no motor vehicle shall be parked within a space of 30 feet in length directly in front of the entrance to the county jail on the west side of William Street except sheriff's cars. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.16; Code 1973, § 25-130) 
Sec. 25-131. - Parking and standing of vehicles. 
(a)  Parking on the following parts of streets shall be limited to parking on the south side of the street, seven days a week, 24 hours a day: 
(1)  West First Street, from Foster to College Avenue. 
(2)  West Second Street, from Euclid to College Avenue. 
(3)  West Third Street, from Hoffman Street to Davis Street. 
(4)  West Gray Street, from Foster Avenue to College Avenue. 
(5)  West Hudson Street, from the northwest corner of the intersection of West Hudson Street and South Walnut Street, westerly a distance of 890 feet. 
(b)  Parking on Baylor Road shall be limited to parking on the north side of the street, seven days a week, 24 hours a day. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, no vehicle shall be or remain parked between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., except as follows: 
(1)  On days with even numbers according to the calendar, on the side of any street on which the properties bear even street numbers. 
(2)  On days with odd numbers according to the calendar, on the side of any street on which the properties bear odd street numbers. 
(3)  No vehicle, as defined and amended and adopted by the Vehicle and Traffic Law of New York State, shall be continuously parked on any street in the same location for more than 48 hours. 
(d)  The provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall not apply where parking is otherwise restricted by signs or where parking is restricted or prohibited on one side of the street for a full city block. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.17; Code 1973, § 25-131; Ord. of 5-4-1959; Ord. No. 90-286, § 1, 5-7-1990; Ord. No. 92-149, § 1, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 99-363, § 1, 9-13-1999; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 1, 1-18-2000; Ord. No. 2014-246, §§ 1, 2, 7-14-2014; Ord. No. 2014-364, § 1, 11-3-2014 ; Ord. No. 2015-74, § 1, 3-9-2015 ) 
Sec. 25-132. - Stopping or standing prohibited. 
    When traffic signs are displayed giving notice of such districts, no vehicle shall be stopped or shall stand within such prohibited district. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.18; Code 1973, § 25-132) 
Sec. 25-133. - Parking in public parking lots and parking garages. 
(a)  Restrictions. 
(1)  When signs are displayed at any public parking lot or parking garages, and ramps, vehicular entranceways and exit ways, giving notice of the times permitting parking, and the fees charged for such parking, except where such parking is controlled by other provisions of this article, a vehicle shall not stand or be parked within a parking space in such lot unless he has first paid the required fee, as posted, for such parking, or in those lots controlled by electronic timing devices, he has first obtained a ticket for such parking indicating the time of entry upon such parking lot. Parking in violation of these provisions or failure to pay the fee for parking as provided is hereby declared to be a parking infraction. 
(2)  No person, other than an authorized person, shall park or permit a motor vehicle owned by him to be parked, in the city hall parking lots, said lots being located to the north of the city hall building, at any time between the hours of 7:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. on any day except Sundays and legal holidays, nor on Saturdays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. The parking of a motor vehicle by a person other than the owner thereof shall be considered to be with the permission of the owner for all purposes under this section. 
(3)  No person, other than an authorized person or a visitor, shall park or permit a motor vehicle owned by him to be parked, in the upper parking lot at the department of public works, at the center island, designated by number and title. All other parking in the upper lot of the department of public works building will be for city vehicles only. 
(b)  A vehicle must be parked within the lines indicating parking spaces; and in no event shall any vehicle be parked so as to occupy more than one parking space, or be parked so as to restrict the entrance or exit of the parking lot or parking garage or any space thereof provided for parking. 
(c)  There shall be no unauthorized parking, stopping or standing in any space or area in any public parking lot, parking garage, ramps or vehicular entranceways and exit ways restricted to municipal use or reserved by lease with the city or designated for parking for the handicapped, or otherwise prohibited by the executive order of the city manager. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all areas owned or operated by the city whether operated by the city or its agent or lessee. All fines collected for violations of this section shall be paid to the city chamberlain. 
(e)  The police department is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this section and to tag motor vehicles in violation in the same manner as on city streets. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.20; Code 1973, § 25-133; Ord. of 7-20-1964 § 1; Ord. No. 79-227, § 1, 4-23-1979; Ord. No. 80-148, § 1, 3-10-1980; Ord. No. 84-431, § 1, 8-6-1984; Ord. No. 84-480, § 1, 9-6-1984) 
Sec. 25-134. - Parking during public emergency. 
(a)  When in his judgment it is necessary for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, the city manager may declare a public emergency. Such public emergency shall be announced through the press, if possible, but in any event by an announcement over one or more local television or radio stations. Until the announcement is made in the same manner that the public emergency is over, parking of vehicles on city streets in the city shall be prohibited as directed by the city manager. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked or abandoned on any city street during any public emergency may be removed by order of the city manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(c)  After removal of any vehicle as provided in this section, the city manager or his duly authorized representative may order the vehicle stored in a suitable place at the expense of the owner. Such owner may redeem such vehicle upon payment of all expenses actually and necessarily incurred in effecting such removal and/or storage. 
(d)  As soon as possible thereafter, the police department shall notify the owner of the removal and disposition of such vehicle. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.21; Code 1973, § 25-134; Ord. of 12-5-1966, § 1) 
Sec. 25-135. - Removal of vehicles during emergencies. 
(a)  Whenever a police officer shall deem it advisable during a fire, accident or other emergency to move or remove and store any parked vehicle for the public safety or convenience, such official shall have the power and authority to do so, for the duration of such emergency, such vehicle not to be released until the reasonable cost of removing and storing are paid by the owner or operator of any such vehicle. 
(b)  After such removal and storage the police property clerk shall, without delay, ascertain the ownership of such vehicle and notify the owner of removal and disposition of such vehicle. 
(Code 1973, § 25-135; Ord. of 2-14-1967, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 25-136. - Abandoned or illegally parked vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section and section 25-137, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Abandoned vehicle shall mean: 
a.  Any motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer deemed abandoned by the state vehicle and traffic law, as amended from time to time; 
b.  Any motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer lacking its engine or transmission or drive train or axles, or wheels or other major mechanical component. 
(2)  Minor emergency repairs shall mean any repairs arising from the sudden, unexpected failure or malfunction of the motor vehicles, motorcycle or trailer and which repair can be accomplished within 24 hours. Such repairs shall not include the removal of any engine, transmission or drive train of the vehicle, motorcycle or trailer. 
(b)  Abandoning prohibited. No person shall cause any motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer to be an abandoned vehicle, motorcycle or trailer on any public street, highway, right-of-way, public parking lot or public parking garage. There shall be a rebuttable presumption that the owner of an abandoned vehicle caused such vehicle to be abandoned. 
(c)  Repairs prohibited; exception. No person shall park or cause to be parked a motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer on any public street, highway, right-of-way, public parking lot, or public parking garage and undertake to repair such motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer thereon except for minor emergency repairs. 
(d)  Immobilization; removal; impoundment. Any abandoned motor vehicle, motorcycle, or trailer or any motor vehicle, motorcycle, or trailer parked in violation of any local law, ordinance, rule, regulation, or state vehicle and traffic law or any motor vehicle, motorcycle, or trailer with three or more unpaid or unanswered violations charging that said motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer was parked, stopped or standing in violation of any local law, ordinance, rule, regulation or state Vehicle and Traffic Law may be immobilized by way of an immobilization device as designated by the city or towed by the city's authorized towing company to a specified lot or yard. The motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer will remain immobilized or in storage until the costs associated with immobilization or towing and storing, in addition to all unpaid parking tickets in the name of the owner or issued under the license plate number affixed to the vehicle being redeemed, are paid by the owner or operator of such motor vehicle, motorcycle, or trailer or by a representative thereof; or the disposition of such motor vehicle, motorcycle, or trailer in accordance with section 25-141. 
(e)  Unlicensed or unregistered motor vehicles. No person shall store outside on private property any unlicensed or unregistered motor vehicle, including any unlicensed or unregistered vehicle used by a person in the sport of racing, except legal junkyards and licensed automobile dealers, for a period longer than seven days in any calendar year. 
(f)  Penalties. In addition to the penalties as set forth in section 1-14 a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00. 
(Code 1973, § 25-136; Ord. of 2-14-1967, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 88-351, §§ 1, 2, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 90-228, § 1, 4-9-1990; Ord. No. 90-333, § 1, 5-21-1990; Ord. No. 2005-166, §§ 2-3, 5-2-2005; Ord. No. 2008-201, § 1, 6-9-2008) 
Sec. 25-137. - Immobilization, towing and storage fees for motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers abandoned, illegally parked or unpaid or unanswered violations; established. 
(a)  A fee of $50.00 is established for expenses associated with the attachment and removal of an immobilization device in addition to any and all other outstanding fines, fees and penalties then due and owing. 
(b)  Towing. 
(1)  If the city causes the motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer to be towed and stored at the city's impound lot, then the owner or operator redeeming the motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer shall pay the towing charge actually incurred by the city for towing and storing the following: 
(i)  Abandoned motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers and motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers parked illegally on the streets of the city; 
(ii)  Motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers parked illegally in a public parking lot, public garage and the ramps, vehicular entranceways or exitways of the parking garage in the city; 
(iii)  Motor vehicles, motorcycles or trailers abandoned or parked in violation of the zoning ordinances of the city; 
(iv)  Motor vehicles in violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 or 318(12); 
(v)  Any vehicle in violation of section 25-136. 
(2)  In addition to the fee set forth in subsection (a) of this section, a fee of $20.00 per day shall be and hereby is established for the impounding of any abandoned vehicle or other vehicles described in this subsection (b), and an additional $50.00 shall be charged to the owner of any motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer, and/or the owner or lessee of the premises upon which an abandoned or illegally parked motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer is located, for administrative costs incurred by the city. 
(c)  If the motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer is towed to the towing company's place of business, then the owner or operator redeeming the motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer shall pay directly to the towing company all expenses associated with the towing and storage of the following: 
(1)  Abandoned motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers and motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers parked illegally on the streets of the city; 
(2)  Motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers parked illegally in a public parking lot, public garage and the ramps, vehicular entranceways or exitways of the parking garage in the city; 
(3)  Motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers abandoned or parked in violation of the zoning ordinances set forth in appendix B to this Code; 
(4)  Motor vehicles in violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 or 318(12); 
(5)  Any vehicle in violation of section 25-136. 
(Code 1973, § 25-137; Ord. of 10-9-1967, §§ 1-3; Ord. of 8-23-1971, §§ 1-3; Ord. of 12-26-1972, §§ 1-3; Ord. of 8-6-1973, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 79-228, § 1, 4-23-1979; Ord. No. 82-103, § 1, 2-22-1982; Ord. No. 88-46, § 1, 1-19-1988; Ord. No. 90-229, § 1, 4-9-1990; Ord. No. 95-448, § 1, 8-21-1995; Ord. No. 2005-167, § 1, 5-2-2005; Ord. No. 2008-202, § 1, 6-9-2008; Ord. No. 2016-60, § 1, 2-16-2016) 
Sec. 25-138. - Handicapped parking space and handicapped parking access aisle. 
    When signs are displayed which designate a parking space as one which is for use by the handicapped, no person shall park, stop or stand a motor vehicle in such space unless the vehicle is registered in accordance with the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 404-a, or there is displayed a valid special handicapped parking permit on the dashboard or sun visor on the driver's side or attached to the rear view mirror when said vehicle is parked in said designated handicapped parking space and is being used for the transportation of a handicapped person. No person shall park, stop or stand a motor vehicle in a handicapped parking access aisle. 
(Code 1973, § 25-138; Ord. No. 80-148, § 1, 3-10-1980; Ord. No. 98-177, § 1, 4-13-1998; Ord. No. 2004-038, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 25-139. - Penalties for parking, stopping or standing in spaces designated handicapped and parking access aisles in parking lots or on public street. 
    Any person who parks, stops or stands a motor vehicle in a parking space marked for use by the handicapped or in a handicapped parking access aisle in violation of section 25-138 shall be subject to a fine of $75.00 plus any mandatory surcharge levied pursuant to of the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1809-b of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 25-139; Ord. No. 82-164, § 1, 3-2-1982; Ord. No. 84-509, § 1, 9-17-1984; Ord. No. 93-513, § 1, 9-20-1993; Ord. No. 98-178, § 1, 4-13-1998; Ord. No. 2000-103, § 1, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 2004-038, § 2, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 25-140. - Parking in public parks. 
(a)  No motor vehicle or motorcycle shall be operated in a public park other than on established public roadways or in parking lots. Maintenance roads shall not be used by the general public. 
(b)  No motor vehicle or motorcycle shall be parked within the limits of any public park other than in designated parking lots. 
(c)  Any vehicle parking in violation of this section shall be subject to the provisions of section 25-137. 
(d)  The police department is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this section and to tag motor vehicles in violation in the same manner as on city streets. 
(Code 1973, § 25-140; Ord. No. 89-387, § 1, 7-3-1989) 
Sec. 25-141. - Disposition of abandoned, unregistered or unlicensed motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers. 
(a)  If an abandoned motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer, as defined in section 25-136, at the time of abandonment has no number plates affixed and is of a wholesale value, taking into consideration the condition of the vehicle, motorcycle or trailers, or an amount of $750.00 or less, title shall vest in the city. 
(b)  Except for motor vehicles, motorcycles and trailers governed by subsection (a) of this section, the city, upon taking custody of an abandoned motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer or upon taking custody of a motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer pursuant to the zoning ordinance, set forth in appendix B to this Code, shall make an inquiry concerning the last owner of such vehicle, motorcycle or trailer as follows: 
(1)  Vehicles, motorcycles or trailers with number plates affixed, to the jurisdiction which issued such number plates; 
(2)  Vehicles, motorcycles or trailers with no number plates affixed, to the department of motor vehicles. 
(c)  The last owner, if known, shall be notified that the vehicle in question has been recovered as an abandoned vehicle, or a vehicle, motorcycle or trailer in violation of the zoning ordinance and that, if unclaimed, it will be sold at public auction or by bid after ten days from the date such notice was given. If the agency described in subsection (a) of this section also notifies such local authority that a lien or mortgage exists, such notice shall also be sent to the lienholder or mortgagee. The state commissioner of motor vehicles shall prescribe the methods of giving notice. Any person claiming such vehicle shall be required to pay the costs of removal and storage of such vehicle. 
(d)  Ownership of such abandoned vehicle, motorcycle or trailer, if unclaimed, shall vest in the city ten days from the date such notice is given; or if the last owner cannot be ascertained, when notice of such fact is received. 
(e)  The provisions of subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section shall apply to any motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer, regardless of its wholesale value, taken into custody by the city pursuant to section 450 of the zoning ordinance, set forth in appendix B to this Code. 
(f)  Disposition of vehicles. 
(1)  If suitable for operation. Upon vesting of ownership in the city, the city shall determine if a vehicle is suitable for operation on a public highway. If so, the vehicle shall be sold at public auction to the highest bidder or converted pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1224.6. 
(2)  If not suitable for operation. 
a.  If the city determines that a vehicle is not suitable for operation on the public highways, it shall sell the vehicle to a vehicle dismantler or scrap processor registered or certified pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a, or to a vehicle dismantler or scrap processor who does not have a place of business in this state but who conforms to the laws and regulations of the state in which he has a place of business. 
b.  A vehicle without a vehicle identification number plate must be sold only to a vehicle dismantler or a scrap processor registered or certified pursuant to the Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a, or to a vehicle dismantler or scrap processor who does not have a place of business in this state but who conforms to the laws and regulations of the state in which he has a place of business. 
c.  Any proceeds from the sale of a motor vehicle, motorcycle or trailer, less any expenses incurred by the city, shall be held by the city without interest for the benefit of the owner of such vehicle for a period of one year. If not claimed within such one-year period, such proceeds shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 25-141; Ord. No. 90-230, § 1, 4-9-1990)

Secs. 25-142-25-147. - Reserved.

Sec. 25-149. - Parking at parking meters. 
(a)  When signs are displayed by a parking meter giving notice thereof, a vehicle shall not stand or be parked within a parking meter space adjacent thereto between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, or at such other hours as may hereinafter be set forth for certain parking spaces, except legal holidays and each general election day, unless the operator of such vehicle shall deposit in such parking meter a United States coin or coins of a denomination designated on the sign on the meter adjacent to such vehicle, and turn handle, sufficient to entitle the operator to park such vehicle in such space for a period not longer than the maximum period of time prescribed by such sign for a coin of such denomination, except that the operator of such vehicle may use any unexpired time of the previous user without the deposit of a coin. No vehicle shall stand or park in a parking meter space when the parking meter adjacent thereto is displaying a signal showing such parking to be illegal or expired. In no event shall a vehicle, regardless of the deposit of additional coins and operation of meter bar, stand or be parked in a parking meter space for a period longer than the maximum time prescribed on the adjacent parking meter. 
(b)  There shall be no parking, stopping or standing at any parking meter space, or at any other permitted parking, stopping or standing space, whenever in the judgment of a police officer or a peace officer such parking, stopping or standing should be temporarily forbidden. The presence of an official bag, labeled no parking or standing, over a parking meter, or a sign forbidding parking, stopping or standing for purposes other than loading or unloading of freight, shall be sufficient indication that no parking, stopping or standing is permitted except for the purposes indicated on the sign. 
(c)  A vehicle parked within a parking meter space shall be parked parallel and adjacent to the curb; in the case of a single meter, with its front bumper alongside of the parking meter adjacent thereto; and in the case of a dual meter, with either its front or rear bumper alongside of the parking meter adjacent to the parking meter nearer the space to be occupied by such vehicle; and in the event that pavement markings are provided indicating parking spaces, that such vehicle shall be parked within the lines indicating such parking spaces; and in no event shall any vehicle be parked so as to occupy more than one parking space. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.15; Code 1973, § 25-149; Ord. of 7-8-1940; Ord. of 3-10-1941; Ord. of 10-11-1948; Ord. of 2-6-1956; Ord. of 3-9-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-17-1966, § 2; Ord. of 9-12-1966, § 4; Ord. No. 97-229, § 1, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 98-231, § 1, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 97-229, § 1, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 2012-61, § 1, 2-13-2012) 
Sec. 25-150. - Parking at metered areas in public parking lots and on metered public streets. 
(a)  When signs are displayed by a parking meter located in a public parking area, giving notice thereof, a vehicle shall not stand or be parked within a parking space controlled by such meter between the hours and on the days designated on such meter unless the operator of such vehicle shall deposit in such parking meter United States coins of a denomination designated on the meter controlling such parking space sufficient to entitle the operator to park such vehicle in such space for a period not longer than the maximum period of time prescribed by such time for a coin of such denomination except that the operator of such vehicle may use any unexpired time of the previous user without the deposit of a coin. Parking for a longer period of time than that permitted above is hereby declared to be a traffic infraction. No vehicle shall stand or park in such parking meter space when the parking meter controlling such space is displaying a signal showing such parking to be a violation. 
(b)  (1)  When signs are displayed in a public parking area giving notice of the use of a pay board, a vehicle shall not stand or be parked within a parking space controlled by and subject to the pay board between the hours and on the days designated on the pay board unless the operator of such vehicle shall deposit in the pay board coin, coins or bills to purchase the right to park a vehicle in a parking space for the maximum time purchased by the operator. No operator shall park a vehicle in a parking space controlled and subject to the pay board after the expiration of the maximum time purchased by the operator. 
(c)  The provisions of subparagraph (b)(1) shall apply to all parking lots owned by the city and controlled by a pay board. All fines collected for violations of this section shall be paid to the city chamberlain. 
(d)  The parking rates for each metered parking space in city owned parking lots and on public streets with metered parking shall be: 
(1)  First 15 minutes ..... Free 
(2)  Each additional 30 minutes ..... 0.25 
(e)  The police department is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this section to tag cars in violation in the same manner as on city streets. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 57.19; Code 1973, § 25-150; Ord. No. 2011-92, §§ 1-3, 3-14-2011; Ord. No. 2011-203, §§ 1-4, 7-5-2011; Ord. No. 2012-172, §§ 2, 3, 6-4-2012)

Sec. 25-152. - Elmira City School District. 
(a)  The city school district supports the public use of school buildings and grounds or portions thereof consistent with the state and federal law for adult education, discussion, religious, civic, social, recreation, entertainment, and such other purposes that promote the welfare of the community, including use as registration and polling places for voters. The multiple uses of the district's buildings and grounds creates an intermingling of vehicular and pedestrian traffic on school grounds within limited areas. The city school district having requested regulation of vehicular traffic on its grounds, the city council of the city does hereby find and declare that the regulation of vehicular traffic on properties owned by the city school district and located within the city will promote the public safety, health and welfare of the persons using school buildings and grounds for the multiple uses permitted by the school district. 
(b)  No person shall operate or park or stand a motor vehicle or motorcycle on property owned by the city school district in a manner contrary to that allowed or prohibited by signs or markings giving notice thereof. 
(Ord. No. 98-403, § 1, 9-28-1998; Ord. No. 2006-235, § 1, 7-24-2006) 
Secs. 25-153, 25-154. - Reserved.

Sec. 25-155. - Rates. 
(a)  Centertown Garage. * 
First two hours or any portion thereof ..... $0.50 
Each additional hour ..... $0.75 
Daily maximum (eight hours or more per day) ..... $5.00 
Overnight rate (after 10:00 p.m.) ..... $3.00 
Special events ..... $3.00 
Monthly business ..... $30.00 
Monthly residential (for those residing within the area bounded by East and West Water Streets, College Avenue, West Clinton Street and Madison Avenue) unrestricted ..... $25.00 
For any person or entity prepurchasing 500 or more parking spaces in accordance with regulations issued by the city manager, the rate is $2.00 per parking space. 
(1)  Upon the effective date of this ordinance and thereafter, any owner or tenant, or both, who develops, by new construction, any commercial or residential or mixed commercial/residential real property within the geographic area set forth below, shall be entitled to purchase monthly unreserved parking spaces in the Centertown Garage at the rate of $10.00 per month during the period from the effective date of this ordinance through December 31, 2019. Effective January 1, 2020, the monthly parking space rate shall be $12.50. To qualify for this rate, the purchaser must purchase a minimum of five parking spaces at the time of each purchase. 
(2)  Upon the effective date of this ordinance and thereafter, any owner and tenant, who redevelops any commercial/residential or mixed commercial/residential building in the geographic area set forth below, shall be entitled to purchase monthly unreserved parking spaces in the Centertown Garage at the rate of $10.00 per month during the period from the effective date of this ordinance through December 31, 2019. Effective January 1, 2020, the monthly parking space rate shall be $12.50. To qualify for this rate, the purchaser must purchase a minimum of five parking spaces at the time of each purchase. Redevelopment means any capital expenditures to an existing building in the geographic area set forth below totaling in excess of $10,000.00. To further qualify, the owner or tenant must submit invoices to the city evidencing the total expenditures incurred for the redevelopment. 
(3)  The geographic area referred to in subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) above shall consist of that area bounded on the south by East Water Street and West Water Street; on the west by College Avenue; on the north by West Church Street; and on the east by Lake Street, said area consisting of both sides of the aforementioned streets. 
(b)  Off street surface parking at 237 West Water Street 
Each 30 minutes ..... $0.25 
(c)  Off-Street Surface Parking at East Water Street (Tax Map Parcel No. 90.17-1-2). 
Overnight (maximum of 24 hours) ..... $5.00 
Monthly (up to 30 consecutive days) ..... $150.00 
(Ord. No. 2001-347, § 1, 10-22-2001; Ord. No. 2012-172, § 1, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 2013-210, § 1, 7-1-2013; Ord. No. 2014-99, § 1, 3-24-2014; Ord. No. 2018-79, § 1, 4-2-2018; Ord. No. 2018-132, § 1, 5-29-2018)

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-172, § 4, adopted June 4, 2012, repealed § 25-156, which pertained to group discount parking program in Elmira Business Improvement District and derived from Ord. No. 2001-347, § 2, 10-22-2001. 
Sec. 25-157. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-172, § 5, adopted June 4, 2012, repealed § 25-157, which pertained to nontransferability; assignment to employees permitted and derived from Ord. No. 2001-347, § 3, 10-22-2001. 
Sec. 25-158. - Hours of operation. 
    The hours of operation of the Centertown Garage shall be 24 hours per day/7 days per week. 
(Ord. No. 2001-347, § 4, 10-22-2001; Ord. No. 2013-210, § 2, 7-1-2013) 
Secs. 25-159, 25-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDESTRIANS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians' rights and duties, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1150 et seq.; power of city to regulate the crossing of any roadway by pedestrians, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640(a)(3). 

Sec. 25-161. - Pedestrians' rights and duties. 
(a)  Pedestrians shall obey traffic signals at all times. 
(b)  Where traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except on a crosswalk. 
(c)  Where traffic control signals are not in operation, the pedestrian has the right-of-way within any marked crosswalk and within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection. 
(d)  Pedestrians shall not cross the roadway other than on a crosswalk in the central traffic district. 
(e)  Every pedestrian crossing any other roadway at a point other than a crosswalk at an intersection shall cross by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb and shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(f)  No pedestrian, whether at a crosswalk or elsewhere, shall suddenly leave the curb or other place of safety and run or walk in the path of a vehicle which is so close that the driver is unable to avoid a collision. 
(g)  For the purposes of subsection (d) of this section, the following parameters shall apply: Central traffic district shall consist of the area bounded by Madison Avenue on the east, Water Street on the south, Second Street on the north, and Columbia Street on the west. Such area shall include both sides of the named boundary streets. 
(h)  Pedestrians shall not walk on the Clemens Center Parkway or the Clemens Center Bridge in those sections having no sidewalk, and "no pedestrian traffic" is so designated by traffic signs. 
(i)  Pedestrians shall not walk on the east side of Lake Street Bridge in that section having no sidewalk, and "no pedestrian traffic" is so designated by traffic signs. 
(j)  Pedestrians shall not walk on the east side of Walnut Street Bridge in that section having no sidewalk, and "no pedestrian traffic" is so designated by traffic signs. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.4; Code 1973, § 25-161; Ord. of 6-19-1957; Ord. No. 84-410, § 1, 7-23-1984; Ord. No. 84-512, § 1, 9-17-1984) 
Sec. 25-162. - Drivers to exercise due care. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.5; Code 1973, § 25-162; Ord. of 6-19-1957) 
Sec. 25-163. - Penalties. 
(a)  Persons violating the provisions of this article shall be served with a ticket to appear at a time therein stated at the pedestrian safety school of the city. Failure to do so shall result in the service of a warrant requiring them to appear in city court. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions in subsection (a) of this section, any violation of this article may be punished in the manner set forth in section 25-14. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 56.6; Code 1973, § 25-163; Ord. of 6-19-1957) 
Secs. 25-164-25-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - BICYCLES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of bicycles and play devices, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1230 et seq. 

Sec. 25-181. - Registration required. 
    No resident of the city shall ride a bicycle as defined by the vehicle and traffic law of the state, and as may be amended from time to time, on the streets, parks or public places in the city unless and until such bicycle shall have been registered as provided in this article and a license obtained as provided in this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.1; Code 1973, § 7-1; Ord. of 9-23-1963, § 1) 
Sec. 25-182. - Registration card issued. 
(a)  Applications for registration shall be made to the city clerk by the owner of the bicycle, or if the owner is an infant under the age of 18 years, then by the parent or guardian of the infant owner of the bicycle on or before January 1, 1973, and on or before January 1 of each year thereafter, upon an application blank furnished by the clerk, and the clerk shall provide and issue to the registrant a registration card showing the name, age and residence of the registrant, the make, color and manufacturer's serial number of the bicycle, the registration number and date of registration. 
(b)  Such application shall also be made by a resident of the city forthwith upon becoming an owner of a bicycle not then registered hereunder and to be used in the city as set forth in section 25-181. 
(c)  The city clerk shall provide and keep a card record of the registration of bicycles and shall furnish the police department of the city such information as it may require for its records. 
(d)  Such registrations shall be for three year periods commencing January 1, 1973, and shall be valid from the date of issuance to the first day of the next succeeding registration period. 
(e)  Prior to the issuance of any license hereunder, a certificate from the police department, fire department, the owner, or if the owner is an infant under the age of 18 years, the parent or guardian of said infant shall complete the inspection form to be furnished by the city clerk indicating the bicycle complies with all rules of law as to equipment and condition. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.2; Code 1973, § 7-2; Ord. of 9-23-1963, § 1; Ord. of 3-19-1973, § 1) 
Sec. 25-183. - License plate provided. 
    A license plate with distinctive number shall be provided and issued to the registrant, which registration plate shall at all times be securely attached conspicuously on the bicycle. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.3; Code 1973, § 7-3; Ord. of 9-23-1963, § 1) 
Sec. 25-184. - Transfer; notification required. 
    In case of transfer of ownership of a registered bicycle, the person to whom it is transferred shall forthwith have the bicycle registered in his name in the manner prescribed in this article, and the vendor shall forthwith notify the city clerk of such transfer of ownership. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.4; Code 1973, § 7-4) 
Sec. 25-185. - Removal of numbers. 
    No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed pursuant to this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.5; Code 1973, § 7-5) 
Sec. 25-186. - Destruction of plates. 
    No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate, seal or registration card during the time in which such plate, seal or card is operative. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city clerk from stamping numbers on the frames of bicycles on which no serial number can be found or on which the number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.6; Code 1973, § 7-6) 
Sec. 25-187. - Dealers; report of purchases. 
    Persons engaged in the business of buying secondhand bicycles are hereby required to make a daily report to the city clerk specifying: 
(1)  The name and address of the person from whom each bicycle is purchased; 
(2)  The description of each bicycle purchased; 
(3)  The frame number thereof; 
(4)  The number of the metallic license plate found thereon, if any. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.7; Code 1973, § 7-7) 
Sec. 25-188. - Dealers; report of sales. 
    All persons engaged in the business of selling new or secondhand bicycles are hereby required to make a daily report to the city clerk giving a list of all sales made by such dealers, which list shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of each person to whom a bicycle was sold; 
(2)  The kind of bicycle sold; 
(3)  A description and frame number thereof; 
(4)  The number of the metallic license plate attached thereto, if any. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.8; Code 1973, § 7-8) 
Sec. 25-189. - Fees. 
(a)  For the license issued pursuant to this article, the sum of $0.25 shall be paid for each year or part thereof that such license shall be valid. 
(b)  In cases where a transfer of ownership is made in the manner prescribed by this article the fee for transfer of the license shall be the sum of $0.25. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.9; Code 1973, § 7-9; Ord. of 9-23-1963, § 1) 
Sec. 25-190. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to arrest and penalty not exceeding $5.00 for each offense. In addition, the parent or guardian of any child as defined herein who knowingly permits any such child or ward to violate any provisions of this article or the state vehicle and traffic law shall be punished as provided in Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1230. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 14.10; Code 1973, § 7-10; Ord. of 3-19-1973, § 1) 
Chapter 27 - TRAILERS, RECREATIONAL VEHICLES, MOBILE HOMES AND PARKS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 27-1-27-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile trailer, trailer coach or trailer means any vehicle or structure so designed and constructed in such manner as will permit occupancy thereof as sleeping quarters for one or more persons, or the conduct of any business or profession, occupation or trade (or use as a selling or advertising device), and so designed that it is or may be mounted on wheels and used as a conveyance on highways or city streets, propelled or drawn by its own or other motive power, excepting a device used upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Cabin plot means a section of ground not less than 30 feet by 40 feet in area, upon which only one camp cottage or cabin is located. 
    Person includes persons, partnership, firm, company, corporation, tenant, owner, lessee or licensee, their agents, heirs or assigns. 
    Tourist camp means any park, tourist park, tourist court, camp, court site, lot, parcel or tract of land upon which one or more camp cottages or cabins are located and maintained for the accommodation of transients by the day, week or month, whether a charge is made or not. 
    Trailer camp. 
(1)  The term "trailer camp" means any park, trailer park, trailer court, court site, lot, parcel or tract of land designed, maintained or intended for the purpose of supplying a location or accommodations for any trailer coach or trailer coaches and upon which any trailer coach or trailer coaches are parked and includes all buildings used or intended for use as part of the equipment thereof whether a charge is made for the use of the trailer camp and its facilities or not. 
(2)  The term "trailer camp" does not include automobile or trailer sales lots on which unoccupied trailers are parked for purposes of inspection and sale. 
    Unit means a section of ground in a trailer camp of not less than 800 square feet of unoccupied space in an area designated as the location for only one automobile and one trailer. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.1; Code 1973, § 26-1) 
Sec. 27-20. - Penalties for violation of article. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a violation and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-14, and every day such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.18; Code 1973, § 26-15; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 1, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 2011-311, § 1, 10-24-2011) 
Sec. 27-21. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article as prescribed herein or such provisions as may hereafter be enacted shall be administered and enforced by the city manager, the superintendent of buildings, the city fire marshal, any police officer, any member of the city bureau of fire prevention and inspection services, building inspectors and code enforcement officers or sworn firefighters. In addition, for the purpose of securing such enforcement, any of the said individuals shall have the right and are hereby empowered to enter upon any premises on which any automobile trailers or camp cottages or cabins are located, or are about to be located, and inspect the same and all accommodations connected therewith at any reasonable time. The city clerk is further empowered to issue orders granting, renewing and revoking such permits and licenses as are provided for in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.2; Code 1973, § 26-2; Ord. No. 2012-174, §§ 2, 3, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-22. - Location outside camps. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful, within the limits of the city, for any person to park any trailer on any street, alley or highway, or other place, or on any tract of land owned by any person, occupied or unoccupied, within the city, except as provided in this article. 
(b)  Emergency or temporary stopping or parking is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than one hour subject to any other and further prohibitions, regulations or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations or ordinances for that street, alley or highway. 
(c)  No person shall park or occupy any trailer on the premises of any occupied dwelling or on any lot which is not a part of the premises of any occupied dwelling either of which is situated outside an approved trailer camp; except the parking of only one unoccupied trailer in an accessory private garage building, or in a rear yard in any district, is permitted providing no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced in such trailer while such trailer is so parked or stored. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.3; Code 1973, § 26-3) 
Sec. 27-23. - Permanent occupancy. 
    Automobile trailers shall not be used as a permanent place of abode or as a permanent dwelling or for indefinite periods of time; provided that any such trailer properly connected with the city water supply and sanitary sewer systems, and constructed and located in compliance with all requirements of the building, plumbing, sanitary, health, zoning and electrical ordinances of the city and not inhabited by a greater number of occupants than that for which it was designated may be permitted on any premises under permits properly secured as provided for in such building, plumbing, electrical, sanitary, health and zoning ordinances. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.4; Code 1973, § 26-4) 
Sec. 27-24. - Zoning of trailer and tourist camps. 
(a)  No trailer or tourist camp shall be located within the extra hazardous district as defined in the building code nor shall any trailer or tourist camp be located in any residence district as defined by the zoning ordinance set forth in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  The City of Elmira Zoning Board of Appeals has the power to grant variances in accordance with the provisions set forth in the zoning ordinance, Appendix B, to this Code to allow the location of trailer and tourist camps in any district in which it is prohibited. 
(c)  No trailer or tourist camp shall be located within the limits of the city, unless city water and sewer connections and fire protection facilities are available. 
(d)  No occupied trailer, camp cottage, cabin cottage or cabin or other building shall be located within the city limits of the city, within the recognized setback line for the zoning district in which such trailer or cabin is located nor less than ten feet from any other building or vehicle or the boundary line of the tract on which located. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.6; Code 1973, § 26-5; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 4, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-25. - Camp plan. 
(a)  Every trailer or tourist camp shall be located on a well-drained area, and the premises shall be properly graded so as to prevent the accumulation of storm or other waters. 
(b)  Units and cabin plots shall be clearly designated and the camp so arranged that all units and cabin plots shall face or abut on a driveway of not less than 16 feet in width, giving easy access from all units to a public street. Such driveway shall be paved and maintained in good condition, having natural drainage into a city street catchbasin, be well lighted at night, and shall not be obstructed. 
(c)  No camp cottage or cabin shall be less than 280 square feet in area nor less than 14 feet wide at its narrowest point, and not less than eight feet high from floor to ceiling and shall not have less than 27 square feet of ventilating openings and all windows must be fully screened. If the floor is of wood, it shall be raised not less than 12 inches above the ground level. 
(d)  The camp shall be so laid out that no unit or cabin shall be located farther than 200 feet from the toilets and service buildings provided for herein, and walkways to such buildings shall be paved and well lighted at night. 
(e)  Every trailer unit shall be furnished with an electric service outlet. Such outlet shall be equipped with an externally operated switch or fuse of not less than 30 amperes capacity and a heavy duty outlet receptacle. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.7; Code 1973, § 26-6) 
Sec. 27-26. - Water supply. 
(a)  An adequate supply of pure water, furnished through a pipe distribution system connected directly with the city water main with supply faucets located not more than 200 feet from any trailer or cabin shall be furnished for drinking and domestic purposes. 
(b)  No common drinking vessels shall be permitted, nor shall any drinking water faucets be placed in any toilet room or water closet compartment. 
(c)  An abundant supply of hot water shall be provided at all times for bathing, washing and laundry facilities. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.8; Code 1973, § 26-7) 
Sec. 27-27. - Service building and accommodations. 
(a)  Every trailer or tourist camp shall have erected thereon at a distance not greater than 200 feet from any unit or cabin it is designed to serve, a suitable building for housing toilets, showers and laundry facilities as required by this article, such building to be known as the service building. 
(b)  There shall be provided separate toilet rooms for each sex. Flush toilets provided with an adequate water supply shall be enclosed in separate compartments having a minimum width of three feet and a minimum depth of four feet and shall be provided for each sex in the ratio of one toilet for each eight units or cabins or fraction thereof. Every male toilet room shall have one urinal for each 16 units or cabins but in no case shall any male toilet be without one urinal. Toilet rooms shall contain lavatories with hot and cold water in the ratio of one lavatory to every two or less water closets. 
(c)  Separate bathing facilities for each sex shall be provided with one shower enclosed in a compartment at least four feet square for each eight units or cabins or fraction thereof. Each shower compartment shall be supplemented by an individual dressing compartment at least 12 feet square. 
(d)  Laundry facilities shall be provided in the ratio of one double tray and one ironing board for each ten units or cabins. 
(e)  The accommodations set forth in subsections (a) through (d) of this section shall be based on the total camp capacity according to accepted plans. 
(f)  Floors of toilets, showers and the laundry shall be of concrete, tile or similar material impervious to water and easily cleaned and pitched to a floor drain. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.9; Code 1973, § 26-8) 
Sec. 27-28. - Waste and garbage disposal. 
(a)  All waste from showers, toilets, laundries, faucets and lavatories shall be wasted into a sewer system extended from and connected with the city sewer system. 
(b)  All sanitary facilities in any trailer which are not connected with the city sewer system by means of rigid pipe connections shall be sealed, and their use is hereby declared unlawful. 
(c)  Each faucet site shall be equipped with facilities for drainage of waste and excess water into the sewer. In no case shall any waste water be thrown or discharged upon the surface of the ground or disposed of by means other than as herein provided. 
(d)  Every unit shall be provided with a substantial flytight metal garbage depository from which the contents shall be removed by the city garbage collection service. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.10; Code 1973, § 26-9) 
Sec. 27-29. - Limitation on length of stay and on number of occupants. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remain or live in any trailer or tourist camp for more than 90 days in each 12-month period, subject to the provisions of section 27-23, except that upon a showing and proof that one or more occupants of a trailer or cabin are engaged in vital national defense work and that there exists in the community a shortage of adequate housing facilities, additional stays of 60 days may be granted by the city clerk, such additional stays being renewable at the end of each 60-day period upon a further and similar showing, provided that this time limitation shall not apply to the licensee of a trailer or tourist camp or his bona fide employees so as to prevent their remaining on the camp premises at all times. 
(b)  No trailer or cabin may be inhabited by a greater number of occupants than that for which it is designed. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.11; Code 1973, § 26-10; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 5, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-30. - Management. 
(a)  In every trailer or tourist camp there shall be an office building in which shall be located the office of the person in charge of such camp. A copy of the camp license and of this article shall be posted therein and the camp register shall at all times be kept in such office. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the attendant or person in charge together with the licensee to: 
(1)  Keep at all times a register of all guests (which shall be open at all times to inspection by state and federal officers and officers of the city) showing for all guests: 
a.  Names and addresses; 
b.  Dates of entrance and departure; 
c.  License numbers of all trailers and towing or other automobiles; 
d.  States issuing such licenses; 
e.  Place of last location and length of stay. 
(2)  Maintain the camp in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all times. 
(3)  See that the provisions of this article are complied with and enforced and report promptly to the proper authorities any violation of this article or any other violations of law which may come to his attention. 
(4)  Report to the city manager all cases of persons or animals affected or suspected of being affected with any communicable disease. 
(5)  Prevent the running loose of dogs, cats or other animals or pets. 
(6)  Maintain in convenient places, approved by the fire department, hand fire extinguishers in the ratio of one to each eight units or cabins. 
(7)  Collect the service charge provided for in section 27-31 from the occupants of each unit in the camp and pay over the money so collected to the city chamberlain. A book shall be kept showing the names of the persons paying such service charges and the amount paid. 
(8)  Prohibit the lighting of open fires on the premises. 
(9)  Prohibit the use of any trailer or cabin by a greater number of occupants than that which it is designed to accommodate. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.12; Code 1973, § 26-11) 
Sec. 27-31. - Service and inspection charges. 
    There is hereby imposed a service and inspection charge of $0.50 per day per unit on the occupants of each unit of trailer camps licensed hereunder. The licensee of the trailer camp shall collect this service charge for the city and pay it over to the city chamberlain, in accordance with such reasonable regulations as the city chamberlain may promulgate governing such payments. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.13; Code 1973, § 26-12) 
Sec. 27-32. - Applicability of plumbing, electrical and building ordinances. 
    All plumbing, electrical, building and other work on or at any camp licensed under this article shall be in accordance with the ordinances of the city regulating such work unless such ordinances are specifically made inapplicable under the terms of this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.14; Code 1973, § 26-13) 
Sec. 27-33. - Interpretation of article. 
    Nothing in this article shall be interpreted so as to conflict with the state housing laws, state legislation regulating trailer camps or tourist camps or any of the requirements of any ordinances of the city not mentioned or made inapplicable by the express terms of this article. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.19; Code 1973, § 26-14) 
Secs. 27-34-27-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 27-71. - Required; application; issuance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained upon any property owned or controlled by him, a trailer camp or tourist camp or combination of the two within the limits of the city, without having first secured a license therefore and for each of them from the city clerk, granted and existing in compliance with the terms of this article. Such license shall expire one year from date of issuance but may be renewed under the provisions of this article for additional periods of one year. 
(b)  The application for such license or the renewal thereof shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00 for each unit and cabin plot in the existing or proposed camp and a license bond in the sum of $1,000.00 to guarantee compliance with the terms of this chapter. The application for a license must be accompanied with a site plan approval resolution issued by the city planning commission in accordance with the provisions set forth in the zoning ordinance of the City of Elmira, Appendix B, to this Code. The application for a license or a renewal thereof shall be made on printed forms furnished by the city clerk and shall include the name and address of the owner in fee of the tract (if the fee is vested in some person other than the applicant, a duly verified statement by that person, that the applicant is authorized by him to construct or maintain the trailer or tourist camp and make the application), and such a legal description of the premises, upon which the trailer or tourist camp is or will be located as will readily identify and definitely locate the premises. The application shall be accompanied by four copies of the camp plan showing the following, either existing or as proposed: 
(1)  The extent and area used for camp purposes; 
(2)  Roadways and driveways; 
(3)  Location of sites or units for trailer coaches or cabins; 
(4)  Location and number of sanitary conveniences, including toilets, washrooms, laundries and utility rooms to be used by occupants of units or cabins (in cases where cabins do not have all such facilities in proper conformance with city building, plumbing and other ordinances); 
(5)  Method and plan of sewage disposal; 
(6)  Method and plan of garbage removal; 
(7)  Plan for water supply; 
(8)  Plan for electrical lighting of units and cabins. 
(c)  Before such license may be issued, the premises must be inspected and approved by the city fire marshal or a member of the city's bureau of fire prevention and inspection services or his/her duly authorized representative as complying with all the provisions of this chapter and all other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Licenses issued under the terms of this article convey no right to erect any building, to do any plumbing work or to do any electrical work. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.5; Code 1973, § 26-26; Ord. No. 2012-174, §§ 6-8, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-72. - Revocation and suspension. 
    The city clerk is hereby authorized to revoke any license issued pursuant to the terms of this article if after due investigation it determines that the hold thereof has violated any of the provisions of this chapter or that any trailer, trailer camp or tourist camp is being maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or is a nuisance. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.15; Code 1973, § 26-27; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 9, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-73. - Hearing on granting, denial, renewal or revocation of license. 
    Any person aggrieved by an order of the city clerk granting, denying, renewing or revoking a license for a trailer camp or tourist camp, under this article, may file a written request for a hearing before the city manager within ten days after issuance of such order. The city manager shall give notice of a public hearing upon this request to be held in not less than five days after service of the notice on the person requesting the hearing. The city manager may also give notice of the hearing to other persons directly interested in the order in question. At such hearing, the city manager shall determine whether the granting, denial, renewal or revocation of the license was in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall issue written findings of fact, conclusions of law and an order to carry out its findings and conclusions. These findings of fact, conclusions of law and order shall be filed with the city clerk and served by the city manager upon all parties appearing or represented at such hearing. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.16; Code 1973, § 26-28; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 10, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 27-74. - Court review. 
    Any order either granting, denying, renewing or revoking any license under the provisions of this article, after the aforesaid hearing before the city manager, may be appealed in the same manner as appeals from any order under the building or zoning ordinance as provided for in General City Law § 81-c. 
(Penal Ords. 1939, § 16.17; Code 1973, § 26-29; Ord. No. 2012-174, § 11, 6-4-2012) 
Secs. 27-75-27-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ALL TERRAIN VEHICLE AND LIMITED USE MOTORCYCLE ("DIRT BIKE") 

Sec. 27-86. - Legislative purpose. 
    The city council hereby finds that the operation of all terrain vehicles and limited use motorcycles ("dirt bikes") in proximity to a dwelling unit or house impacts the general welfare of residents of a dwelling unit or house given the noise emanating from an all terrain vehicle and limited use motorcycles ("dirt bikes). The purpose of this division is to reduce or eliminate the deleterious impact from the operation of all terrain vehicles and limited use motorcycles ("dirt bikes"). 
(Ord. No. 2013-283, § 1, 9-9-2013) 
Sec. 27-87. - Definitions. 
    All terrain vehicle or ATV means an "all terrain vehicle" or "ATV" as defined in section 2281 of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, now and as hereinafter amended. 
    Limited use motorcycles shall mean a motorcycle as defined in section 121-b of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, now and as hereinafter amended, which motorcycle is intended primarily for off highway operation commonly known as a "dirt bike". 
(Ord. No. 2013-283, § 2, 9-9-2013) 
Sec. 27-88. - [Offenses-All terrain vehicle.] 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate for recreational purposes an all terrain vehicle within the City of Elmira in any district zoned residential at any time and within 150 feet of any dwelling in any other zoning district at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2013-283, § 3, 9-9-2013) 
Sec. 27-89. - [Offenses-Limited use motorcycle ("dirt bike").] 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a limited use motorcycle ("dirt bike") within the City of Elmira in any district zoned residential at any time and within 150 feet of any dwelling in any other zoning district at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2013-283, § 4, 9-9-2013) 
Chapter 29 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 29-1-29-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Disposal of garbage and refuse, § 73-A. 

Sec. 29-18. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved container means a watertight container constructed of galvanized metal or unbreakable plastic which can withstand typical cold weather temperature (minus 20 degrees Fahrenheit) without becoming brittle and which can stand up to normal use. The contents in the container must be secured in a plastic bag as defined in this subsection. Container shall not exceed 20 gallons in capacity; it shall be equipped with a tight fitting cover and have two substantial handles or bails for easy dumping. Plastic bags having at least a two-mil thickness may be used if they are securely tied at the top and are free from tears; additionally, the plastic bag must be of the kind that allows the contents to be clearly visible and the weight of each individual plastic bag must not exceed 30 pounds. 
    Exclusions means prohibited materials. They are: 
(1)  Flammable or explosive substances; 
(2)  Paint, thinners or solvents; 
(3)  Pesticides, acids, caustic and similar wastes; 
(4)  Refillable-type gas cylinders; 
(5)  Feces; 
(6)  Ashes; 
(7)  Furniture and appliances; 
(8)  Stones; 
(9)  Dirt; 
(10)  Grass clippings, leaves and brush; and 
(11)  All other prohibited materials as determined by the operator of the Chemung County landfill. 
    Garbage means every waste accumulation of meat, vegetable, or similar organic matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking, or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable and also includes tin cans, glass, paper cartons or other cartons that have contained food materials. 
    Ownership means all garbage and trash set out for collection shall be vested in the city once placed in the garbage collection trucks. All such material is declared to be public property. 
    Solid waste means and includes all those items as described under the terms "garbage" and "trash".
